Ford has a voting record more moderate than Cranston's liberal pattern, and he is a far less controversial figure. ``Alan has been a respected colleague for the past 16 years and my thoughts and prayers are with him for a complete and speedy recovery,'' Ford said in a statement Thursday. Few other changes are expected in the Senate organizational meetings before the 102nd Congress convenes in January. With the Senate remaining under Democratic control, George Mitchell, D-Maine, is unchallenged for majority leader and Bob Dole, R-Kan., likewise for minority leader. Cranston has been the deputy Democratic leader since 1977, including the last two years under Mitchell. Mitchell called Cranston's announcement ``a sad one for all his colleagues, but especially for me. His help and support in my first Congress as majority leader meant more to me than I can easily express.'' In the House, which holds its organizational meetings next month, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and his leadership team are expected to return on the Democratic side. Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., is replacing Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., as Democratic campaign chairman. There is unrest among House Republicans, however. After another losing electoral season, Rep. Don Sundquist, R-Tenn., is challenging the party's long-time campaign chairman Guy Vander Jagt for his job. Sundquist denied in a letter to colleagues that his campaign is a slap at House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., who has been closely overseeing Vander Jagt's operation. Gingrich himself barely survived in Tuesday's election, winning by less than 1 percent of the vote, and there is talk that Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., might mount a challenge for the whip's job. Lewis, chairman of the House Republican Conference, was upset that Gingrich was pushing Rep. Carl Pursell, R-Mich., to run against him, sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Texas Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT victim's name, Siedschlag sted Siedschleg
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine airplane attempting to land in heavy rain at an east Texas airport crashed Thursday night in thick woods, killing all five people aboard, police said. The Piper Aerostar crashed shortly after 6 p.m. near Lake Nacogdoches, about eight miles west of the city. The victims were identified as Jim Grisham, the pilot, Tim Owens and Joe Siedschlag, all of Hot Springs, Ark., Mary Angel, 36, and her 8-year-old son Thomas, both of Peachtree City, Ga. The ages of the three men were not immediately available, said Pat Denman of the Texas Department of Public Safety in Lufkin. It was not immediately known who owned the plane, which crashed at A.L. Mangum Airport. The plane was about six miles east of the airport when it crashed. Nacogdoches is 151 miles southeast of Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Couple Married to Each Other and the Navy
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Nancy and Christopher Romei are wedded to each other, and to the U.S. Navy. Like most military couples, their country comes first when duty calls. Both are part of Operation Desert Shield, although they are 1,000 miles apart and haven't seen each other in more than three months. Romei didn't find out for sure his wife had been mobilized until he had been at sea for a month. ``This is our chosen profession. Being apart is just a fact of life. We just accept it and live with it,'' said Romei, 33, a chief petty officer aboard the guided missile cruiser USS Biddle on duty in the Red Sea. His wife is a corpsman and X-ray technician at the Navy's Fleet Hospital No. 5, located on the eastern side of the Arabian peninsula. ``It's part of the contract,'' said Mrs. Romei, 38. ``He always told me he was married to the Navy first. Besides, this (separation) won't last forever. It's just a little piece of life.'' The Biddle was scheduled to leave Norfolk, Va., Aug. 7 as part of its regular tour of the Mediterranean Sea. It was diverted to the Red Sea to enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq for its takeover of Kuwait, and Romei, a native of Leeds, Ala., went with it. His wife, originally from Valparaiso, Ind., was stationed at a Navy hospital in Virginia Beach, Va. She got a call in the middle of the night saying she was being deployed in Saudi Arabia. All she could do was send her husband a letter. When duty called, she was ready. ``The Navy trained me to do this job. It's time to produce for the Navy,'' Mrs. Romei said during a break from her duties. The military has separated them before. They saw each other only nine days during a recent 18-month period. But this time, they're both away from home. Mrs. Romei persuaded a friend to take power of attorney and pay the mortgage, take care of the monthly bills and tend to their two cars. They have no children or pets, but most of their houseplants became casualties of war. ``It was like pulling my hair out trying to find someone to do these things,'' Mrs. Romei said. Unless things change dramatically, the couple will be apart for their 10th wedding anniversary on Jan. 22. And she won't be with him to celebrate his birthday on Jan. 7. But Romei is more concerned about his wife's safety than about sentimental occasions. ``I'm not comfortable with her being there,'' Romei said. ``I feel a lot safer because I'm on a warship. I'm designed to fight. ``Where she is, a leaker on a plane or a Scud missile could get through. If they (the Iraqis) thrust hard south, they could break through. I don't have any doubts about who will win ultimately, but ...'' The biggest worriers are their parents, however. ``They ask why. Why are we here? Is it for oil? Or is it for principle? And if it's for principle, why haven't we done anything?'' Romei said. Meanwhile, the couple had a common message for each other and their parents: ``I love you.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Lose Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 22,931.80, down 38.01 points or 0.17 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Panama Will Try Noriega if United States Drops Case
With PM-Noriega-Tapes
DOC.TEXT: Panama wants to try ousted dictator Gen. Manuel Noriega if the United States drops its case against him, President Guillermo Endara says. ``In the case that the North Americans can't do it, we're going to ask for him, and he will be judged in accord with Panamanian law, because he committed many, many crimes,'' Endara told reporters Thursday. Noriega's lead defense attorney Frank Rubino said Thursday he plans to move for dismissal of the U.S. drug trafficking case against the former Panamanian strongman. Noriega has been in jail in Miami since shortly after a December U.S. invasion of Panama ousted him from power. Rubino's statement was in response to CNN broadcasts of parts of taped conversations between Noriega and his lawyers that the defense said prejudice Noriega's case. Vice President Ricardo Arias said Noriega has ``very serious charges against him'' in Panama. The Panamanian government has charged Noriega and at least seven of his officers with looting the treasury. ``If for any reason he goes free in the United States, he would have to be extradited to Panama to face justice, which the Panamanian people demand,'' said Arias, who along with Endara spoke to reporters after a business-related news conference. Foreign Minister Julio Linares, also at the news conference, said Panama is considering whether it should request Noriega's extradition. The Foreign Ministry said it is cooperating with the United States in talks which began last week for the development of a joint law enforcement agreement that would help control drug trafficking and money laundering. Panama established new rules for preventing illicit drug money transactions in March, the ministry noted. ``With the dictatorship overthrown, the legal steps mentioned have become powerful, effective instruments of legal and administrative action to combat drug trafficking and money laundering, the ministry said in a news release.

DOC.HEAD: Historian, Poet Win Ingersoll Prizes
DOC.TEXT: Alabama historian Forrest McDonald and English poet Charles Causley won the 1990 Ingersoll Prizes. The Ingersoll Foundation has awarded the prizes since 1983 to recognize authors whose works affirm the moral principles of Western civilization, the sponsor said. McDonald, 63, of Coker, Ala., a historian at the University of Alabama, won the Richard M. Weaver Award for Scholarly Letters. He has written several books on early American history, including studies of the presidencies of George Washington and Thomas Jefferson and a biography of Alexander Hamilton. Causley, 73, of Launceston, England, won the T.S. Eliot Award for Creative Writing. He has written several collections of poetry and a number of books for young readers. He also is the editor of several poetry anthologies. Each author received $20,000 at a dinner Thursday night. Previous winners of the letters award include Edward O. Wilson, Andrew Lytle and Robert Nisbet. Novelists V.S. Naipaul, Eugene Ionesco and Jorge Luis Borges are among previous winners of the creative writing award.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor-Elect Calls for Restrictions on Barry's Powers
DOC.TEXT: Mayor-elect Sharon Pratt Dixon wants the District of Columbia City Council to restrict Mayor Marion Barry's authority to spend money and make personnel changes until he leaves office in January. Dixon also called Thursday for a 20 percent increase in the money the federal government pays the city yearly to offset the loss in property tax revenue caused by the presence of so many tax-exempt federal offices. At a news conference, Dixon urged the council to override Barry's veto of a measure that would prohibit him from signing contracts worth more than $1 million for services or office space. She also asked for legislation prohibiting government raises, promotions or the conversion of temporary appointments to career service. Both emergency measures, which would expire after 30 days, will be considered by the council next week. Barry, who is appealing a six-month prison sentence for cocaine possession, has denied approving anything but routine contracts or making any unusual personnel moves. But Dixon said, ``I wouldn't have urged emergency legislation if I didn't think it was at least a potential problem.'' Dixon, Council Chairman-elect John A. Wilson and Eleanor Holmes Norton, who will become the district's non-voting delegate to Congress, said they had agreed to lobby Congress to raise the federal payment from $430 million to $516 million. They said the $86 million increase roughly equals the amount the district would have received if the federal payment had risen with inflation instead of remaining flat for the last five years. City officials have said an increased payment is essential to dealing with the district government's mounting deficit, which could reach $200 million next year.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Issues Warning on Body-Building Drug
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is warning consumers against taking an illegally marketed and possibly dangerous drug used for strength training and body building. The FDA said Thursday that it had received reports of more than 30 people in California, Florida and Georgia becoming ill after taking GHB, or gamma hydroxybutyric acid. The drug is also called sodium oxybate and gamma hydroxybutyrate sodium. The FDA said GHB can cause nausea and vomiting, severe respiratory problems, seizures and coma. GHB is sold as powder or granules through mail order outlets, health food stores, gyms and fitness centers. It is promoted for strength training, body building, weight loss and as a replacement for L-tryptophan. L-tryptophan, a food supplement used as a sleep aid and for depression and weight control, was ordered off the market last March when it was linked to an outbreak of a rare blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. GHB is being evaluated in approved clinical trials as a treatment for narcolepsy, a sleep disorder.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Rules Would Require Universal Phone Access for Hearing-Impaired
DOC.TEXT: Rules proposed by the Federal Communications Commission would require all telephone companies to provide service to hearing- and speech-impaired callers by mid-1993. The commission's 5-0 vote Thursday set into motion rules to fulfill the communications provisions of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990. The act, which President Bush signed in July, requires that the nation's 26 million hearing- and speech-impaired individuals have access to phone company relay services that allow them to communicate with hearing callers. Impaired callers typically punch a keyboard connected with a telephone operator, who then relays the message either electronically to another impaired person or verbally to a hearing caller. The provisions cover intrastate and interstate calls and states will be allowed to establish prices for intrastate services, with FCC oversight. The FCC must establish rules within a year, and phone companies must meet those provisions by July 26, 1993. The proposal requires, among other things, 24-hour service, seven days a week, with rates ``commensurate with those of functionally equivalent voice communications services.'' Relay operators may not refuse calls, limit their length or reveal or alter their contents.
DOC.HEAD: Task Force To Study Improvements In Boston-New York Rail Service
DOC.TEXT: A Transportation Department task force will study how to shorten rail passenger travel time between Boston and New York, Secretary Samuel K. Skinner says. Skinner announced Thursday that the federal task force will assign priorities to projects to improve service between the two cities. Scheduled for completion by next summer, the task force will also develop ``logical cost allocations'' for improvements among interested state governments, local transportation authorities and private parties, he said. ``Now that the Washington-New York portion of the northeast corridor has been improved, we need to turn our attention to the New York-Boston segment,'' Skinner told a meeting of the Railway Progress Institute. ``Facilities and services need to be upgraded to improve the travel time on the New York-Boston run and to enhance the commuter services that share the right of way with Amtrak,'' Skinner said. ``Speedy and reliable rail service would encourage more passengers to use the trains and this could help to relieve some of the congestion in the major airports in the Northeast,'' he said. The departmental study, expected to cost $1 million, will be headed by Gil Carmichael, administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration, and Brian W. Clymer, administrator of the Urban Mass Transit Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Cable TV mogul Ted Turner has bought a large opal and diamond ring for actress Jane Fonda, and they apparently will be getting engaged, a Fonda spokeswoman said. The ring, which Turner bought Tuesday at Tiffany's in Los Angeles, will be presented to Fonda on her Dec. 21 birthday, said Pat Newcomb, a publicist for the Academy Award-winning actress. Asked if the ring was an engagement ring, Newcomb told The Associated Press: ``I guess you could call it that.'' She described the ring as having an opal between a pair of diamonds. The celebrity couple has no immediate plans to set a wedding date, Newcomb said. Fonda, 52, and Turner, 51, traveled recently to the Soviet Union for the premiere of ``Gone With the Wind,'' the crown jewel of Turner's MGM movie archives. If the engagement does culminate in marriage, it would be the third for Fonda, who was married to French director Roger Vadim and California Assemblyman Tom Hayden, the former 1960s student radical. She has two children. It also would be the third marriage for Turner, who was previously wed to Judy Nye and Jane Shirley Smith. He has five children. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Harry Reasoner, the folksy ``60 Minutes'' correspondent who helped start the top-rated CBS News program in 1968, is cutting back on his workload next season. ``It's been a nice ride, but you can't go on forever,'' Reasoner said Thursday. He decided to scale back from full-time reporter status to become the show's ``editor emeritus'' and a ``contributing correspondent.'' That means he'll do perhaps six reports a year instead of 20. ``I suddenly realized I'd been working 53 years, about half of it on `60 Minutes,' and I thought I'd like to take it a little easier,'' he said. Reasoner, 67, began his journalism career as a Minneapolis newspaperman and has won several Emmy awards and a Peabody award for his broadcast work. He joined CBS in 1956, left in 1970 to work at ABC and returned to CBS and ``60 Minutes'' in 1978. He and Mike Wallace, now 72, were the original on-air correspondents for ``60 Minutes.'' --- BOSTON (AP) - Ted Danson, Kirstie Alley and other regulars of TV's most famous neighborhood bar celebrated the 200th episode of ``Cheers'' in the city where a real-life basement tavern inspired the show's Hollywood set. The cast was honored Thursday at a ceremony outside City Hall as thousands of fans braved chilly weather to greet the TV stars. ``This is overwhelming,'' said George Wendt, who plays Norm Peterson, ``Cheers'' heavyweight, beer-swigging barfly, after a noisy welcome by people chanting ``Norm, Norm.'' ``Sorry we screwed up your lunch hour,'' he joked. The TV bar mirrors the layout and decor of the the Bull & Finch Pub, which has become a popular stop for tourists. ``Cheers,'' now in its ninth season, was No. 1 for its time slot last year and has won 22 Emmys. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Turning 81 doesn't scare Katharine Hepburn, who says: ``I look forward to oblivion.'' ``I'm what is known as gradually disintegrating,'' Hepburn told The Associated Press. ``I don't fear the next world, or anything. I don't fear hell, and I don't look forward to heaven.'' The star of such films as ``On Golden Pond,'' ``Bringing Up Baby,'' ``The Philadelphia Story'' and ``Guess Who's Coming to Dinner'' turned 81 Thursday. In the interview in her home last month, Hepburn said she still gets acting offers. ``Yes, I get offered roles,'' she said. ``But I'm fascinated by writing now. I find all life thrilling.'' --- FORT SMITH, Ark. (AP) - Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton kept a campaign promise by dancing through the streets of this onetime frontier town. He sweetened the deal with some impromptu jamming on the saxophone. The Democrat, re-elected to a fifth term Tuesday, had pledged to dance through the streets of Fort Smith if he won in Republican-dominated Sebastian County. The governor and his wife, Hillary, stepped out Thursday to the strains of ``Satin Doll.'' Police stopped downtown traffic for about 45 minutes. Clinton, who has played his saxophone on NBC's ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson,'' later joined the band in a rendition of ``Summertime,'' after someone gave him a sax. --- GATLINBURG, Tenn. (AP) - Country music singer T.G. Sheppard was afraid the fish wouldn't bite during filming for a cable TV show - so he took a few extras with him. Turns out he didn't need to. Sheppard brought some rainbow trout with him on the Little Pigeon River Thursday while filming the fishing show for The Nashville Network, but he caught his own fish and didn't have to use them. The singer dubbed the unofficial ambasador of tourism for this southeastern Tennessee city moved here in 1987 and owns a restaurant-bar and a bed and breakfast inn. His recordings include the songs ``I Loved 'Em Every One'' and ``Slow Burn.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Sexually Assaulting Woman With 46 Personalities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in penultimate graf, `He said ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OSH1
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of sexually assaulting a woman who testified against him with six of her 46 personalities maintains she wasn't mentally ill and that she consented to have sex with him. Mark A. Peterson, whom a jury Thursday found guilty of second-degree sexual assault, denied he knew the 27-year-old woman had a multiple-personality disorder and said he will appeal. ``I have been the victim for just having a fling with a girl,'' Peterson said. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine during sentencing scheduled for Dec. 10. He remained free on $10,000 bond. ``I still don't think she is mentally ill,'' Peterson said after the verdict. ``What's there to be sorry about? Why should I be sorry for her?'' The woman was diagnosed in February as having the disorder. The diagnosis has only been recognized in the past decade. She blinked her eyes and bowed her head as she summoned six different personalities to the witness stand Wednesday. Four of them were sworn in individually. The woman testified that one personality, a 20-year-old woman, had sex with Peterson, 29, in a municipal park June 11 after a coffee date. Under Wisconsin law, it is a crime to have sex with people known to suffer from a mental illness that makes them incapable of understanding their conduct. Peterson testified: ``She excited me. ... She was pretty. ... I asked her if I could love her. She said, `Yes.''' District Attorney Joseph Paulus told the Circuit Court jury of six men and six women that Peterson, who is married and unemployed, exploited the 20-year-old. Peterson treated the victim ``like a piece of meat at his disposal to play games with,'' Paulus said. ``(The woman) is his little secret. She is the person he can call on to have sex. She is the mental illness he can manipulate.'' The woman testified that Peterson manipulated the personality that was prevalent at the time to force her to have intercourse. She said the 20-year-old didn't know what sex was. Her real persona, she said, was unaware of the affair until learning about it from another personality, a 6-year-old girl. The jury, which deliberated about six hours, was asked to decide three issues: whether the woman was mentally ill, whether the illness made her incapable of appraising her conduct and whether Peterson knew of the illness. Jury foreman David Ward said, ``A statement Peterson gave police that said he was aware of the woman's different personalities was a key to the conviction.'' Peterson said he signed the statement on June 14 only because he was tired of questioning. Defense and prosecution psychiatrists differed over the legitimacy of the disorder diagnoses and whether the woman, who earned an associate degree from college, was aware of her conduct. The woman ackowledged that, as a teen-ager, she saw the motion picture ``The Three Faces of Eve'' concerning a woman with multiple personalities. Psychiatrists said about 7,000 Americans have multiple personality disorder, many of them having assumed protective mentalities to escape child abuse. She said her adoptive parents abused her as a child. Peterson denied knowing of any mental problem until, following the affair in his car, she switched to a new personality after he drove her home. ``I was very surprised,'' he said. ``I never seen that before.'' He said he telephoned the next day to apologize and she told him: ``I'm going to prosecute you, you bastard.'' Defense lawyer Ed Salzsieder argued Peterson was guilty of nothing more than bad judgment and promiscuity. Peterson's ``no rocket scientist,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0453, fixing slug
NEW DELHI: new government.
DOC.TEXT: Chandra Shekhar will preside over the smallest minority government India has ever had. His dissident faction had only 56 votes in the policy-making lower house of Parliament when the vote of confidence was taken, although aides claimed Thursday it now controls 280 of the body's 522 votes. Chandra Shekhar's aspirations were reinforced by an announcement by former Prime Minister Rajiv Ghandi that he had declined an offer to head a government and his Congress Party would back him, but without joining a coalition. No single party in Parliament has a majority. By agreeing to support Chandra Shekhar from outside, Gandhi and his Congress Party could make or break the new government but would not hold any posts in the Cabinet. Gandhi could use the opportunity to prepare his own party for new elections. His party has 195 seats, and its small-party allies have 15. Singh's government was shaken by separatist struggles in Kashmir and Punjab states, rising prices and the ousted prime minister's program to increase the number of government jobs reserved for low-caste Hindus. The policy led to violent demonstrations and a wave of suicides among upper-caste Hindus. The government was dealt a final blow last month when the Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew support from the coalition in protest over Singh's handling of bloody clashes over a shrine claimed by both Hindus and Moslems. About 370 people have been killed in the riots.

DOC.HEAD: Chandra Shekhar Named New Prime Minister, To Form New Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, ADDS background, minor editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: Socialist Chandra Shekhar was named India's new prime minister Friday, after he helped topple the government of V.P. Singh this week amid religious violence, separatist struggles and a disputed job policy. President Ramaswamy Venkataraman, who picked the new prime minister, ``was satisfied I am able to form the government,'' Chandra Shekhar told reporters. Chandra Shekhar will be sworn in on Saturday and will face Parliament on or before Nov. 20 to prove his majority in Parliament. The new 63-year-old prime minister appeared composed while speaking outside the presidential palace following a 35-minute meeting with the president. Asked what his immediate programs would be, he said: ``Priorities I shall discuss after tomorrow's swearing-in.'' His first challenge will be to stem a wave of violence between India's Hindu majority and Moslem minority. At least 370 people have died in the last three weeks in riots sparked by a Hindu fundamentalist attempt to replace a mosque with a temple in the Hindu holy town of Ayodhya. Prime Minister Singh, in power for 11 months, lost a vote of confidence in Parliament on Wednesday. It was the first time an Indian government was ousted by Parliament since the country won independence from Britain in 1947. Chandra Shekhar would preside over the smallest minority government India has ever had. His newly named Janata Dal (Socialist) Party had only 56 votes in the policy-making lower house of Parliament when the vote of confidence was taken. Aides claimed Thursday that the group now controls 280 of the body's 522 votes. Chandra Shekhar's aspirations were reinforced by an announcement by former Prime Minister Rajiv Ghandi that he had declined an offer to head a government and his Congress Party would back him, but without joining a coalition. No single party in Parliament has a majority. By agreeing to support Chandra Shekhar from outside, Gandhi and his Congress Party could make or break the new government but would not hold any posts in the Cabinet. Gandhi could use the opportunity to prepare his own party for new elections. His party has 195 seats, and its small-party allies have 15. Singh's government was shaken by separatist struggles in Kashmir and Punjab states, rising prices and the ousted prime minister's program to increase the number of government jobs reserved for low-caste Hindus. The policy led to violent demonstrations and a wave of suicides among upper-caste Hindus. The government was dealt a final blow last month when the Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew support from the coalition in protest over Singh's handling of bloody clashes over a shrine claimed by both Hindus and Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: California Senator's Retirement Plans Spotlight Scramble for Successor
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston's decision not to seek re-election in 1992 because of prostate cancer has focused attention on an already crowded field of would-be successors. But some of them may instead challenge the person Gov.-elect Pete Wilson picks as his successor for California's other U.S. Senate seat. Attracted by Cranston's political weakness stemming from his involvement in the savings and loan scandal, at least 10 Democrats, including former Gov. Jerry Brown, former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein and Walt Disney Corp. President Frank Wells, had floated trial balloons about challenging Cranston or running if he stepped down. Likely Republican candidates include former Rep. Ed Zschau, a moderate who narrowly lost to Cranston four years ago. Zschau might be challenged in the Republican primary by a conservative such as former U.S. Treasurer Bay Buchanan, sister of Washington commentator Pat Buchanan, or television commentator Bruce Herschensohn, a former White House aide to Richard Nixon. But the political outlook is complicated by the fact that California's other Senate seat will change hands early next year. Wilson, a Republican, was elected governor Tuesday and will appoint a senatorial successor in January to serve until a special election is held in 1992 on the same ballot with the race to fill Cranston's seat. Some potential candidates for Cranston's seat probably will switch to the race against Wilson's successor. None of the possible contenders to replace Cranston made formal announcements after Cranston issued his written statement Thursday. Most declined to comment entirely. Rep. Barbara Boxer of San Francisco, who has been the most outspoken Democrat about her intentions to run against the 76-year-old Cranston, said only that ``my concern is for Alan's health. My hopes and prayers are for a full recovery.'' A spokesman for Rep. Bob Matsui, D-Sacramento, said Matsui intends to enter the race but ``there will not be a formal announcement for some time.'' Rep. Mel Levine of Los Angeles said through spokesman Elmy Bermejo that he also ``is interested in looking at the race.'' A spokeswoman for Feinstein, who narrowly lost the race for governor to Wilson, left the door open for a senatorial run. ``She has said her intention is to remain in public life. How that happens is unclear. She will look at the race,'' Feinstein spokeswoman Dee Dee Myers said. Brown, currently the state Democratic Party chairman, declined requests for comment. He had hinted that he would run for the seat if Cranston stepped down. Cranston also said he would not seek re-election by his Democratic colleagues next Tuesday to the post of assistant majority leader, which he has held since 1977. His chief rival for that job, Sen. Wendell Ford of Kentucky, also limited his remarks to concern about Cranston's health. Cranston's written announcement made no reference to the Senate Ethics Committee investigation of his relationship with Charles Keating, the indicted former president of Lincoln Savings and Loan who contributed $850,000 to a voter registration drive and other political groups associated with Cranston. Cranston's popularity has plunged since he was named as one of five senators who allegedly intervened with federal regulators on behalf of Keating's savings and loan empire. The thrift later collapsed at a cost of $2 billion to the federal government in addition to wiping out the uninsured savings of at least 22,000 mostly elderly Californians. In a survey last summer, pollster Mervin Field listed 10 potential Democratic contenders for Cranston's seat, and found that Cranston finished third, behind Brown and Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy, who tied for first. Other prospective Democrat candidates, in descending order of support in Field's survey: Boxer, state Controller Gray Davis, San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos, Matsui and Rep. Tom Lantos of Burlingame, the Disney Corp.'s Wells and Levine. Another independent pollster, Steve Teichner, said Cranston's announcement would have no impact ``because I don't think there was anyone who thought he was going to run again anyway.'' Teichner said he didn't expect to get a clear picture of who might run in either party for Cranston's seat until Wilson names his successor. Wilson, meanwhile, refused to give any hint of either his pick or when he would announce t. Cranston's statement said his physicians told him his cancer ``is apparently totally curable, but immediate treatment is necessary.'' He added that he wanted to complete his final two years in the Senate ``free of the burdens and the perils of campaigning and fund-raising.'' He was elected to his first of four Senate terms in 1968 after two terms as state controller. In 1984 he waged a brief, unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic nomination for president.

DOC.HEAD: Social `Mavericks' Really Are Influenced By Others, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Most people who seem to do and say whatever they want while ignoring others actually care about their ``social maverick'' image and will change their stated beliefs to protect it, a new study says. Researchers caught some of them in the act of doing that when they were judged too conformist, showing such people pay more attention to others than they let on. The study shows ``the appearance of being indifferent to others is an affectation to some degree,'' said Roy F. Baumeister, a psychology professor at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. ``But you also want to keep in mind that being recognized as something is a big part of being that way. Any trait has to be socially validated, so it's important to them that their autonomy be recognized.'' University of Florida psychologists Barry Schlenker and Michael Weigold decided to test independence, using 94 UF students who had scored high or low on a test that measures, in part, independent-mindedness. Schlenker and Weigold reported their results in the October issue of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Changing stated beliefs may be unconscious and certainly not devious, Schlenker said. ``Self-presentation is part and parcel of everyday life. ... There's nothing evil about it,'' he said. Other psychologists disagree, he said. They say that while some people tailor their words and deeds to make an impression, others are more autonomous, acting on their inner beliefs and tuning out the opinions of others. In the study, the students first completed an opinion questionnaire that ranked how strongly they agreed or disagreed with particular statements about topics like religion and affirmative action. They also completed a questionnaire about personal interests. In a later session, they were randomly split into two groups and told they were about to meet another student. One group was told that this person considered them conformist because of their answers on the personal interest questionnaire. The other students were told they had been judged independent. Then the students were handed another opinion questionnaire, which duplicated some items of the first one. They were told that its asterisk markings indicated which responses were given by most other students. In fact, this was bogus. For half the students, chosen randomly, the markings made it seem that their own opinions largely followed campus norms. For the others, their opinions were made to look quite different. The students were then asked to fill in this questionaire, and told that the person they were about to meet would scrutinize it. As a result, some students faced this situation: You consider yourself independent, but you're about to meet somebody who thinks you're a conformist. Now you find out he's right. If you fill out this new questionnaire honestly you'll affirm that offensive judgment, but you can look autonomous again if you shade the truth a little. As a group, people with that dilemma changed their expressed opinions away from those they thought were conformist. ``If by expressing their real attitudes it made them look dependent, they misrepresented their attitudes to re-establish an image of autonomy,'' Schlenker said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Continues Surge Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to surge against the Japanese yen today in Tokyo, while share prices regained most of their morning losses with the help of bargain hunting. The dollar closed at 130.50 yen, up 1 yen from Thursday's 129.50-yen finish. It opened at 130.45 yen and ranged between 130.30 yen and 131.00 yen. Amid worries over the increasing tensions in the Middle East, Japanese investors bought the dollar up to the 131-yen level in an attempt to increase their dollar positions for fear that war may break out in the Persian Gulf during a three-day weekend in Tokyo, dealers said. Japanese financial markets will be closed Monday for a national holiday commemorating Emperor Akihito's enthronement. Dealers said reports that President Bush ordered major increases in the U.S. Persian Gulf forces initially helped boost the U.S. currency. Many investors consider the dollar a safe haven at a time of international crisis such as the Mideast dispute. Meanwhile, Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said today that the dollar is not falling precipitously on foreign exchange markets. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 38.01 points, or 0.17 percent, to end the week's trading at 22,931.80. The index, which lost 530.44 points Thursday, was 346.23 points lower at the end of the morning session. It regained most of that in the afternoon. Traders said the index quickly recovered toward the close, sparked by arbitrage buying to take profits from future-spot price gaps by large brokerages, in addition to adjustments for their short, or oversold, positions following the index's morning plunge. ``But very few people were buying because of their fears about the intensifying tensions in the Middle East,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. He said investors avoided buying also because of the long weekend in Japan. The declining yen and the government bond prices due to the fears about the Gulf prompted them to step off to the sidelines. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 84.16 points, down from Thursday's 84.26-point finish. Their yield was higher at 8.900 percent from 7.890.

DOC.HEAD: Who CDC Says Should Get Flu Vaccination
With PM-Flu Season
DOC.TEXT: Flu vaccination is strongly recommended for the following groups of people, according to the federal Centers of Disease Control in Atlanta: - All people over age 65. - Anyone between the ages of 6 months and 65 years with chronic heart or lung problems; nursing home residents; and people under regular medical care during the past year for diabetes, kidney conditions, compromised immunity (including infection with the virus that causes AIDS) or inherited blood disorders such as sickle cell anemia and thalassemia. - Children under 18 receiving long-term aspirin therapy for conditions such as arthritis. This recommendation is based on the rare but known link in children between aspirin, influenza and the development of Reye's syndrome, which can be fatal or cause permanent brain damage. - Physicians, nurses and other health-care workers who deal with people in the above high-risk groups, employees in nursing homes and chronic health-care facilities, providers of home care and household members of high-risk people. - Anyone who wants to reduce the chances of getting the flu. --- Who should avoid the vaccination, according to the CDC: - Anyone allergic to eggs. The vaccine is grown in chicken eggs, and even though highly purified, could cause an adverse reaction. - Anyone with a fever, until the fever subsides.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We're no longer the not-ready-for-prime-time players.'' - Jane Danowitz, executive director of the bipartisan Women's Campaign Fund, on the success of women candidates in Tuesday's elections. --- ``And they're going to do it over my dead veto - or live veto, or something like that, because it ain't going to happen, I'll guarantee you.'' - President Bush, saying he will oppose any future congressional efforts to raise taxes. --- ``I don't fear the next world, or anything. I don't fear hell, and I don't look forward to heaven.'' - Actress Katharine Hepburn on turning 81 on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl's Surprise Border Gesture A Boost for Mazowiecki Government ^With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Polish officials are elated by German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's unexpected decision to sign within three weeks a treaty confirming his country's long-disputed border with Poland. The decision to move up the signing is also a political boost for Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. ``One of the most thorny problems disappears from the Polish-German front,'' the pro-Mazowiecki daily Gazeta Wyborcza said today of the development. Kohl and Mazowiecki met Thursday along the Oder River and decided that the 45-year dispute over the Polish-German border would finally be laid to rest with a treaty-signing ceremony in Warsaw before the end of the month. The line on the Oder and Neisse rivers, drawn by the victorious Allies after World War II, gave Poland 40,000 square miles of former German territory in Silesia, Pomerania and East Prussia. The acquired territory is one-third of today's Poland. The border was originally meant to be provisional, pending a post-war peace treaty that never took place. It created tension between Poland and Germany for decades, and right-wing German politicians called for restoring some or all of the land to Germany. Although Germany already had promised to accept the border as part of the process that led to German unification Oct. 3, the treaty was not expected to be signed until next year. The Kohl government had sought to link it to a larger friendship pact that would include guarantees of human rights for up to 1 million ethnic Germans who remain in Poland. A German official traveling with Kohl privately described the decision to speed up the border treaty as a gift to Mazowiecki, who is locked in an uphill campaign for president against Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa. The treaty is to be signed by Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski and German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. It was possible it could be signed even before Polish elections on Nov. 25. Briefing reporters after the summit in the Polish border town of Slubice, Mazowiecki expressed deep satisfaction with the ``important results'' and the ``good will'' showed by Kohl. Beside the early signing of the border treaty, he pointed to progress on a range of Polish-German issues, including the Kohl government's intention to abolish by Christmas mandatory visas for Poles traveling to Germany. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said the Germans accepted Poland's view on the delicate issue of its ethnic German minority - that ethnic Germans will have rights on a par with other ethnic groups in Poland and generally accepted European standards. There had been calls in Germany for extending them special status or even dual Polish and German citizenship. The two leaders also agreed to upgrade the 372-mile road linking Warsaw and Berlin, much of which is only two lanes, to remove trade barriers and to establish additional border crossings.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Say Enthronement Violates Constitution
DOC.TEXT: Late one spring night, Toru Yuge stood up and reached for a book from a shelf above the window in his second-floor study. Immediately after he sat down at a low table beneath the window, two bullets shot throught the pane, sending shards of glass across the room. The gunshots were also sending a message to Yuge. ``I thought that we would be harassed by ultra-rightists, but I didn't expect that kind of attack so suddenly,'' said the soft-spoken Yuge, president of Tokyo's Ferris University. A few days before the shooting, he and the presidents of three other Japanese Christian colleges had issued a statement criticizing government plans to sponsor enthronement ceremonies for Emperor Akihito. They and other opponents charge that the rites violate the constitution's separation of religion and state, and say the government is using virtually the same Shinto ceremonies that made Akihito's father and grandfather ``living gods.'' ``In planning the ceremonies, the government has basically returned to the pre-war laws that were deleted from the postwar constitution,'' Yuge says. ``They are reinstating the idea that the emperor is god and thereby going completely against the current constitution.'' Yuge, 66, says he and the other presidents continue to receive harassing phone calls and remain under police protection. He now closes the shutters before working at home and informs the police each morning of his plans for the day. Twenty-five other university presidents have since joined in supporting their statement, although others declined out of fear, Yuge says. ``This is an issue that will have a strong impact on Japan's future. So it's natural that there are strong feelings on both sides,'' he says. ``But because of its importance, we need to be able to discuss it openly, without the threat of violence on either side.'' Many Japanese between the political extremes see the coronation rites that begin Monday as quaint, mysterious observances far removed from their lives. In a poll released Wednesday by the Nippon Television Network, nearly half the respondents said they had no interest. But others say the ceremonies have profound implications for Japan's political future. Japan's Constitution, written under U.S. guidance during the Allied occupation after World War II, changed the emperor's status from living god to ``symbol of the state.'' But critics say the rites are an attempt to once again redefine and strengthen the emperor's role by linking it with Shinto religion and myth. ``The Cabinet, including the prime minister and Imperial Household Agency, is doing something unforgivable,'' says Yuge. ``The government and the business circles behind it want to strengthen the emperor to extend their own authority. So it's a very important turning point.'' Yoshiyasu Kawane, a Japanese history professor at Osaka City University, says the government has planned the rites to be as similar as possible to the enthronements of the past two emperors. It was during that period that the government reformed Shintoism, Japan's highly decentralized indigenous religion, into a centralized state religion used to glorify the emperor and rally support for the government, especially during World War II. ``The government is trying to create a unifying, nationalistic force using the same process as in the past,'' Kawane says. ``For example, the Parliament is debating a law that would allow the dispatch of Japanese troops overseas. What purpose would Japanese soldiers be willing to die for now? Not very many people want to die for the prime minister.'' Opponents particularly criticize the planned use during Akihito's enthronement of a 20-foot-high royal said to be patterned after one used by the sun goddess - thus conveying divinity. In Osaka, more than 1,500 people, including Buddhists, Catholics, Protestants, lawyers and academics, have filed suit in an attempt to block the use of government funds for the enthronement. Japan's largest Christian organization, the National Christian Council of Japan, has gathered 130,000 signatures on a petition condemning state funding of the Nov. 22-23 Daijosai, or ``Great Food Offering Ritual.'' More than 1,000 people will participate in a 100-hour hunger strike beginning Nov. 19 in another protest. In the Daijosai, Akihito is to hold an overnight ``communion'' with the sun goddess, from whom the imperial line is said to have descended. Rightists believe the emperor is reborn as a living god following a union between the two. The Socialist Party, the largest opposition group, plans to boycott the rite, and leading lawyers have questioned its constitutionality. While ultra-rightists support a stronger role for the emperor, ultra-leftists demand the abolition of the imperial system and have vowed to disrupt the enthronement. Police count more than 60 violent leftist attacks this year, more than twice the number in 1989, including bombing Nov. 1 that killed a policeman. But Yuge says the harassment will not keep him from speaking out. This week, he released another statement condemning the use of violence by both sides to suppress freedom of speech.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Declare Victory in Medfly War
DOC.TEXT: The crop-destroying Mediterranean fruit fly has been wiped out in California after a $52 million campaign that lasted 15 months, officials said. ``We're here to celebrate that we have eradicated the Medfly in California,'' Jack Parnell, deputy secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, said during a news conference Thursday with state agriculture chief Henry Voss. They officially lifted a quarantine barring movement of fruit and vegetables from infested areas. Medfly traps will continue to be placed statewide to detect any new arrivals. The arrival of illegal fruit and vegetables, usually carried in travelers' luggage, virtually ensures future infestations, one official said in an interview last weekend. ``There is some perverse streak in human nature. They seem to believe it's fun to outsmart authorities and bring in just one mango or just one pineapple from Hawaii,'' said Gera Curry, spokeswoman for the state Department of Food and Agriculture. ``All it takes is one person.'' Quarantines had been imposed because of worries that Medflies could spread from urban Southern California to rural agricultural areas and wreck the state's $18 billion-a-year farming economy. Slightly smaller than a common housefly, the Medfly lays its eggs in fruit and vegetables. The can afflict hundreds of different plant varieties. Florida declared victory over the Medfly in August, four months after finding a single fly near Miami International Airport. The Medfly has plagued California farmers since the early 1980s. From 1980 to 1982 state and federal officials spent $100 million to battle the pest. The latest infestation caused a public outcry when the state repeatedly sent helicopters to spray the pesticide malathion over dozens of communities in a 500-square-mile area. Citizens filed 300 damage claims and numerous lawsuits. ``There is no health hazard related to malathion in the amounts we use,'' Voss said. But he added: ``It's something we hope we won't have to do again. We hope science can come up with alternatives.'' Roy Cunningham, chairman of the state Medfly Science Advisory Panel, said last weekend that if the fly returns, enhanced detection measures should prevent infestations from reaching the same scale. In 1980 and 1989, the state waited too long to begin eradication, he said.

DOC.HEAD: New York City Bans Cigarette Vending Machines
With PM-CDC-Cigarettes, PM-EPA-Tobacco Lobby
DOC.TEXT: New York City has taken another step to curb cigarette smoking. The City Council voted overwhelmingly to ban the sale of cigarette vending machines in most public places to keep minors from buying smokes. Mayor David Dinkins, a former two-pack-a-day smoker, is expected to sign the bill into law. The council passed it 33-1 on Thursday. The move makes New York the largest city in the country to restrict cigarette vending machines, Councilman Sal Albanese said. Salt Lake City and Minneapolis have enacted similar bans. The city already prohibits the distribution of free cigarettes on the street and plans to phase out cigarette advertising on city-owned billboards, on taxis, at baseball stadiums and in the subways, said Councilman Joseph Lisa. Tobacco industry officials decried the latest ban. ``The tobacco industry agrees with the goal of keeping cigarettes out of the hands of kids, but it is a misguided notion to think that by banning cigarette vending machines that's what you're going to accomplish,'' said Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Washington-based Tobacco Institute. She said 30 percent of cigarette machines are located in bars, where children are not supposed to be anyway. A spokesman for cigarette maker Philip Morris Inc., Les Zuke, called the legislation ``unnecessary'' and ``an overreaction.'' He said vending machines account for only 3 percent of cigarette sales. The bill allows machines in taverns and bars in hotels and motels as long as they are within sight of the owner or operator, who is supposed to stop minors from buying. State law bans the sale of cigarettes to those under age 18. The bill would ban machines from such places as restaurants, bowling alleys and theaters. Violations could result in fines ranging from not more than $300 for the first offense to $1,000 for the third. Any subsequent violations could result in suspension of cigarette licenses for up to one year. Councilman Jerome O'Donovan, the lone dissenter, said he doubted the law would be enforceable and that youngsters still could get cigarettes by buying them across-the-counter. The Music, Cigarette & Amusement Association, Inc., representing over 150 small businesses in the vending machine industry, said in October the proposed ban would result in the loss of jobs for 2,000 unskilled and semi-skilled workers in the city. Also on Thursday, Patrick Halpin, the executive of Suffolk County on New York's Long Island, vetoed legislation meant to restrict access to cigarette vending machines because it was not strong enough.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Beef Up Armed Forces, But Still Dwarfed By Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `The Saudis...' with 1 graf to CORRECT Saudi arms spending to $40 billion sted $15 billion. Pickup 4th graf `King Fahd...'; Also in Friday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Despite spending billions of dollars on air defenses and anti-tank weapons and plans to double the size of its army, Saudi Arabia will still be unable to fend off a full-scale Iraqi attack alone. Unless Saddam Hussein's formidable military machine is crippled in the gulf confrontation, that means a sizeable Western military presence will almost certainly have to remain in the region for some time to come. The Saudis have spent an estimated $40 billion on advanced weapons systems over the past decade. But they were unable to take on Saddam's million-strong military juggernaut when it crushed Kuwait in August and appeared to threaten the Saudis' own desert kingdom. King Fahd had little option but to appeal for U.S. and allied help to protect a country which contains Islam's holiest shrines, despite an outcry by some Moslem hard-liners. The crisis has benefited the Saudis inasmuch as the threat to their oilfields overcame the pro-Israel lobby in the U.S. Congress, which for years blocked the sale of state-of-the-art weaponry to Riyadh on the grounds it was technically at war with Israel. Now the Americans have pledged to sell the Saudis some $20 billion worth of sophisticated hardware, including F-15 C/D Eagle fighters, Patriot missiles, 350 M1A2 Abrams tanks and 500 Bradley Fighting Vehicles. But even after delivery of the new arsenal over the next two or three years, analysts say the Saudis will be unable to take on Saddam alone, if he's still around. ``The Saudi defense plan relied on being able to hold the attackers off for long enough to get outside assistance,'' said Nadav Safran, a professor of Middle East studies at Harvard University. ``When Saddam's troops marched into Kuwait, the Saudis realized that even after two decades of beefing up their defenses, they still didn't have the capacity to hold him off, even for a few days,'' said Safran, who is the author of ``Saudi Arabia: The Ceaseless Quest for Security.'' King Fahd and his defense minister, Prince Sultan, are planning to more than double the size of the 65,000-man regular Saudi armed forces, which is supported by a 56,000-man National Guard. It is unclear where the recruits will come from. Saudi Arabia, which is as large as the United States east of the Mississippi, has only about 8 million citizens and has long suffered from a shortage of men of military age. As in most gulf countries, the Saudi military is a volunteer force, and no plans have been announced for conscription. According to the government-controlled press, 50,000 men have volunteered for the kingdom's Citizen's Army since Aug. 2. The volunteers receive one month's military training. In the event of war, these hastily trained troops are supposed to be integrated into regular army units. Merging the regular armed forces headed by Prince Sultan with the National Guard, commanded by Crown Prince Abdullah, has been ruled out for the time being. Fahd reportedly favored such a move a decade ago, when he was crown prince. But he was overruled by other members of the royal family - wisely, according to Safran, because of the threat to the monarchy posed by a large army. ``Even if they should merge the army and National Guard, they couldn't develop a capacity to defend themselves against challenges like that presented by Iraq,'' Safran said. ``So to run the risk of a military coup just for the sake of developing an army that couldn't even guard against the main danger anyway doesn't make sense.'' The Saudi Air Force has 179 combat aircraft to Iraq's 500-plus, and 550 battle tanks to Saddam's 5,500. The new U.S. arms package is a key element in the Saudi plan to bolster its military. But U.S. Representative Mel Levine contends that the Saudis still couldn't defend themselves, ``no matter how gold-plated their equipment is.'' Levine, an Israel supporter and critic of the proposed arms sales, argues the administration is using the invasion of Kuwait as a pretext to overcome the pro-Israel lobby's influence. Despite the Saudi military buildup, the kingdom will still have to rely on balancing regional powers with money and diplomacy rather than on military might. That is how the Saudis have coped with regional threats in the past, including a rebellion in neighboring Yemen backed by the late Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser in the 1960s, and the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Martin Marris is based in Bahrain and has covered the Middle East for four years.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Detectives Find One State's Law Isn't Working
With PM-Cigarette Machine Ban, PM-EPA-Tobacco Lobby
DOC.TEXT: Minors trying to buy cigarettes have a 2-out-of-3 chance of succeeding, according to an undercover operation that tested one state's law against selling smokes to people under age 18. Federal health oficials reported Thursday that Colorado's 1987 law prohibiting merchants from selling tobacco to minors and prohibiting youngsters from buying wasn't working too well. The national Centers for Disease Control said many vendors may not be familiar with this law, and ``some may believe enforcement is unlikely or that the profits from cigarette sales to minors outweigh possible financial penalties for violating the law.'' The fine for violations, by merchants or juveniles, is only $25, said Walter Young, director of the Prevention Programs division of the Colorado Department of Health. The Coalition for a Tobacco-Free Colorado, a consortium of public and private health organizations, sent 11 young volunteer teams to 121 sites to see if the children could buy tobacco. At 77 sites, or 64 percent, they were successful. ``It's disappointing that merchants have not gotten the message that they're not supposed to sell to kids,'' Young said. All 24 times that minor volunteers went to a cigarette machine, no one stopped them. The 97 other attempts involved vendors or sales clerks; 53 of those were successful. Colorado's cigarette snoops ranged from age 9 to 17. The survey was done in August 1989. ``Sales clerks did not appear to discriminate in their sales practices between very young adolescents and those closer to legal age,'' the CDC said. Among those buying from sales clerks, the success rate for volunteers ages 15-17 was 55 percent, virtually identical to the 54 percent success rate for the other volunteers. Options that could cut down on illegal cigarette sales include banning cigarette machines, but machines account for less than 10 percent of sales to minors, Young noted. Since the survey, Colorado health officials have distributed pamphlets, door stickers and display signs to merchants to encourage compliance with the law, Young said. The CDC said that the minors participating in the project didn't actually break the law. They approached machines but didn't buy, and they told any helpful clerks they didn't have enough money for the purchase.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Dead In Black Factional Fighting In Natal Province
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen blacks were stabbed to death and four were wounded in a vicious factional fight in the eastern province of Natal, police said today. Police said two groups of men clashed Thursday night in Bruntville, a black township 80 miles northwest of the port city of Durban. Police dispersed the groups and found 15 bodies, all with stab wounds. Authorities did not identify the combatants. In a separate incident, one man was killed and 12 injured when attackers with assault rifles and a hand grenade fired on a bus transporting workers Thursday night in Sebokeng, 38 miles south of Johannesburg. The battle in Bruntville erupted after recent confrontations between rival groups. A meeting hall was damaged Wednesday before residents of a migrant workers hostel were scheduled to gather there. During the day Thursday, assailants with guns, knives and gasoline bombs attacked a workers hostel, leaving one man dead and dozens injured. Eighteen housing units were destroyed by fire, police said. Women and children then began fleeing Bruntville for the nearby town of Mooi River, apparently anticipating the large-scale fighting that broke out later. Some 5,000 blacks have died in faction fighting in Natal Province since 1986. The main combatants have been supporters of the African National Congress and the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party. The ANC and Inkatha are the country's two largest black political movements, and both oppose the apartheid system of racial segregation. But they differ offer tactics and the vision of a future South Africa. The two sides have been holding periodic peace talks in Natal, but the ANC on Thursday indefinitely postponed the next round of discussions. The ANC-Inkatha feud in Natal spread to the Johannesburg area in August, leaving more than 800 dead.

DOC.HEAD: President Names New Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Socialist Chandra Shekhar, facing a nation bloodied by religious and ethnic strife, was named India's new prime minister today. Chandra Shekhar, the dissident leader who helped topple Prime Minister V.P. Singh and his government on Wednesday, will be sworn in Saturday and will seek Parliament's endorsement by Nov. 20, President Ramaswamy Venkataraman announced. The president said he chose Chandra Shekhar because he ``has the strength to form a viable government'' with the support of the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Venkataraman said he offered three other parties the chance to form a government, but all refused. ``It will not be in the national interest to plunge the country into a general election at this time ... and every effort should be made to provide the country with a reasonably stable government,'' said the statement. Chandra Shekhar, 63, appearing composed as he spoke to reporters outside the presidential palace after a 35-minute meeting with the president. The president ``was satisfied I am able to form the government,'' he said, but he declined to discuss his Cabinet or his agenda. Asked what his immediate programs would be, he said: ``Priorities I shall discuss after tomorrow's swearing-in.'' Later he told reporters he felt nothing special after being named prime minister-designate. ``I am as normal as always,'' he said. Singh resigned Wednesday after losing a parliamentary vote of confidence the same day. Chandra Shakhar's first challenge will be to stem a wave of violence between India's Hindu majority and Moslem minority. At least 370 people have died in the last three weeks in riots sparked by a Hindu fundamentalist attempt to replace a mosque with a temple in the Hindu holy town of Ayodhya. About 150 other people have died in protests by upper-caste Hindus over Singh's affirmative action program to reserve more government jobs for lower castes. More than half were students and teen-agers who committed suicide, blaming Singh's policy for their action. The president said he offered Congress, the largest party in Parliament, first option to form a government. Congress declined, but said it would give ``unconditional support'' to Chandra Shekhar, the statement said. He then proposed the task to the Hindu right-wing Bharataya Janata Party, the next largest group, and the Left Front, an alliance of communist and socialist parties, before turning to Chandra Shekhar. As prime minister, Chandra Shekhar would preside over the smallest government India has ever had. His dissident faction of Singh's Janata Dal party had only 56 votes in Parliament when the government lost a vote of confidence on Wednesday. Chandra Shekhar's group, which broke away from the Janata Dal party earlier in the week, has claimed the support of 280 members in the 522-seat decision-making lower house of Parliament. Gandhi's Congress Party has 195 seats, and its small-party allies have another 15. Critics have argued that the arrangement leaves the new government vulnerable to Congress, which could withdraw its support as soon as it feels ready to face elections. Singh's Janata Dal formed the government after the November 1989 general elections when it prevented Gandhi's party from winning a majority. The 11-month-old government was reduced to a minority after the Bharatiya Janata Party, angered by his blocking of the Hindu campaign over the disputed mosque, withdrew support. Chandra Shekhar's defection dealt the government its death blow.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Denies Union's Allegations of Age Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: A broadcast union at odds with NBC claims that NBC News is trying to get rid of some older staffers by putting them in a common labor pool described as ``professional exile.'' The network denied it. ``These people all have jobs and they're not going away,'' Don Browne, NBC's executive news director, said of about 35 NBC news writers and producers, who will be taken from specific programs and put in the pool for use as needed. The move was done as a cost-cutting measure, with the executive producers of shows like ``Today'' and ``NBC Nightly News'' deciding which members of their staff would be shifted to the labor pool. John Clark, president of the New York local of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, said Thursday that 12 of 21 NABET members affected are age 50 or over, and ``we think these are people the company would like to get rid of.'' He characterized the pool as ``professional exile'' for those sent there. Browne denied that and other allegations by Clark, including his claim that NBC is apparently retaliating against NABET members who sued the network for overtime pay by also putting them in the labor pool. Browne said pool members would be put on duty with programs or work in NBC News bureaus as requirements dictated. ``These people are going to be very active,'' he said. Clark, whose 900-member local is NABET's largest, said the union will add a claim of age discrimination to a unfair labor practices complaint it has filed against NBC with the National Labor Relations Board. No action has been taken yet on the complaint, which was filed after NBC in August put into effect a new three-year contract that a majority of the union's 2,300 members at NBC previously had rejected. Three years ago, NABET struck NBC in a bitter walkout that lasted 17 weeks. No strike vote has been called this time, so far, although no new negotiations are planned, Clark said.

DOC.HEAD: Ceasar Takes Long Count Against the Law
DOC.TEXT: Bar patrons couldn't pin him down, but the long arm of the law finally wrestled Ceasar the bear to the mat. Caesar, a North American black bear that has wrestled patrons of Midwest bars and nightclubs for the past six years, was held Thursday in his air conditioned trailer behind the Gazander Restaurant & Lounge. Police in this southwest Chicago suburb warned bar proprieter Steve Sineni and bear owner Sam Mazzola they would be arrested if Caesar wrestled again at the lounge. They cited two city ordinances that carry $500 fines each and a state health law. Sineni said he would seek a court order today allowing the bear back into action. Eight patrons paid $10 apiece on Oct. 22 and 29 to get on the mat with Caesar, hoping to win $1,000 promised to anyone who pinned the 7-foot, 6-inch, 970 pound bear. No one did. Animal rights activists also picketed the bar, but assistant manager Dominic Roti said Caesar was treated well. Roti, at 5-foot-11 and 217 pounds, challenged Caesar and lost. ``For the first couple of minutes, you make friends with the bear. Then he knocks you down and puts his paw on top of you,'' Roti said. That was enough for Police Chief George Dulzo, who said he had no intention of taking Caesar into custody. ``We won't drag the bear off stage,'' Dulzo said. ``I've seen the bear. He's bigger than me. Probably smarter, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Bars CNN From Broadcasting Noriega-Lawyer Conversations
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge barred the Cable News Network from broadcasting Manuel Noriega's taped conversations with his lawyers, saying the ousted Panama dictator's right to a fair trial on drug charges is in jeopardy. Defense attorney Frank Rubino said he would demand that the case against Noriega be dismissed. ``We are absolutely shocked and horrified that the United States government would wiretap General Noriega and his lawyers engaging in the most sensitive of communications,'' Rubino said. But Justice Department officials said the taping was routine, and that Noriega had known his calls would be monitored. A federal prison spokesman said it was up to Noriega to inform officials that he was talking with his attorneys so they would stop the recording. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler on Thursday told CNN it couldn't broadcast the tapes, made by prison officials, and demanded an investigation into how the network got them. He also ordered the taping stopped. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, in Tampa on Thursday, said U.S. officials want to find out how the tapes were leaked to CNN. ``It concerns us greatly that an apparent unauthorized use was made of these tapes,'' he said. CNN accused the judge of exercising unconstitutional prior restraint and demanded an immediate hearing on the issue from the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. No hearing was immediately scheduled by the appeals court, but Hoeveler scheduled another hearing in his court for late this afternoon. Meantime, he told the news station not to broadcast, at least through today, any tapes that would interfere with attorney-client privilege rights. ``Because of our belief the order is unconstitutional, we will continue our coverage as we challenge this restraining order in the courts,'' said CNN President Tom Johnson. Hoeveler said he had to weigh Noriega's right to a fair trial against CNN's right to freedom of the press. ``It's becoming more and more difficult in this case to assure that both parties get a fair trial,'' he said. U.S. Justice Department officials said the taping was routine and produced a document in English and Spanish that Noriega signed acknowledging that his phone conversations would be monitored. Rubino complained that the taping of Noriega's conversations violated his client's right to private meetings with his attorneys and jeopardized his case because the U.S. government now knows his defense strategy. U.S. Bureau of Prisons spokesman Gregory L. Bogdan in Washington said prisoners are supposed to inform guards when they are talking to their attorneys so the monitoring can be stopped. Federal prosecutors told Hoeveler they haven't heard the tapes. Rubino was skeptical. ``And I believe in Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny and the Tooth Fairy,'' he said. The taping flap is the latest threatening to delay or derail Noriega's trial on charges he accepted $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel to protect their smuggling operations through his country. The U.S. government has earmarked $6 million of $20 million in frozen Noriega assets for payment of his attorneys, but last month Panama filed a lawsuit accusing Noriega of looting its treasury and said it would seek to have those assets frozen. Noriega's defense teams says it needs the money to put together his defense before the case can go to trial. The trial is scheduled to begin early next year, but both sides agree it will probably be delayed. Panamanian President Guillermo Endara said Thursday that if the United States does not go through with the trial, Panama wants Noriega returned to face charges there. ``In the case that the North Americans can't do it, we're going to ask for him, and he will be judged in accord with Panamanian law, because he committed many, many crimes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Six Degrees of Separation' Reopens at Lincoln Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf at end with Times review. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: On second viewing, ``Six Degrees of Separation'' reconfirms its status as the most imaginative play of the year. John Guare's scathing, savagely funny tale of New York chic officially reopened Thursday after moving from a small theater in Lincoln Center to the much larger Vivian Beaumont. The move makes the play eligible for Tony Award nominations next May. They could give the prize right now. There probably won't be a better new play all season. Guare's play, which originally opened last June, resonates on many levels - social satire, rapid-fire farce, intellectual funhouse, tragic pop fable and just plain good story, to name a few. The plot, based on a real-life incident, concerns a young black man who claims to be the son of actor Sidney Poitier and how he bamboozles all these rich, supposedly sophisticated New Yorkers. Along the way, Guare manages to skewer everything from ``Cats'' to overpriced Italian restaurants to race relations. The author of ``The House of Blue Leaves'' has an ear for the way present-day New Yorkers talk and think. And Jerry Zaks directs in slam-bang style, never allowing the play to careen out of control. The bigger theater hasn't lessened the production's impact. What has, oddly enough, is the casting of Courtney B. Vance in the pivotal role of Paul, the young black man who disrupts the lives of these Upper East Side trendies. Vance is a fine actor but he lacks the magnetism that James McDaniel brought to the role last summer. McDaniel, who left the show to appear in the television series ``Cop Rock,'' had a sinuous charm, a quality that could be ingratiating and unnerving at the same time. That appeal is missing from Vance's stiff portrayal of the hustler who makes fools out of these members of the upper crust. The rest of the cast was - and still is - just about perfect. Stockard Channing manages to make the play's bewildered heroine both funny and poignant. She wants to believe Paul's tall tale, celebrating his imagination while forgetting his lie. And John Cunningham acts and looks picture perfect as the WASP art dealer not above a little finagling to make some big bucks. The large supporting cast is just fine and there are several standout cameos - Peter Maloney, a mournful parent who doesn't want to know what his child is doing; Evan Handler as a vindictive rich kid, and Robert Duncan McNeil as the country bumpkin destroyed by Paul's deceptions. ``Six Degrees of Separation'' is one of those rare plays that deserves a second look. Frank Rich, reviewing the play in Friday's New York Times, said he found it ``as funny and moving and provocative as ever - still a fresh experience, not last season's calcified hit.''

DOC.HEAD: New York City Cutting Jobs, Selling Land to Close $388 Million Budget Gap
With PM-Philly Finances
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins, struggling to close the city's massive budget deficit, announced $288 million in job cutbacks now and warned of many more later. The national recession, which is striking the Northeast economy especially hard, was blamed for the cuts. They will include more than 550 layoffs in schools, hospitals and parks, combined with 5,000 jobs openings that will not be filled, Dinkins said Thursday. Slashing jobs and the $100 million sale of a Manhattan parking lot to the federal government are supposed to make up a $388 million budget shortfall for the current fiscal year. Dinkins said he'll feel the bite too. He plans to cut his staff by 170 people. The budget gap for the next business year, which begins July 1, 1991, is expected to top $1.6 billion. Future efforts to deal with that shortfall could mean 20,000 lost jobs, Dinkis said. Ten thousand of the jobs to be slashed for fiscal year 1992 will likely result from layoffs, with another 10,000 from attrition, budget director Philip Michael said. The city has 224,563 workers. Under the plan announced Thursday, city schools face hundreds of teacher layoffs and 1,000 more jobs lost through attrition. Other cuts include delaying recycling programs and closing some fire companies. No job cuts were planned for the police force. The cuts were forced by a drastic drop in tax revenues. ``The root of all these problems is the economy,'' Michael said.

DOC.HEAD: Miss U.S.A. Wins Miss World Contest
DOC.TEXT: The new Miss World is 21-year-old Gina Marie Tolleson of Spartenburg, S.C. The brown-haired, brown-eyed Ms. Tolleson, who is six feet tall, was crowned at the 40th annual Miss World beauty contest Thursday night by last year's winner, Aneta Kreglicka of Poland. First runner-up was Miss Ireland, 20-year-old air stewardess Siobhan McClafferty. Miss Venezuela, 19-year-old dance teacher Sharon Raquel Luenso Gonzales, was third. A panel of judges made the selection. The contest at the London Palladium was watched live by a worldwide television audience of 500 million, the organizers said. In Britain, however, the 90-minute show, which included performances from singer Jason Donovan and pianist Richard Clayderman, was screened later. In recent years British television companies have declined to show the contest live, citing a decline in the number of viewers it attracts. Ms. Tolleson won $19,000 in cash and a work contract worth $59,000. Ms. Tolleson, who said she hopes to become a broadcaster after finishing her studies, is trained in ballet, jazz and tap dancing. Her hobbies include horseback riding and gardening. This year marked the Miss World contest's return to London. It was held in Hong Kong for the first time last year after 38 years in the British capital.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
