Traders said the market was digesting a spate of statements and news events, while banks were adjusting their positions ahead of a three-day weekend in the United States and Japan. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.00 yen to a closing 130.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 129.58 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.4908 German marks, up from 1.4885 -1.2515 Swiss francs, down from 1.258 -5.006 French francs, up from 4.9935 -1.6810 Dutch guilders, up from 1.678 -1,120.50 Italian lire, down from 1,129.75 -1.1676 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1685 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9643, compared with $1.9670 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $384.85 per ounce at midmorning, down from $385.75 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $385.25, up from $384.75 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.73 to close at a bid $384.58. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.24 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.25.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in South, Clouds Over Much of East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `High temperatures...', to CORRECT that high was for Thursday sted Friday.
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across parts of the South early today and freezing temperatures and fog gripped much of the eastern United States. Temperatures in the 20s and low 30s were recorded in New York, Massachussetts, Minnesota and Ohio early today as a cold front moved across the area. Clouds also blanketed a large swath of the eastern half of the country from the Great Lakes to the South, and rain fell on Arkansas, Louisiana and Tennessee early today. The Eastern Seaboard was expected to see clear skies later in the day, with temperatures in the 40s and 50s in the north, the 60s in the central area and the 70s farther south. Clear skies were anticipated across most of the Midwest and West with temperatures mostly in the 40s and 50s in the Midwest and 70s and 80s in the West. Rain was forecast for parts of the Pacific Northwest, where highs in the 50s and 60s were expected. High temperature for the nation Thursday was 89 degrees at Naples, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Police Implicate Leftist Radicals In Fire
With PM-Enthronement Foes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police believe leftist radicals opposed to Emperor Akihito's coronation set a fire today that razed a building on the grounds of one of Japan's most important Buddhist temples. The Hachibuindo hall of Enryakuji temple was found ablaze just after midnight by a temple guard, said a police official in Otsu, 230 miles west of Tokyo. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said wires and eight charred batteries were found at the site of the fire, a common indication of arson. No one was injured. ``We believe the fire may have been set by an ultra-leftist group and are conducting an investigation with that in mind,'' he said. Radical groups opposed to Emperor Akihito's coronation on Monday have claimed responsibility for setting fires at several Shinto shrines over the past month and are suspected of arson attacks on three this week alone. The Kakurokyo, or Revolutionary Workers Association, on Wednesday also claimed responsibility for blasts at a police dormitory that killed one officer and injured six other people on Nov. 1. Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion, is deeply tied to the monarchy, and Enryakuji is the head temple of the Tendai sect of Buddhism, which has been closely associated with Japan's nobility throughout its history. Enryakuji priests began a special prayer service to mark Akihito's formal enthronement this afternoon, a temple employee said. He said the prayers will continue until next month. The employee, who also requested that he not be named, said the temple had not received any threatening phone calls from radicals. Enryakuji temple, recognized as one of the most venerable of Japan's holy places, was originally built in 788. The hall that was destroyed in today's fire had just been rebuilt two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Countries Will Fight Alongside U.S., Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs graf 4, As Baker, with two new grafs to include Baker quotes. Inserts grafs 20-21, We think, with Baker quotes. Editing throughout to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Arab forces would fight alongside U.S. troops to liberate Kuwait from Iraq, a senior U.S. official said today near the end of a trip by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. However, the official said he was not sure whether France would go along. Baker will meet with French President Francois Mitterrand and Foreign Minister Roland Dumas in Paris on Saturday. ``I don't know where the French would be,'' said the official, who briefed reporters under rules of anonymity. Baker left today for London. As to the Soviets, ``they are not optimistic and indeed after having sent two diplomatic missions of their own to Baghdad, I think it's fair to say that they are disappointed in the lack of a response that's been received,'' Baker said today. ``They're disappointed in the adamant attitude of Saddam Hussein in refusing to comply with 10 United Nations resolutions. I think they are as disappointed and as frustrated as most of the rest of the world community,'' he said on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' Referring to Yevgeny Primakov, a Soviet Mideast expert who has been dispatched twice to Baghdad by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the senior official told reporters, ``They sent an emissary and he was stiffed.'' Until now, the Soviets had hailed Primakov's trips as productive and said they had given leaders cause for optimism. Over the last several weeks the Soviets have raised hopes that a political solution could avert military action in the Persian Gulf region. But on Thursday, for the first time publicly, they gave their approval of the use of military force to get Iraq out of Kuwait if peaceful pressure tactics fail. Baker has talked about a military option at every stop during his travels to Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and the Soviet Union. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, during a news conference with Baker Thursday, made no mention of military action until he was pressed by reporters. ``Whether or not the use of force could be ruled out - probably this could not be ruled out - and a situation may emerge which effectively would require such a move,'' Shevardnadze said then. The official said Saudi officials during meetings last week were ``absolutely'' committed to fighting alongside U.S. troops. ``There's no doubt in my mind Saudi forces would be committed,'' he said. Egyptians, ousted Kuwaitis and other Arab forces in the Gulf region also would join with the United States, the official said. However, Syria was a puzzler. The official said he was not sure what Syria would do, although ``they might lead the charge'' against Iraq. The United States had enlisted Syria in its makeshift alliance despite U.S. allegations that the Damascus government has supported terrorism. Syrian President Hafez Assad and Saddam lead rival factions of the Ba'ath Party and are bitter enemies. Saddam already has linked Syria's military presence in Lebanon to Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. Baker came to Moscow on Wednesday seeking at least Soviet acquiescence if the Bush administration presented a resolution to the United Nations Security Council to authorize the use of force as a last resort to liberate Kuwait. But the official said Baker had not asked Gorbachev or Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze during their talks to support such a resolution. ``We haven't even authorized the drafting of a resolution,'' the official added. ``We think that a specific resolution of the security council that leaves no doubt about that option (of force) would be preferable from a political standpoint,'' Baker said today on NBC's ``Today'' show. ``That's not to say it's required. It's not a precondition,'' Baker said. Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China, one of five Security Council members who could veto the resolution, told Baker Tuesday in Cairo that Beijing would not block such a resolution. Meanwhile today, Baker acknowledged that a major arms control agreement due for signing in 10 days at a Paris summit still was not finished. Besides some technical issues, he said, neither side had approved methods of verifying weapons reductions or paying the cost of inspections. The treaty is the intended showcase of a 34-nation summit meeting in Paris that President Bush is due to attend Nov. 19-21. It would be the most comprehensive arms control accord in history, encompassing Europe from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union. Near the conclusion of Baker's 13 hours of talks on Thursday in Moscow, the two sides managed to reach an agreement in principle on deployment of tanks, anti-aircraft artillery and other non-nuclear arms in four European zones. The arrangement needs the approval of Turkey and Norway. Baker sent Ronald Lehman, director of the U.S. Arms Control Agency, to Oslo, Norway, and Stephen Hadley, of the U.S. National Security Council, to Ankara, Turkey, to consult with government leaders in those capitals. Hanging in the balance also is another accord to cut U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent. Shevardnadze said there were ``some difficult problems'' with that pact, which Bush had hoped to sign at another summit meeting this winter in Moscow. The outlook is clouded by disagreement over several issues, including how much leeway the Soviets would have to keep testing their SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Pawnbrokers Benefit From Tough Times
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of usurious, loath. SUBS 6th graf, `Many of..', to CORRECT spelling of fliers. CORRECTS category code. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Pawnshops are increasingly becoming home to the gold that made the 1980s glitter as layoffs wrack Wall Street and other industries. But after years of being rudely portrayed by Hollywood as a usurious business preying on the impoverished, the pawnbroking industry is loath to be seen as a leading recessionary indicator. Lincoln Square Pawnbrokers is an example of the boom. Newly hard-pressed New Yorkers have contributed to a 10 percent jump in unreclaimed valuables hocked this year at the tiny pawnshop. ``This is the largest increase in 15 years,'' said owner Gary Kalter. He said gold jewelry is his most frequently pawned item. Kalter is not alone in reaping a windfall from the weak U.S. economy. Many of the roughly 8,000 U.S. pawnbrokers report that white-collar professionals who just a few years ago wouldn't be caught dead near their shops are skulking in to hock their Rolex watches, diamond rings and other symbols of the fast-cash '80s. Many of these former high-fliers - including lawyers, developers and real estate agents - need cash to buy Christmas gifts or other luxury items, but have exceeded their credit card limits. Typical of those doing a robust business is the 150-store Cash America Investments Inc., which went public in 1987 and has grown 25 percent in each of the past five years. ``Our stores look like little Kmarts - well lit and departmentalized,'' said Eugene Estep, vice president and director of investor relations at the Fort Worth, Texas-based chain. Nevertheless, the pawnbroking industry would rather not publicize its boon from hard times, and many brokers deny they are benefiting from the slump. ``Our business is good in good times and bad, and that's the reason we've been around for 2,000 years,'' Estep said. ``Our industry has had a PR problem,'' said Louise Seawright, president of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based National Pawnbrokers Association. ``Everyone watches TV and the media does have a way of dictating a lot of the public's thinking.'' Mindful of its image, the trade organization in New York State recently changed its name from the Pawnbrokers Association to the Collateral Loan Brokers Association of New York. And while business is booming across the nation, times are decidedly mixed in New York City. Tough state regulations and high rents have helped reduce the number of pawnshops from 120 in 1940 to 20 in 1980 to just 15 in 1990. The remaining shops have been left to split up New York's bustling customer base, so stores now generally do a high-volume but low-revenue business. Squeezed between a peep-show store and a Pizza Hut, S&G Gross Co. in midtown Manhattan writes about 100 loans a day, or about 25,000 a year, about the same as a small bank branch. A loyal customer base has helped the four-generation business remain in the hands of Robert Gross, 71, and his son Gary, 46. S&G's past is written both inside and out of the shop. On the sooty store front, three golden metal balls - the ancient symbol for pawnbroking - hang below a two-sided neon sign: ``Loans.'' Inside, on the wall of a narrow cluttered office is a turn-of-the-century photo of a gas-lit banquet at the old Savoy Hotel. Members of the state trade group, about 200 tuxedoed pawnbrokers at five long tables, pose for the camera seated in plush leather chairs. Among the men are Robert's father, Sol, then 30, and Robert's grandfather, a burly man in his 50s with a Teddy Roosevelt-style mustache and a confident visage. These days a less staid bunch, a dozen or so pawnbrokers representing a dramatically smaller industry, meet under more modest circumstances at less posh Manhattan restaurants. Tapping the shop's new $40,000 computer system, Gary notes that keeping track of customers' loans has cut down on some of the haggling. In another sign of changing times, the store several years ago limited itself to selling jewelry, and it no longer deals in household items customers could buy cheaper in department stores. ``You could see that advancements in electronics were making items obsolete,'' Gary said. ``I said to myself, `Myself, this is 10 percent of the business and 90 percent of the aggravation.'''

DOC.HEAD: Contaminated Eye Drops Causing Severe Infections, Doctors Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to give name of bacteria and ADD comment from lab technician. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The drops ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Tainted eye drops specially prepared by a pharmacist caused a severe infection that cost one woman an eye and similar infections in at least a dozen other people, doctors say. After the woman whose eye had to be removed came in for treatment this week, surgeons at Allegheny General Hospital discovered the drops were contaminated by a tenacious bacteria called pseudomonas, Dr. John Kennerdell, chairman of the hospital's ophthalmology department, said Thursday. ``Normally we don't find any bacteria in medication, but with that specimen we found over 100 colonies,'' said Matthew Rigg, a hospital lab technician. ``We couldn't believe how strong it was.'' The prescription eye drops, prepared at Hieber's Drug Store by pharmacist and owner Joseph Kilkeary, were designed to ease inflammation after cataract surgery. ``I've been selling these drops for years without a problem,'' Kilkeary said. He said 20 to 25 customers bought the drops in October. They have been told to quit using them and return them to the pharmacy or their doctors. Thirteen people were hospitalized for treatment in Pittsburgh, doctors said. One man who used the drops but shows no sign of infection was under observation. Doctors removed the woman's right eye last week after antibiotics failed. The other 12 are receiving large doses of antibiotics. Two have impaired vision and could lose an eye, Kennerdell said. ``Once this type of bacteria gains access to the inside of the eye it causes a very devastating infection,'' he said. ``That's why it's so dangerous.'' The drops contain a liquid solution and Indocin, an anti-inflammatory drug normally taken orally for arthritis. Pharmacists commonly mix solutions not offered by drug companies when doctors prescribe them, said Harvey Miller, a Food and Drug Administration spokesman in Philadelphia. The practice is legal, but the FDA will investigate the tainted eye drop case, he said. Gary Bruell, a spokesman for Merck Sharp & Dohme, the maker of Indocin, said: ``We really can't comment on what physicians or pharmacists may be doing with the product outside its current labeling,'' he said. Kilkeary said he didn't know how the bottles became tainted. Lab tests on bottles in the store found no contamination, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 14-Month-old Girl Drowns in Bathtub As Parents Sleep
DOC.TEXT: A 14-month-old girl who got up in the middle of the night to play with her sister drowned in the bathtub while her parents slept, a sheriff's spokesman said. Investigators believe Heather Mayhak and her 2-year-old sister wanted to wash up after covering themselves with peanut butter and spaghetti sometime before 2:45 a.m. Thursday. ``They were playing house,'' said Curt Benson of the Pierce County sheriff's department. The baby's body was discovered after a neighbor in the apartment below, Allen McCane, was awakened by water dripping from the ceiling onto his face from the overflowing bathtub above. McCane said the parents came to the door with the 2-year-old, then the father went looking for Heather. The girl was found lifeless in the tub. A nurse who lived nearby and Fire Department paramedics tried to resuscitate the girl, neighbors said. But she was pronounced dead a short time later at a Tacoma hospital, Benson said. Benson said the parents were sleeping in their bedroom and didn't hear the children playing in the living room.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Says Government Planes Dropped Bombs on Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A government plane dropped two bombs on the recently reopened Jaffna hospital today, injuring five civilians, the International Committee of the Red Cross said. The aircraft circled above the hospital before dropping the bombs, the Red Cross said in a statement. The first bomb fell just outside the hospital grounds, it said. ``The second bomb fell within the clearly defined security area,'' the Red Cross said. ``The roofs and windows of four hospital buildings were also blown off due to the bomb explosions.'' The statement said five people were hurt in the attack, but it was not immediately clear how seriously they were injured, or whether the injured were patients or workers. The hospital is in Jaffna city, a stronghold of the Tamil Tiger guerrillas on the northern Jaffna Peninsula. A senior military official in Colombo confirmed the Red Cross had filed a complaint about the bombing, which the government was checking. He said on condition of anonymity that the investigation would take time. ``The ICRC made strong representations to Sri Lankan authorities to again obtain firm guarantees that similar violations should not reoccur,'' the Red Cross statement said. On Tuesday, the Red Cross announced it was reopening the state-owned hospital, having notified the government and Tamil rebels that the area had been declared a ``hospital zone.'' The hospital and a ``safety area'' around it would be clearly marked with red crosses for easy identification from the ground and air, the Geneva-based organization said. The 1,200-bed hospital would also be under the protection of the Red Cross and no armed personnel or military vehicles allowed within its compound. The hospital was closed when the Tigers ended a 13-month cease-fire in June and resumed their war for a Tamil homeland on the Sinhalese-dominated island. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told Colombo-based diplomats on Tuesday the government accepted the Red Cross proposals for reopening the hospital. Elsewhere, four Tamil rebels and a soldier were killed in fighting during the past 24-hours in the north and east of Sri Lanka, military officials said. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old Tamil rebellion.

DOC.HEAD: Women Politicians Shatter Myths Along With Glass Ceilings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, The good, to CORRECT that Rodine is president sted chairwoman
DOC.TEXT: Women candidates proved this week that they can raise millions, play political hardball and win the big ones, feminist fund-raisers and analysts say. ``We're no longer the not-ready-for-prime-time players,'' said Jane Danowitz, executive director of the bipartisan Women's Campaign Fund. ``The good old boys better watch out,'' said Sharon Rodine, president of the National Women's Political Caucus, also a bipartisan group. ``This is the start of something very big.'' Start is the operative word. Though Democrat Ann Richards weighed in with a breakthrough gubernatorial win in high-stakes Texas, the numbers of women at the highest levels of government are the same or lower than before Tuesday's elections: three governors, two senators and 28 House members, down from 29. But Rodine said lower-level gains put women in position to exploit dozens of open congressional seats expected to arise in 1992 as a result of redistricting and a last-chance opportunity that year for retiring members to take their campaign war chests with them. Among the statistics compiled by Rutgers University's Center for the American Woman and Politics: -A record 85 women ran for statewide elective executive offices and 47 won. Combined with 10 holdovers, women now hold 17 percent of these offices. -A record 2,063 women sought state legislative seats - 210 more than in 1988, the largest increase in recent elections. The percentage of women state legislators is expected to rise about one percentage point to 18 percent. ``The big story is not the numbers-crunching or just looking at Capitol Hill,'' Rodine said. ``It's the new pool of women who jumped in at the state and local level.'' The feminist analysts cited exit poll findings that in many races, women candidates attracted most of women's votes. They attributed the gender gap largely to abortion and, to a lesser extent, ``kitchen table'' issues such as education, drugs and jobs. ``Women's votes elected Ann Richards and probably other women,'' said Ruth Mandel, director of the Rutgers center. If women had been the only voters in California and North Carolina, ``Dianne Feinstein would be packing up to move to Sacramento and Harvey Gantt would be on his way to Washington,'' Mandel added, referring to the losing Democratic candidates for California governor and North Carolina senator. Danowitz said the elections shattered a number of myths. She said the hard-fought, mudslinging Richards race disproved ideas that women can't win the big races, can't raise big money, can't take the heat of political battle and can't attract the votes of other women. In addition, Danowitz said, the week's elections raised the number of female state attorneys general from one to four - dispelling the notion that women are weak on crime. The election also boosted from 15 to 22 the number of women holding state treasurer, auditor or comptroller posts, according to the campaign fund's count. ``Voters entrusted their pocketbooks to women,'' dissolving the myth that women are weak fiscal managers, Danowitz said. Three Republican women who quit the House to challenge Democratic senators won praise from the feminists although they all lost badly. ``These women took a risk and should be applauded. We're going to have to go after incumbents,'' said Rodine. Mandel said their risks were not in vain. ``I don't think there are any automatic sacrificial lambs anymore. Even if they don't make it this time, they have advanced themselves in some way,'' she said. Ellen Malcolm, founder of the Democratic fund-raising group EMILY's List, noted that despite the static overall number of women in Congress, Democrats have made substantial gains. In 1972, she said, there were 14 Democratic women in the House and in 1986 there were 12. ``We were losing ground. We have turned that around. We now have 20. That's a two-thirds increase,'' Malcolm said. In 1992, she predicted, with the large number of open seats, ``you're going to see that line go straight up.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Delays Considering Controversial Abortion Ban
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted today to delay considering a church-supported bill that would outlaw abortions, which have been legal in Poland since 1956, and jail doctors who perform them. The Sejm, or lower house, voted not to take up a draft bill banning abortion that was passed by the Senate on Sept. 29. Instead, a motion was passed to put off the discussion until after presidential elections on Nov. 25. A possible runoff is scheduled for Dec. 9. Opponents of the abortion ban fear it will pass if it comes to a direct vote, so they are trying to delay debate during the current parliament term, which should end early next year. Calling for immediate consideration was Marek Jurek, of the Citizen's Parliamentary Club, the caucus of deputies elected with the backing of Solidarity. He said the abortion bill has nothing to do with the presidential elections and that postponing it would be perceived as foot-dragging. After the motion, proposed by 17 deputies, to consider the bill today was defeated, the Sejm voted 140-93 with 49 abstentions to delay debate until after the elections. The two main presidential candidates, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, say they accept church teachings and so support the legislation. The only candidate opposing the legislation is leftist Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz. Legalized abortion was introduced by the country's former Communist rulers in 1956 without a public debate. Although more than 90 percent of Poland's population is Catholic, 800,000 abortions are performed annually, terminating an estimated one in two pregnancies. Other forms of birth control are not widely available. The bill would impose no criminal penalties for women who undergo abortions, but doctors could be sentenced to three years in prison. The bill provides for abortions only when a woman's life is threatened or the pregnancy is a result of a rape or incest.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishops Raise Moral Questions On U.S. Involvement In Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic Archbishop Roger M. Mahony offered qualified support to U.S. actions in the Middle East but urged the government to consider the moral ramifications before resorting to force. In a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Mahony urged the Bush administration, ``in continued cooperation with the United Nations, the Soviet Union, Arab states, and other nations (to) stay the course of persistent, peaceful and determined pressure against Iraq.'' The Los Angeles archbishop wrote Baker on Wednesday as chairman of the International Policy Committee of the U.S. Catholic Conference. The letter was released Thursday. Mahony said the nation's 390 Roman Catholic bishops, spiritual leaders of 55 million Catholics, support U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq and condemn ``Iraqi aggression and the taking of hostages'' after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But ethical considerations should not be ``ignored or neglected in a focus on simple military and geopolitical considerations,'' Mahony said. ``Is the damage to be inflicted and the costs incurred by war proportionate to the objectives to be achieved by taking up arms?'' he wrote. ``Will war with Iraq leave the people of Kuwait, the Middle East and the world better or worse off?'' ``We understand that a strong military presence can give credibility to a vigorous pursuit of non-violent solutions to the crisis,'' he said. But he added that he was concerned that the pressure to use military force may grow as efforts to pursue non-violent options ``almost inevitably become difficult, complex and slow.'' ``As Catholic bishops, we are deeply concerned about the human consequences of the crisis - the lives already lost or those that could be lost in a war, the freedom denied to hostages, the victims of aggression and the many families divided by the demands of military service,'' he said. In September, Mahony wrote the administration requesting that the trade embargo against Iraq not include essential food and medicine for civilians. In the letter released Thursday, the archbishop cited so-called ``just war'' criteria outlined in the U.S. bishops' Pastoral Letter on War and Peace released in May 1983. That letter emphasizes that Catholic tradition does not rule out the use of force absolutely, but it does make a clear presumption against war. U.S. policy-makers should consider whether their goals justify the use of force, Mahony said. Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, has said he was praying for a peaceful solution so ``that the soldiers, sailors and air men of all forces now arrayed in the region may soon be restored to their families.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Ex-French Official Met With Aziz on Release
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An official Iraqi newspaper said today the foreign minister held secret talks with a former French government official, Claude Cheysson, that led to the release of more than 300 French hostages. The paper, Al-Jumhouriya, said the talks were endorsed by the French government. On Thursday, French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas denied Cheysson had a mandate from the government to negotiate the release of French hostages. The Iraqi daily did not say when or where the alleged meeting between Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and Cheysson took place, but Arab diplomats said the two met in Tunis. They said the Palestine Liberation Organization opened the way for talks, held just one week before the Frenchmen were released. Cheysson is a former French foreign minister. In late October, President Saddam Hussein freed French nationals, saying France was trying in good faith to find a solution to the 3-month-old gulf crisis. Some said it was a move to divide the world alliance against Iraq. Western officials have criticized efforts by other former leaders - including Edward Heath of Britain, Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, and Willy Brandt of Germany - to free Western captives. All have met with some success. Their governments, however, have denied that any deals were struck in exchange for the release of hostages. The former politicians have maintained they were acting purely on humanitarian grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Attacks Bases; Vows To Protect Christians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Israeli attacks on suspected guerrilla bases. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `Although Jezzine ...,'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops today attacked suspected Shiite Moslem guerrilla bases north of Israel's ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon after officials guaranteed the safety of Christians living nearby. The army said tanks, paratroopers and infantry units moved against strongholds near the towns of Jaba, Kfar Milki and Mazraat Ayn Abu Siwar. The statement said the areas were used by Hezbollah militia to launch attacks against Israeli troops and the South Lebanon Army militia, which is trained and financed by Israel. The bases were damaged and there were no Israeli casualties, according to the army. It gave no information about possible Hezbollah casualties. The attacks occurred five to eight miles west of Jezzine, a largely Christian town 12 miles from the northern tip of the security zone, which was created by Israel in 1985 after it withdrew most of its troops from Lebanon. Although Jezzine is patrolled by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia, fears have arisen recently that the Lebanese government's plan to rid Beirut of Moslem militias could push them southward and threaten the town. On a visit to south Lebanon on Thursday, Defense Minister Moshe Arens promised that the Israeli army will do whatever is necessary to protect Jezzine, army radio said. ``We will do what is needed in order to ensure that the control over these areas is not harmed,'' Arens was quoted as saying. He did not elaborate. Danny Neveh, an aide to Arens, said today the defense minister was trying to make it clear what Israel's security concerns are, given the possible changes in Beirut. ``Israel's main interest is the security of its northern border,'' Neveh said. ``This means we are not going to allow anything that may threaten our interest in security zone and in the Jezzine area.'' He declined to say whether this meant Israel was willing to commit troops if Jezzine were threatened. Neveh also said there was no move to expand the security zone to include Jezzine. Arens, who was accompanied Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, the army's chief of staff, made the promise to the SLA commander, Gen. Antoine Lahad, the radio said. Lahad was quoted in Thursday's Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper as saying he would fight to keep other militias out of Jezzine. ``In the present situation, where there is no state of Lebanon, I will refuse any entry of Lebanese forces into Jezzine,'' Lahad said. The Al Hamishmar and Hadashot newspapers quoted senior Israeli army officers as saying Israel now considers Jezzine ``a red line'' not to be passed by Lebanese or Syrian forces. They were quoted as saying Israel was ``changing the map'' of the security zone. Israel, however, has announced no official extension of its zone. Lahad has long wanted Jezzine incorporated into the security zone and recently told Israeli correspondents that the town was ``an inseparable part'' of the zone. Hadashot reported that Lahad was sending his best troops to protect Jezzine.

DOC.HEAD: Record Chain To Pull 2 Live Crew Album From Shelves for Dismissed Charges
DOC.TEXT: A Dallas County judge dismissed eight misdemeanor obscenity charges againt a music store chain in an agreement with prosecutors under which the chain will stop selling an album by rap group 2 Live Crew. Sound Warehouse Inc. will stop selling the album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' said Gerald H. Goldstein, an attorney for the chain. The album was deemed obscene by a federal judge in Florida. Dallas County Criminal Court Judge George Shepherd said he dropped the charges Thursday at the request of prosecutors. Assistant District Attorney David Pickett got statewide news coverage when he announced at a July news conference that his office would file charges against Sound Warehouse for distributing the album. ``One of the wags in the courthouse thought it was curious that it happened two days after the election,'' Shepherd said. Pickett lost his bid for a district court seat in Tuesday's election. The rap album's lyrics, which prompted protests nationwide, include more than 200 lewd words and phrases, Pickett said then. Pickett did not immediately return a phone call from The Associated Press. Sound Warehouse maintains a published policy of not selling adult-oriented materials to minors, Goldstein said. ``The DA's office probably decided it was time to get on to protecting the citizens of Dallas from real criminals on the street,'' Goldstein said. ``With Sound Warehouse, we are talking about a responsible retail outlet.'' In Florida, a record store owner was convicted last month of misdemeanor obscenity for selling the album, but members of the Miami-based group were acquitted in a separate trial of obscenity charges stemming from a live performance at a nightclub.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Reformed Church Confesses Role In `Evil' Apartheid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to ADD comment from Chikan, Potgieter declining to say what church does not support. Pickup 10th pvs, `The Rustenburg...'
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch Reformed Church joined other Christian denominations today in rejecting apartheid as a sin and confessed the church's role in implementing the system of legalized segregation. The Dutch Reformed Church, the main church of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who control the government, had argued for decades that the Bible supported apartheid. That position isolated it from other denominations. But at the end of a weeklong conference of 90 Christian churches, leaders of the Dutch Reformed Church joined in supporting a statement condemning church participation in apartheid. ``We confess our own sin and acknowledge our heretical part in the policy of apartheid which has led to such extreme suffering,'' the joint statement said. `We denounce apartheid in its intention, its implementation, and its consequences as an evil policy.'' The conference in Rustenburg, 60 miles northwest of Johannesburg, was the largest ever gathering of Christian churches in South Africa. The so-called Rustenburg Document also recommended that the government remove all apartheid laws, set up a one-person, one-vote democracy, seek equitable wealth distribution, restore land to blacks, and arrange an affirmative action program to advance blacks. Rev. Peter Potgieter, head of the Dutch Reformed Church, said his church agreed with the basic message of the document, but not with some of the details. He declined to be more specific, but it appeared his reservations were with the specific political recommendations in the document. He cautioned that the document was not official church policy, which must be decided by the church's synod. Nonetheless, the church's participation in the conference and its general support for the final document was its strongest repudiation of apartheid to date. The church first said apartheid was wrong several years ago but had not declared it a sin or confessed its role in building the system. The Rev. Frank Chikane, leader of the South African Council of Churches, praised the document but said he understood the Dutch Reformed Church's hesitation to give it full support. ``I feel that we have started a process, and I'm just hoping the Dutch Reformed Church will be able to move ahead with us,'' he said. ``I understand they're constrained, they have to answer back to their own membership.'' The Rustenburg Document did not cite the Dutch Reformed Church by name. It said all South African churches should have done more to resist apartheid. ``Some of us actively misused the Bible to justify apartheid, leading many to believe that it had the sanction of God,'' it said. Other churches, the document said, ignored apartheid by preaching the ``sufficiency of individual salvation without social transformation.'' ``We adopted an allegedly neutral stance which in fact resulted in complicity with apartheid,'' it said. Still other churches condemned apartheid but did little to resist, the statement said. Virtually all South Africa's leading clergymen attended the conference, including Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and Chikane. Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his opposition to apartheid, said he accepted the repentance: ``The confession is not cheaply made, and my response is not cheaply made,'' he said. The white branch of the Dutch Reformed Church has about 1 million members, including President F.W. de Klerk and most of the Cabinet. There are separate branches for blacks and people of mixed-race, which have staunchly opposed apartheid. The white branch of the Dutch Reformed Church said last month it wants to merge with its sister churches, but no action has been taken. De Klerk has promised to dismantle apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that will allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power.

DOC.HEAD: President Cancels Plans for Waste Dump After Protests
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo fired a Cabinet minister today and canceled plans to build a nuclear waste dump to restore order on an island where thousands of people rioted to protest the proposed dump. Today, during the the second day of rioting on Anmyon Island, police fired tear gas to break up a rally by several hundred people. About 3,000 troops erected roadblocks and patrolled the scenic island off the nation's central west coast to prevent further violence among its 50,000 residents. Most shops and schools were closed and many people stayed home. South Korea's most serious anti-nuclear protest was mounted by villagers who accused the government of ignoring their demands not to build the waste dump. The protests began peacefully earlier this week after publication of a newspaper report about the government's plans for the dump. South Korea has nine nuclear power plants in operation and plans to build more. Previous protests have involved minor clashes or peaceful rallies. The rioting on Anmyon prompted government officials to announce today they were scuttling plans for the dump. Roh fired his minister of science and technology, Chung Kun-mo, and the island's police chief, both of whom he held responsible for the unrest. Roh named Kim Jin-hyon, 56, a managing director of the Dong-A Ilbo newspaper, to succeed Chung. Police said 73 people were arrested on Thursday and charged with inciting riots. They said hundreds of firebombs were confiscated. Several dozen people were reported injured in a day-long rampage that began early Thursday. Two policemen were in serious condition with head injuries inflicted by stick-wielding protesters on Thursday, news reports said. Witnesses said the violence began with an early morning rally Thursday by 3,000 people. The number quickly swelled to 10,000 as primary, middle and high school students boycotted classes and joined in the protest. Protesters set fire to a police station and a district government office on Thursday, the witnesses said. They held eight government officials for two hours, forcing them to strip to their underpants before freeing them. Late Thursday, about 2,500 riot police firing tear gas took control of several government offices and police stations occupied by the protesters, who bombarded them with firebombs and rocks, the witnesses said. They said the protest calmed shortly before midnight when the police retreated and the government announced it would not build the waste dump. Police used tear gas again today to break up a rally by several hundred villagers who shouted anti-government and anti-nuclear slogans. More police contingents were sent to arrest protest leaders today. Police were ordered to track down radical students to determine if they instigated the riot.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Election Wins Are New Blow To Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd pvs, `Laborite Terry...' with 1 graf to rephrase `scooped by' to `won.' Pickup 4th, `In the northwest...'
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Labor Party's easy victory in two special parliamentary elections is prompting renewed speculation of an imminent challenge to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's leadership of the Conservative Party. In the most humiliating result from Thursday's voting, the Conservatives slumped to third place behind the centrist Liberal Democrats in Bradford North, a district the Conservatives had controlled in the early 1980s. Laborite Terry Rooney, 39, won by 52 percent of the vote to hold Bradford North with 9,514-vote majority, up from a slim 1,663-vote margin in Britain's 1987 general election. In the northwest England dockland town of Bootle, a socialist stronghold, Labor's Joe Benton gathered 22,052 votes, some nine times as many as the second-placed Conservatives' 2,587. The elections - caused by the deaths of the previous legislators in the two districts - were the first since Mrs. Thatcher's deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, quit last week. Howe resigned in protest of Mrs. Thatcher's resistance to a drive for closer union of the European Community. ``I think out there we're not very popular at the moment,'' Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker said of the result of Thursday's ballot in Bradford North. Baker blamed continuing high interest rates as the government pursues a long struggle to bring down Britain's 10.9 percent inflation rate and the upheaval over Howe's resignation. He maintained the party did not want or need a leadership election. But Conservative legislator Tony Marlow said pressure would increase pressure for a challenge to Mrs. Thatcher at the annual leadership election this month. ``I think there will be a new prime minister before Christmas,'' Marlow said. He is the most outspoken among rank-and-file Conservative legislators fearful of losing their seats at the next election, which must be held by mid-1992. The leadership election, in which Conservative legislators vote, is scheduled for Nov. 20. Apart from a feeble challenge last year, Mrs. Thatcher has been reelected annually as the sole nominee since she became party leader in 1975. Thatcher loyalists joined Baker in trying to quench the speculation. ``We are worried, of course, that we may not win the next election,'' said legislator Ivor Lawrence. ``But we are not worried that we must look for somebody to replace Mrs. Thatcher.'' In Bradford North, the Tory vote crumbled in a huge 23 percent swing against the government. The Tories got 6,048 votes, well behind the Liberal Democrats' 9,105. In national opinion polls, the Conservatives are trailing between 12 and 20 points behind Labor. Mrs. Thatcher still has solid control of the 650-member House of Commons. The Conservatives have 373 seats, Labor 227 and the Liberal Democrats 20. Other seats are held by minority regional parties.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Unions Say They're Willing To Accept Pay Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Striking Daily News workers are ready to take the same pay cuts that their colleagues at the Post accepted two months ago, the newspaper unions' leader announced. George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, made the announcement Thursday after News publisher James Hoge said that union negotiators had offered only small concessions during the 10 months of negotiations that preceded the strike. McDonald, head of the 10-union coalition of workers at both the News and the Post, responded, ``Go back and say to Hoge that McDonald said at a press conference: `We'll match what we gave the Post.''' News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson said that McDonald, ``should learn that the place for negotiations is at the bargaining table, not at a news conference.'' In September, nine of the 10 unions agreed to nearly $20 million in wage cuts at the Post after publisher Peter Kalikow said the only alternative was to close the paper. Many employees agreed to a 20 percent pay cut by switching to a four-day work week. McDonald said of the Post: ``They came to us very honestly and said, `Look, we've lost some $29 million this year, we'll show it to you.' We saw their books. We believed them.'' ``Now the same people who are members of our unions would do the same thing at the Daily News if they had the opportunity,'' McDonald said. ``Do you think they like to be out on strike?'' The News strike began Oct. 25 with a dispute at the paper's Brooklyn plant. Some deliverers walked off the job; the News responded by bringing in replacement workers. The walkout spread to eight of nine other unions at the paper. The unions, representing 2,100 workers, had been working without contracts since March 30. Finding a Daily News in the city remained a challenge today as the strike against the tabloid entered day 16, with newsstand vendors saying the threat of union retribution has convinced them to shun the paper. ``Nobody's selling the Daily News. The unions, they are coming every day and checking,'' said Shamini Khan, owner of a newsstand at 49th Street and Broadway. ``I want to sell it but it's risky. I'm scared.'' A Thursday morning spot check of outlets in lower and midtown Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn found dealers almost bereft of the paper. Hoge said Wednesday that 600,000 papers were being printed each day, with two-thirds of those finding their way to readers. Pre-strike circulation was about 1.09 million copies daily, making the News the nation's third largest metropolitan daily. Hoge said deliveries were being made to about 2,000 of the more than 12,000 normal outlets.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Martin Luther King Jr. Didn't Attribute Parts of Writings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, `The slain..', to UPDATE with no immediate comment from Mrs. King. Picks up 4th graf, `King's school...'.
DOC.TEXT: Martin Luther King Jr. borrowed words and ideas extensively from other sources for his doctoral dissertation and other writings without giving proper citations, a Stanford University historian says. ``Several of King's academic papers, as well as his dissertation, contain numerous appropriated passages that can be defined as plagiarism,'' historian Clayborne Carson said in a story The Wall Street Journal published today. The slain civil rights leader's widow, Coretta Scott King, chose Carson to lead the Martin Luther King Jr. Papers Project, which she founded in 1984 to gather his papers from locations around the country and produce a multivolume collection. Mrs. King's spokesman, Steve Klein, said today that she was aware of the newspaper story but had no immediate comment on it. King's school papers are his most obscure and insignificant writings, but the discoveries have prompted debate, anguish and soul-searching among scholars who have worked on the project. Associate Editor Ralph Luker, a follower of King who was jailed during a civil rights protest, said he suffered ``deep anxieties'' over the findings and ``many hours of lost sleep.'' David Garrow, a member of the project's advisory board and author of ``Bearing the Cross,'' a Pulitzer Prize-winning biography of King, said the discovery ``had a tremendously shaking, emotional impact on me.'' ``To me, 98 percent of what makes it most interesting is: Why did he do it? Was he so insecure that he thought this was the only way to get by? It's disconcerting, because it is fundamentally, phenomenally out of character with my entire sense of the man.'' The questions about his academic work surfaced in late 1987, nearly 20 years after his death, when evidencewas discovered by a Stanford graduate student who was working for the King Papers Project. In some parts of the dissertation King wrote as a doctoral candidate at Boston University, he lifted passages nearly verbatim from other texts without using any quotation marks or footnotes, the Journal reported. After that discovery, Carson told his staff to check the sources of nearly of all King's academic work. It became apparent that throughout his seven years of graduate school, King's essays, especially in his major field of graduate study, systematic theology, often borrowed from other sources without citing them as required by academic policy, the Journal reported. When the problem was found, three project editors and a half-dozen student researchers worked for nearly two years annotating all of King's 150 or so academic papers. Carson said King likely did not intentionally do anything wrong by sometimes failing to attribute materials in his writing. ``The best evidence for that,'' he said, ``is that he saved his papers and donated them to an archive - at B.U. of all places.''

DOC.HEAD: Chemicals Leak Into River, Thousands Affected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT time of spill to Oct. 31-Nov. 5, sted Nov. 2, ADD quotes, comments from Latvian prime minister, details on plant, spill and problems in other cities, ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A toxic chemical has leaked into a river in Byelorussia and Latvia, forcing the shutoff of drinking water to at least two cities and tainting the river for hundreds of miles, officials said today. The leak apparently came from the national government's Chemical and Petrochemical Ministry, which produces chemicals for military weapons, said Viktor Yukhno, the controller at Latvia's government water authority. City and republic leaders said officials never informed them of the leak into the Daugava River, which occurred sometime between Oct. 31 and Nov. 5. ``It is just the same as Chernobyl. We only learned that something went wrong when we saw fish floating belly up down the stream,'' said Latvian Deputy Prime Minister Ilmar Bisher, referring to the 1983 nuclear power plant disaster in the Ukraine. He said two men suffered minor poisoning after eating fish. ``We hope there will be no more cases,'' said Bisher, head of a Latvian commission investigating the leak. Drinking water from the river to the Latvian capital, Riga, a city of nearly 1 million people, was turned off Thursday morning, said Yukhno. The city's residents have been using water from underground wells, but pumps are not powerful enough to bring water to taller buildings and many residents remain without water, Yukhno said. The city gets about a third of its water from the river. It is not known when Riga's water supply from the river will be turned back on, but Bisher said it should take 10 days for all the contaminated water to flow out to sea and clean water to refill city's reservoir. Water also was cut to Daugapils, a city of 150,000 about 120 miles east of Riga, and crews have trucked in water for the city and other areas, Bisher said. He said much of the contamination already has passed Daugavpils and water may be turned back on by Saturday, he said. The plant is located in the Byelorussian town of Novopolotsk, 480 miles upriver from Riga, and 880 miles west of Moscow, said Yukhno. The chemical was a component of cyanide, Yukhno said, but officials were still testing it to determine exactly what kind. There was no immediate word on how the leak occurred or if chemicals were still being spilled, and no cleanup efforts were reported. Neither plant officials nor the official state press have commented on the incident. ``This does not only affect Riga, but the whole (republic),'' said Riga Mayor Andris Inkulis in Stockholm, Sweden, where he was visiting. ``We warned people over television and radio so they could save some water.'' Local officials were still testing the chemical and trying to determine how much had leaked. Inkulis said unofficial reports on the leakage range from three tons to up to 60 tons. Yukhno said it was impossible to determine how many people may be affected in Latvia or Byelorussia, because many have begun using well water. Riga is the largest city on the river, lying at its mouth on the Baltic Sea. But hundreds, possibly thousands, of other people live in areas along the river and traditionally used the river for food and drinking water.

DOC.HEAD: Anniversaries of Wall Opening and Crystal Night; Gorbachev Visits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 11-14, `Jochen Feilcke...' to CLARIFY news conference by Schabowski was taped last year. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `The Bundesrat...'
DOC.TEXT: Germany today marked a year since the opening of the Berlin Wall, a joyful anniversary interlocked with a bitter one: the night in 1938 when breaking glass heralded the Holocaust, war and German partition. Officials of newly united Germany also warmly welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who arrived in Bonn today to a 27-man military honor guard. The Soviet president's visit is highly symbolic since his reforms helped collapse the Iron Curtain and open the Berlin Wall. He was to sign a 20-year German-Soviet non-aggression treaty and was expected to receive financial aid for his nation's troubled economy. Commemorations of the wall's opening were to include the unveiling of a monument at one of the former crossing points between East and West Berlin, and a ceremony to honor the more than 200 people killed trying to escape East Germany. At the same time, Germany's Jewish community held memorial ceremonies on the 52nd anniversary of attacks on synagogues, Jewish homes and businesses known as Kristallnacht - Crystal Night - because of all the glass shattered by Nazi thugs. By the time World War II ended seven years later with Germany's division, 6 million Jews had been killed, many rounded up in full view of fellow Germans and transported to death camps. Heinz Galinski, a Jewish leader in Germany, said many Germans ``have never accepted Nov. 9 as a day of commemoration'' though it led to the Holocaust. The mayors of West Berlin and East Berlin, Walter Momper and Tino Schwierzina, said in a joint statement Thursday the two Nov. 9 anniversaries should remind Germans of the need to fight against oppression of minorities. They called for the public to participate in national affairs as ``the best protection against against misuse of state power.'' Jochen Feilcke, a member of parliament from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats party, called ``completely erroneous'' statements from Communists that former East German officials played a major role in opening the wall. ``Berliners streamed that night to the border crossings and took over the wall at the Brandenburg Gate,'' he said. Last week, a report in the newspaper of the former Communist Party, Neues Deutschland, said medium-level East German security officers decided to let the pressing crowds through the wall, fearing border guards would be killed otherwise. Guenter Schabowski, a member of the then ruling East German Communist Politburo, also said last year the East German government had intended to allow its citizens to travel abroad before the wall opened. Portions of a news conference by Schabowski was planned to be broadcast over loudspeakers late today in the central square in East Berlin. The Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament, was to mark the wall anniversary by holding its first meeting in Berlin in 31 years, moving from Bonn, the federal capital. The two Germanys united Oct. 3 into a country of nearly 80 million people, by far the biggest in Europe. Their leaders pledged repeatedly that the new Germany will not seek to dominate the continent, nor would it forget the Nazi part of its history. Television news programs Thursday ran long recapitulations of the celebrations that erupted at the Brandenburg Gate last Nov. 9 when it became known that East Germans were free to travel to the West. One year ago, massive pro-democracy demonstrations and the flight of refugees to the West prompted East Germany's Communist leaders to begin opening the Berlin Wall. Hundreds of people spontaneously climbed the 11{-foot wall that symbolized the divisions of Germany and Europe. Shedding tears of happiness, some began using hammers and chisels on the concrete barrier; soon a thriving business was started selling chips of the wall as souvenirs. Bulldozers have finished removing 81 percent of the wall from downtown Berlin, and have about two miles to go, officials say. Elections in East Germany early this year booted the Communists from four decades of power, leading to last month's unification. The first unified German parliamentary elections are Dec. 2. The sweeping change, however, has been painful for many former East Germans as the switch to capitalism has caused inefficient businesses to shut down, causing rising unemployment.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives: Kahane Slaying Suspect May Have Been Depressed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `The New...', and 9th graf pvs, `Chief of...', with police comment on reports.
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of assassinating Rabbi Meir Kahane may have been taking an anti-depressant drug that critics claim induces violent behavior, according to a published report. The New York Times in today's editions quoted an unnamed law enforcement source as saying that the accused, El Sayyid Nosair, was taking Prozac. Officer Hugh Barry, a police spokesman, said today he could not confirm the report. Several lawsuits are pending against the drug's manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co., which has denied allegations that the drug can induce suicidal or homicidal behavior. The Food and Drug Administration also has found no link. Nosair, 34, who has denied fatally shooting the radical rabbi in a Manhattan hotel on Monday night, entered no plea at his arraignment in Bellevue Hospital's intensive care unit. Nosair was shot in the throat by a U.S. Postal Service police officer after the incident. In Waterbury, Conn., FBI agents, New York City detectives and local police searched the home of a man they described as a friend of Nosair. No arrests were made Thursday night. Neither the man's identity nor the address was disclosed. ``The gunman had a connection in Waterbury,'' said Waterbury Chief of Detectives John Griffin. ``He has a friend, a Moslem. They both met in a mosque. We searched the man's house. I can't say if we found anything.'' New York police have said they believe Nosair acted alone, but are not aware of his motive. The 58-year-old Kahane was the American-born rabbi who founded the anti-Arab Kach Party in Israel and the militant Jewish Defense League in this country. His killing Monday night touched off anti-Arab riots in Israel. Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said Thursday that relatives told police they thought Nosair had been under a doctor's care. Barry said police believe he was being treated for depression. Nosair was on documented sick leave from his job with the city's Department of General Services five days last week, said department spokesman John Beckman. The diagnosis was confidential, Beckman said. Borrelli speculated that Nosair, a native Egyptian who has an engineering degree, may have felt frustrated because he couldn't fulfill his potential in this country. Nosair began working for the General Services in April 1988, repairing heating and cooling systems in courthouses. In addition, Nosair injured his hand or arm in an accident at work in which he was nearly electrocuted, Borrelli said. The combined stress ``was acting on him; he wasn't getting ahead,'' Borrelli theorized. New York Newsday quoted an unidentified source as saying that Nosair threw a tantrum in a locker room Monday because he was being transferred to Brooklyn. Beckman confirmed that Nosair was to be transferred from Mahattan to Brooklyn, effective Thursday, but both he and Borrelli said they had no evidence that Nosair had a tantrum over it. ``It wasn't punitive,'' said Beckman. ``He was a satisfactory worker.'' Beckman said the department has 108 other employees who do the same job as Nosair. ``These guys take these jobs with the understanding they will be transferred. Of the 109, last year there were 61 transfers.'' Borrelli said police have found a car, registered to Nosair in New Jersey, parked a few blocks from the midtown hotel where Kahane was murdered. On Wednesday, the Department of General Services suspended him without pay until further notice, based on his alleged criminal activity and because he allegedly used a false Brooklyn address. Though his job has a New York City residency requirement, Nosair lives in Cliffside Park, N.J., Beckman said.

DOC.HEAD: King Introduces Constitution Reducing His Powers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with prime minister's comments, elections to be held. Minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra, whose grip on absolute power was shaken by a springtime pro-democracy uprising, today enacted a constitution reducing his powers. The new document establishes a constitutional monarchy and declares the Himalayan nation a multiparty democracy. It abolishes the old system under which political parties were banned and the king ruled with a non-partisan legislature that routinely approved measures favored by the monarch. ``I feel very much elated on such a historic occasion for which the people have been aspiring and have laid down their lives,'' Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai told a news conference. The draft of a proposed constitution was completed two months ago, but enactment bogged down in a tug-of-war between the palace and Bhattarai's fledging government over how much power the king should retain. Bhattarai said the king agreed to act in the same fashion as Britain's constitutional monarchy. He said general elections will be held sometime between mid-April and early May next year. In a message broadcast live on national radio and television, Birendra said the new constitution ``will help to forge the people in a bond of unity and advance the cause of multiparty democracy in a constitutional monarchy.'' He said the document takes effect immediately. The adoption of the new constitution culminates a pro-democracy campaign that began in late winter with weeks of strikes and street demonstrations by doctors, lawyers, students and the long-banned political parties. The turning point came on April 6 when police opened fire as 200,000 demonstrators marched to the royal palace. At least 72 people were killed, according to official accounts. Witnesses put the death toll at more than 300. Shortly afterward, the king caved in to pressure and asked Bhattarai, a top leader of the Nepali Congress Party, to form an interim government until elections could be held in the spring of 1991. The Nepali Congress Party and all other political parties were banned by Birendra's father, King Mahendra, when he ended an 18-month experiment with democracy in December 1960. Birendra was crowned king in 1972 when his father died. He is the latest monarch in the 223-year-old Shah dynasty. The new constitution declares Nepal a ``Hindu and constitutional monarchical kingdom.'' The Buddhist and Christian minorities had sought to have Nepal declared a secular state. Hindus comprise 90 percent of Nepal's 17 million people. Moslems make up 5 percent, while Christians comprise 3 percent. Most of the others are Buddhists. Under the new constitution, Nepal will have a two-house Parliament consisting of a policy-making House of Representatives and an upper house called the National Council. All 205 members of the House of Representatives and 35 of the 45 members of the National Council will be elected. The remaining 10 members of the upper house will be appointed by the king.

DOC.HEAD: West Virginia Teachers' Back-To-Work Order Thrown Out
DOC.TEXT: West Virginia teachers who staged an 11-day wildcat strike this year won a major victory today when the state Supreme Court ruled a county judge had no right to order them back to work. The five justices unanimously overruled Kanawha County Circuit Judge John Hey's statewide back-to-work order. The opinion written by Justice W.T. Brotherton Jr. said Hey had no jurisdiction to issue an order that would affect the rights of teachers outside Kanawha County. It said Hey's action was precluded by a 1981 state law. ``We're pleased with the decision and we feel the Supreme Court has certainly acted appropriately and that Judge Hey was out of line,'' said Kayetta Meadows, president of the West Virginia Education Association. Teachers struck over low pay March 7. On March 16, Hey issued an injunction telling the strikers to return to work statewide. Meadows and other educators filed a petition with the Supreme Court the same day, asking it to annul Hey's order. The teachers returned to work two days later. After the teachers returned to work two days later, the union asked the Supreme Court to dismiss their petition. But the court decided to consider the issue the teachers raised. ``Although the present situation clearly results in a waste of judicial resources, we do not believe that the circuit court of one county has the authority to enjoin the acts of citizens occurring in other counties, except where the judge of the other county is interested in the proceeding and unable to act,'' Brotherton wrote. In an unusual twist, the court used the opinion to lecture both sides. ``All parties to this strike must realize that ultimately, our state's plans for an economic renaissance depend upon our children and their ability to cope with the complex issues that will face them,'' the opinion said. ``Unfortunately, work stoppages which involve the public schools, regardless of merit or length, serve only to harm the children of this state,'' Brotherton wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Iraq says it will never pull out of Kuwait, despite the U.S. order to ship additional troops to the Persian Gulf and Moscow's qualified consent to the use of force in the region. ``There is no reason for this force, or the previous force,'' Iraq's ambassador to Washington, Mohamed Al-Mashat, said Thursday on CBS' ``America Tonight.'' ``We haven't done anything to the United States.'' ``Believe you me, we will never surrender or capitulate,'' he said. --- Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday new U.S. troop deployments to the Persian Gulf will include half of all American land forces in Europe. That means as many as 200,000 more Americans are being sent to the area. Cheney's estimate of the Army forces being moved from Germany suggests an additional 100,000 ground troops are heading to the gulf. That indicates the total new deployment ordered by Bush would approach 200,000, including an Army division from the United States, at least 20,000 sailors and at least 45,000 Marines. --- Iraq's government-run newspaper said Friday that Iraq and France conducted secret talks that led to the release of more than 300 Frenchmen from Iraq. The paper, Al-Jumhouriya, said the talk between Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and former French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson were endorsed by the French government. France has denied any deals were struck in exchange for release of the hostages. --- In Moscow, a senior U.S. official said Friday that Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Arab forces would fight alongside U.S. troops to free Kuwait. But the official said the extent of France's support is not known. Secretary of State James A. Baker III flew from Moscow to London Friday on his mission to strengthen allied resolve against Iraq's 3-month-old occupation of Kuwait. Baker will meet Saturday with French leaders in Paris. --- Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt was scheduled to leave Baghdad Friday night with 170 Westerners, including 120 Germans. Diplomats said five Americans were on the list. In a more personal attempt to influence Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, 11 British women flew to Baghdad to seek the release of their captive husbands and relatives - against the advice of their government.

DOC.HEAD: Men Turn Up Four Days after Plane Reported Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The Phoenix...', to CORRECT that plane is single-engine, sted twin.
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers who suffered broken bones in a plane crash hiked for four days through the wet, cold Chiricahua Mountains before being rescued, authorities said. Robert Rowe, 52, hampered by a broken wrist, nose and ribs, and Carl Rowe, 37, who suffered a broken foot and wrist, hiked 14 to 16 miles through rugged terrain before finding a road and hailing a ride to safety Thursday. Devorie Griffiths, co-owner of the Portal store and cafe in this small town near the New Mexico state line, said the two men were caked with dried blood when they hobbled into the store about 9 a.m. ``They were pretty cut up but they appeared to be in pretty good spirits. They were glad to be out of there,'' she said. ``It's a miracle they are alive.'' The Rowes were flown by helicopter to Tucson Medical Center, where they were listed in satisfactory condition today. The Phoenix men were flying their single-engine Cessna 182 into canyons scouting for deer Sunday when they found themselves without room to maneuver. Carl Rowe, who was the pilot, was forced to crash land the plane. ``It was the best landing you could have made between two trees,'' said Robert Rowe. It rained and snowed in parts of the Chiricahuas this week, and a storm front had dropped nighttime temperatures into the 20s and 30s. The men drank from streams but had no food. Russ Griffiths, an emergency medical technician who helped the men, said they were ``very cold and very wet. They appeared to be in the early stages of hypothermia and we worked to stabilize them so they would not go into shock.'' ``They had been hallucinating. They said they saw people - especially children - walking around in front of them,'' he said. Wreckage of the single-engine plane was spotted Wednesday by a hunter, but the bad weather hampered efforts by searchers who had been looking for the men since the plane was reported missing Sunday night.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Want All U.S. Judges Barred From Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that motion asks for two officers, sted one; INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf, `Special Assistant...', to add that attorney declined to explain why. Picks up 9th graf, `Moody, 56...'.
DOC.TEXT: No federal judge in the country could impartially hear the case of a man charged in mail bombings that killed a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer, the man's lawyers say. Attorneys for Walter Leroy Moody Jr. asked in a court motion Thursday that the Senate Judiciary Committee appoint two independent officers to hear the case. That a federal judge was one of the victims damages the impartiality of all federal judges, the lawyers argued in a hearing before U.S. Magistrate William Harper. Moody's lawyers refused to enter a plea in the arraignment before Harper rules on their motion. A plea of innocent was automatically filed. Harper referred the case to U.S. District Judge Richard Freeman for trial. No hearing was scheduled on the motion. Defense attorney Bruce Harvey said he believed the motion was the first of its kind anywhere. ``The rationale behind (the request) is clear: no federal judge can be impartial in a case involving the assassination of a colleague as a result of the performance of his official duties,'' Harvey said. Special Assistant U.S. Attorney Howard Shapiro declined to comment. The court motion did not indicate why the attorneys think two independent officers should be appointed, and Harvey declined to explain or give other details. Moody, 56, was charged in a 70-count indictment Wednesday with making and sending a series of mail bombs that killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance in Alabama and attorney Robert Robinson in Georgia. Moody faces a maximum penalty of life in prison and a $250,000 fine from a murder charge in the death of Vance. He faces the same sentence in Robinson's death from a charge for transporting explosive material with intent to kill. Moody also is charged with a variety of other offenses related to the bombings. If convicted on all 70 counts, Moody could face seven life terms plus 385 years in prison and fines of $16.9 million. Moody did not speak at the hearing. He was returned to the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary, where he is being held on unrelated witness tampering charges. Harvey said courthouses across the country have had extra security put in place after Vance's killing, and judges and their families have altered their lifestyles. Officials in Alabama and Georgia said they were considering whether to pursue separate state murder charges - which can carry the death penalty - against Moody for the bomb slayings.

DOC.HEAD: Record Chain To Pull 2 Live Crew Album From Shelves for Dismissed Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede to CORRECT spelling of ``against.''
DOC.TEXT: A Dallas County judge dismissed eight misdemeanor obscenity charges against a music store chain in an agreement with prosecutors under which the chain will stop selling an album by rap group 2 Live Crew. Sound Warehouse: 2nd graf

DOC.HEAD: Figure In Silverado Debacle Claims $196 Million In Debts
DOC.TEXT: The former Denver developer who defaulted on $106 million in loans from Silverado savings and loan has filed for personal bankruptcy, claiming $196 million in debts. Nathan Jones, an attorney representing ex-developer Bill Walters, said Thursday that creditors include Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.; Mellon Bank; Silverado; and Walters' ex-wife, Mary Lou Walters. Jones said creditors probably will get only a fraction of what they are owed. The case was filed last week in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif. ``There are a few assets available, possibly a few hundred thousand dollars,'' Jones told The Denver Post. ``Bill is a good guy who has gotten a lot of bad publicity. He was at the end of his rope.'' Walters became a prominent figure in the nation's thrift crisis because of his business relationship with President Bush's son Neil, a Silverado director. Bush voted to approve the $106 million in loans to Walters, who then defaulted on all the loans. Later, it was disclosed that Walters invested $150,000 in Neil Bush's unsuccessful JNB Exploration oil company and extended him a $1.75 million line of credit through his Cherry Creek National Bank. During early and mid-1980s, Walters, 45, was one of Denver's highest-profile developers, listing his net worth at $200 million during those years. He was chairman of the Greater Denver Chamber of Commerce in 1987-88. Walters developed 3.5 million square feet of office and residential property in the Denver area and controlled 24 million square feet of undeveloped land - the size of downtown Denver. In addition to Cherry Creek National Bank, he purchased the South Denver National Bank and the Bank of Westminster. But the oil bust took its toll on Walters' real estate and banking holdings. He sold Cherry Creek National Bank in 1988 and it failed last month. The other two banks failed in 1987. The bankruptcy filing lists Walters' biggest creditors as Manufacturers Hanover, owed $111 million, and Mellon Bank, owed $23 million. Jones said Walters owes Silverado $18.5 million - the part of the $106 million that Jones says Walters is personally liable for - and Mary Lou Walters about $5.35 million. Earlier this year, Walters told a congressional panel investigating Silverado's $1 billion failure that he was broke, but vowed not to seek bankruptcy protection and to pay back what he owed Silverado. But a few weeks later, Walters was found to be living in a $1.9 million estate in Newport Beach, Calif., listed in the name of his wife, Jacqueline. The government has filed a $200 million lawsuit against Bush and other former Silverado directors for their role in the thrift's failure.

DOC.HEAD: Army Soldier Reported Found Dead in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army soldier was found dead in a shower in Saudi Arabia, the Pentagon said today. A preliminary investigation showed no evidence of foul play, it said. The soldier, whose identity was being withheld until relatives were notified, was found in the shower on Thursday. The cause of the death was being investigated. The soldier was assigned to the 118th Ordnance Detachment, 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, which deployed to Operation Desert Shield from Fort Bliss, Texas. Because investigatiors have not ruled out that the death could be from natural causes, it was not added to the total of 43 accidental deaths in Desert Shield since the deployment began Aug. 7, the Pentagon said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Xanax for Treatment of Panic Disorder
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first medication for the treatment of panic disorder, a disease that will affect 3 million Americans at some point in their lifetimes. The medication is Xanax, made by The Upjohn Co. and was approved in 1981 for the treatment for clinical anxiety and anxiety associated with depression. Panic disorder is characterized by repeated panic attacks in which a patient is struck by intense fear. Symptoms of panic attacks can include chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, trembling and sweating, nausea and abdominal distress. The symptoms often mimic a heart attack. The company, announcing the FDA action Thursday, estimated that between 1 percent and 2 percent of the population - an estimated 3 million Americans - will suffer from panic disorder in their lifetimes.
