For about 60 percent of people with the disorder, it will disrupt their social and working lives, which can lead to secondary depression, said officials of the company based in Kalamazoo, Mich. A biochemical malfunctioning in the brain is believed to cause panic attacks, the company said. Xanax, known generically as alprazolam, can block the attacks by interacting with several different systems in the brain. Upjohn studied alprazolam's role in the treatment of the disorder in a two-phase study that involved more than 1700 patients in more than 14 countries, the company said. Common side effects included sedation and fatigue, and they subsided when the dose was reduced or as the medication was continued, Upjohn said. However, higher doses of Xanax may be needed for longer periods of time to treat panic disorder, the company said, and this could lead to greater chance for dependence. Upjohn officials said that when the treatment is being discontinued, ``gradual dosage reduction under a physician's direction is essential to minimize the potential for adverse effects.''

DOC.HEAD: Indonesian Poet Banned from Reading Poetry
DOC.TEXT: Police barred a well-known Indonesian poet from publicly reading two of his poems Friday, saying they posed a threat to racial and religious harmony. Jakarta police issued the ban on W.S. Rendra, one of several Indonesian artists who must obtain a special permit from the government in order to perform his works. Indonesia, the world's most populous Moslem country, prohibits publishing or publicly performing material that it deems could lead to racial or religious disturbances. The banned poems, entitled ``For the Sake of the People of Rangkasbitung,'' and ``Prayer of the Youth from Rangkasbitung in Rotterdam,'' are said to be critical of the Indonesian government. Rendra was to have read eight poems at poetry reading sessions Thursday and Friday. He refused to read the other six works in protest. ``If I read the rest of my poems I would not be doing justice to my feelings,'' Rendra said. Last month, police banned a politically sensitive play, contending it threatened public order.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Treasure Unearthed in Southern Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Archeological excavations in southern Yugoslavia have unearthed gold Roman coins buried some 1,500 years ago, news reports said Friday. The 99 coins were found in an underground vault at Gamzigrad, 245 miles south of Belgrade, where they were apparently hidden by Roman officials in the face of a barbarian onslaught in the 5th century. The value of the coins, discovered last week during restoration work on a ruined palace, has not yet been appraised, according to the newspaper Politika. Gamzigrad, known as Romuliana in Roman times, was a thriving trading center that was devastated by advancing Ostrogoths. The site has been under excavation for the past two decades.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl, Gorbachev Sign Historic Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with pact signed. Pickup 6th, `Kohl is...' TRIMS thereafter to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed a historic non-aggression treaty with Chancellor Helmut Kohl today and got a hero's welcome for letting the Berlin Wall and Iron Curtain collapse. Gorbachev's first visit to united Germany came on the first anniversary of the opening of the Berlin Wall, a fitting coincidence because his reforms helped bring the Cold War barrier down. Both Kohl and Gorbachev stressed the importance of the historical changes that have allowed closer ties as they signed the broad agreement that is to serve as the foundation of future relations. ``Having signed this document one could hardly ... think about until recently, we have officially ended a whole historical process and opened a deep perspective for ourselves,'' said Gorbachev. In the treaty, initialed in Moscow on Sept. 13, both nations pledge not to attack the other and to honor the borders of all European nations. A short-lived alliance between Germany and the Soviet Union at the start of World War II contributed to the deaths of 27 million Soviet citizens when the allies became foes. ``We are closing the book on the painful past and clearing the way for a new beginning,'' Kohl said in a speech at the signing cermony. Gorbachev arrived at Cologne-Bonn airport this morning in an Ilyushin-62, and was met by a 27-man German military honor guard. He was greeted by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and gave a hearty wave as he stepped out of the plane. Later, Gorbachev was greeted by President Richard von Weizsaecker at the government's Villa Hammerschmidt palace next to the Rhine River. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, stopped to chat with a crowd of people waiting for him outside the palace before entering. Mrs. Gorbachev later visited the picturesque city of Linz on the Rhine River with Kohl's wife, Hannelore. The 20-year non-aggression treaty that Kohl and Gorbachev signed aims to assist Gorbachev's financially strapped nation. Details on the amount of future German aid were expected to dominate their behind-the-scenes talks. Kohl is grateful to Gorbachev for his blessing of German unity, and has said many times Gorbachev should get help in mastering problems at home. ``We Germans have many reasons to give thanks to Mikhail Gorbachev,'' Volker Ruehe, general secretary of Kohl's Christian Democrats, said Thursday. A festive reception was planned for Gorbachev, his wife Raisa and for Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Kohl arranged to hold private talks with Gorbachev in Bonn today and at his home in Oggersheim, 45 miles south of Frankfurt, on Saturday. Gorbachev was to spend tonight at the opulent Petersberg guest house just outside Bonn, on a mountain overlooking the Rhine River. A state dinner is scheduled at the government guest house this evening. Kohl has scheduled a visit for Gorbachev to Speyer, home of the 11th-century Speyer Cathedral, resting place for eight German emperors. The two leaders also planned a trip to Deidesheim, a village known for its wines. Shevardnadze and Genscher on Saturday are to fly to Genscher's hometown, Halle, in former East Germany. After lunch, Genscher plans to show his guest around the city. Serious business will be mixed in with the sightseeing.

DOC.HEAD: Combat Veterans Hope For Peace, Trigger-Happy Kids Want War
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: In the sands of Saudi Arabia, untested soldiers and combat veterans are playing a different waiting game. Many of the young are itching for war. The men who've been there are hoping for peace. Marine Lance Cpl. Wayne Lewis, 21, of Reading, Pa., said after years of watching war movies he wants to experience the real thing and go home. After 30 years in the Marines and two tours in Vietnam, Brig. Gen. Mike Myatt, commander of the 30,000-member Marine ground force in northeastern Saudi Arabia, said he hopes his men will leave the desert without firing a shot. It's the classic dichotomy: age and experience versus youth and impatience. As Operation Desert Shield enters its fourth month, the impatience to attack the Iraqis and liberate Kuwait is increasing, especially in the lower ranks. But those who have survived the carnage of the battlefield seem more inclined to wait for economic sanctions and diplomatic efforts to deliver an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. About 230,000 Americans are in the Persian Gulf region, at the moment only to defend Saudi Arabia, but clearly training for an offensive operation against Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's troops if President Bush gives the word. Their average age is probably in the low 20s, and youths with pimples definitely outnumber gray-haired veterans. For Lewis, an environmental and safety specialist with Vertical Marine Fighter Attack Squadron 311, the possibility of death is a risk ``sort of like being a police officer. ``We see all the movies and want to go to war and see what it's really like,'' he said. ``The older Marines ... just want to go home. They've got wives and families to go to. ... Some of them have already seen it happen. They don't want to go through it again,'' Lewis said. ``I just think the older people want to take their time,'' said Senior Airman Mike Beam, 22, of Houston, with the 401st Supply Squadron. ``We just want to go in and clean house and go home. ``All of us don't want this to be another Vietnam War. Do it once - take them out, and just make Iraq a big parking lot.'' As Myatt ran his officers through a war game responding to a two-pronged Iraqi attack on eastern Saudi Arabia, he recalled Vietnam and said ``those who have fought before are hoping this can be solved by political or diplomatic means. ``Nobody who's been in combat ever wants to go back into combat. But they know that if we have to, we have to be ready,'' said Myatt, 49. That was echoed by Capt. Dean Hendrickson, 46, of Jacksonville, Fla., a 23-year veteran who now commands Air Wing 17 on the USS Saratoga, where the crew's average age is between 19 and 20. ``Anybody who's been in this stuff before doesn't look forward to it,'' said Hendrickson, who flew fighters in Vietnam. Sgt. Rosie Abraham, 35, of Selma, Ala., with the Army's 326th Medical Battalion, who missed Vietnam, said she wants to go home ``with all my parts'' and is prepared to wait. ``The younger ones is like, hurry up, let's get this over with,'' she said. ``I don't think they understand what's the meaning of seeing somebody all shot up, a leg here, an ankle over there, a hand over here.'' Army Sgt. Michael Hellon, 24, of Orange County, Calif., with the 525 Military Intelligence Brigade of the 18th Airborne Corps, dismissed the bravado of the trigger-happy kids as pure hype. ``Nobody wants to go to war,'' he said. ``They just talk a bunch of junk. When the bullets start flying, they'll be the first ones in the foxholes with their heads down.'' Certainly not all young servicemen are trigger-happy. Senior Airman Dan Abert, 21, of Syracuse, N.Y., with the 1st Air Medical Evacuation Squadron, had some advice for the president. ``Wait it out to the max,'' he said. ``Bush is getting pretty tense and I think Saddam wants to see that. Maybe he should go to Maine for a little while longer, come back, and sit it out.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Universal Studios Tour Will Take Months to Rebuild
DOC.TEXT: ``King Kong'' will roar at tourists again soon, but the Universal Studios Tour won't fully recover for months from an arson fire, officials said. The sheriff's department Friday said the damage was estimated at $25 million. Tuesday's fire damaged 20 percent of the studio's 420-acre backlot. Dan Slusser, vice president and general manager of Universal City Studios, said Thursday it would take six months to rebuild the backlot. The ``King Kong'' attraction will re-open in a few days, spokeswoman Joan Bullard said. Michael J. Huston, a 40-year-old security guard booked for investigation of arson, was being held Friday in lieu of $1 million bail. Lt. Ken Chausse, chief of the sheriff's department arson unit, said investigators were still sifting through the lot for physical evidence. ``We have strong admissions from (Huston), but you can have anybody come up and tell you they did something,'' Chausse said. ``You have to corroborate it, or it doesn't mean anything.'' Huston's mother, Debra Dragusica, said he told her Thursday that he was responsible. ``He says his mind switched off,'' she said. ``He says it wasn't him when he did it. ... When he realized what he did, he ran to get help.'' Robert Dragusica, who said he is Huston's half brother, said Huston was innocent. But he did say Huston had been mentally disabled since serving in Vietnam in 1969. The backlot was used to film such productions as ``Lady Sings the Blues,'' ``Dirty Harry,'' the ``Back to the Future'' films, Michael Jackson's ``Moonwalker'' and ``Streets of Fire.'' About a dozen movies and television shows are now looking for replacement filming locations, Slusser said. Stock analysts said a proposed $9 billion merger between MCA Inc., Universal's parent company, and Matsushita Industrial Electric Co. would not be influenced by the fire. MCA said the fire losses, estimated at about $20 million, are covered by insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Legislation Extending Trade Benefits to Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today signed legislation to extend most-favored-nation trade benefits to Czechoslovakia. He called the measure ``an important milestone not only in U.S.-Czechoslovak relations, but also in Czechoslovakia's re-integration into the global economy and the community of free nations.'' Under the agreement, the United States and Czechoslovakia will grant each the lowest possible tariffs on their goods. The Bush administration earlier awarded the preferentialtrade status to Poland and Hungary in the aftermath of the upheaval in Eastern Europe. Bush said he was ``particularly pleased'' to sign the measure at this time because he will be in Prague, Czechoslovakia, later this month as part of an eight-day trip to Europe and the Persian Gulf. He praised the Warsaw-pact nation for ``tremendous strides'' toward economic reform and trade liberalization. Most-favored-nation status is denied to countries that do not have open markets or which have restrictive emigration policies. Toddy's action will result in sharply lower tariffs for Czechoslovakia's exports to the United States and vice versa. Before the new benefits can take effect, Czechoslovakia's Federal Assembly must give the arrangement final approval. Bush said the move ``will provide the impetus for greatly expanded trade between the United States and Czechoslovakia and the first step toward a normalization of our bilateral trade relations.'' The United States has also offered to grant the Soviet Union such status, but it is being delayed until the Soviet Union enacts a more-liberalized policy on emigration by Soviets Jews and other minorities.

DOC.HEAD: New Prime Minister Is An Aging Angry Young Man of Indian Politics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chandra Shekhar uses both names on second reference. Version of story also moved for PMs.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-India, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: India's new prime minister, Chandra Shekhar, is the aging angry young man of Indian politics. Left-leaning since his university days, the 63-year-old politician tapped for the job Friday has long advocated social and economic justice for India's masses. Most of India's top political leaders have. Few have had much luck changing things in a country of 880 million people where fewer than half can read and write and the average annual income is barely $300 But Chandra Shekhar, who seems to be perpetually scowling through his salt-and-pepper beard, knows a little more about such things than most of his fellow players at the top ranks of the national political game. He was born in the village of Ibrahimpatti near the borders of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar state 460 miles southeast of New Delhi. The region is geographically remote but politically in the center of northern India's Hindu heartland. It has produced all of the country's prime ministers. Years ago, Chandra Shekhar told an interviewer he was the first educated man from his village of 1,000 people. ``My mother is illiterate. My father too is hardly literate,'' he said. But like all of India's prime ministers, he came from an upper caste in the complex Hindu social system, which automatically confers pride and privilege if not wealth. Chandra Shekhar rejected this. Hedropped his family's surname of Singh, which made him instantly recognizable as a member of the ``Thakur'' or ``landlord'' caste. He now goes only by his first name, Chandra Shekhar, which is written as two words. He studied political science at Allahabad University in Uttar Pradesh state and joined obscure socialist groups. In 1967 he switched to the Congress Party that produced India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, and the prime ministerial dynasty of Nehru's daughter, Indira Gandhi, and her son, Rajiv Gandhi. Chandra Shekhar was briefly a stalwart of Mrs. Gandhi, supporting her decision to nationalize banks and abolish the maharajahs' privy purses. But he broke with her as she moved deeper into authoritarian rule, culminating in the state of emergency from 1975 to 1977 when she suspended civil rights and elections. He was one of thousands of political leaders jailed by Mrs. Gandhi during the emergency. Much of his 21 months in prison was spent in solitary confinement. When Mrs. Gandhi lifted the emergency and over-confidently called elections in 1977, Chandra Shekhar was among the founders of the Janata Party that defeated her. But the prime minister's job went to someone else. Chandra Shekhar became the party's president. Less than two years later, the Janata government fell part in internal bickering. History looks like it's ready to repeat itself - except this time the party broke apart before the government did. Chandra Shekhar remained president of the Janata Party until 1988 when it disbanded to become a major component of the Janata Dal party, a collection of politicians drawn together by little more than their dislike of Rajiv Gandhi. He joined the Janata Dal led by Singh, the prime minister whose 11-month-old government was ousted in a Parliament vote Wednesday. Only two days before the vote, Chandra Shekhar led a breakaway faction of the Janata Dal party in opposing Singh. Chandra Shekhar calls his splinter group the Janata Dal (Socialist), which counts between 50 and 60 members in the 522-seat policy-making lower house of Parliament. For the moment at least, he has the support of his long-time foe, Rajiv Gandhi, and Gandhi's 195-member Congress Party. How long Chandra Shekhar can keep the prime minister's job is questionable. Gandhi, after a year as opposition leader, is waiting in the wings for yet another non-Congress Party government to disintegrate. If the Congress Party withdraws support, it is unlikely Chandra Shekhar could find sufficient support elsewhere to survive. Until the current political maneuvering, Chandra Shekhar was best-known in India for the 2,500-mile walk he did over six months in 1983. He traveled from India's southernmost tip to New Delhi, saying he wanted to see first-hand and dramatize the plight of the country's downtrodden. It was a tactic borrowed from India's beloved independence leader and apostle of nonviolence, Mohandas K. Gandhi, the ``Mahatma,'' or ``Great Soul.'' But Chandra Shekhar's ``padayatra,'' or ``foot travel,'' produced little more than publicity for him.

DOC.HEAD: Space Center Says Falling Soviet Rocket Caused Strange Light
DOC.TEXT: Mysterious lights observed by thousands of people in the night sky over France came from pieces of a Soviet rocket re-entering the atmosphere, the French space center said Friday. The phenomenon, described by witnesses as a collection of small lights in a triangle shape, was seen across France on Monday evening. The National Center of Space Studies said information provided by U.S. space officials had established that the light came from pieces of a Soviet rocket that had launched a telecommunications satellite Oct. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Mine Blast Kills 8, Injures 10
DOC.TEXT: A gas explosion in a coal mine in southern China has killed at least eight miners and injured 10, an official report said. The explosion Wednesday afternoon was the second in five months at the Furen Coal Mine in Guangdong province, the local Yangcheng Daily reported Thursday. The paper was seen in Beijing on Friday. The mine was operated by a private contractor who did not pay attention to safety precautions and did not provide equipment to measure gas levels, the paper said. A similar gas explosion in June killed three miners, it said. Yangcheng Daily reporters, contacted by phone, said Friday they had no new information about the blast or a new death toll. Calls to the Shaoguan county government, where the mine is located, were not answered. Most Chinese mines lack modern equipment and safety provisions. Official figures indicate that about 1,780 miners were killed last year, the lowest annual death toll in 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Capsizes, 22 People Feared Drowned
DOC.TEXT: A fishing boat ferrying marooned villagers across a flooded area capsized Friday and at least 22 people were feared drowned, police said. The victims had been stranded in Talawilla by heavy monsoon rains, according to police officials in nearby Wennappuwa, 30 miles north of Colombo. At least 28 people were on the boat when it capsized, the police said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Six people were rescued and 15 bodies were recovered. The other passengers were missing and feared dead.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Offers Drive-Through Flu Shots for Harried Motorists
DOC.TEXT: Too busy to get sick, and too busy to get out of the car? A hospital is offering free drive-through flu shots for Southern California's automobile-obsessed residents. ``Roll up your sleeve and put your arm out the car window as you queue up for Los Angeles County's first drive-through flu clinic on Saturday Nov. 10 at Pomona Valley Hospital Medical Center,'' the hospital declared in a news release. Volunteer nurses will spend the morning injecting motorists with a vaccine effective against three strains of influenza that health officials believe may reach the United States this winter: A-Shanghai-89, A-Taiwan-86 and B-Yamagata. The hospital opted to provide the drive-in shots because construction at the hospital has reduced the number of parking spaces. But the hospital hasn't gone completely automobile crazy. ``Walk-ins also will be accepted,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Legislation on Nutrition Labeling
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed legislation today requiring food manufacturers to put more nutrition information on package labels. THe bill, designed to help consumers choose a more healthful diet, sets specific standards for what information must be on food labels. It also prohibits manufacturers from making health claims on their packaging unless scientifically proven according to the Food and Drug Administration. The legislation also requires that bulk food in bins, raw fish and fruits and vegetables be displayed with a sign or brochure providing nutritional information. Food sold by restaurants, cafeterias, hospitals and grocers with annual sales of less than $500,000 is exempt. Labels would be required to display: -Serving size. -Number of servings per container. -Calories per serving and number of calories from fat. -Amount of fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, total carbohydrates, complex carbohydrates, sugars, dietary fiber, protein. It forbids disease-prevention claims unless the FDA has found the contention supported by science. The measure requires the Department of Health and Human Services to publish draft regulations 12 months after enactment, and final regulations six months later.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Protesters Run Over
DOC.TEXT: Two abortion protesters were run over by a small pickup truck outside an abortion clinic. The two were lying in front of the Mahoning Women's Center when they were run over Thursday. The demonstrators were not seriously injured. The driver, whose name was not released, was not charged, police said Friday. Police Chief Randall Wellington said the driver was distracted by demonstrators, and did not intend to run over anyone. A 30-year-old man who identified himself only as Joseph said his legs were run over as the vehicle attempted to enter the clinic's parking lot. The pickup skinned his knee, but he said he wouldn't press charges because it would detract from what he called the ``sacrificial rite'' of his protest. A woman who was run over declined to talk to reporters. Paramedics said they found no injuries when they examined the woman, who had tire marks on the back of her coat. Three demonstrators who were not among those injured were arrested on disorderly conduct charges. Last Friday, 25 protesters who pushed their way into the clinic were arrested and charged with criminal trespassing and resisting arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Afrikaner Church Rejects Apartheid, Confesses Role in Segregation
DOC.TEXT: The white Dutch Reformed Church joined other Christian denominations Friday in rejecting apartheid as a sin and confessed the church's role in implementing it. The main church of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who dominate the government had argued for decades that the Bible supported the system of legalized segregation. The position isolated it from other denominations. But at the end of a weeklong conference of 90 Christian churches, leaders of the white Dutch Reformed Church joined in supporting a statement - the Rustenberg Declaration - condemning church participation in apartheid. ``We confess our own sin and acknowledge our heretical part in the policy of apartheid which has led to such extreme suffering,'' the joint statement said. ``We denounce apartheid in its intention, its implementation, and its consequences as an evil policy,'' the statement added. The conference in Rustenburg, 60 miles northwest of Johannesburg, was the largest ever gathering of Christian churches in South Africa. The declaration also recommended the government remove all apartheid laws, set up a one-person, one-vote democracy, seek equitable wealth distribution, restore land to blacks and arrange an affirmative action program to advance blacks. The Rev. Peter Potgieter, head of the Dutch Reformed Church, told an impromptu news conference during final debate on the document that his church disagreed with some elements. He said it objected specifically to the call for a one-person, one-vote electoral system and other political recommendations, but agreed with the condemnation and confession of apartheid. Potgieter also said the document was not official church policy, which must be decided by the church's synod. For years, the white Dutch Reformed Church has been isolated from most other Christian churches because of its refusal to reject the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. It argued for decades that the Bible supported apartheid, citing biblical passages that referred to different people in different nations. The church also considered whites, and Afrikaners in particular, a ``chosen people'' destined to rule South Africa as part of ``God's will.'' In a major policy statement in 1960, the church said segregation could be justified. Twenty-six years later, it declared racial discrimination a sin, but withheld comment on apartheid. The mere presence of white Dutch Reformed Church leaders at the conference marked a breakthrough in interchurch relations, organizers said. The Rev. Frank Chikane, leader of the South African Council of Churches, praised the document but said he understood the Dutch Reformed Church's hesitation to give it full support. ``I feel that we have started a process, and I'm just hoping the Dutch Reformed Church will be able to move ahead with us,'' he said. ``I understand they're constrained, they have to answer back to their own membership,'' Chikane added. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu said he hoped the white church's objections avoided critical sections of the declaration. ``Obviously, what we hear is political,'' Tutu said. ``It is going to be up to them to demonstrate through action what they have said in words.'' The Rustenburg Declaration said all South African churches should have done more to resist apartheid. ``Some of us actively misused the Bible to justify apartheid, leading many to believe that it had the sanction of God,'' it said. Other churches, the document said, ignored apartheid by preaching the ``sufficiency of individual salvation without social transformation.'' ``We adopted an allegedly neutral stance which in fact resulted in complicity with apartheid,'' it said. Some churches condemned apartheid but did little to resist, the statement added. ``Those of us who were the victims of apartheid acknowledge our own contribution to the failure of the church,'' it said. The white branch of the Dutch Reformed Church has about 1 million members, including President F.W. de Klerk and most of his Cabinet. There are separate branches for blacks and people of mixed-race, which have staunchly opposed apartheid. The white branch of the Dutch Reformed Church said last month it wants to merge with its sister churches, but no action has been taken.

DOC.HEAD: One British Tourist Dies, 14 Injured In Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A British woman died and 14 other British tourists were injured when their tour bus overturned Friday near the West Bank settlement of Maale Adumim, the national Itim news agency said. Police could not be reached for comment. An officia at the British consulate confirmed the accident but declined to give details. The group was on its way to visit Masada, the remains of a large fortress built on a hill above the Dead Sea, when the driver lost control on roads slippery with the season's first rain, Itim said. The British consulate said the names were being withheld pending notification of families.

DOC.HEAD: New Troops in Gulf Will Include Half of Forces in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 5-6, Bush also... to UPDATE with Navy announcing which carriers heading for gulf; picks up 5th graf pvs, Cheney's remarks ...
DOC.TEXT: American military forces in the Persian Gulf will reach up to 430,000 within weeks, nearly doubling existing U.S. firepower in the region and matching Iraq's troop strength in Kuwait. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today half of all American land forces in Europe would be moved to the Persian Gulf. About 200,000 Army troops are stationed in Europe, most in Germany. Those 100,000 European-based troops would join 230,000 U.S. troops already deployed to the gulf and another 100,000 being sent abroad from U.S. bases. President Bush signed deployment orders for the dramatic new escalation on Thursday. The scale of the additional U.S. troop deployments is enormous. Once the added forces are in place, America will have more troops in the gulf region than it had in Europe during the Cold War when the perceived enemy was a nuclear superpower. About one-third of the Army's worldwide force will be in the Saudi desert. Bush also ordered the Navy to dispatch three aircraft carrier battle groups to the gulf area, in addition to the three already there. Today, the Navy announced it was sending the USS Theodore Roosevelt and the USS America, both based at Norfolk, Va., and the USS Ranger, from San Diego, Calif. Each of the carriers includes about 80 aircraft and about 5,500 sailors. The Navy said it would announce later which escort ships would accompany the carriers. Cheney's remarks today to the Conservative Leadership Conference indicated that President Bush intends to have about 430,000 U.S. forces in the gulf area within weeks - equaling the current level of Iraqi troops in and around Kuwait. ``The additional increment will give us the capacity to undertake offensive action should that become necessary,'' Cheney said. He suggested in comments to reporters later that Bush's new order means the approximately 230,000 U.S. forces already there will not be rotating back to the United States early next year as Cheney had tentatively planned. Asked whether the full contingent of American forces in the gulf would be there for the duration of the crisis, Cheney said, ``That's correct.'' Bush said Thursday in announcing new deployments for Operation Desert Shield that he still hoped to get Iraq out of Kuwait without starting a war. But he said he wanted an ``adequate offensive military option'' in case United Nations economic sanctions and diplomatic pressures against Iraq prove futile. Analysts said the move brought the United States closer to war with Iraq. ``The Iraqis, in effect, are being put on notice that they will be attacked'' unless they withdraw from Kuwait under Bush's terms, said Frank Gaffney Jr., director of the Center for Security Policy and a former Pentagon official. About 230,000 U.S. air, ground and sea forces now are in and around Saudi Arabia, and a coalition of other Western and Arab nations has put at least 100,000 troops in the gulf area. The Iraqi force in Kuwait and southern Iraq is estimated at 430,000. Bush and Pentagon officials refused to disclose specific numbers of weapons and soldiers in the gulf region. But additional Army forces being brought in from Germany will more than double the number of U.S. tanks in Saudi Arabia, to about 2,000, judging from organization charts and estimates by Army sources. The Pentagon estimates that Iraq has about 3,500 tanks in and around Kuwait. Bush said he hoped Iraqi President Saddam Hussein viewed the stepped-up U.S. deployments to the gulf as evidence that the Western and Arab coalition arrayed against him was serious about using military force if diplomatic and economic pressures fail. ``If this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better,'' Bush said. He added later, ``When he surveys the force that's there ... he will recognize that he is up against just a foe that he can't possibly manage militarily.'' ``I am concerned that the administration is moving to establish an offensive capacity in advance of a U.N. resolution authorizing offensive action,'' said Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He said the international trade embargo against Iraq has not had ``a decent chance to produce results.'' The Marines are sending the 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force from Camp LeJeune, N.C., which includes roughly 45,000 men and is about equal to the Marine unit now in the gulf. In addition, the Marines are deploying the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade from Camp Pendleton, Calif., with at least 5,000 men, and the four-ship 1st Maritime Prepositioning Ship Squadron from Norfolk, Va. That doubles the size of the Marine commitment to Desert Shield and taps virtually all the Marine combat power available in the United States, according to senior Marine Corps officials. The Marines also will have a few thousand men aboard a group of Navy ships that form a specially tailored amphibious assault unit to be deployed from San Diego, Calif. One such amphibious unit already is afloat in the gulf. Together they could be used to launch an assault on Kuwait City, where Western hostages are being held. Bush ordered the Navy to send three aircraft carrier battle groups to the gulf area to join the three - the USS Saratoga, the USS Midway and the USS John F. Kennedy - that already are there. He did not say which carriers would be added. The Navy also is sending the USS Missouri, a World War II-era battleship equipped with 16-inch guns, Tomahawk cruise missiles and nearly 2,000 crew members. One battleship, the USS Wisconsin, has been in the gulf since late summer. The Army is transferring the equivalent of about 2{ armored divisions from Germany, plus command units, and the famous ``Big Red One'' 1st Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Riley, Kan. For the first time in the crisis, the Pentagon also ordered combat units of the Army National Guard to active duty.

DOC.HEAD: Feminist Candidate Wins Ireland's Presidential Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Mrs. Robinson, details of vote count. Pickup 9th pvs, `Mrs. Robinson was...'
DOC.TEXT: Mary Robinson, a lawyer who had fought to legalize divorce and contraception, was elected president of Ireland today. Mrs. Robinson, the first woman elected to the office, overtook former deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Brian Lenihan on the second round of counting, election officials said. She finished with 52.8 percent of the vote, said Tim Sexton, who supervised the count. In an interview minutes before the announcement, Mrs. Robinson noted that it was the anniversary of the opening of the Berlin Wall. ``And I think something has crumbled away in this election - the old preconceptions, the old political ways,'' said Mrs. Robinson, who in the past had battled church and state in campaigns to liberalize Irish society. ``I think the joy and the hope and the sense of moving forward in this election is quite tangible,'' she said. She will be inaugurated Dec. 3, succeeding Patrick Hillery, who must retire after two seven-year terms in the largely ceremonial post. Mrs. Robinson received 84.8 percent of the second-preference votes from supporters of Austin Currie, the Fine Gael party nominee who ran third. In the first round of counting, Lenihan of the Fianna Fail party had 44.1 percent of the vote to 38.9 percent for Mrs. Robinson and Currie's 17 percent. Since no one got a majority in the first round, the result turned on the second choices marked by Currie's supporters. Mrs. Robinson was nominated by the leftist Labor Party and the Workers Party, but she belongs to neither. The two parties pulled a combined 14.7 percent of the vote in last year's parliamentary election. She is the first president since 1945 not a member of the majority Fianna Fail party. It was Ireland's first contested presidential election in 17 years. Mrs. Robinson, 46, served 20 years in the Irish Senate but found more success in the courts in pressing her causes of equality for women and minorities. As an advocate of legalized divorce and contraception, she was often at odds with much of the country and her own Roman Catholic Church. Earlier today, Mrs. Robinson said she had been elated when it became clear that she was in position to win. ``I had this extraordinary sensation of just how important it was, particularly for women,'' she told reporters at her Dublin home. ``I quite literally wanted to go out and dance in the street. I almost had to be restrained. I know the joy that is there in so many people's hearts. They have told me how much this election means to them and I know why.'' Anticipating her victory, The Irish Times said in an editorial today the election ``marks the point at which a narrow and often cruel road, journeyed by a society often narrow and cruel, gives the first sign of broadening out.'' The Irish Press said the election ``signals a change in Irish society and a shift away from traditional attitudes and allegiances.'' Mrs. Robinson is a lecturer on European Community law at Trinity College, her alma mater. She also holds a master's degree from Harvard. Fianna Fail and Fine Gael, which have dominated Ireland since it gained independence from Britain in 1922, are both conservative on social and economic issues. Lenihan, 59, was perhaps the most popular man in Fianna Fail and had been expected to win the election easily. But Prime Minister Charles Haughey was forced to dismiss Lenihan as deputy prime minister and defense minister last week to save his coalition government from collapse. Lenihan was accused of lying about his role in a 1982 effort by Fianna Fail leaders seeking to avoid a national election following a no-confidence vote against the government of former Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald Currie, 51, was a leader in the Catholic civil rights campaign in Northern Ireland in the 1960s and a founder of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the main Catholic party in Northern Ireland. He was elected last year to the Dail, the lower house of Ireland's Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Police Hunt Schoolgirl's Abductor as Jittery Parents Keep Eye on Kids
DOC.TEXT: Nervous parents throughout central Connecticut stood lookout at school bus stops following the kidnapping at gunpoint of an 8-year-old girl. The youngster was released unharmed, but the kidnapper remained at large Friday. Police said they were making progress, but declined to elaborate. A man described as in his mid-30s drove up to a school bus stop Wednesday morning where three girls were standing. He displayed a gun, and ordered them into his car, police said. He grabbed an 8-year-old, but the girl's 5-year-old sister and their friend, 10, managed to flee. The kidnap victim was released about an hour later more than 10 miles away in Guilford.Police said none of the girls knew the gunman. Roadblocks were set up Wednesday and Thursday morning on the roads where the kidnapping occurred and where the girl was released. Wallingford police Sgt. Joseph Curran said the roadblocks ``turned up information,'' but he would not release any details. In Wallingford and the neighboring town of North Branford, parents were urged to have adults stand lookout at school bus stops, school officials said. In Cheshire, a worried mother called police Thursday afternoon to report her son was late coming home from elementary school and that a crossing guard had reported seeing him get into a car. Police said it turned out that the child had taken a ride from a friend's mother. All three girls returned to their elementary school Thursday, where they ``seemed to be adjusting surprisingly well,'' said Schools Superintendent Joseph Cirasuolo. Cirasuolo said some parents drove their children to school rather than having them take the bus, but that bus usage was down only slightly.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Say Anti-Drug Effort Needs National Image, Logo
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the President's Drug Advisory Council said Friday that President Bush should speak on television twice a year to reinforce his commitment to the war on drugs. They also urged the country's 500 richest businesses to pay for anti-drug booklets for each of the nation's 32 million grade-school children and said all professional sports team uniforms should carry anti-drug patches. ``There needs to be a national image, a national symbol, a national logo that everyone can look at like the American flag,'' said Orange County Sheriff Brad Gates, founder of California's Drug Use is Life Abuse program. The council's National Leadership Forum heard from the heads of three substance abuse programs in California, Florida and Washington singled out as national models. ``This is not a war on drugs. This is really a rebuilding effort - rebuilding our communities so we have safe places to live and work and go to school,'' said Paul Dziedzic, special assistant to Washington Gov. Booth Gardner. Edward ``Thad'' Foote, president of the University of Miami and chairman of The Miami Coalition, said his group has determined that some old assumptions about drug abuse were wrong. ``We were perilously close to just throwing up our hands a few years ago,'' Foote said. ``We found out this problem wasn't going to go away by building more jails or sending more ships to the Caribbean.'' Dade County has demolished 700 crack cocaine houses in Miami over two years and boasts a ``virtually unheard of'' 4 percent recidivism rate in an alternative ``drug court'' that expunges criminal records of drug abusers who complete treatment-education programs within a year, Foote said. ``And we finally figured out if you want to break the cycle of addiction for poor sick people, you've got to find them a job,'' he said. Gates said Orange County has beefed up law enforcement but also made a priority of changing attitudes about drugs through a marketing approach modeled after anti-smoking campaigns. The California program has made popular a logo, ``Drug Use is Life Abuse.'' It also enlisted the help of Walt Disney Co. to develop a booklet with three animated animal characters, ``Skippy, Spike and Wise Owl Mike,'' who preach against substance abuse through a rap song. The booklets could be published for 10 cents each if the nation's top 500 companies would donate a total of $3.2 million for mass production of 32 million copies, he said. Gates said the Los Angeles Rams sported an anti-drug emblem on their uniform in 1989, but the idea has been opposed by the NFL and other sports leagues. ``We need a logo on the uniform of every professional sports team, football, baseball, basketball and soccer,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Killed in Faction Fighting
DOC.TEXT: A battle between rival black factions broke out in a Natal township following an attack on a workers' hostel, and police said Friday that 16 people had died. The violence in Bruntville on Thursday sent women fleeing with their children to a nearby town. Police said all the victims were men who had stab wounds. In another incident Thursday, assailants attacked a bus carrying workers in the Johannesburg township of Sebokeng. Police said one man was killed and 12 were injured. Authorities did not identify the combatants in either case, but most township fighting has been between supporters of the African National Congress and the rival Inkatha Freedom Party, the country's largest black political movements. The Bruntville fighting apparently was sparked Wednesday when a meeting hall was damaged before residents of a workers' hostel were to have met there. On Thursday, attackers with guns, knives and gasoline bombs attacked one of the township hostels, killing one man and injuring dozens. The hostels, which house migrant workers, have been frequent targets of attack in the township violence. Women took their children and fled for the nearby town of Mooi River, apparently anticipating more violence. Police said that later that night, a battle broke out between two groups of men in Bruntville. Officers dispersed them and found 15 bodies. The township is in the eastern province of Natal, 80 miles northwest of Durban. About 5,000 blacks have died in factional fighting in Natal Province since 1986. In August, the fighting spread to Johannesburg townships, where about 800 blacks have been killed. A court on Friday refused bail to five men arrested in massacres related to the unrest. The five are alleged to have been involved in the slaying of 21 people killed in two train attacks in September near Johannesburg. Each faces 21 charges of murder and 49 of attempted murder.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Saddam Can't Divide the Anti-Iraqi Forces
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today praised the nations opposing Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf and said Saddam Hussein's attempts to divide the multinational effort are bound to fail. However, Gorbachev was evasive when he was asked whether he would support the use of force to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait, or whether Soviet soldiers might take part in such a miliary action. Earlier this week, Gorbachev's foreign minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, gave qualified support for a proposed U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force by the armies, navies and air forces of many nations arrayed against Iraq. The Soviet president told reporters today that the U.N. efforts to isolate Iraq have been a ``victory'' for the nations participating. ``Everything we have done up to now ... has been a great victory,'' said Gorbachev, pointing out the scope of the international effort to isolate Iraq. ``For the first time in history we have acted together in so critical a situation,'' he said. ``Let no one reckon on driving a wedge into that unity.'' Gorbachev's remarks, which are similar to comments on the gulf crisis that he and other Soviet officials have made earlier, came during a news conference on the first day of a two-day official visit to Germany. As proof of the international ``victory,'' Gorbachev noted that oil is still being pumped in the Middle East and ``the world economy is functioning.'' Gorbachev said it will be up to the United Nations to decide what steps to take next against in the gulf crisis. ``The United Nations should now decide how to proceed further,'' said Gorbachev, adding: ``We should act firmly, and consistently.'' ``We have condemned the aggressor. All attempts to shake unity will continue to be doomed,'' he added. Saddam has repeatedly tried to divide the anti-Iraq forces by releasing some countries' hostages while holding onto others. He has also tried to divide the West from its Arab allies by saying that negotiations over his invasion of Kuwait should be tied to a solution of the dispute over Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Gorbachev said that the gulf crisis is presenting the world with a ``test of the new politics'' of international cooperation that have evolved with the end of the Cold War. He said the crisis has set off a search for ``a new approach that is politically appropriate'' for dealing with the problem.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Football Player Indictment, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0610,0403
DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Indicts NFL Kicker in Heroin-Smuggling Ring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3-4th grafs, bgng `Ricky Williams...', with to DELETE incorrect reference to Williams being Igwebuike's attorney; he is co-defendant Ibekwe's attorney; CORRECT that player will turn himself in in Minneapolis sted Tampa. Picks up 4th graf, `Igwebuike's name...'. Version moved on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Vikings placekicker Donald Igwebuike was indicted today by a federal grand jury on charges he schemed to smuggle heroin from his native Nigeria. Igwebuike was charged with conspiracy to import, conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute and the importation of heroin. He was at Vikings' headquarters in Eden Prairie, Minn., this morning and was to turn himself in to federal authorities in Minneapolis later in the day, said Minnesota U.S. Attorney Jerry Arnold. Igwebuike's name was linked to the case two weeks ago when ABC News reported that prosecutors in Tampa had ``irrefutable'' evidence connecting the placekicker to an attempt to smuggle heroin into the United States from Nigeria. Igwebuike was charged on three counts of a four-count indictment that also named Maduwuba Ibekwe and Ibezim Ofedu, who had already been arrested and charged in the case. Ibekwe, a taxi driver and substitute teacher in Hillsborough County, was arrested Oct. 12 at Orlando International Airport where a a U.S. Customs Service inspector discovered three pellets containing heroin. Ibekwe, who allegedly swallowed 31 packets of heroin before boarding his flight to Orlando, was released from a hospital three days later after he passed more packets. Ibekwe, earlier charged with importation of heroin, pleaded innocent and is being held without bond at the Hillsborough County Jail. Ofedu also was denied bond after court records said he accepted about 400 grams of heroin from an undercover customs agents. Attorney Larry Reed said Igwebuike did not help Ibekwe import heroin but simply wanted Ibekwe to rush $12,000 to his parents in Nigeria. Reed said the kicker's parents received the money. Custom agents searched Igwebuike's Bloomington, Minn., apartment the day after the ABC report and reportedly seized telephone records and other personal papers. Igwebuike has been one of the most accurate and consistent placekickers in the NFL during his career. Before going to Minnesota this year, he spent five years with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and is the club's all-time leading scorer with 416 points.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Deployment Is Signal for Possible War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES grafs 3-4 pvs, `Republican Sen. ...' because Gorton's comments were made Wednesday night, before Bush's announcement. SUBS last graf pvs to conform.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress say President Bush's massive deployment of nearly 200,000 additional U.S. forces to the Persian Gulf is a signal to the nation to get ready for war. ``I think the American people need to prepare themselves for a major conflict in the Middle East,'' said Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee. There was cautious support for the latest military buildup, but Rep. Charles Rangel was harshly critical of Bush's action. ``With this troop buildup, the president is sending every signal that instead of seeking peaceful solutions, he plans to rush the nation into war,'' Rangel said Friday. Rangel, D-N.Y., suggested that while many U.S. allies have placed a stronger emphasis on a diplomatic solution to the more than three-month stalemate, ``the president really seems to be going his own way on this.'' Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho, said he wouldn't second guess Bush. The president, Symms said, ``has sole responsibility for assuring we have adequate military might.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said that although Bush has broad support from the American people, the backing is ``very thin.'' ``There's a great deal of uneasiness about all of this,'' he said. ``They do not want American casualties. They feel that very, very strongly.'' Hamilton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Middle East subcommittee, said Bush ``needs to be more precise and more articulate than he has been about the reasons for our deployment there and precisely what our commitment has been.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. A week later, Bush sent thousands of U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia and the gulf area to stop further Iraqi aggression. On Thursday, Bush announced the deployment of additional forces to provide the United States with the offensive power necessary if there is a conflict with the 430,000 Iraqis in and around Kuwait. The list of units involved indicates as many as 200,000 more Americans will be sent. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney indicated Friday that the approximately 230,000 U.S. forces already in the area won't be rotated back to the United States early next year as the Pentagon had planned. Democratic Rep. Jim Slattery of Kansas said he hoped the increase in U.S. troops would lead to a peaceful solution. ``Hopefully, deployment ... will convince Saddam Hussein to retreat from Kuwait,'' Slattery said. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, expressed concern that the United States was moving to create an offensive capability ``in advance of a U.N. resolution authorizing offensive action.'' ``The United States should not be the unilateral policeman of the world,'' Pell said. Slattery, Pell and Skelton made their comments Thursday night.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Associates Form Committee
DOC.TEXT: Advisers to Gov. L. Douglas Wilder have formed a committee that could be converted to a presidential campaign organization if the nation's first elected black governor decides to run in 1992. ``That's absolutely true,'' Paul Goldman, chairman of the Democratic Party of Virginia, said Friday of the Committee for Fiscal Responsibility in 1992. ``Yes, we will be fund raising, but that's not the primary purpose.'' Papers to create the committee were filed Thursday with the Federal Election Commission in Washington, D.C. Goldman is executive director of the committee, and Mark Warner of Alexandria, a key fund-raising adviser to the governor, is its treasurer. Goldman said the committee is designed to promote a message of fiscal responsibility ``as part of the theme the Democratic Party should present to the country in 1992.'' He said the committee could make contributions to candidates who share the goal of fiscal responsibility. It also would help send committee members who favor spending cuts over new taxes to meetings across the country. The committee is not a campaign organization for Wilder to seek the 1992 Democratic nomination for president, but could be made into one, Goldman said. Wilder declined to comment on the committee. His spokeswoman, Laura Dillard, said, ``That committee is something that's Mr. Goldman's.'' Wilder, the first elected black governor in U.S. history, has said he plans to serve out his term, which ends in January 1994. But he increasingly has thrust himself into the national spotlight by stumping for Democratic candidates and by promoting his opposition to new taxes. As governor, Wilder has ordered substantial spending cuts to meet a projected $1.4 billion shortfall in the state budget.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces in Gulf Bolstered for Offensive Option
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 3rd pvs, `In Moscow...' to UPDATE with Gorbachev's remarks on unity of anti-Iraqi forces. Subs 8th, `In a...' and 24th, `Bush, at...' to CONFORM.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2;LaserColor DHA101,2
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has given its qualified consent to the use of force, and President Bush has ordered more than 150,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf, giving the multinational forces an offensive military option. Secretary of State James A. Baker III flew from Moscow to London today on his mission to strengthen allied resolve against Iraq's 3-month-old occupation of Kuwait. Baker will meet Saturday with French leaders in Paris. In Moscow, a senior U.S. official said today that Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Arab forces would fight alongside U.S. troops to free Kuwait. But the official said the extent of France's support was not known. In another boost for the anti-Iraqi forces, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today said Saddam Hussein's attempts to divide the multinational effort are bound to fail. Speaking in Germany, where he is on an official visit, Gorbachev said: ``Everything we have done up to now ... has been a great victory.'' ``For the first time in history we have acted together in so critical a situation. Let no one reckon on driving a wedge into that unity.'' Iraq's government-run newspaper said today that Iraq and France conducted secret talks that led to the release of more than 300 Frenchmen from Iraq. The paper, Al-Jumhouriya, said the talks between Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and former French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson were endorsed by the French government. France has denied any deals were struck for hostages. Western officials have criticized efforts by former leaders - including Edward Heath of Britain, Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, and Willy Brandt of Germany - to free hostages, claiming they help divide the anti-Iraq alliance. Brandt left Baghdad for Frankfurt today with 177 Westerners, mostly Germans. But those on the flight included three Americans and 14 Britons - seven more Britons than originally indicated. Two Americans were held back when Iraqi officials told the U.S. Embassy their papers were not in order. In a more personal attempt to influence Saddam, 11 British women headed to Baghdad today to seek the release of their captive husbands and relatives - against the advice of their government. At the United Nations today, Iraq's attempt to introduce a General Assembly resolution criticizing the U.S. military buildup in the Perisan Gulf drew a stinging rebuke when an assembly committee unanimously refused to consider it. The U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas Pickering, called the Iraqi motion, ``ill-founded, tendentious and mendacious,'' President Bush on Thursday ordered the new troops to the gulf, saying he wanted an ``adequate offensive military option'' should global sanctions fail to persuade Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. But despite the talk of offensive capability, Bush said he still hoped Saddam would ``come to his senses'' and avoid combat by pulling out. Bush did not give numbers, but Pentagon officials said in private conversations that full deployment of the units involved would involve about 150,000 troops. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in Washington today the new troop deployments would include one-half of American land forces in Germany. He said Bush intends to have about 430,000 U.S. forces in the gulf area within weeks. ``The additional increment will give us the capacity to undertake offensive action should that become necessary,'' Cheney said today. There are now 230,000 U.S. military personnel in the region. Allies from 26 countries have sent 100,000 soldiers to the multinational force assembled in the area. About 200,000 Army troops are stationed in Europe, most in Germany. Iraq's ambassador to Washington, Mohamed Al-Mashat, called the new U.S. deployment plan ``an unfortunate development.'' ``There is no reason for this force, or the previous force,'' he said Thursday on CBS' America Tonight. ``We haven't done anything to the United States.'' ``Believe you me, we will never surrender or capitulate,'' he said. Iraq has deployed an estimated 430,000 soldiers in Kuwait and southern Iraq since invading its southern oil-rich neighbor Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, oil and money. The invasion increased Iraq's share of world oil reserves to 20 percent and sent crude prices skyrocketing. In Moscow, meanwhile, Baker accomplished his goal of gaining Soviet consent for the use of force should peaceful measures fail. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said military might should not be ruled out, but cautioned it should be used only under U.N. auspices. ``A situation may emerge which effectively would require such a move,'' Shevardnadze told reporters after meeting with Baker. Before the crisis, Moscow was Baghdad's principal ally and principal weapons supplier. Bush, at his news conference, said ``we're on the same wavelength'' with Gorbachev in terms of his policy goals in the Middle East. He said he felt there were no ``mixed signals'' from Moscow. The Bush administration, impatient that months of U.N. economic sanctions have failed to dislodge Saddam's troops from Kuwait, intends to ask the U.N. Security Council to authorize force if the Baghdad government doesn't agree to a pullout. The 11 British women left today for Baghdad, where they hope to ask Saddam to release their husbands and relatives on humanitarian grounds. The British Foreign Office advised the women against going and called the trip ``risky,'' but they ignored the advice. Hundreds of Americans are among those still trapped in Iraq, some held at strategic sites as ``human shields'' to deter attack by the U.S.-led multinational force in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Reportedly was on Prozac
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of shooting to death radical Rabbi Meir Kahane reportedly was taking the anti-depressant Prozac, which has been blamed by some users for suicidal and homicidal behavior. Police confirmed Friday that El Sayyid Nosair was taking an drug for depression, but would not say which one. The New York Times reported he was taking the prescription drug Prozac. The drug's manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co. Inc., has denied any connection between Prozac and aberrant behavior, a position reiterated Friday by company spokesman Edward A. West. ``According to press reports, the shooting of Rabbi Kahane appears to have been a premeditated act by a distressed individual who was under a doctor's care and may have been taking multiple drugs,'' West said. ``Ongoing analysis of controlled, double-blind clinical trials do not support a causal relationship between Prozac and violent behavior,'' he said. But several lawsuits against Eli Lilly cite the drug as a catalyst for murder and self-mutilation. The son of a Kentucky man who killed eight people in a 1989 shooting rampage while taking Prozac has sued the maker, contending the drug is unsafe. A Long Island woman who suffered through 18 months of self-mutilation while on the drug also has sued the company for $150 million. Prozac's known side effects include nausea, a rash, agitation and jittery nerves. Nosair, 34, remained in fair condition Friday in the intensive care unit of Bellevue Hospital, said spokeswoman Karen Crowe. She refused to comment about medication. He has been hospitalized since the Monday night shooting of Kahane, an anti-Arab extremist. Nosair, who is from Egypt, was wounded during an exchange of gunfire with a U.S. Postal police officer as he fled the slaying, taking a bullet in the throat, authorities said. Investigators have not linked Nosair, of Cliffside Park, N.J., to any terrorist groups. Once out of intensive care, Nosair will continue his recovery at the Bellevue medical unit for prisoners, Crowe said. Police have speculated Nosair's depression stemmed from job frustration. Nosair, who has an engineering degree, was employed by the city as a heating and air conditioning mechanic.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Post Names New Editor, Senior Vice President
DOC.TEXT: Charles Cooper has been appointed editor and senior vice president of The Houston Post, succeeding C. David Burgin. Burgin, 51, will assume the same positions at the Alameda Newspaper Group, publisher of four daily newspapers in Northern California. Publisher William Dean Singleton announced the changes Thursday. The Post and the California newspapers are members of Singleton's Houston-based MediaNews Group. Cooper, 47, has been managing editor of the Post for the past two years. ``Charles Cooper is one of the key architects of changes at the Post over the last two years,'' Singleton said. ``Our readership gains have been solid. Our change in editors doesn't mean any change in direction.'' Cooper came to the Post in 1988 from the Dallas Times Herald, where he was assistant managing editor. Before that he was with the San Francisco Examiner for 14 years, serving in news and sports editorships. He is a past president of the national Associated Press Sports Editors organization. Cooper grew up in Midland and graduated from the University of San Francisco. He served seven years in the Army. Before joining the Examiner in 1974, Cooper worked at the European Stars and Stripes, the Overseas Media Group in Germany, and as a freelance writer in Spain and California. Singleton praised Burgin's ``magnificent job in turning The Houston Post in the right direction,'' and said Burgin's departure leaves him with ``a lot of mixed emotions. We're very, very close.'' Burgin, a native of Somerset, Ky., and a graduate of Miami University in Ohio, previously served as editor of the San Francisco Examiner, the Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel and the Peninsula Times Tribune in Palo Alto, Calif. He also had been sports editor at the Examiner and at The Washington Star and the Washington Daily News. Earlier in his career, he was Capitol Hill and White House reporter for Scripps-Howard News Service and a foreign correspondent for the New York Herald Tribune.

DOC.HEAD: Monster Truck Wins Against Volvo This Time
LaserPhoto PX2
DOC.TEXT: Hardly a fair contest, maybe, but hot rod enthusiasts cheered a measure of revenge Friday for a 13,000-pound ``monster truck'' that squashed a row of Volvos. Some in the crowd figured the little guy deserved getting bashed this time, the response of the U.S. Hot Rod Association to a Volvo television commercial that has been pulled from the air. ``I loved it. It was great. They had it coming to them,'' said Billie Burns, who brought three children ages 4, 2 and 8 months from nearby Folcroft to the exhibition in the parking lot of the Spectrum sports arena. The trucks had arrived for a weekend competition at the Spectrum. She was not impressed with the way the Volvos held up briefly before succumbing to ``Bearfoot'' and its 1,000-pound tires. ``They were stomped,'' she said with a grin. In Pittsburgh, however, another monster truck had big trouble with a Volvo. ``Big Boss'' and its 800-pound tires got stuck on a 1975 green Volvo in the parking lot of Civic Arena. Burns, like some other spectators, said they came to see Volvo's comeuppance for an ad in which a Volvo appeared to be the only car left relatively intact in a line of autos run over by Bearfoot. The Texas attorney general challenged the ad and the company pulled it this week, saying that unknown to Volvo, the Volvo in the line of cars had been reinforced. Friday, Bearfoot and two other monster trucks, Predator and Black Stallion, took turns getting their own licks in as TV crews and a small crowd watched. ``We don't have a knock against Volvo,'' Hot Rod Association spokesman Steve Greenberg said. ``We're doing this in good-natured fun. It is tongue-in-cheek.'' ``There is a reputation to uphold here,'' he added, citing questions caused by the ad about the power of the monster trucks, which he said draw 4 million fans a year to events around the country. The junked Volvos in Philadelphia were no match over the long haul. But the trucks needed a few swipes to get the job done. The roar of the trucks drowned the crowd's cheers with each pass. The white-and-blue Predator crushed a line of five cars - a Pontiac, three Chevys and a Volvo in the middle. The roof of the Volvo wagon held up enough that it might have protected passengers. Then Black Stallion took one run at a line of six Volvos, breaking them in for four runs by Bearfoot. One on the end gave the trucks particular trouble before giving way. Bearfoot finally finished it by coming at an angle to smash another that had roof supports still standing, coming to rest on the crushed car. Bearfoot driver Todd Blaeser said he was surprised by how well the Volvos held up. Usually, he said, a line of cars would be finished off in two or three runs. Asked if Volvo had passed the test, he looked at the pile of six crushed cars with the metallic blue truck on top of it and said, ``It doesn't look like it, does it?'' ``We've run into Volvos that have stood out in a pile of cars as being tougher,'' said Blaeser, 23, of Chippewa Falls, Wis. Volvo spokesman Robert Austin watched the car stomping on television from his office, and said while the Volvos ``didn't come out unscathed,'' they appeared to hold up well compared with other cars. At one point, the Predator got stuck on the Volvo on its third pass over the five cars. ``It was apparent that the Volvo was standing up to the full weight of the truck. So I would leave it to the public to draw their own conclusions,'' Austin said.

DOC.HEAD: Woops, Wrong Airport
DOC.TEXT: A Continental Express flight from Houston to Jackson landed at a private airfield seven miles from the commercial airport where it was due. The ATR-42 turboprop was carrying 33 passengers when it landed Thursday night at Hawkins Field rather than Jackson International Airport in nearby Rankin County, airline spokeswoman Peggy Mahoney said. She said the crew was grounded Friday while officials tried to determine what went wrong. Hawkins Field had served as Jackson's commercial airport until 1963, when the other airport opened. The crew was flying into the area for the first time, Federal Aviation Administration officials said. ``This sort of thing is unfortunate. It happens once in a while,'' said Jacques Lonchambon, an operations inspector with the FAA in Houston. Mahoney said passengers on Flight 2682 were taken to hotels or to Jackson International Airport. Continental Express is a wholly owned subsidiary of Houston-based Continental Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Earthquake in New Madrid Area Heightens Fears of Big One
DOC.TEXT: A small tremor caused no damage or injuries but heightened concerns about a major earthquake that has been forecast for the area. Thursday night's quake measured 3.6 on the Richter scale and was felt in at least three states - Missouri, Kentucky and Tennessee. The quake struck along the New Madrid Fault, which produces hundreds of tremors a year, but most are hardly felt. Iben Browning, a New Mexico climatologist, has forecast a 50-50 chance for a major earthquake along the fault on or about Dec. 3. ``That's why you're hearing about this one,'' geophysicist Russ Needham said of Thursday night's quake. ``Had it been a year ago, it would have been reported and that's about it.'' Many scientists have criticized Browning's methods and conclusions. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Protesters Seize Town Buildings In Eastern Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT three dead were rebels. Pickup 5th pvs, `The attackers ...
DOC.TEXT: Former Contra rebels attacked a police station in eastern Nicaragua on Friday, leaving three guerrillas dead in the most violent anti-government clash in months, a Cabinet official said. Thirty-five people, including nine police officers, were wounded in the battle, said Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado. The attack appeared to be part of a growing weeklong protest in the eastern half of the country of President Violeta Chamorro's economic policies, her administration's ties with the opposition leftist Sandinistas and a failure to keep promises of resettlement aid to demobilized Contras. Hurtado told reporters the attack in Nueva Guinea, about 190 miles east of Managua, took place before dawn. He said 21 people were arrested, but only five were held on weapons charges. Hurtado said the three dead were former Contras. The attackers fired on the station with AK-47 assault rifles, then fled to a nearby church where they surrendered, Hurtado said. The dissidents seized government buildings in another eastern town Thursday night. The protests started last week by blocking the main highway linking eastern and western Nicaragua. It remained barricaded Friday. Armed forces chief Gen. Humberto Ortega has threatened to use the army to clear the road, but so far the military has taken no action. Protesters have demanded withdrawal of all Sandinista-controlled security forces along the Rama road and the removal of Hurtado, the Cabinet official in charge of internal security, and Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law Antonio Lacayo. Lacayo is Minister of the Presidency and holds most of the power behind the scenes in the administration. Much of the resentment stems from Mrs. Chamorro's decision to keep the Sandinistas in control of the military and police.

DOC.HEAD: Mary Robinson, Ireland's President-elect, Represents Something New
With AM-Ireland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mary Robinson is a woman of forceful opinions about the rights of women and minorities, opinions she will be obliged to keep to herself as president of Ireland. ``That doesn't really worry me,'' she said late in her campaign. ``If I'm elected, that's an enormous boost .. and my views are known. What I would represent is more space and more pluralism and more tolerance - just by being elected.'' Mary Robinson is the first woman and the first candidate of the left to be president of Ireland. ``The president is the honorific and symbolic head of state,'' said Tom Garvin, lecturer in politics at University College in Dublin. By tradition, they are expected to be above politics. In 1976, when President Cearbhall O Dalaigh exercised his power to refer legislation to the Supreme Court for review, there was such an uproar in Parliament that he felt compelled to resign. If Mrs. Robinson decides to challenge the traditional constraints placed on Irish presidents, it won't be the first time she has challenged the status quo. When Mrs. Robinson entered the Senate in 1969, she was the first Roman Catholic to represent Trinity College, a historically Protestant institution. And, at age 25, she was Ireland's youngest senator and Trinity's youngest professor of law. Born in the County Mayo town of Ballina, Mary Bourke grew up in a country that was deeply conservative and dominated by the Roman Catholic Church. Her parents, both physicians, treated her the same as her four brothers. ``Nobody ever expressed any surprise that I wanted to be a lawyer, or to do anything different from the boys,'' she once said. ``If she wanted something, she worked with it and got it ... quietly and without fuss, but very purposefully,'' her father, Dr. Aubrey Bourke, said on Thursday. She accepted a scholarship to Trinity College, which her church then regarded as off-limits. When she married a Protestant, fellow law student Nick Robinson, her disapproving parents refused to attend the ceremony. After winning a first-class honors degree at Trinity, then a masters in law from Harvard, she jumped into public life. She introduced legislation in the Senate in 1970 to make contraceptives legally available, and tried again in 1973 and 1974. In 1976, she proposed that Ireland legalize divorce. She won court cases to permit women to serve on juries, to overturn laws criminalizing homosexuality, to restore inheritance rights for illegitimate children and to give women legislators such as herself the same pension rights as their male colleagues. Contraceptives were made available by law to ``bona fide couples'' in 1979 and to anyone over 18 in 1985, but the ban on divorce was upheld in a national referendum in 1986. Abortion is still illegal. Though she is president of Cherish, which supports single women who decide to carry pregnancies to term, she also represented students at Trinity College who were providing information about the availability of abortion in Britain. ``The denial of information is simply putting a further load on women who are going to go anyway,'' she said in a recent interview. ``The statistics in England show that the numbers are remaining at the same level but they are going later, at greater risk. I think that is very cruel and very inhumane,'' she said. The decision to run for president, Mrs. Robinson has said, was not entirely her own: it was put to a vote around the dinner table and approved by her husband, her daughter, Tessa, 18, and sons William, 16, and Aubrey, 9. Tall, slender and a bit reserved, Mrs. Robinson began campaigning for the largely ceremonial office in May. Her staff estimates that she rolled up 25,000 miles crisscrossing the country in a bus that relentlessly blared an insipid instrumental version of the Simon and Garfunkel tune, ``Mrs. Robinson.'' The candidate's intention was to shake up the country and to challenge a front-runner who, she said, simply offered ``more of the same.'' Asked what she thought was wrong with her country, she said: ``Irish society isn't sufficiently pluralist for a start, insufficiently tolerant of difference. We haven't got it in our constitution, in our laws or in our ethos.'' As president, she said she would make the sprawling official mansion in Dublin's Phoenix Park a forum for contact and discussion for all manner of groups. The ``hand of friendship'' would also be extended, she said, to the Protestants of Northern Ireland who reject any thought of uniting with the republic she will head.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Satellite Companies Selling Photos Of Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Pentagon spokesman Oborn in 2nd and 3rd grafs
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Commercial satellite companies are selling photographs of the Persian Gulf that could provide sensitive military details about Iraqi and U.S. troop deployments in the region. The Pentagon has tried to keep secret operational information about troops in Saudi Arabia, but has not made any move to block satellite companies from selling the commercial film, spokesman Rick Oborn said. Oborn said he had not seen any commercial satellite pictures but said he would be concerned if they revealed operational information. He said he knew of no attempts to block the sale of the photos. Peter Zimmerman, a professor of applied sciences at George Washington University, said the pictures made available by Soyuzkarta, a Soviet trade organization, ``are among the finest unclassified imagery I have ever seen.'' A camera focused on an area could probably pick up the placement of large vehicles, the site of a troop deployment and topographical details such as trenches, he said. Individual people would be indistinguishable. The pictures ``would be very useful'' for Iraqi and U.S. forces in the gulf to help determine military information about the other side, Zimmerman said. But Jeffrey Richelson, author of ``America's Secret Eyes In Space,'' said a skilled photo interpreter is often needed to identify objects from satellite pictures. Soyuzkarta is one of three commercial firms that sell satellite photographs of the gulf. The other two are SPOT Image, a French-owned company and Landsat, a U.S. concern.
