SPOT Image says it will sell pictures only to people with security clearances to prevent the images from falling into Iraqi hands; Landsat says its pictures of the gulf region show only sand; Soyuzkarta says it tries to make sure only legitimate customers buy the pictures. Soyuzkarta's photographs show items roughly 15 feet in size, and have the highest resolution among the three companies. With computer enhancement, the images are clearer. Velon Minshew of Fort Worth, Texas, a U.S. distributor for Soyuzkarta, said the company has pictures of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq for the months of August and September. Each frame showing an area 50-60 square miles sells for $1,560. Clark Nelson said SPOT Image's pictures show a resolution of about 30 feet. The pictures sell for anywhere from $500 to $3,000. Generally, the Landsat pictures of the gulf region show ``a lot of sand,'' cording to Dick Mroczynski, a company spokesman. Landsat's pictures, much less clear than those of Soyuzkarta and SPOT, were designed as a mapping tool, and are often used by geologists and others trying to determine land formations. Under U.N. sanctions, the commercial satellite companies are barred from selling pictures to Iraq. Minshew refused to say who has purchased Soyuzkarta's pictures, but the company will sell to legitimate organizations who agree not to transfer the information. Nelson of SPOT Image said his company sells photographs to the Defense Department. ``We are not selling to the Iraqis or anybody associated with the Iraqis,'' he said, and only those with ``proper security procedures'' are allowed to purchase the pictures. Nelson said he knew nothing of a recent report in The Washington Times that said Iraq is believed to have obtained satellite pictures indirectly from SPOT Image. The newspaper cited U.S. intelligence sources as its source. Television networks have not made wide use of the satellite pictures, although CBS' ``60 Minutes'' program showed a photograph purporting to show a uranium mine in Iraq. An interpreter pointed out the images. Spokesmen for CBS, ABC, NBC and CNN said their networks were not using other gulf pictures. John Stack, the foreign assignment editor at NBC, said the network has used satellite pictures in the past to show, among other things, the nuclear explosion at Chernobyl in the Soviet Union. Electronic images provided by commercial satellites are not nearly as sophisticated as the data sent by intelligence satellites, Richelson said.

DOC.HEAD: Belgium Orders Investigation into Secret Anti-Communist Group
DOC.TEXT: Belgium has ordered an investigation into the activities of a secret group formed during the Cold War to fight potential communist invaders in several NATO countries, an official said Friday. Defense Minister Guy Coeme said his government suspected the little-known group might be linked to a series of murders around Brussels between 1983 asnd 1985. The inquiry was launched after speculation was raised in Italy that the Italian branch of the organization, known as Operation Gladio, might have orchestrated right-wing terrorism. The anti-Communist groups were organized in the 1950s and operated in several other countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including Greece and Portugal. They set up information and communication networks and also had a special sabotage division to be put to se in case of a communist invasion, officials of both Italy and Belgium said. Cells of the secret network were active in Portugal during the 1950s to defend the rightist government of dictator Antonio Oliveira Salazar, according to a radio report in Lisbon on Friday. The Greek defense minister, Yannis Varvitsiotis, said Friday the CIA helped set up a similar network in Greece in 1955 to organize a guerrilla war against any communist invader. Known as Operation Sheepskin, it was dismantled by 1988, he said. Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, who has headed the Belgian government almost continuously since 1979, said he was never informed of the existence of the Belgian arm of the group, which he said was set up by the Belgian military. ``It was not an official network,'' Martens told a news conference Friday. He said, however, that NATO knew of the groups' activities, although they were not an official part of the organization. ``This network is a complete anachronism. We favor abolishing it,'' Martens said. Italy has asked NATO to investigate whether the secret groups are still needed. NATO spokesman Florent Swijsen declined comment on the groups, saying: ``NATO's established practice on matters of military secrecy is not to provide information or to comment in any way.'' Coeme said Operation Gladio cell officials met in Brussels two weeks ago ``to see whether it was still useful to have this kind of service,'' considering the growing East-West cooperation. In Italy, speculation abounds that the group was involved in right-wing terrorism during the 1970s and 1980s. However, Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti said Thursday he had no evidence that any crimes were committed in Operation Gladio. Belgium is investigating whether it was involved in a series of supermarket attacks and robberies that left at least 28 people dead between 1983 and 1985. The attackers were always more bent on killing than stealing. The violent incidents have often been linked by authorities to right-wing terrorism. Police have made little progress in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Cyanide Leak Into River PoisonsWater Supplies
DOC.TEXT: A cyanide leak into a river in the Soviet republics of Byelorussia and Latvia has poisoned water supplies to several cities and caused at least two people to become ill, officials said Friday. The leak into the Daugava River, apparently from a chemical weapons plant, occurred sometime between Oct. 31 and Nov. 5, said authorities in the two republics. They said officials of the plant, which makes chemicals for use in chemical weapons, never told them about the leak. ``It is just the same as Chernobyl. We only learned that something went wrong when we saw fish floating belly up down the stream,'' said Latvian Deputy Prime Minister Ilmar Bisher. He referred to the 1983 nuclear power plant disaster in the nearby Ukraine. ``Two men ate a (fish) and got minor poisoning. We hope there will be no more cases,'' said Bisher, head of a Latvian commission investigating the leak. Local officials were still testing the waters and trying to determine how much of the chemical had leaked. ``Some say it was only three tons, other reports mention up to 60 tons,'' said Mayor Andris Inkulis of Riga, the capital of the Latvian republic. Drinking water from the river was turned off in Riga on Thursday, said Viktor Yukhno, the controller at Latvia's government water authority. The city of nearly 1 million gets one-third of its water from the river, officials said. The city's residents have been using water from underground wells and a lake, but pumps are not powerful enough to bring water to taller buildings and many residents remain without water, Yukhno said. Bisher said Riga's water reservoir was also contaminated and it may take 10 days for river water supplies to be restored. ``This does not only affect Riga, but the whole (republic of Latvia),'' Inkulis said in Stockholm, Sweden, where he was visiting. ``We warned people over television and radio so they could save some water.'' Water also was cut to Daugavpils, a city of 150,000 about 120 miles east of Riga, Bisher said. Officials have trucked in water for the city and other areas. Daugavpils gets three-quarters of its water from the Daugava, but much of the contamination already has passed and water may be turned back on by Saturday, he said. The chemicals apparently leaked from the plant in the Byelorussian town of Novopolotsk, 480 miles upriver from Riga just over the republic's border. ``We think the poison comes from the weapons factory, but they don't tell us anything,'' Inkulis said. ``If only we had been told when this happened right away, but we weren't and now the poison runs out into the sea.'' There was no word on the leak from plant officials or the state press. Bisher said the plant is operated by the national government's Chemical and Petrochemical Ministry. Preliminary analysis showed the chemical was either hydrogen cyanide or potassium cyanide, Inkulis said. It was not clear how the leak occurred. It was impossible to determine how many people were affected in Latvia or Byelorussia, because many have begun using well water in recent years. Riga is the largest city on the river, lying at its mouth on the Baltic Sea. But hundreds, possibly thousands, of other people live in areas along the river and traditionally used the river for food and drinking water.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Xanax for Treatment of Panic Disorder
DOC.TEXT: The leading anti-anxiety drug has become the first medication approved for panic disorder, officials said Friday. An estimated 3 million Americans - 1 percent to 2 percent of the population - will suffer from panic disorder in their lifetimes. For more than half of them, it will disrupt their social and working lives. The illness is characterized by repeated panic attacks, in which a patient is struck by intense fear. By avoiding situations associated with the attacks, some sufferers become housebound or are unable to go outside alone. Symptoms of the attacks can include chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, trembling and sweating, nausea and abdominal distress. The symptoms often mimic a heart attack, which can lead to an incorrect diagnosis, said officials of the Upjohn Co., which makes Xanax. The Food and Drug Administration first approved Xanax in 1981 for the treatment for clinical anxiety and anxiety associated with depression. Common side effects of Xanax in panic disorder-sufferers include sedation and fatigue, but as is the case with anxiety treatment, those reactions eased when the dose was reduced or as the medication was continued, Upjohn said. However, because higher doses of Xanax may be needed for longer periods of time to treat panic disorder, the FDA was concerned about the potential for dependency on the drug. ``At higher doses and longer duration, there is potential for physical dependency on Xanax and withdrawal symptoms when the drug is stopped or reduced too rapidly,'' said FDA spokeswoman Eva Kemper. ``Because of that possibility, Xanax must be withdrawn gradually and under a physician's supervision,'' she said. A biochemical malfunctioning in the brain is believed to cause panic attacks, the company said. Xanax, known generically as alprazolam, can block the attacks by interacting with several different systems in the brain. Upjohn studied alprazolam as a treatment for the disorder in a two-phase study that involved more than 1,700 patients in more than 14 countries, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Children's Artwork From 1938 Found Behind Chalkboard
DOC.TEXT: Workers pulling down a slate chalkboard in an elementary school found buried treasure - chalk drawings elementary school children had done a half-century earlier. The workers were preparing to cover the wall-length chalkboard with a bulletin board at Concord Elementary School Tuesday. They noticed the slate was loose, pulled it off and found a farewell from the 6A Graduating Class of 1938. Further investigation turned up more artwork beneath another chalkboard, apparently left behind by someone who couldn't bear to erase them when new slates were installed over the worn ones 52 years before. The wall-length boards included six still-vivid colored chalk pictures by student artists and the signatures of several dozen children who attended Lily Lodmell's class. One of the names was of a now 64-year-old construction worker who lives lives a few blocks away. ``That's me - No. 17. That's my signature,'' Carl Marra exclaimed when he was summoned to the school. Marra, whose name was signed Marro then - a birth certificate error he later corrected - is a lifelong resident of the South Park neighborhood. Marra said he did not remember doing the blackboard farewell, but added: ``I remember most of the kids. We all lived on the same street.'' Several of his long-ago classmates still live in the area, he said. The chalk pictures are drawings of scenes in Norway, Portugal and Italy on one board, and Holland, Sweden and Mexico on another. The room's present teacher, Bernice Moore, said her third-grade students were very excited by the discovery. ``They talked about what they must have been studying at the time ... probably about those countries.'' Principal Toby Gonzales informed the Seattle School District's archives office of the find and taped off the area to protect it while plans were made to put it on display in a hallway or elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: One Congressman Concedes Defeat In Cliffhanger; Second Incumbent Holds Out
DOC.TEXT: One final cliffhanger congressional race remained in limbo Friday, a day after another close race ended with an incumbent conceding defeat. Democratic Rep. Jim Bates of San Diego trailed Republican challenger Randy Cunningham by 982 votes in the 44th District with an unknown number of absentee ballots still to be counted. The San Diego County registrar of voters said they would not be tabulated until Tuesday. Bates, who was seeking a fifth term, had been reprimanded by the House ethics committee last year for sexually harassing two female aides. On Thursday, Democratic Rep. Douglas Bosco of Sebastopol acknowledged he had lost a bid for a fifth term to Republican developer Frank Riggs. Bosco trailed Riggs by 1,973 votes with an unknown number of absentee ballots still uncounted, but an aide said the congressman didn't believe those votes would change the outcome. Riggs tried to take advantage of the national savings and loan scandal, claiming that Bosco had become a wealthy man by ``consorting with scoundrels'' who ran two local, failed S&Ls. But Bosco's downfall seemed to be due to a strong showing by Peace and Freedom Party candidate Darlene Comingore, who appealed to liberals dissatisfied with Bosco's positions on environmental and foreign policy issues. Comingore got nearly 15 percent of the vote. Bosco's loss leaves the makeup of the newly elected Congress at 267 Democrats, 166 Republicans and one independent, with Bates' seat still undecided. If Bates loses, the result would be a net gain of eight seats for the Democrats and a loss of nine for the GOP. In California, Democrats held 27 of the state's 45 House seats before the election and the Republicans held 18. If Bates loses, Democrats will hold 26 seats and the Republicans 19.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic States Want Independence Recognized
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania on Friday asked countries planning to sign the most comprehensive arms control treaty in history not to legitimize the Soviet Union's claim to the Baltic states. They also said at a summit in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, that their states should be separately identified in the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty. The accord covers weapons and troops in Europe from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union and is to be the centerpiece for a 34-nation summit Nov. 19-21 in Paris. The treaty covers deployment of tanks, anti-aircraft artillery and other non-nuclear arms in four European zones, including the Baltics. The three presidents said treaty signatories should explicitly state that Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia were never legally incorporated into the Soviet Union. Presidents Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, Arnold Ruutel of Estonia and Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia asked signatories to ``refrain from legitimizing the presence of or any additions to the Soviet armed forces on their (the Baltics') territory.'' ``Silence on this issue might be construed by the Soviet Union as tacit recognition of the forcible incorporation of the Baltic States into the Soviet Union,.'' In an appeal reported by Baltic news services, the leaders said the Baltics should be separately identified in the treaty so they could control its implementation on their territory. Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia together have a population of 8 million people. The three states are in various stages of drives to break out of the Soviet Union, which annexed them in 1940 in a deal with Nazi Germany. The Baltic presidents failed in their bid to be invited to the Paris summit as observers, but Landsbergis told a news conference Friday, ``We hope to participate in the conference at least as guests of a delegation of one of the countries that takes part.''

DOC.HEAD: Feminist Candidate Wins Ireland's Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with additional quote, CLARIFIES that she elected Friday. Pickup 10th pvs, `By tradition...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: Mary Robinson, a feminist lawyer elected as the first woman president in Ireland's history on Friday, thanked the country's womn who ``instead of rocking the cradle ... rocked the system.'' ``I don't know whether to dance or to sing. I have done both and I hope to do more,'' she said after being declared the winner of a tradition-shattering presidential campaign. Mrs. Robinson finished with 52.8 percent of the vote, overtaking former deputy prime minister Brian Lenihan, the nominee of the dominant Fianna Fail party, in the second round of counting. The 46-year-old attorney and professor of law was the first woman elected president, and the first to beat Fianna Fail in a contested presidential election. ``We were up against the might and the money and the very effective machine of the greatest political party in this country and we beat them,'' said Mrs. Robinson. She pledged to work for the poor, the homeless, the sick and the unemployed and ``above all the women of Ireland who are still struggling in the long march to equality and equity.'' ``To all those who have no voice or whose voice is weak I say take heart, there is hope. ``Look what you did in this election. You made history.'' Her support, she said, came from ``men and women of all parties and none, by many with great moral courage who stepped out from the faded flags of the civil war and voted for a new Ireland, and above all by the women of Ireland - the women of Ireland who instead of rocking the cradle ... rocked the system.'' By tradition, Ireland's presidents are above politics, and Mrs. Robinson had acknowledged that winning would mean an end to the battles she had fought to legalize divorce and contraception, and to make information available on abortion. She has said that she intends to open the sprawling presidential mansion to an array of interest groups. That invitation was open, she said, even to the Protestants of Northern Ireland, who reject any thought of unifying the island. Mrs. Robinson will be inaugurated Dec. 3, succeeding Patrick Hillery, who must retire after serving two seven-year terms. Prime Minister Charles Haughey congratulated Mrs. Robinson and pledged his support, but her victory was an embarrassment for his party and prompted talk of a challenge to his leadership. Lenihan led with 44.1 percent of the vote to 38.9 percent for Mrs. Robinson after the first round of counting. Since neither had a majority, the result turned on the second choices of the 17 percent who had voted for Austin Currie, the Fine Gael party's nominee. Nearly 85 percent of that vote went to Mrs. Robinson, who is an independent but was nominated by the Labor and Workers parties. The two parties had combined for only 14.7 percent of the vote in last year's parliamentary elections, and Mrs. Robinson was the first candidate from the left to win a presidential campaign. Fianna Fail had monopolized the office since 1945. The Irish Press, traditionally a Fianna Fail supporter, said the election ``signals a change in Irish society and a shift away from traditional attitudes and allegiances.'' In 20 years in the Irish senate and as an attorney, Mrs. Robinson battled church and state in efforts to legalize divorce and contraception. In Ireland's deeply conservative society, she was regarded as a radical. She won court cases to permit women to serve on juries, to overturn laws criminalizing homosexuality, to restore inheritance rights for illegitimate children and to give women legislators the same pension rights as their male colleagues. Contraceptives were made available by law to ``bona fide couples'' in 1979 and in 1985, to anyone over 18. However, the ban on divorce was upheld in a national referendum in 1986. Mrs. Robinson says she personally opposes abortion, but she recently represented students who sought to distribute information about the availability of abortion in Britain. Raised as a Roman Catholic, she defied her parents by marrying a Protestant, Nick Robinson, a fellow student at Trinity College. Robinson took three months off from his own legal practice to work in the campaign, which had been launched only after a favorable vote from their three children, Tessa, 18, William, 16, and Aubrey, 9.

DOC.HEAD: Young Farmers Adapt to Changes in Agriculture
By JOSEPH COLEMAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A national organization that has represented young farmers for more than a half century is making changes to adapt to an era of farmers with business suits and MBAs who work with computerized tractors. But some fear the spirit of the traditional farmer may be lost in the shuffle. Two years ago, to keep up with the times, Future Farmers of America updated its name to the National FFA Organization. This week, delegates at the organization's 63rd annual convention voted to reword the farmer's four-paragraph ``agriculture, education and citizenship'' creed to reflect changes in the industry. Among the changes, they replaced ``the future of farming'' with ``the future of agriculture,'' and ``rural America'' with ``American agriculture.'' ``Agriculture has changed in many ways,'' said C. Coleman Harris, the FFA national executive secretary. ``The farm operator has so many different people to deal with.'' Harris said the FFA was attempting to broaden a spotlight formerly focused only on farmers to encompass engineers, biotechnicians, business specialists and computer scientists. ``There are so many others that need to get under that umbrella,'' Harris said. But some members think changing the creed is going too far. ``They are cutting out the words `farmer' and the basis of farming,'' said David Bowles, 15, an FFA member from Sarasota, Fla. Eric Frederick, 27, an agriculture teacher at Marion County Technical Center in Farmington, W.Va., said he would rather see a new emphasis that incorporates changes in the industry without ignoring the old values. ``I don't agree with all of it,'' he said of the changes. Still, it was difficult to find anyone among the more than 20,000 members at the convention who said he was a farmer. The crowd was full of future veterinarians, businessmen and women, and fertilizer experts. Kevin Stone, 17, from Onita, Ill., works part-time in a grocery store while he prepares for a career as a businessman dealing in fertilizer and crops. ``It's not really the farming industry,'' Stone said. ``There are lots of jobs you can get without having a farming background.'' Even members who fit the mold of the traditional farmer acknowledged the changes technology has meant for farming. Mark Stalder, 17, of Junction City, Kan., was raised on his family's ranch without computers. He said working with new computerized tractors was ``like being born again.'' Stalder said he is taking courses in horticulture, crop production and animal and environmental science to prepare for his career as a farmer. But despite his fancy education, he said his parents won't have any trouble keeping him on the ranch. ``I was born there, and I plan on living there for the rest of my life,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: General Assembly Rejects Iraqi Attempt to Debate U.S. Buildup
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. panel rebuked Iraq on Friday by unanimously refusing to consider a resolution that would have denounced the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The Iraqi motion said the gulf crisis began Aug. 7, when U.S. forces began arriving in Saudi Arabia to counter Iraq's army. Iraq's draft did not even mention Kuwait, which it overran on Aug. 2 and has declared is its 19th province. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering called the Iraqi attempt to introduce the General Assembly resolution ``ill-founded, tendentious and mendacious.'' Pickering noted that Kuwait and Saudi Arabia invited Washington to send troops to defend them. The U.N. Charter's Article 51 allows nations to defend themselves against aggression either alone or with allies. The Iraqis tried to introduce the motion in the assembly's General Committee, a 29-member panel with broad geographic representation. The committee assigns items to the agenda and considers requests for new resolutions. Iraqi delegate Adnan Ahmed Mohammed said he had rewritten his speech to the committee since Thursday, when President Bush ordered 200,000 more U.S. troops be sent to the gulf to give the international force opposing Iraq an ``adequate offensive military option.'' The American move will nearly double the current U.S. strength. There are now 230,000 U.S. military personnel in the region. Allies from 26 other countries have sent about 70,000 of their own soldiers. Iraq has deployed an estimated 430,000 soldiers in Kuwait and southern Iraq since invading its oil-rich neighbor in a dispute over land, oil and money. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said a new Security Council resolution authorizing the use of military force would make the U.S. military buildup legal under the U.N. Charter: ``If it is in the context of Article 42, even though I would regret any recourse to force, it would be legitimate,'' he said. Diplomats in New York and U.S. officials in Washington have confirmed the United States has prepared a resolution that would authorize force under Article 42, but is waiting to introduce it until Secretary of State James A. Baker III has lined up enough support among U.S. allies on the Security Council. Mohammed, the Iraqi delegate, said Bush and U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ``blew the horns of war'' in announcing the dispatch of new Americans troops. He called it proof of the ``aggressive schemes against Iraq and the Arab nation.'' ``Are we approaching a catastrophe? Are we expecting a tragedy to take place?'' Mohammed asked. He accused the United States of thwarting any attempts at an Arab diplomatic solution. He said Washington had ignored Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 12 proposal that an Iraqi withdrawal be linked to establishment of a Palestinian homeland. Bush has rejected any specific conditions for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, but he has said other issues in dispute could be discussed after a pullout. In a scornful voice, Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad A. Abulhasan rejected the proposed Iraqi resolution. He said it was the ``Iraqi regime that launched an unjustified, unprovoked attack against Kuwait.'' Other delegates who assailed the Iraqi proposal were from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Britain, Senegal, Czechoslovakia, France, Honduras and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Seeking European Support for Possible Iraq Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Dumas comment, inserting new 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday neared the end of a trip seeking support for possible military action against Iraq, confident that Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Arab forces would fight alongside U.S. troops but less certain about France. A senior official on the trip said it was still unclear ``where the French would be.'' He commented as Baker headed into the trip's final leg, which included talks with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Friday and French President Francois Mitterrand on Saturday. He was also to meet in Paris with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who said in advance of the visit, ``The effort of France is real and second-largest after the U.S.A. ... This is very clear between the Americans and us.'' Thatcher, a staunch supporter, said after her meeting with Baker, ``Obviously, we stand absolutely together.'' She said no further U.N. authority would be needed to take military action against Kuwait but that she would back any U.S. move for additional support from the world body. Referring to the nations arrayed against Iraq on the issue of Kuwait, she said, ``We obviously would like to keep this coalition together and so we are considering how best to do that.'' Baker said before leaving Moscow for London on Friday that the Soviets were disappointed with the results of their overtures to Iraq and were no more optimistic than the United States about President Saddam Hussein reversing his invasion of Kuwait. After Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a special emissary to Baghdad in September and again last month, reports surfaced in Moscow that hopes of a negotiated settlement had been raised. But Baker effectively deflated such a hopeful impression of Yevgeny Primakov's mission. ``I don't think the Soviets are any more optimistic than we are about the willingness of Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait,'' Baker said. The senior U.S. official, commenting on condition of anonymity, said Primakov was ``basically stiffed'' by Iraq. And yet, the official said of Saddam: ``Everybody knows he has the capability to do a 180-degree (turnabout) on short notice.'' ``But I don't know whether his antennae will be set in a `receive' mode or not,'' the official said. ``We've seen no evidence in all of the diplomatic activity that's taken place, we've seen no evidence on the part of Saddam Hussein to even begin to comply with the United Nations resolutions. He added that Gorbachev shares that view. Nearing the end of Baker's eight-day mission to seven countries, the official said troops from Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Arab states in the Persian Gulf would fight alongside American forces in the event of a war to liberate Kuwait. He said Syria's participation, as well as France's, was uncertain. Despite a judgment that Syria fosters terrorism, the Bush administration has tried to engage President Hafez Assad in the alliance against Saddam. The Syrian leader offered up to 15,000 troops, but only about a third were sent to Saudi Arabia, where most of the allied force is deployed. The senior official said, however, that Syria might end up ``leading the charge'' against Iraq. Assad and Saddam Hussein head rival factions of the Baathist party and are bitter rivals. Syria stood alone among the larger Arab states in backing non-Arab Iran in its eight-year war with Iraq. When Baker left Washington last Saturday, one of his goals was to see whether the four nations who are permanent members of the U.N. Security Council along with the United States would support a resolution authorizing the use of force as a last resort to evict Iraq from Kuwait. Baker on Tuesday gained the acquiescence of Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Wichen and a reluctant commitment on Thursday from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Mrs. Thatcher's consent was a cinch, but Mitterrand, who has been urging a negotiated settlement, may be difficult to convince. Baker sees him Saturday in Paris. In light of the lukewarm reception on the journey, Baker said Thursday night he was not on a decision-making trip. On Friday, he said no resolution to use force was being prepared. Gorbachev, meanwhile, has urged that Saddam be approached through some kind of ``Arab mechanism,'' and he said recently there were ``now more arguments than ever in favor of saving the situation by using the Arab factor.'' On another subject, Baker said a treaty to cut non-nuclear weapons in Europe still was not finished. He said the main problem was failure to reach agreement with the Soviet Union on methods of verifying adherence to the treaty's provisions and how the casts of inspection would be apportioned. President Bush has said unless the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty was ready to be signed he would not attend a 34-nation summit meeting in Paris Nov. 19-21. Another nagging problem has concerned the forces the Soviets would be permitted to keep in the areas of Leningrad and Kiev. Baker and Shevardnadze agreed on terms near the end of their 13 hours of talks Thursday night.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Bill Requiring New Disclosures of Universities
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday signed legislation requiring colleges and universities to make public their graduation rates, campus security procedures and campus crime rates. The legislation applies to any institution participating in federal student aid programs. The institutions will have to certify to the Education Department that they have campus security policies and will have to distribute to students, prospective students and employees an annual report of crime statistics. The bill also requires that the colleges provide students and prospective students with graduation rates. The institutions must report to the education secretary, as of July 1993, on the numbers and graduation rates of students who receive athletic-related student aid. That information must be broken down by race, sex and sport. The schools also must provide this information to potential student athletes, their parents, guidance counselors and coaches.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Killed While Hanging Out Bus Window
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old girl heading home from a volleyball tournament was killed when she hit her head on a telephone pole while hanging out a bus window, police said Friday. Tylene Vega, a seventh-grader at Emerson Junior High School, died at St. Joseph's Hospital on Thursday night, said Detective Edward Oakley. She was hanging out the bus window talking to a friend when the accident occurred. The girl had attended a city-wide junior high school girl's volleyball tournament at Lincoln High School before the fatal accident, Oakley said. No charges were filed against the driver of the bus.

DOC.HEAD: Gov. Kay Orr Concedes Governor's Race to Nelson
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Kay Orr on Friday conceded the governor's race to Democrat Ben Nelson, pledging she would work with him. ``The counting of the absentee and disabled ballots has not significantly changed the balance of total votes in the gubernatorial election. Therefore, I am officially conceding the election to Mr. Nelson,'' Mrs. Orr said in a statement. Mrs. Orr was out of the state on a previously planned vacation and was not expected to return until Thursday, said Cindy Evert, a spokeswoman for the governor. Nelson defeated Mrs. Orr, the nation's first Republican woman elected governor, in Tuesday's election by 4,658 votes in unofficial returns, not including absentee ballots. County officials continued to work Friday on counting absentee ballots and canvassing the tallies to certify the vote. But the absentee vote count appeared to follow election night patterns.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards More Than $77 Million for Brain-Damaged Boy
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded $77.8 million to a couple whose baby was left paralyzed, mute and partially blind after he was given an overdose of medicine at one hospital and an overdose of an antidote at another. Stephen and Mary Blake of Skokie also were awarded $135,000 in past medical expenses for their son, Andrew, now 5. A Cook County Circuit jury returned the decision Thursday against Mead Johnson and Co., a subsidiary of Bristol-Myers Squibb; Ravenswood Hospital Medical Center; Children's Memorial Hospital; and Dr. Metta Wongsarnpigoon. Judge Charles Durham said the award was a record for Illinois. ``We are delighted with the award. It will provide for Andrew's future,'' said Jerome Mirza, the Blakes' attorney. ``Our lawyers are in the process of reviewing the verdict and we would not comment while it is under review,'' Bristol-Myers Squibb said in a statement Friday. A Children's Memorial statement expressed sympathy for the Blakes, but didn't say whether the hospital would appeal. Telephone calls to Ravenswood were not immediately returned Friday. Directory assistance did not have a listing for Wongsarnpigoon. The boy is paralyzed from his shoulders to his feet and requires nursing care at least eight hours a day. The Blakes' lawyers had argued that dosage information Mead Johnson provided for its expectorant Quibron was excessive and outdated and caused Wongsarnpigoon, a pediatrician at Ravenswood, to give Andrew an overdose. He had been hospitalized at Ravenswood for bronchiolitis and possible asthma in January 1986. After the overdose, the boy - then 3 months old - started having seizures, lawyers said. He was transferred to Children's Memorial, where he was given Charcoaid, a prepacked mixture of charcoal and the anti-poison drug sorbitol. The child received a massive overdose of sorbitol, became dehydrated and suffered cardiac arrest and brain damage, according to testimony in the six-week trial. The jury found the maker of Charcoaid - Requa Inc. of Greenwich, Conn. - innocent of liability. ``We're thrilled that they recognized that the product was safe,'' Requa attorney Joan Levin said. She said the company had argued that labeling on the product was printed ``exactly per the requirements of the Food and Drug Administration - no more, no less.''

DOC.HEAD: Fence Removed from Steam Grate
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department has dropped a plan to stop homeless people from sleeping on a steam grate just yards from the street entrance to the office of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Workers recently removed a partially constructed fence around the steam grate. The fence drew protests in September from homeless people and their advocates. The day of the protest, someone drove off with the iron gate, which had not been installed by workmen. Until this week, the fence had stood without the gate. That allowed homeless people to continue to sleep atop the grate, which covers a vent to a steam tunnel that runs between the Justice Department and several adjacent government buildings. Workmen planted holly bushes around the grate before removing the uncompleted fence. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said the fence was to be installed as a security measure. ``The attorney general never thought it was a good idea,'' Eramian said, adding that Thornburgh didn't know about plans to build it until the day of the protest. A department source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said an alternative measure had been taken to prevent anyone from entering the steam tunnel.

DOC.HEAD: Protestant Force Claims it Killed Roman Catholic
DOC.TEXT: An outlawed Protestant paramilitary group said Friday its gunmen had killed a Roman Catholic man. In a statement to the British domestic news agency, Press Association, the Ulster Volunteer Force said four of its men shot Malachy McIvor, in his early 40s, in a garage Thursday night in Stewartstown, East Tyrone county. ``This war is not being waged against the Catholic community, but against the Provisional IRA and until they cease their campaign of genocide against the loyalist people, the war will continue,'' the statement said. The mainly Catholic Irish Republican Army is fighting to end British rule and unite the province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland under a leftist administration. Various Protestant groups oppose the IRA. Police said McIvor had no known links with any paramilitary group and appeared t be the victim of a random sectarian attack.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Whip Through Northwest; Thunderstorms Hit Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Winds whipped through the Pacific Northwest on Friday, and thunderstorms rumbled through the Southeast. High wind warnings were posted for the eastern slopes and the upper Yellowstone Valley of Montana, southeast Wyoming and eastern Washington state. Winds reached 46 mph Friday morning at Othello, Wash., 70 mph at Rawlins, Wyo., and 78 mph between Cheyenne and Laramie, Wyo. Winds damaged trees and caused power outages near Spokane, Wash. Strong, gusty winds developed and advisories for blowing snow were posted over the mountains in northern Colorado. Advisories also were posted for the northern mountain passes of Colorado because of the gusty winds, snowpacked roads and poor visibility in the blowing and drifting snow. A flood warning was posted for parts of northwest Washington state, where more than four inches of rain fell across the area overnight. Several more inches of rain were expected. Flood watches were posted for the foothills and Piedmont of South Carolina, and for the northeast Georgia mountains. Showers and thunderstorms extended over the Florida panhandle into southern Alabama, as well as parts of Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee, the Carolinas, Virginia and West Virginia, Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana and Lower Michigan. Rain also fell across northwest Montana, the Idaho panhandle, the coast of Washington state, and north-central California. Snow fell in northern Lower Michigan and Upper Michigan. Freezing rain was scattered in northeast Montana. Freezing rain produced a layer of ice near Glasgow, Mont., and advisories were posted for slippery roads. The nation's low Friday morning was 5 degrees at Alamosa, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 30 degrees at Glasgow, Mont., to 88 at Fort Myers airport in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Would-be Raisa Watchers Dogged by News Hounds
With AM-Germany-Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev stepped out of the sleek, black limousine Friday and she soon disappeared into an army of photographers. Instead of getting a good look at one of the world's most famous women, many well-wishers went home grumbling about freedom of the press. ``This is scandalous!'' yelled an elderly lady struggling to see Mrs. Gorbachev. ``It's not right the press gets to see Raisa and we ordinary people don't,'' said the woman, who would only identify herself as Gisela. A police officer trying to clear a path for Mrs. Gorbachev shrugged and said, ``That's freedom of the press.'' ``Freedom for whom? Not for us!'' the woman retorted. Mrs. Gorbachev visited Linz, a picturesque little city on the Rhine River, while her husband, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was meeting about 20 miles away in Bonn with Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Her rousing welcome reflected her husband's immense popularity in Germany. The side trip by Mrs. Gorbachev was announced at the last moment. City officials got just a few hours notice. ``We were driving down the autobahn and heard about this on the radio,'' said one onlooker, Helmut Bittner of Leverkusen. ``Of course we would rather see Mikhail, but this visit is important too,'' said Bittner. With Mrs. Gorbachev about to arrive, Bittner exuded enthusiasm for the Soviet leader, saying Kohl should promise plenty of financial aid to Gorbachev. ``We cannot forget we have Gorbachev to thank for unification,'' said Bittner. ``It's in our interest that the Soviet Union remains stable. How would anyone feel if we woke up tomorrow and a general had taken Gorbachev's place?'' said Bittner. He was in a crowd of several hundred standing in near-freezing air on the square in front of Linz's 600-year-old city hall. Mrs. Gorbachev's Zil limousine showed up about 40 minutes late. Despite the delay, the throng remained in the hope of seeing her. When her car finally arrived, she surprised everyone by telling her chauffeur to stop short of the city hall. Dressed in a grey winter coat, Mrs. Gorbachev went right to the throng, showing some of her husband's celebrated zest for working the crowd. Cheers rang out. But a legion of photographers and camera teams soon engulfed her. Security men shoved photographers and reporters aside, who in turn fell against Mrs. Gorbachev's well-wishers or stepped on their toes. Mrs. Gorbachev then disappeared inside the city hall, where she signed Linz's guest book. Most of her most ardent admirers, however, were stuck outside.

DOC.HEAD: Arguments Given in Key Insider Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: Government lawyers urged a federal appeals court Friday to reverse an important insider trading ruling because it would hamper their ability to prosecute certain securities violations. The arguments before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals followed a decision overturning the conviction of a stockbroker charged with trading on inside information about the 1986 takeover of the Waldbaum supermarket chain. Federal prosecutors have asked the court to reverse the ruling, which found there was insufficient evidence to show that the information the broker received from a member of the Waldbaum family was confidential. ``We believe this will open a gaping hole by providing an essential safe harbor of trading by family members,'' SEC attorney Paul Gonson said. Gonson's presentation included a lively debate with one of the judges over why the SEC had never fully defined insider trading. ``Why doesn't the SEC promulgate a rule that tells all of us what you think insider trading is?'' asked Judge Jon O. Newman. ``How are the people in the investment community supposed to know?'' Gonson said the SEC had tried to formulate a definition, but had failed. ``The commission attempted this over a long period of time, but decided it was better to leave it to be developed on a case-by-case basis,'' Gonson said. All 12 judges of the court sat Friday to consider reversing the 2-1 decision issued May 2 by three of their other colleagues. The hearing, called an ``en banc'' proceeding, is the last vehicle of appeal in the federal judiciary before a case is taken to the U.S. Supreme Court. The appeals court did not issue a decision Friday. Chestman, a former broker with Gruntals & Co., was convicted last year of a series of crimes as a result of trades the government said he made after receiving privileged information about A&P's takeover of Waldbaum Inc. The government had charged that Chestman learned of the planned takeover from one of his clients, Keith Loeb, a nephew by marriage to Waldbaum's founder, Ira Waldbaum. Evidence at trial showed that Loeb learned about the deal from his wife, who in turn heard it from her mother, who was told by her brother, Ira Waldbaum. Chestman's attorney, Elkan Abramowitz, said the earlier decision should stand because there was no proof to show that Chestman knew Loeb was privy to the company's business secrets. ``Not every conversation in a family situation is a breach of fiduciary duty if revealed,'' Abramowitz said. ``In absence of a breach of fiduciary duty, there can be no fraud.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney David Brodsky, however, claimed that all the Waldbaum family members in the chain of communication knew the information about the takeover was confidential, and that Chestman, too, knew he was breaking the law. ``Chestman knew exactly what was happening. He was getting non-public information from Loeb,'' Brodsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Celebrate First Anniversary of Wall's Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with few attending ceremonies, quotes, color, trims. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER3,4,5
DOC.TEXT: Germany marked the anniversary of the Berlin Wall's collapse Friday, but some among the shivering crowds at ceremonies said the joy of the event had faded because of pressing economic problems. Friday was also the 52nd anniversary of the nocturnal rampage against Jewish homes, businesses and synagogues that foreshadowed the Holocaust. In East Berlin, about 3,000 Jews attended a commemoration of the Nov. 9, 1938 Crystal Night pogrom, named for the shattered glass left by Nazi thugs. A monument to German reunification - a four-foot-square section of the dismantled wall - was unveiled at one of the border crossing points where thousands of East Germans streamed across last year in unheard-of freedom. The monument was inscribed with the message: ``Berliners came together again.'' But in contrast to the wild celebrations that began spontaneously on Nov. 9, 1989, events for the first anniversary drew smallish crowds. Newspapers printed sober editorials about the problems of unemployment in the economically stunted former communist part of Germany, which officially united Oct. 3. ``It's true a whole new world has opened up for us,'' said East Berliner Erika Brut. ``One wants to celebrate, but there are so many problems.'' She and her husband, Thorsten Brut, 42, a teacher, were among a few hundred people shivering in near-freezing weather late Friday on Marx-Engels Square in East Berlin to watch a documentary of last year's wall opening. ``Looking at the pictures, it all seems so long ago. Our lives have changed completely in the last 12 months,'' Brut said. The main symbol of the former division of Berlin and Germany, the Brandenburg Gate, was busy with a flea-market atmosphere of rows of tables offering everything from Soviet army caps to chips of the wall for sale. But the wall on which last year's celebration occurred is gone. Six sections of it stand on a nearby square so visitors can see what it looked like. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose policies allowed the Soviet client governments of Eastern Europe to crumble, was greeted Friday in Bonn with a hero's welcome. Gorbachev and Chancellor Helmut Kohl signed a 20-year treaty of friendship and cooperation. Grateful German leaders said they hoped they could help Gorbachev solve the Soviet Union's desperate problems. Berlin's Jewish community for the first time held its main commemoration of Crystal Night in the splendid Ryke Street synagogue, in a working-class neighborhood of East Berlin. Heinz Galinski, leader of the Central Council of German Jews, said the significance of the wall's opening ``remains a half-truth if it conceals the earlier imprinted meaning of the date.'' ``And half-truths are not a good foundation for building a healthy future.'' Galinski said Germans have never acknowledged fully the horrible events that started on Kristallnacht. Six million Jews had died by the time World War II ended in 1945 and Germany lay in ruins and partition. Germany had 540,000 Jews before the war but only 30,000 now, Galinski said. He recalled the words of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, one of the American military commanders in Berlin: ``Democracy in Germany will be measured by the extent Jews can live there.'' West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper, unveiling the wall monument at Bornholmer Bridge, also referred to the memory of Crystal Night, but concentrated on the immediate past and the future. ``For Germans, Nov. 9, 1989, was the happiest day in the postwar era. Those who witnessed it will never forget,'' said the Social Democrat. Momper will share the mayoralty with his East Berlin counterpart, Tino Swierzina, until elections on Dec. 2 when unified Germany holds its first parliamentary elections. The Bundesrat, the upper house of Germany's parliament, met in Berlin on Friday for the first time in 31 years, joined by newly elected representatives from the five eastern states created when East Germany joined the West. The rapid pace toward unification has thrust the nation into a host of new problems. Lawmakers are faced with rising unemployment in former East Germany and claims on property by Germans who fled before the wall was erected in 1962. The subject of who deserves credit for the spontaneous opening of the wall is still a point of debate. While East Germany's former Communist rulers have claimed some responsibility, it was not clear whether their Nov. 9 decision to permit freedom of travel meant freedom to emigrate permanently or also permission to have unhindered contact with the West. Last week, a report in the former official Communist newspaper, Neues Deutschland, said medium-level security officers decided on their own to let the pressing crowds through the wall, fearing border guards would be killed otherwise. ``It was the thousands of East Berliners who gathered at the border crossing and demanded to be let through,'' Momper said. ``The power of the individual defeated the system of oppression in former East Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: Former CIA Agent Testifies To Iran-Contra Grand Jury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to add no comment from Fernandez lawyer; SUBS last graf to add sentence on others pleading guilty, specify North conviction on aiding and abetting
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (P) - A former CIA station chief testified Friday to a federal grand jury about his involvement in the secret Contra resupply operation of former White House aide Oliver North. Joseph Fernandez was subpoenaed by Iran-Contra prosecutors who are trying to piece together the precise roles in the affair played by Ronald Reagan, George Bush and key officials at the CIA, the State Department and the Pentagon. Reagan and Bush have said they didn't know North was overseeing a private resupply network during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels in 1985 and 1986. Independent counsel Lawrence Walsh is trying to determine if their denials are truthful, say sources outside the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office who are familiar with the four-year investigation. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for Walsh's office, refused to comment on Fernandez's appearance or on any aspect of the probe. Tom Wilson, a lawyer representing the former CIA station chief, also declined to comment. Fernandez was compelled to testify under a court order granting him immunity from prosecution in exchange for his testimony. The former CIA station chief in Costa Rica had faced criminal charges of lying and obstruction to hide his involvement with North's operation, but the Bush administration blocked the case from going to trial last year. In 1985 and 1986, Fernandez acted as a go-between for North and the Contras fighting in southern Nicaragua. As the head of CIA operations in Costa Rica, he passed along information to pave the way for air drops of weapons and assisted on an airstrip construction project in Costa Rica that was to be part of the North network. Fernandez also discussed the airstrip project with Elliott Abrams, the assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs who met frequently with North. Fernandez's CIA superiors told Congress in 1987 that they hadn't been aware of all his activities on behalf of North. Fernandez contradicted them, telling congressional investigators he kept the agency informed at all times of precisely what he was doing and for whom. If his case had gone to trial, Fernandez was prepared to show that CIA stations and facilities in Honduras and El Salvador were ``all deeply involved in ... the resupply operation,'' according to a recent federal appeals court decision and court papers filed in the case. In court papers, Fernandez said he would have shown ``who at the CIA supported the resupply operation, how they did it, where they did it, why they did it, and who else at the CIA knew about it.'' One period Walsh's investigators are focusing on is October 1986, according to the sources. On Oct. 5 of that year, a resupply plane in North's network was shot down over Nicaragua, triggering a political firestorm on Capitol Hill and threatening to expose the operation. Reagan, Abrams and others in the administration stated categorically that the U.S. government had no connection to the shot-down flight. Abrams later said he found out from the CIA nearly three weeks after the shootdown that there was a U.S. government connection to the flight. Walsh's grand jury probe began last May. North has testified at least half a dozen times and former national security adviser John Poindexter at least twice. Also testifying was G. Philip Hughes, a former aide to Bush when he was vice president and now U.S. ambassador to Barbados. Walsh has said the grand jury probe may produce additional indictments. North was convicted of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, destroying documents and accepting an illegal gratuity in the scandal, but a federal appeals court panel set aside the conviction. Poindexter was convicted in April of conspiracy, two counts of obstruction and two counts of making false statements. He is appealing. Six other people have entered guilty pleas or been convicted in jury trials in the affair.

DOC.HEAD: Family Concerned About Health of Freed Columbus Man
With AM-Gulf-Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: The family of Miles Hoffman, who was shot in the arm by Iraqi troops in Kuwait and held at a chemical plant near Baghdad, said Friday they were elated that the 33-year-old financial analyst has been freed. ``The first order of business will be to take care of that arm,'' said Hoffman's brother, Chancellor. ``He needs to get to the hospital.'' Hoffman was one of three Americans and 174 other Westerners who flew to freedom in Germany on Friday after talks between Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. They had been detained since Iraqi forces overran Kuwait Aug. 2. Hoffman's family said he was shot when Iraqi soldiers tried to force their way into his Kuwait City apartment on Sept. 5. The bullet shattered a bone in his left forearm and he was hospitalized for about a week. He was later held at a strategic chemical plant 45 miles south of Baghdad, they said. Westerners in Iraq have been used as ``human shields'' to deter attack by the U.S.-led multinational forces stationed in the Persian Gulf. Hoffman, 33, a financial analyst with the Kuwaiti government, wore a cast on his arm and appeared to be in pain. Some reports said gangrene had developed from the wound. ``It's just marvelous. It's just wonderful,'' Hoffman's mother, Ann, said of his release. Mrs. Hoffman said she wasn't planning a welcome home party just yet. ``If he wants one, we'll have one,'' she said. Mrs. Hoffman said her son probably will have other things on his mind, such as getting a job. ``He'll do exactly what he wants to do,'' she said. ``But I don't think he'll stay here.'' Hoffman's British fiancee, 27-year-old Nicola Murgatroyd, was scheduled to arrive in Baghdad on Friday. Ms. Murgatroyd, who had planned to marry Hoffman Aug. 17, was among 11 British women who traveled to Baghdad Friday to seek the release of their captive husbands and relatives - against the advice of their government. The British Foreign Office advised the women against going and called the trip ``risky,'' but they ignored the advice. Mrs. Hoffman, who wrote several letters to Saddam urging her son's release, said she doesn't know Ms. Murgatroyd's whereabouts or whether she knows Hoffman has been released. ``We're all thinking about Nikki,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Villagers Riot over Plans for Nuclear Waste Dump
LaserPhoto SEL2
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo fired a Cabinet minister and a provincial police chief on Friday after thousands of villagers rioted to protest government plans to build a nuclear waste dump. It was the nation's most violent anti-nuclear protest - with about 22 people reported injured - and officials said plans would be scuttled for a waste disposal facility on scenic Anmyon Island, 90 miles southwest of Seoul. By late Friday, about 3,000 riot police had fanned out to restore order among the 50,000 residents. Police said 73 people were under arrest for inciting Thursday's violence, when at least 10,000 men, women and schoolchildren attacked government facilities and police vehicles with firebombs, rocks and clubs. Television news showed men in business suits, laborers, elderly women and young children jabbing fists in the air at an anti-nuclear rally. Many wore headbands and sashes with anti-government, anti-nuclear slogans. Four government officials, six police officers and about a dozen residents were injured, some seriously, news reports said. A police station was burned to the ground and two vehicles were destroyed, reports said. Roh named Kim Jin-hyon, 56, a managing director of the Dong-A Ilbo newspaper, to succeed Chung Kun-mo as minister of science and technology, and he named a new chief police officer for the island. In Korea, public officials traditionally are fired and held responsible for social unrest over government policies in their jurisdiction. ``People are fearful of nuclear power and appear to misunderstand nuclear waste,'' Chung said before leaving the Cabinet. About 2,500 riot police firing tear gas launched a pre-dawn attack Friday to recapture local government offices and police stations bombarded by firebombs and rocks during the night. Police used tear gas again in the afternoon when hundreds of villagers tried to rally. Protesters shouted anti-government, anti-nuclear slogans. Witnesses said the situation appeared under control late in the day. Hundreds of firebombs, anti-government placards, leaflets and containers of paint thinner were confiscated Friday, police said. About half the island shops and businesses were closed. Telephones were out of order most of the day. News reports said most students stayed away from classes Friday. Dozens of residents staged a sit-in at town offices demanding the release of jailed residents, reports said. South Korea has nine nuclear power plants in operation and plans to build more. The government has said it will run out of storage facilities for tons of nuclear waste by 1994. Past protests involved minor clashes or peaceful rallies. Other communities had successfully protested plans for a nuclear waste dump. The plans for Anmyon Island were not made public, but apparently involved both a waste dump and research facility. A newspaper first reported the plans early in the week and islanders immediately began protests, which initially were peaceful. Anmyon is a picturesque coastal island in the Yellow Sea and plans exist to develop it into a tourist resort area. A causeway connects it to the mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Hearing to Decide if Philippines and Marcos Reached Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A dispute over whether there is a settlement in a racketeering lawsuit brought against Imelda Marcos by the Philippine government will go to a hearing next month, a federal judge ruled Friday. The lawsuit is an attempt by the Philippines to recover some of the billions of dollars the government of President Corazon Aquino alleges was stolen during two decades of rule by the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Mrs. Marcos' attorney claims the government agreed to settle in exchange for 60 percent of funds in Hong Kong bank accounts controlled by the former first lady. The amount of the accounts was not revealed. The Philippine government claims that only the groundwork for settlement has been laid, but there is no settlement yet. If the agreement is carried out, it would be the first known settlement between the government and the Marcoses. U.S. District Judge Mariana Pfaelzer scheduled the evidentiary hearing for Dec. 10, saying it was necessary because documents submitted by both sides did not prove conclusively there was an agreement. ``I don't believe there now is a settlement unless you have the witnesses to testify,'' she told Mrs. Marcos' attorney, James P. Linn. ``Our position is that we have an agreement and that the court should enforce it,'' Linn said. He said among depositions he hoped to present would be one from Mrs. Aquino. Attorney Ronald Olson, representing the Philippines, said, ``We're prepared to put our witnesses up to deny the existence of an agreement.'' Mrs. Marcos came to court but did not make any statements. Outside court, she tearfully complained to reporters that she was tired of her legal battles and wanted to return to her homeland with her husband's body, which is in Hawaii. The Philippine government has refused to let Mrs. Marcos or her husband's remains return. Mrs. Marcos said she has no idea how much money is in the Hong Kong accounts and maintained that there was indeed a settlement agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Kahane Follower Suspected of Revenge Killing of Elderly Arabs
DOC.TEXT: A court on Friday ordered a follower of slain Rabbi Meir Kahane held for five days on suspicion he killed two elderly Palestinians in the occupied West Bank to avenge the extremist rabbi's death. A judge of the Kfar Saba Magistrates Court in suburban Tel Aviv ordered the continued detention of Ben Zion Gobstein, police spokeswoman Ruth Shlezinger said. Gobstein was detained Thursday with two other members of Kahane's anti-Arab Kach movement in connection with the shooting deaths of a Palestinian man and woman, both in their 60s. The two other Kach members were released Friday, Ms. Shlezinger said. They were identified as David Cohen and David Axelrod, a great-grandson of the Russian revolutionary leader Leon Trotsky. All three lived in Kfar Tapuah, a Jewish settlement about four miles north of the Palestinian village of Lubban Sharqiyah where the two Arabs were slain Tuesday morning. In Jerusalem, police and the army blocked Palestinians from the occupied territories from attending Friday prayers at the Al Aqsa mosque. The army also ordered Palestinians in the West Bank not to travel outside their towns and villages, apart from Bethlehem and Ramallah, two large cities near Jerusalem. Widespread curfews were imposed in the Gaza Strip, confining 150,000 Palestinians to their homes. The measures were aimed at preventing vengeance attacks in the still-tense atmosphere following Kahane's slaying by an Arab-American in New York on Monday. Hundreds of police reinforcements were deployed near the Temple Mount, site of the Al Aqsa and Dome of the Rock mosques. It is known in Arabic as Haram es-Sharif, or the Noble Sanctuary. The raised platform is the third holiest place in Islam, and the adjacent Western Wall - commonly known in the West as the Wailoing Wall - is the holiest site in Judaism. As a result of the precautions, fewer than 7,500 Palestinians took part in the Friday prayers. Police reported no incidents. Meanwhile, Palestinians in the occupied areas observed the second day of a general strike commemorating the 36th month of their uprising against Israeli occupation. In the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian accused of collaborating with the Israeli authorities was killed by fellow Arabs in the Shati refugee camp. Fuad Hassan Abdallah, 25, was beaten and strangled to death with an electric cord, Arab reports said. His death raised to 296 the number of Palestinians killed by other Arabs since the uprising began in December 1987. Most were accused of collaboration with Israel. At least 773 Arabs have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians in the revolt. Fifty-two Israelis also have died. A Jerusalem Magistrates Court judge, meanwhile, ordered the leader of Kahane's Kach party, Yekutiel Ben-Yaakov, freed from jail. He had been held on suspicion of incitement after calling on mourners at Kahane's funeral to avenge his death. Israeli newspapers in Friday weekend editions focused on concerns over the climate of political violence in the country. The daily Maariv said ``the devil of hatred and fear'' had been released with Kahane's death. ``Kahanism is not dead,'' warned Kol Hair, a Jerusalem weekly.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Hits Hezbollah Bases in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Israeli forces on Friday destroyed bases of the Shiite Moslem Hezbollah militia north of Israel's buffer zone in south Lebanon, a day after the Jewish state pledged to guarantee the safety of Lebanese Christians there. The army command said a combined force of tanks, artillery and the elite infantry unit Givati hit its targets and returned safely. It had no information on possible Hezbollah casualties. The army said the bases were near Jaba, Kfar Milki and Mazraat Ayn Abu Siwar, from five to eight miles west of the Christian town of Jezzine and about 12 miles from the northern tip of Israel's self-proclaimed buffer zone. The area is controlled by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia. The army said the bases were used ``for organizing and launching attacks'' against Israeli troops and the SLA. Israel has become concerned about the situation in southern Lebanon after rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's fall in Beirut last month. Jezzine fears Moslem militias pushed out of Beirut by the government could move southward and threaten the town. Another fear is Lebanese President Elias Hrawi's plan to implement a Syrian-backed peace accord designed to restore government control over the war-torn nation, including the buffer zone. On a visit Thursday to south Lebanon, Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens promised the Israeli army will protect Jezzine, army radio said.

DOC.HEAD: Germany, Soviet Union Renounce Force, Pledge Cooperation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from state dinner, German in Linz, minor editing. No pickup. ^With AM-Germany-Anniversary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed an historic non-aggression treaty with united Germany on Friday and won praise from German leaders for his role in the peaceful fal of the Berlin Wall. Gorbachev's first visit to united Germany coincided with the one-year anniversary of the opening of the wall and came just five weeks after East Germany, Moscow's longtime Warsaw Pact ally, merged into the new Germany. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Gorbachev stressed the importance of the changes that have allowed closer ties between Bonn and Moscow as they signed the broad agreement that is to serve as the basis of future relations. But the Soviet Union's huge internal troubles were also part of talks between the two leaders. After a state dinner for Gorbachev late Friday, the head of Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest company, said emergency deliveries of food and clothing to the Soviet Union may be needed this winter. ``Everyone is awaiting a very difficult, terrible and hard winter,'' Daimler-Benz chief Edzard Reuter said of the situation in the Soviet Union. ``There must be immediate help.'' In the treaty, initialed in Moscow on Sept. 13, both nations pledged not to attack the other and to honor the borders of all European nations. ``We are closing the book on the painful past and clearing the way for a new beginning,'' Kohl said in a speech at the signing ceremony. After a short-lived alliance, Germany attacked the Soviet Union at the start of World War II. About 26 million Soviets were killed. The new non-aggression treaty, one of three signed Friday, replaces agreements that once linked the Soviet Union to West Germany and East Germany. Moscow's ties to East Germany long hindered better relations with Bonn. ``I have you to thank Mr. President, for the decisive contribution so that Germany, our fatherland, could unify on Oct. 3 in peace and freedom and in agreement with all its neighbors,'' Kohl said at a joint news conference with Gorbachev. President Richard von Weizsaecker said the fall of the Berlin Wall, which paved the way for unity, ``would not have been possible'' without Gorbachev's political reforms. Earlier in the day, Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, stopped to chat with a crowd waiting for him outside the government's Villa Hammerschmidt palace next to the Rhine River. But the crowds were far smaller than those that swarmed around the Soviet leader during his triumphant visit to Bonn in June 1989. Still, some Germans exuded enthusiam for Gorbachev and his achievements. ``We cannot forget we have Gorbachev to thank for unification,'' said Helmut Bittner of Leverkusen. ``It's in our interest that the Soviet Union remains stable. How would anyone feel if we woke up tomorrow and a general had taken Gorbachev's place?'' Bittner added. He was in a crowd of several hundred standing in near-freezing air in front of Linz's city hall waiting for Gorbachev's wife to arrive on her own side trip. The dramatic retreat of Communism and the dismantling of the Iron Curtain the past year has radically altered relations between the Soviet Union and Germany. Gorbachev relinquished Moscow's powerful role in German affairs this summer when he agreed to a unified Germany's membership in NATO. Germany's Western European allies have reacted skeptically to the growing relationship between Germany and the Soviet Union, remembering the devastating consequences of cooperation between Adolf Hitler and Joseph Stalin. Gorbachev sought to allay such concerns. ``The Soviet-German treaty is not directed at anyone. Our agreement and cooperation are part of the ongoing construction of the all-European house,'' Gorbachev said in a speech before the treaty was signed. Now Gorbachev needs substantial foreign economic assistance to bolster his political position and holdthe splintering Soviet Union together. Kohl gave Gorbachev a boost saying he wanted ``the reform policy of the Soviet Union that is linked with the name Mikhail S. Gorbachev to be successful.'' The German leader pledged further aid in his dinner speech. ``In view of the painful but unavoidable transition, we are prepared with words and deed to help further,'' Kohl said without announcing specifics. Gorbachev directly appealed for aid in his speech. ``From you (Germans), we would like courage, generosity ... and a healthy readiness for risk.'' The non-aggression treaty, the major agreement, makes Germany the Soviet Union's largest trading partner within the European Economic Community. The Soviet Union already has received a commitment of $19.5 billion this year from the German government and German banks. But private investors are reluctant to invest as political instability mounts in the Soviet Union. Germany is trying to cope with the presence of about 600,000 Soviet soldiers and their families still stationed on former East German territory. Despite the unrest at home, Gorbachev was all smiles when he emerged from his Ilyushin 62 at Cologne-Bonn airport and was greeted by a 27-member German military honor guard. He was met by German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and later met with Weizsaecker at the government's palace. Gorbachev is to visit Kohl's home state of Rhineland-Palatinate on Saturday before returning to Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: France Remembers de Gaulle's Death 20 Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: France commemorated the 20th anniversary of Charles de Gaulle's death Friday with a respect and affection that eluded the former war hero and president in his final years. Throughout the country, religious services, exhibitions, symposiums, television programs and plays paid tribute to de Gaulle as leader of French resistance to Nazi occupation and founder of the current constitutional system with its strong president. In contrast to his sometimes tempestuous presidency from 1959 to 1969, De Gaulle now is admired by Frenchmen of all political persuasions. A poll published Thursday in the newspaper Le Monde said 84 percent of the respondents believe de Gaulle's record in office was ``positive.'' The near-universal admiration contrasts with the general's last years, when students and workers rioted in the streets. De Gaulle's unpopularity culminated in a humiliating defeat at the polls in 1969 and drove him from the presidency. Nineteen months later, on Nov. 9, 1970, while playing solitaire at his home in Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises, de Gaulle suffered a ruptured aneurism and died. The following afternoon his son, Philippe, went on television to announce, ``General de Gaulle is dead, France is a widow.'' Only his family, close wartime colleagues and villagers attended his funeral on Nov. 12, while dozens of heads of state attended ceremonies at Notre Dame cathedral in Paris. Today, it is hard to find de Gaulle bashers. One exception is ``Recours-France,'' (Help-France) an organization of former French residents of North Africa, many of whom lost everything when France embarked on decolonization. ``For the French from Algeria ... he will forever be regarded as the man who betrayed, mislead and abandoned us, without ever pronouncing a single word of compassion for our tragic exodus,'' the organization said in a statement Friday. At the start of the Algerian revolution, de Gaulle pledged to maintain French rule. He later granted independence to end the bloodshed. Many ardent leftists have become de Gaulle admirers. Regis Debray, a former adviser to Socialist President Francois Mitterrand, described de Gaulle as ``the last great man of the 19th century and the first great man of the 21st.'' In a new book, ``A Demain de Gaulle,'' (Tomorrow, de Gaulle) Debray - once a leading exponent of guerrilla warfare and a champion of the late Che Guevara - paid homage to the general's traditionalist values. Mitterrand himself paid tribute Friday, sending his army chief to lay a wreath at de Gaulle's tomb in Colombey-les-deux-Eglises. Exhibitions and documentaries abound, including one on De Gaulle's manipulation of the media for political purposes. Alain Peyrefitte, De Gaulle's information minister, has said De Gaulle himself edited television newscasts and used the media ``as an instrument of power.'' This month also marks the first time De Gaulle's life and achievements have been presented in fiction. Based on a forgotten scenario by William Faulkner, one of de Gaulle's most fervent admirers, director Denys Granier-Deferre has made a TV movie recounting the war years. A lesser-known side of de Gaulle is depicted in ``Villa Luco,'' a play about de Gaulle's secret visit to elderly, ailing Marshall Philippe Petain, condemned to life imprisonment for collaborating with the Nazis. This year also marks the 100th anniversary of de Gaulle's birth and the 50th anniversary of his famed radio appeal from London for Frenchmen to resist the Nazis.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Shows Videotape of Temple Mount Incident
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Liberation Organization on Friday showed the Security Council a dramatic videotape of the violence on Temple Mount last month when at least 20 Palestinians were killed by Israeli gunfire. The grainy film showed Palestinians fleeing Israeli gunfire on the eastern side of the plateau near the Al Aksa Mosque. The 15-minute tape was punctuated by gunfire, smoke and screams. Some of the 15 council members appeared to grimace at the events. M. Nasser Al-Kidwa, the PLO representative to the United Nations, told the council the tape ``shows premeditated Israeli determination to cause the largest possible number of dead and wounded among Palestinian civilians.'' The PLO showed the tape to support its call for the Security Council to deploy U.N. military observers to protect Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories and in East Jerusalem. Israel has rejected the demand, saying the presence of a U.N. observer group in the occupied lands would violate its sovereignty. Al-Kidwa said the tape was taken by ``a non-Palestinian neutral person ... a Westerner who happened to be in Jerusalem.'' The photographer was not identified. Al-Kidwa said the film was shot from the Mount of Olives facing east and did not support Israeli charges that the violence was provoked by Palestinians throwing stones at Jews praying at the Western Wall. He said it also repudiated Israeli charges that the violence had been incited by bellicose calls by Moslems over loudspeakers. The PLO provided what it said were translations from Arabic of appeals made from the mosque, appealing to Israeli forces to stop firing and to allow amublances, doctors and nurses to tend to the injured. ``Restrain yourselves, rise to your responsibility if you have any sense of reason,'' said one cleric in a mosque.
