Later, Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov told reporters the tape was damaging and undermined Israel's argument that the violence had been provoked by Palestinians throwing stones at Jewish worshipers. ``One element was very vivid, that there was no planning in the movements of the Palestinians. They were running in all directions and that was not some kind of planned attack on the Israelis. ``And of course the sound, the sound of so many shots fired. That was absolutely unnecessary.'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering and the Israeli envoy had no comment. Al-Kidwa said he hoped the tape would lead to ``further concentration ... (on) the means and measure to provide protection to the Palestinian people.'' The violence showed ``barbarism of police and army personnel against our people which cannot be in self-defense,'' the Palestinian envoy said. The Security Council previously has been the scene of dramatic pesentations. In 1989, Panama presented videotape it claimed showed U.S. preparations for an attack. Earlier, the United States showed photographs of what it said were heavily armed Libyan planes that were attacked by U.S. warplanes in 1988. In September 1983, the Soviet Union displayed a videotape of the pilot and control tower conversations before the shoot-down of a Korean airliner that strayed into Soviet airspace. Friday's meeting was a continuation of a session that began Wednesday to discuss the secretary-general's report on the need to protect Palestinians in the territories captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. The report did not recommend stationing U.N. observers or expanding U.N. observers or other staff in the area. The council is expected to continue debating the issue for several days. The United States is expected to veto any resolution that calls for sending observers to the territories. However, another possible resolution, this one calling for a meeting of parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention, could be accepted by the United States. The convention calls for humanitarian treatment of civilians in time of war. Israel is a signatory, but says the provisions do not apply to the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Snake Kills Mother, Swallows Baby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A python killed a 30-year-old woman and swallowed her 5-year-old child in a remote mountain village, a newspaper reported Friday. The newspaper, Kompas, said the dead woman was found after the 18-foot-long snake attacked her and her baby in Ranapanjang, a village 250 miles northwest of Jakarta. After a two-day hunt, villagers found the snake Tuesday and split it open to retrieve the child's body, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: High-Definition TV Equipment Goes on Sale in Japan
DOC.TEXT: High-definition television, a new generation of TV with clearer, wider images, hit the Japanese market this week, years ahead of its scheduled release in other nations. Most major Japanese electronics makers introduced new consumer HDTV products, including televisions, videocassette recorders and adaptors that allow HDTV broadcasts to be seen on present TV sets. The new TV sets are at least 10 times as expensive as current models, however. Sony's 36-inch HDTV monitor, one of the cheaper models, goes for the equvalent of $17,700. The 32-inch Toshiba model is priced at $30,700. ``In five years, we hope to bring that down to about 1 million yen ($7,700),'' said Hideji Matsuda of Toshiba's new media division. HDTV offers extremely detailed images, digital sound and wider, cinema-style screen proportions. Until now the equipment was aimed at a small number of professionals and was large, heavy, and expensive. HDTV adaptors, for example, weighed as much as 209 pounds and filled a small cabinet. But new models displayed this week by many companies weigh as little as 13 pounds and are the size of a large cable TV adaptor. In Europe, companies have developed a competing HDTV system that is not expected to be brought to market until 1992. In the United States, government officials are still debating what technical standards to set for HDTV and how it should be broadcast. Unlike Japan, where HDTV signals are broadcast directly from a satellite to viewers' homes, the U.S. Federal Communications Commission is exploring a ``simulcast'' system in which current land-based television stations would broadcast normal programs on their present channels and HDTV information on separate channels. Japan Broadcasting Corp., the public television network, currently broadcasts one hour of HDTV satellite programming a day. Full-time broadcasting is scheduled to start in early 1992. Although Japan's HDTV system is not compatibile with current equipment, with the new adaptors, anyone with a regular television will be able to tune in HDTV programs, although with regular picture quality. HDTV monitors announced by Sony, Matsushita, NEC, Toshiba and other companies can receive regular Japanese TV broadcasts.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Official Arrives in Jordan for Gulf Talks
DOC.TEXT: Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen arrived in this capital Friday on a two-day official visit for talks with officials on possible solutions to the gulf crisis. ``I'm not carrying special peace proposals, and I will not act as a mediator,'' Qian said on arrival. ``I am here to exchange views with my Jordanian counterpart on issues of joint interests, and to seek peaceful means to end the gulf crisis.'' Qian arrived from Saudi Arabia at Marka Airport in Amman, where he was met by Jordan's Foreign Minister Marwan Qassem. He is scheduled to hold talks with King Hussein on Saturday and leave for Baghdad, Iraq, the next day. China, a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, has expressed some reluctance about the military option to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Jordan has called for a diplomatic solution.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Officials Present Philadelphia Recovery Plan
LaserPhoto PX4
DOC.TEXT: Spending cuts, the sale of city assets and $125 million in new taxes are needed to avoid a virtual shutdown of city government and to raise its rock-bottom bond rating, state and local Democratic leaders said Friday. The plan - announced by Mayor W. Wilson Goode, state House Speaker Robert W. O'Donnell and other officials - also would set up an independent control board whose authority would be triggered if the city failed to balance future budgets. ``The plan represents the critical first step for the city's fiscal recovery,'' Goode said. ``As a esult of this coming together of leadership, we now have the elements necessary to solve our problems.'' No City Council members or Republicans joined in the announcement, which left many details sketchy. Other political leaders and bond-rating agencies gave the plan mixed reviews. Gov. Robert P. Casey in Harrisburg called the plan ``an important first step.'' He pledged full support of a recommendation for an immediate sale of temporary loan notes to avert a cash crisis. ``It also seems clear that the other recommendations made today do not enjoy the same broad consensus as the note sale,'' Casey added. ``I encourage all participants to continue their discussions with elected officials of both parties in a further effort to narrow differences and arrive at consensus.'' House Minority Leader Matthew Ryan, a Republican from suburban Delaware County, scoffed at such provisions in the plan as a $50 million increase in state aid. The plan was drafted behind closed doors in the last two months by Democratic state and city officials after Wall Street snubbed the city's attempt to float $375 million in temporary loan notes. The failed note issue resulted in the severe cash crunch that would deplete city coffers during December if nothing is done. The Democrats urged a three-pronged attack: - The city would issue $250 million to $300 million in temporary loan notes with backing from Merrill Lynch, local banks, the state treasury and the city's pension fund. The money would allow the city to continue operating and be repaid with tax receipts due in the spring. - It would eliminate a $229 million deficit, expected by July 1, by raising $140 million through deficit financing bonds and $90 million by selling city-owned assets, which were not specified. - The city's budget would erase a projected $279 million deficit for fiscal 1992 through new taxes, higher state and federal aid and lower court costs. The officials urged approval of a 1 percent sales tax they said would raise $100 million, an unspecified $25 million tax and $9 million from mandatory withholding of the existing city wage tax for city residents who work in the suburbs. The officials said they had backing from three Philadelphia congressmen for a $33 million increase in federal aid. Cuts of $45 million would come through unspecified mayoral actions and $16 million would come through improved efficiency in the Philadelphia courts, they said. Bond-rating agencies have lowered the city's debt to junk-bond status, the lowest among major U.S. cities. The agencies have urged city and state leaders to cooperate to find permanent solutions. Hyman C. Grossman, managing director at Standard & Poor's Corp., said the plan needed Republican backing to clear the GOP-controlled state Senate. ``Without that, there's nothing to comment on,'' he said. Colleen Woodell, a vice president at Fitch Investors Service, said the talks had been encouraging, but may have fallen short. ``Dollarwise, I'm not sure it does what they need to have done,'' she said. ``I would need to be convinced.'' City Council passed a precariously balanced $2.1 billion general fund budget May 31 for the fiscal year that began July 1. By September, a $206.4 million deficit was projected because several assumptions had turned sour. Major factors included sluggish tax receipts, inaction by state legislators on city-passed tax measures and arbitration-awarded police and firefighter pay increases.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Woman With 46 Personalities Vulnerable to Exploitation
DOC.TEXT: Friends and doctors said Friday they were worried that tabloid television and international exposure surrounding the sexual assault of a young woman with 46 personalities will lead to exploitation of the victim. ``My concern is she may very well be exploited by everybody as she has been before,'' said Dr. Inam Haque, a psychiatrist at Winnebago County Mental Health Clinic who has treated the woman since 1986. The 27-year-old woman, whose name has been withheld by the media to protect her identity as a rape victim, told the Oshkosh Northwestern she was elated by Thursday's verdict. ``We did it,'' she said. ``Anybody like us, myself and the insiders (her other personalities) will be able to get protection now.'' A Winnebago County jury on Thursday convicted Mark A. Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh of second-degree sexual assault. He faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced next month. The jury found the unemployed grocery store bagger, who is married, knew the woman was mentally ill and manipulated one of her personalities - a naive 20-year-old woman who didn't know what intercourse was - to have sex with him two days after he met her. Wisconsin law forbids sexual contact with mentally ill people who can't understand the consequences of their actions. The victim said her real self only learned of the June 11 assault because a 6-year-old personality was ``peeking.'' Peterson maintained after the verdict he did not know the woman was mentally ill and was the victim of an overzealous prosecutor. He promised to appeal. The woman's testimony, which often involved her closing her eyes and bowing her head as she switched personalities, dramatized a rare psychiatric diagnosis called multiple personality disorder. Ruth Reeves, a neighbor and friend, said the woman would retain a lawyer to help her handle the publicity and requests for interviews. ``It appears that everybody wants a piece of the action,'' she said. The television show ``Inside Edition'' announced Friday it plans to air an interview with the woman next week, showing footage of the woman switching personalities. Inside Edition reporter Janet Tamaro said the show decided to use the interview after consulting with the woman, her mother, Mrs. Reeves and counselors about the consequences of revealing her identity. ``We were willing to do it any way all of them were willing to do it - any way they wanted,'' Ms. Tamaro said. ``We really left it up to them to decide.'' District Attorney Joe Paulus, who prosecuted the case, said he worries the woman may be exploited. He said he had nothing to do with arranging her interviews with tabloid televisions shows. ``She still functions in the community. She is capable of making everyday decisions on her own. She has got to make her own decisions in life,'' he said. The illness often results from childhood abuse that forces the sufferer to create multiple personalities to avoid confronting reality, experts say. In an interview with the Appleton Post-Crescent, the woman said she held no grudges against people who doubt her mental illness. At one point this year, she estimated she had 86 personalities, but many have merged together, she said. The woman, born in South Korea, said she believes her father was an American, probably a GI. She was taken to an orphanage shortly after birth. ``I had no maternal or paternal care of any kind,'' she told the paper. ``I was not touched or picked up, except to be changed or fed. I was a very angry, lonely, sad baby.'' After eight months, she was adopted by parents who picked her out of a catalog, she said. Her adoptive father physically abused her, she said. He was ill ``and couldn't help it.'' The woman said the multiple personalities began when she was still an orphan in South Korea.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf of first item in AM-People to CORRECT that Tolleson was Miss United States sted Miss USA.
DOC.TEXT: Miss United States Gina Marie Tolleson spent Friday enjoying a champagne breakfast and attention from the media after being crowned Miss World. She said she hopes to be home by Thanksgiving. Tolleson, 21, won the 40th annual Miss World beauty contest Thursday night and pocketed prizes including $19,000 in cash and a work contract worth $59,000. The University of Georgia sophomore told reporters she would use the money to pay for a Jeep Cherokee she recently bought, do a little shopping and ``just sit on'' the rest. First, she said, she would get some sleep. ``I'm just resting the rest of the day, catching up on my beauty sleep which I desperately need.'' She said she and her mother called her father back home in Spartanburg, S.C., before she went to bed Thursday. ``I'm a daddy's girl,'' she said. ``I wish he could have been here.''

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian President in Tiff With Press
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara on Friday said that journalists wanted to be treated like ``sacred cows,'' and several newspapers excised his name from stories in a dispute over press laws. Journalists are demanding an end to the strict laws that were carried over from the regime of former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was overthrown by the U.S. invasion in December. The government has used the laws to issue summons to reporters who attended an opposition news conference and to arrest on charges of criminal slander a columnist who had criticized Endara. Organizers of a protest march on Thursday vowed to impose ``the law of ice'' and freeze coverage of the president. Several newspapers and radio stations referred to Endara on Friday only as ``the president of the republic,'' without mentioning his name. Endara, speaking to reporters before leaving Friday to attend the enthronement of Emperor Akihito in Japan, said he was shocked by the behavior of reporters who confronted him after Thursday's march. Endara said he had refused to receive the demonstrators in his office because ``they wanted to enter just because they were reporters, as if they were the sacred cows of this republic, and they aren't.'' ``That was an uproar of the worst sort ... the things they shouted at me were really outrageous. I could not receive or talk to any person who shouts in that way,'' he said. Endara's press secretary, Rene Hernandez said ``the president's policy is to defend freedom of expression,'' but he said ``criticism should not be confused with calumny.'' He said if reporters want the laws changed, they should petition the legislature.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Back Bush's Decision for Troop Buildup
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops stationed in the Saudi desert say President Bush is right to give Operation Desert Shield more muscle for a possible attack on Iraq. ``Militarily speaking, he's absolutely right,'' Air Force Capt. Patrick Ryan, 28, of New Orleans said Friday as he waited for a flight at an air base in eastern Saudi Arabia. Bush on Thursday ordered more than 150,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf to join the 230,000 U.S. military personnel in the region. Allies from 26 countries have sent another 100,000 soldiers to join the multinational force deployed after Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``I don't think we have to worry much about the Iraqis launching an offensive anymore,'' said Ryan, a fighter pilot. ``The big thing right now is how to get those guys out of Kuwait, and to launch an offensive it's going to take quite a lot of firepower.'' Like many servicemen here, Ryan said he hoped Iraqi President Saddam Hussein would pull his troops out of Kuwait, but that U.S.-led forces must be prepared if he refuses. The president said he wanted the allied forces to have an ``adequate offensive military option'' should global sanctions fail to convince Saddam to withdraw. Iraq has deployed an estimated 430,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq since the invasion. A ranking U.S. military official in Saudi Arabia, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``If there was a doubt in Saddam Hussein's mind about U.S. resolve to use any option required, if it comes to that, this should pretty well clear it up.'' Army Maj. Frank Irons, 40, of Knoxville, Tenn., a logistics expert, said he thought more troops would limit casualties in the event of war. ``I would think the more people, the more firepower we get in here would enhance our chances if we were to go on the offensive to do a quicker job, therefore saving a lot of people and limiting the casualties that we would probably have,'' he said. News of the new mobilization was just filtering out to the troops in the field. At the Army's 530th Supply and Services Battalion headquarters, which provides logistics support for thousands of soldiers, there was some concern in the laundry and bakery about the mobilization. ``The only thing I'm worried about is having to make more bread,'' said Spec. Norman Wiemken, 22, of Polo, Ill., who was baking some of the 3,000 loaves made daily. ``Just more laundry,'' Pvt. 1 Lawandra Hinton, 20, of Newport News, Va. said with a laugh. She was sorting through some of the 12,000 pieces of clothing washed at her laundry every day.

DOC.HEAD: Service Station Clerk Slain as Customers Fill Up Gas
DOC.TEXT: Service station attendant Michael Hicke, shot twice in the head, lay unnoticed for several hours while some customers pumped free gas for themselves. Now police have unveiled a new twist: A friend has admitted he shot Hicke once during an armed robbery, then shot him again to end his misery when he began ``making funny noises and gurgling.'' Brothers Emil Wisniewski, 18, and Anton Wisniewski, 25, were charged Friday with first-degree intentional homicide and armed robbery in Hicke's death. Police said the 18-year-old victim - who worked at a Shell gas station in the Milwaukee suburb of Greenfield - and two suspects had lived in the same neighborhood years ago and were friends. Hicke's body was discovered in the station's car wash section about 35 yards from the gas pumps about 7 a.m. Sunday by a customer searching for the attendant. The customer had pumped gasoline, looked for the clerk and found him dead with two bullet wounds to the head, Detective Dirk Wichgers said. Police believe five other customers pumped a total of about $40 in gas without paying between midnight and 7 a.m., during the hours after Hicke was believed to have been shot, Wichgers said. One of the five left the money in a tray in the attendant's booth and another returned the following day to pay, said station owner Edward F. McMahon. According to a criminal complaint, the Wisniewski brothers planned earlier to go to the gas station because ``there was a lot of money there and the guy was supposed to have cocaine in the trunk of his car.'' But when the two arrived, they found Hicke was working the shift for another employee. Investigators said the two tried to convince Hicke to do a ``fake robbery.'' The younger Wisniewski and Hicke went to the car wash to smoke marijuana, while the older Wisniewski tried to break into the floor safe in the attendant's booth, police said. After hearing the hammering, Hicke tried to return to the booth, the two struggled and the younger Wisniewski shot Hicke in the face, investigators said. Wisniewski returned shortly afterward and shot Hicke again in the side of the head at point-blank range. He told police he fired the second shot ``to make sure he was dead because ... (I) didn't want him to suffer, because he was `making funny noises and gurgling.''' The homicide charge carries a mandatory penalty of life in prison, and the armed robbery count carries a maximum of 20 years. McMahon, the station owner, said he was perplexed by the actions of the customers who pumped gas without paying on the night Hicke was shot. ``You'd think there would be more concern about why the person is not there,'' McMahon said. ``That's the only human thing to do.''

DOC.HEAD: Fines Proposed for Pacific & Southwestern Bells, Nynex
DOC.TEXT: Four Bell telephone companies should be fined $250,000 each for accounting violations that diverted money to other telephone companies, the Federal Communications Commission said Friday. Commission officials said telephone customers were not hurt by what the companies did. The FCC sent notices of apparent liability to Pacific Bell, Southwestern Bell, New England Telephone and New York Telephone. Companies receiving such notices are given 30 days to show why they should not pay the fine. The commission also sent a letter of reprimand to the National Exchange Carrier Association Inc., a telephone-company operated entity that collects and distributes the ``access charges'' that long-distance companies pay local telephone companies to connect with the local networks. The association, based in Whippany, N.J., distributes access charge revenues to the local companies based on revenue and cost information reported by these companies, the FCC said. ``This letter concluded that certain NECA directors apparently failed to ensure the accuracy of the data reported to NECA and that the NECA board of directors, as a whole, apparently did not display proper vigilance,'' the FCC said. The apparent violations were discovered during an audit of the association. The Bell companies, as regulated monopolies, are allowed to earn only a fixed percentage above the costs of their investments, currently about 12 percent. After all participating companies collect their expenses from the common line pool, they claim profits from what's left over. The Bell companies make claims according to their permitted rates of return; what's left over is available for the smaller companies. Richard Firestone, chief of the FCC's common carrier bureau, said the Bell companies deliberately reduced their expense claims in order to increase the size of the profit pool, thus increasing the profits available to the smaller companies and boosting their rates of return on the investments concerned. Just why the Bell companies would want to boost the rates of return for other companies by understating their own expenses was not clear, and the amount of money involved was not stated. The commission did not immediately release the audit report on which its action was based. Firestone would not speculate on the Bell companies' motives. But he emphasized that telephone customers did not lose any money as a result of the companies' actions. The issue for the FCC, Firestone said, was that the companies' reporting of their earnings and expenses must be credible. Commissioner Andrew C. Barrett said in an accompanying statement that the association board ``blatantly subverted the commission's processes and penalties'' even though the Bell companies appeared to have ``given money away.'' Barrett said the board ``intended to manipulate the FCC's processes to achieve unstated and potentially unlawful ends'' and its ``intention to deceive commission staff to achieve political or other goals cannot go unpunished.'' Lou Saviano, spokesman for Pacific Telephone in San Francisco, said, ``we think they're just over-reacting to what is essentially an honest mistake and we think it would be grossly unfair for the FCC to penalize us.'' ``We acted on the basis of the best information that was available to us with the intent of being fair. When they advised us we made a mistake we fixed it ... voluntarily gave the money back,'' he said. Nynex spokesman Peter Goodale, reached in New York, said the companies had ``cooperated with NECA and the FCC in connection with the audit ... but we're unaware of any improprieties that the FCC believes it may have found.'' The FCC also required the association to have an independent auditor report to the commission within 180 days on other adjustments phone companies reported during 1988 and 1989, and on safeguards to prevent future problems.

DOC.HEAD: Trafficker Dies With Cocaine-filled Condoms in Stomach
DOC.TEXT: A young man who had just arrived on a flight from Kenya collapsed and died when a cocaine-filled condom burst in his stomach, hospital officials said Friday. The unidentified man died last week after arriving from Nairobi, Kenya, the officials said. They said several other condoms containing cocaine were found in the man's stomach during an autopsy. He was traveling on a Nigerian passport, but airport officials found he was carrying four other passports in his jacket. Traffickers sometimes hide illegal drugs in condoms in their bodies to conceal it from authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistani Cabinet Sworn In
DOC.TEXT: President Ghulam Ishaq Khan on Friday swore in an 18-member Cabinet of veteran bureaucrats and announced that he will retain the foreign and finance ministers of the caretaker government. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will likely keep the defense portfolio, as did his predecessors. More than half of Pakistan's $10 billion budget goes to the military. Sharif may expand his Cabinet later, but officials say it will be much smaller than the record 58-member Cabinet of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, a political survivor, will remain as foreign minister. He held the post in the Bhutto government and in the army-backed caretaker government that replaced her administration. Sartaj Aziz will stay on as finance minister, a post he held in the caretaker government. The president dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government in August, saying corruption, political ineptitude and mismanagement had paralyzed Parliament. A right-wing coalition known as the Islamic Democratic Alliance swept parliamentary elections on Oct. 24 and provincial elections three days later. Ms. Bhutto charged widespread vote tampering, an accusation her opponents and most international observers dismiss. Sharif, leader of the alliance and architect of Ms. Bhutto's stunning loss, was sworn in on Wednesday as prime minister of Pakistan's fifth freely elected Parliament in 43 years. Ishaq Khan leaves Saturday for Japan to attend the enthronement of Emperor Akihito. He is expected to meet with Vice President Dan Quayle in Tokyo to discuss a stalled $573 million U.S. aid package.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Disease Kills 100 Turtles At World's Only Turtle Farm
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 turtles at the world's only known sea turtle farm have died in the past two months from a mysterious disease that has the farm's director baffled. Since late September, more than a dozen breeding turtles and more than 100 infant turtles on this Caribbean island have died from the illness, said Dr. James Wood, director of the government-owned Cayman Turtle Farm. He said he suspects a virus because the turtles have not responded to antibiotics. Samples of turtle tissue were sent to the University of Florida School of Veterinary Medicine in Gainesville for study, Wood said. The farm raises turtles for export to such countries as Japan, Singapore and the Philippines, where turtle meat is considered a delicacy.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Newspaper: Iraq, France Met Secretly Over Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Hoffman, Swanke taken to U.S. hospital on arrival in Frankfurt, new hostage release numbers, quotes, details. Edits to conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA5,BX5,LON3
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's official newspaper said Friday that Baghdad's foreign minister and a former French official held secret talks that led to the release of more than 300 French hostages from Iraq. France denied it sanctioned the talks. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt flew from Baghdad to Frankfurt Friday aboard a German jetliner carrying 174 Western captives to freedom. Brandt negotiated the release of the hostages, who included three Americans. One of the Americans was Miles Hoffman, 33, of Columbus, Ga., shot in the arm Sept. 5 by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. Hoffman was whisked off the plane by authorities and taken to the U.S Air Force Regional Hospital in Wiesbaden, German, for treatment. Earlier, after he was given his boarding documents at Baghdad's airport, Hoffman told TV cameras, ``Good riddance.'' A second American, Don Swanke, 66, of Westlake Village, Calif., also was taken to the Wiesbaden hospital, 25 miles outside Frankfurt, for a precautionary checkup, said Air Force Capt. Tom Gilroy. Swanke lost 33 pounds in captivity. The airport rang out with the cheers of the hundreds on hand for the arrival as the German jetliner touched down. Relatives who hadn't seen each other since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 wept and embraced as they emerged from the plane. Some held signs reading, ``Thank you, Mr. Brandt.'' Brandt told a news conference before leaving Baghdad that he was carrying proposals for settling the 3-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. Western officials have charged that independent efforts by governments and former leaders to win release of their nationals risks dividing the world alliance against Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But speaking in Bonn, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday said no one can ``drive a wedge'' into the international solidarity. In Washington, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday that American military forces in the gulf will reach up to 430,000 within weeks - 200,000 more than are now deployed. Cheney said the additional troops would give U.S.-allied forces the offensive military option to drive Iraqi troops from the oil-rich emirate, which it invaded in a dispute over land, oil and money. Iraq's Al-Jumhouriya newspaper reported, meanwhile, that Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and former French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson met for secret talks endorsed by France. The daily did not say when or where the meeting between Aziz and Cheysson took place. Arab sources said the talks, set up by the Palestine Liberation Organization, took place in Tunis late last month, one week before Saddam said French nationals were free to go. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas denied that Cheysson or anyone else had a mandate to negotiate the release of hostages, freed by Saddam in late October. France has repeatedly said it made no deal with Iraq. The French government did not, however, deny that the talks took place. And there was no indication whether they involved a diplomatic effort to seek a peaceful solution to the 3-month-old gulf crisis. France has made no formal public pledge regarding the circumstances under which it would fight Iraq, saying such decisions should be made by the U.N. Security Council. The release of the French nationals was interpreted by many Western officials as an effort by Iraq to divide opposition to its occupation of Kuwait. But Gorbachev, during a news conference in Bonn, said: ``For the first time in history we have acted together in so critical a situation.'' ``Let no one reckon on driving a wedge into that unity,'' he said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met Friday with British officials in London, on a weeklong tour of Middle Eastern and European nations to gather support for possible military action against Iraq. Later, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said London and Washington stood ``absolutely together'' on the gulf crisis. Baker was to meet in Paris with French officials on Saturday. In Moscow, the previous stop on Baker's tour, a senior U.S. official said Friday that the moderate Arab forces would fight alongside U.S. troops to liberate Kuwait, but he was uncertain that France would go along. ``I don't know where the French would be,'' the official said on condition of anonymity. Several former leaders - including Edward Heath of Britain, Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, and most recently Brandt - have negotiated freedom for some of the hundreds of hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. No reason was given for the release of the Americans, which included Swanke's wife Brenda, among the other captives. About 1,000 Americans are still held. The three had been held among hundreds of others as human shields at strategic Iraqi sites to deter attack by the multinational forces stationed in the gulf region. Hoffman, a financial analyst with the Kuwaiti government at the time of the invasion, was shot in the left arm by Iraqi troops who tried to force their way into his apartment in Kuwait City. There were reports that gangrene developed from the wound, and the U.S. Embassy had placed him on its list of release requests twice before. Hoffman's arm was in a cast and he appeared in pain. Patience with Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait and its holding of Western hostages appeared to be growing thin. The U.N. trade embargo on Iraq has not yet pushed Iraq into any retreat from the emirate. On Thursday, the Soviet Union said for the first time it would not rule out military action as a last resort and President Bush announced there would be new troop deployments, without offering any figures. Once the added forces are in place, America will have more troops in the gulf region than it had in Europe during the Cold War. About one-third of the Army's worldwide force will be in the Saudi desert. ``The additional increment will give us the capacity to undertake offensive action should that become necessary,'' Cheney said Friday. At the United Nations, an attempt by Iraq to introduce a General Assembly resolution criticizing the U.S. military buildup in the gulf drew a stinging rebuke Friday when an assembly committee unanimously refused to consider it. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering called the Iraqi attempt to introduce a resolution ``ill-founded, tendentious and mendacious.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorney for White Killer Says He'll Seek Amnesty for Client
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing radical who shot to death six blacks will seek his release under a government amnesty program, his lawyer said Friday. Wim Cornelius said his client, Barend Strydom, qualified because he was acting on instructions from an extreme right-wing group when he mowed down the blacks in downtown Pretoria on Nov. 15, 1988. Cornelius is serving a death sentence. The government said Nov. 1 it would consider amnesty for political prisoners under an agreement with the African National Congress. It said certain criteria would be considered in each case, such as whether the act was committed under orders from a political organization. The agreement was primarily aimed at ANC members and sympathizers imprisoned for crimes related to the anti-apartheid struggle. Strydom, a former police officer, claimed he was acting on behalf of a shadowy group called the White Wolves.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldier Found Dead in Shower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with ID, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army soldier taking part in Operation Desert Shield has been found dead, apparently of natural causes, in a shower, military officials said Friday. The soldier was identified as Sgt. James Wilcher, 25, by officials at Fort Bliss, Texas, where he had been stationed earlier. They said he was found dead Thursday after dinner. A preliminary investigation showed no evidence of foul play, the Pentagon said. ``It is suspected that he died of natural causes. However, the exact cause of death is not known at this time. Medical help was immediately available and all attempts to revive him were unsuccessful,'' the Fort Bliss news release stated. The soldier was assigned to the 118th Ordnance Detachment of the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, which was sent to Saudi Arabia from Fort Bliss in El Paso. Forty-five U.S. servicemen have died during the Saudi operation to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, 43 in accidents, one by suicide and Thursday's fatality.

DOC.HEAD: Boschwitz Apologizes For Letter Suggesting Wellstone Wasn't A Good Jew
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Rudy Boschwitz apologized Friday for a letter sent to some Minnesota Jews on behalf of his unsuccessful re-election campaign suggesting his challenger was not a good Jew. ``I deeply regret having allowed the letter to be written and accept full responsibility for it,'' said Boschwitz, who is Jewish. Paul Wellstone, who upset the Republican senator in Tuesday's election, said he appreciated Boschwitz's remarks and accepted his apology. ``I think it should be the final word,'' said the senator-elect, who is also Jewish. The letter, written by two of Boschwitz's Jewish supporters and signed by them and 70 others, was printed on Boschwitz campaign stationery and mailed at campaign expense Nov. 1. ``Wellstone has no connection with the Jewish community or our communal life,'' the letter said. ``His children were brought up as non-Jews.'' The letter noted that Wellstone served as co-chairman of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign in Minnesota, and said, ``Jesse Jackson has embraced, literally and figuratively, Yasser Arafat, and has never repudiated that embrace.'' Moreover, Wellstone never disassociated himself from any of Jackson's policies, the letter said. The letter angered Wellstone's Jewish supporters, some of whom described it as an attempt to split the Jewish vote over the issue of Israel. Two days before the election, Wellstone said the letter was ``completely unforgivable.'' ``This is making an issue of the fact that we have an interreligious marriage,'' said Wellstone, whose wife is Christian. ``This is the most sensitive issue in the Jewish community there is.'' Boschwitz initially stood by the letter. But on Friday, after the Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported that the letter had generated angry discussion among Jews in Israel and the United States, the senator said he was sorry. ``Bringing Jews and non-Jews together has been an important element of my public service and private life,'' Boschwitz said. ``Others will judge over time whether I have made a positive contribution in this regard, but for the moment I simply reiterate my apology.'' Wellstone said Boschwitz' statement showed a ``tremendous amount of sincerity and conviction.'' ``His remarks are powerful,'' Wellstone said. ``It was very hurtful to everybody in our family, but this is a wonderful statement, and I think it's in the past.'' Wellstone said he didn't believe the letter was the major reason why Boschwitz lost the election, but he said, ``In the end, it was very damaging for them.''

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Attack on U.S. Embassy After Base Talks End in Manila
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with grenade attack on U.S. Embassy, no injuries. Picks up 3rd pvs, `The next...'
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified assailants fired two grenades early Saurday at the U.S. Embassy one day after American and Philippine panels ended talks on the future of six military bases. There were no injuries in the attack, which took place at 6:50 a.m. when the embassy was closed. One grenade landed in Manila Bay behind the compound and exploded, embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said. The other landed in front of the chancery building but did not explode, he said. There was no claim of responsibility, though the attack was similar to one staged last December at an American residential area. That attack, which caused no injuries and minor damage, was blamed on Communist rebels. At the end of talks Friday, there were reports the bases' future would be linked to U.S. aid to the Philippines. The next meeting was set for December. Spokesmen for both sides predicted the talks would be completed by January. ``The discussions over the past two days were useful in widening the areas of consensus and narrowing the areas still to be discussed in more detail,'' U.S. spokesman Stanley Schrager told reporters. Philippine spokesman Rafael Alunan said the two sides had reached no agreements but ``succeeded in widening the areas of consensus and narrowing the areas that still need to be threshed out.'' On Thursday, Alunan said the U.S. delegation agreed ``to junk the bases agreement and start from ground zero.'' Alunan did not elaborate. But Philippine officials have said they want any new agreement to cover trade concessions, debt relief and other issues. About 50 militant youths held a brief rally near the Central Bank building, where the panels met, and burned an American flag before dispersing peacefully. In Angeles, 50 miles north of Manila, police arrested eight leftist students who burned an American flag a few yards from the Clark Air Base gate. The talks centers on the status of Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller facilities whose lease expires on Sept. 16. Most Philippine politicians have called for phasing out the bases, although U.S. officials say they want a ``residual'' American military presence here. The United States currently maintains about 40,000 troops, military dependents and Defense Department civilians at the bases, among the largest on foreign soil. The bases and related infrastructure provide jobs for scores of thousands of Filipinos. After his arrival Wednesday, U.S. special negotiator Richard Armitage told Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus that Washington would remove its 48 combat aircraft and 1,800 Air Force personnel from Clark Air Base. Manglapus, chief Philippine negotiator, said last September the Philippines wanted to take control of Clark when the current bases agreement expires in September. Philippine officials said they were willing to negotiate the status of the Subic Bay naval base and the other installations. Alunan said the Philippines was sticking by its demand for ``sovereign control'' of the bases by next year. The six bases are technically Philippine installations but are effectively under American control. Schrager told reporters Friday said the Americans wanted a transition period to transfer the bases to full Philippine control and that the time-frame could vary depending on the installation. On Thursday, he said the United States ``would like to maintain access to some of these facilities and to maintain a small residual American military presence in the country similar to the agreements we have with many other countries around the world.'' Any new agreement must be ratified by two-thirds of the 23-member Philippine Senate, where opposition to the installations is strong. Opinion surveys show most Filipinos support the bases, but many influential figures in government, academic circles and media oppose them as an infringement on sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Section of Berlin Wall Dedicated Where Churchill Warned of Iron Curtain
DOC.TEXT: Westminster College, where Winston Churchill first warned of an Iron Curtain's descent across Europe, rededicated part of the fallen Berlin Wall on Friday as a monument to peace and freedom. Former President Reagan told about 4,000 people at an outdoor ceremony that the wall sections transplanted to Missouri stand as proof that ``the political map of Europe has been rewritten.'' ``The future has been redefined, even as the veil has been lifted on a cruel and bloody past,'' Reagan said. Churchill's granddaughter, artist Edwina Sandys, joined together eight sections of the wall to form the 32-foot-long sculpture. She carved two passages in the 11-foot-high concrete in the shapes of a man and a woman so ``people can pass through freely.'' Reagan led dignitaries in walking through the openings in the wall, which is a stark gray on the side that once faced east. They emerged on the old west side, adorned with bright graffiti. The word ``Unwahr,'' German for ``untruth,'' appears frequently on the wall, which has been placed near a bronze statue of Churchill. Ms. Sandys, whose sculptures have been displayed in Europe and at the United Nations, said she was accustomed to working in marble. ``Thirty-two feet of concrete created quite a challenge ... unyielding slabs of concrete, steeped as they are in heroism and history,'' she told the audience. The sculpture was dedicated on the one-year anniversary of the fall of the wall, and more than three years after Reagan, during a Berlin visit, called on Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to ``tear down this wall.'' Churchill first invoked the image of an Iron Curtain to describe growing Soviet influence during a speech at Westminster on March 5, 1946. ``From Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic, an Iron Curtain has descended across the Continent,'' he said. ``Today we come full circle from those anxious times,'' Reagan said. ``Out of one man's speech was born a new Western resolve.'' Some of those attending the ceremony Friday had been on hand for Churchill's speech 44 years earlier. Raymond Miller of Fulton drove the town's mayor in the parade for Churchill and said it was one of the highlights of his 64 years. ``I'm real thrilled about being part of history he predicted back in 1946,'' Miller said.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Library: Watergate Tapes Take Back Seat to Gowns, Paintings
DOC.TEXT: The new Nixon presidential library said Friday it is delaying two Watergate tape exhibits so it can display Dwight Eisenhower paintings and first lady gowns. The decision was strictly a financial one, said library director John Taylor, who denied that the move represents a reluctance to feature the scandal that forced Richard M. Nixon's 1974 resignation as president. ``We have a concise and compelling Watergate story. I feel confident it is all right to transfer my attentions elsewhere,'' Taylor said. Some scholars questioned the library's postponement of exhibits featuring two tape recordings from March 1973. ``They don't want to play it. The simplest explanation will suffice. Things are no different than since 1972 - coverup is the order of the day,'' said Stanley Kutler, a University of Wisconsin professor and author of the recently published ``The Wars of Watergate: The Last Crisis of Richard Nixon.'' Taylor said the library's section on Watergate already includes a crucial June 23, 1972, tape recording of a conversation between Nixon and his aides. The tape is edited and includes accompanying narration. On the tape, Nixon agrees to ask the CIA to block an investigation by the FBI into the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate hotel-office complex. ``The portions of the June 23 tape on exhibit are the most decisive and critical portions,'' Taylor said. ``Some observers might say they are the most clear signs of wrongdoing.'' Taylor called the charge of a coverup ``silly'' and noted that the tapes are available to the public elsewhere. He also said the library - the nation's only fully privately funded presidential library - has an obligation to paint a broader picture of Nixon's life and to entertain visitors as well. ``We are an attraction, one that is involved with describing a career that spans and continues to span almost a half of a century,'' including Nixon's terms as vice president under President Eisenhower, Taylor said. A showing of 23 of Eisenhower's oil paintings is ``an integral part of the story,'' Taylor said. He also said improving the display of gowns worn by Nixon's wife, Pat, is justifiable. ``Gown and textile displays of this nature are very popular at the Smithsonian (the Washington museum) and at other presidential exhibits,'' he said. He said he ultimately intends to exhibit the two Watergate tapes, at a cost of $15,000 to $20,000, with the same kind of narration and editing used to put the June 23 tape in a historical context. ``A lot of people saying that it is a coverup are really saying that the Nixon library should not have the opportunity to place Nixon documents in a context he feels is accurate,'' Taylor said. On one of the tapes, from March 21, 1973, White House counsel John Dean said: ``We have a cancer within, close to the presidency, that is growing.'' On the March 22 tape, Nixon said he wanted his aides to ``stonewall it, plead the Fifth Amendment, cover up. ... '' The Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace in Yorba Linda, about 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles, opened in July with festivities attended by Nixon, President Bush and others.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishops Urge Restraint in Iraq Showdown, Use `Just War' Criteria
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Roman Catholic bishops gave qualified support to U.S. actions in the Middle East, but said the United States should maintain non-violent pressure on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The bishops' position was submitted to Secretary of State James Baker III in a letter sent Wednesday by Los Angeles Archbishop Roger Mahony, chairman of the International Policy Committee of the U.S. Catholic Conference. In the letter, the archbishop cited so-called ``just war'' criteria outlined in the U.S. bishops' Pastoral Letter on War and Peace released in May 1983. The criteria make war a last-resort action taken only after exhausting peaceful means, and weighing possible losses against the values at stake and the probability of success. ``A resort to war in violation of these criteria would jeopardize many lives, raise serious moral questions and undermine the international solidarity against Iraq,'' Mahony wrote. ``My concern is that the pressure to use military force may grow as the pursuit of non-violent options almost inevitably become more difficult, complex and slow,'' the letter said. The Catholic Conference, composed of 390 bishops, earlier said it opposed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and supported United Nations sanctions. Mahony urged continued cooperation between the United States, the Soviet Union, Arab states and other nations.

DOC.HEAD: Brandt Arrives in Frankfurt with 174 U.S, Other Foreign Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 3 `A second' to CORRECT spelling 2nd reference of Swanke name. Picks up 4th, `The airport...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt arrived here Friday from Baghdad with three Americans and 171 other Westerners whose freedom he sought in talks with Iraqi strongman Saddam Hussein. One of the Americans, Miles Hoffman, 33, of Columbus, Ga., shot in the arm Sept. 5 by Iraqi forces in Kuwait, was immediately taken off the plane and taken to the U.S. Air Force Regional Hospital in Wiesbaden, Germany, for a checkup, Air Force spokesman Capt. Tom Gilroy said. A second American, Don Swanke, 66, of Westlake Village, Calif., also was taken to the U.S. hospital in Wiesbaden, 25 miles west of Frankfurt, for a precautionary checkup, Gilroy said. Swanke lost 33 pounds during his captivity. The airport rang out with the cheers of the hundreds on hand for the arrival of the former hostages as the German jetliner touched down. Relatives who hadn't seen each other since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 wept and embraced as they emerged from the plane. Some held signs reading, ``Thank you, Mr. Brandt.'' Others departed the plane carrying children; one woman hugged Brandt. ``Good riddance,'' Hoffman told TV cameras at the airplane boarding counter in Baghdad as he clutched onto his U.S. passport and boarding documents. His arm was in a cast and he seemed to be in pain. Swanke and his wife, Brenda Swanke, were presented to reporters by U.S. authorities. The captives, including 120 Germans, had been ordered freed by Saddam after he met with Brandt. At least two other Americans were held back earlier when Iraqi officials told the U.S. Embassy their papers were not in order. It was unclear if they would be allowed to leave later. Also on the plane were nationals from Britain, Italy, Switzerland, Finland, Holland, Portugal, Belgium, Norway and Luxembourg, the German carrier Lufthansa said. Earlier reports of a Canadian aboard could not be confirmed. The airline's manifest only listed nationalities, not names. Brandt said upon his departure that he had discussed with Saddam efforts to achieve a durable and solid settlement for the problems of The Middle East. At the Baghdad airport, Brandt told a news conference he was carrying proposals for settling the 3-month-old gulf crisis. ``I need a weekend to go through my notes and put together what I have,'' Brandt said, refusing to elaborate. Brandt said he would consult with European leaders next week on the outcome of his talks with Hussein. He said he was impressed with Saddam, adding, ``I have reasons to be most grateful to Saddam Hussein and the government, not only for their hospitality, but also because there is a prospect of peace.'' Foreign Minister Tarik Aziz, who accompanied Brandt to the airport, criticized Bush administration plans announced Thursday to send another 200,000 troops to the Persian Gulf. ``Bush should send diplomats, not more troops, and he should start a dialogue,'' the foreign minister said when reporters asked him for a reaction to the U.S. move. ``If he wants to scare Iraq he already has enough troops. The decision to send troops will not be helpful. It is not going to find a solution,'' Aziz said. Americans are among foreign hostages held at strategic sites as ``human shields'' to deter attack by U.S.-led multinational forces stationed in the gulf. Swanke, who was working as a construction engineer at Kuwait University at the time of the invasion, ``We were worried for a hundred days.'' ``I was worried but I was not afraid,'' Mrs. Swanke added. She held onto her husband's arm as they embarked on German-bound plane. Swanke said that on Sept. 5, ``they (Iraqi troops) kicked our door down,'' and the couple were taken to the Regency Hotel in Kuwait. From there they were taken to Baghdad, he said, ``where we stayed in a hotel for a week.'' He said the couple were then taken to Mosul, a town about 240 miles north of Baghdad, and kept in a house. After three weeks the couple were moved onto a base, ``I think it was a missile assembly and storage area,'' Swanke said. The couple said they had no idea why they were chosen to be released and credited Brandt with their final departure. ``They (Iraqis) wouldn't give us our passports last night. They wouldn't give them to us today. He (Brandt) personally intervened and got our name on the list,'' Swanke said. Hoffman, a financial analyst with the Kuwaiti government at the time of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion, was shot when Iraqi soldiers tried to force their way into his Kuwait City apartment, according to reports from Columbus. The bullet shattered a bone in his left forearm and he was hospitalized for about a week, the reports said. Hoffman was brought to Baghdad and then moved to a strategic site outside Baghdad. There were reports that gangrene had developed from the wound, and the U.S. Embassy had placed him on its list of release requests twice before. Hoffman's relatives, who had been working for weeks to win his release, were overjoyed when they were told by the State Department that he had been freed. ``Everything's confirmed. It's just marvelous. It's just wonderful,'' his mother, Ann, said in Columbus. ``We're ecstatic,'' said Hoffman's brother, Chancellor. ``We need to check on his arm. He needs to get to a hospital.''

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Defends Quality of Play
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov said Friday he believed his match against world champion Garry Kasparov has produced better chess than has been described in the press. ``I would not say the quality of the match is at a low level,'' Karpov told a news conference. ``In this match, all games were very complicated. In all games we witnessed very sharp, acute and interesting struggle, except for the 10th game.'' The 10th was one of 10 games that the two Soviet players called a draw. Each also has one victory and after a month of play they are tied at 6 points each. The match now moves to Lyons, France, for the final 12 games beginning Nov. 24. The first player to score 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of the $3 million total purse. A 12-12 tie would enable Kasparov to retain the crown he lifted from Karpov in 1985, but the money would be split. Kasparov did not appear at the news conference. The sponsor said he did not know where the champion was or why he decided not to attend. Karpov, 39, sometimes in English and sometimes through a translator, told reporters that he thought having the championship partly in New York ``maybe will help revive the interest in chess in this country that had been there in 1972.'' ``I remember the time of the chess boom in America in 1972, when (Bobby) Fischer became world champion,'' he said. It was a time, he recalled, when a tournament in San Antonio offered play at a level high enough to attract a 21-year-old Karpov. But Fischer, feuding with the international chess bureaucracy, never defended his title and chess interest here waned. Several questioners seemed to invite Karpov to say that his longstanding personal antagonism for Kasparov was softening and that he could concede that the champion's influence has been good for him and for chess. ``You're trying to persuade me to love Kasparov as a mother would try to persuade a child to go to sleep,'' Karpov said. ``I respect him as a chess player very much. I have no other words to express it. As concerns his personality, I have spoken what I think about his behavior and I don't want to repeat myself.'' Karpov said he'd use the next two weeks to rest up and recover from jet lag. Also, ``I think it is no secret that both Kasparov and myself will be doing a lot of chess work.''

DOC.HEAD: Writer John Hugh Maclennan Dead at 83
DOC.TEXT: John Hugh MacLennan, an award-winning novelist considered among Canada's finest writers, died Wednesday at his home at age 83. The cause of death was not immediately known. MacLennan is best known for his 1945 novel ``Two Solitudes,'' which became a byword for the strains between French and English-speaking Canadians, although that was not its original connotation. The son of a Nova Scotia doctor, he studied at Dalhousie University, Oxford and Princeton. The Rhodes scholar came to Montreal in 1935 to teach classics at Lower Canada College and joined McGill University's English department in 1951. He retired from McGill in 1981. MacLennan stopped writing in 1984 with his last novel, ``Voices in Time.'' His first published novel, ``Barometer Rising,'' came out in 1941, followed by ``The Precipice,' ``The Watch That Ends the Night'' and ``Return of the Sphinx.'' MacLennan was awarded Canada's Governor-General award three times for fiction and twice for nonfiction - more than any other writer. Jack McClelland, former head of the McClelland and Stewart publishing firm in Toronto, said MacLennan was the most important novelist in Canada. ``He was a stylist. He had great depth of understanding of our country as a whole. He was, as an individual, thoughtful, with an extraordinary sense of humor and wit. He was really a lovely person.'' MacLennan is survived by his second wife, Frances, and by a sister in Halifax.

DOC.HEAD: Family Concerned About Health of Freed Columbus Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf, `Hoffman was ... ' and ADDS 5 grafs at end with comments from family of other Americans released. CHANGES slug from Gulf-American to Gulf-Americans to reflect additions.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: The family of Miles Hoffman, who was shot in the arm by Iraqi troops in Kuwait and held at a chemical plant near Baghdad, said Friday they were elated that the 33-year-old financial analyst has been freed. ``The first order of business will be to take care of that arm,'' said Hoffman's brother, Chancellor. ``He needs to get to the hospital.'' Hoffman was one of three Americans and 174 other Westerners who flew to freedom in Germany on Friday after talks between Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. They had been detained since Iraqi forces overran Kuwait Aug. 2. The other two freed Americans were Brenda and Don Swanke. Mrs. Swanke's parents, Samuel and Gertrude Thomas of Oak Ridge, Tenn., were overjoyed to see their daughter and son-in-law on a television newscast. ``It would be wonderful to have them home by Thanksgiving,'' Mrs. Thomas said. Hoffman's family said he was shot when Iraqi soldiers tried to force their way into his Kuwait City apartment on Sept. 5. The bullet shattered a bone in his left forearm and he was hospitalized for about a week. He was later held at a strategic chemical plant 45 miles south of Baghdad, they said. Westerners in Iraq have been used as ``human shields'' to deter attack by the U.S.-led multinational forces stationed in the Persian Gulf. Hoffman, a financial analyst with the Kuwaiti government, wore a cast on his arm and appeared to be in pain. Some reports said gangrene had developed from the wound. ``It's just marvelous. It's just wonderful,'' Hoffman's mother, Ann, said of his release. Mrs. Hoffman said she wasn't planning a welcome home party just yet. ``If he wants one, we'll have one,'' she said. Mrs. Hoffman said her son probably will have other things on his mind, such as getting a job. ``He'll do exactly what he wants to do,'' she said. ``But I don't think he'll stay here.'' Hoffman's British fiancee, 27-year-old Nicola Murgatroyd, was scheduled to arrive in Baghdad on Friday. Ms. Murgatroyd, who had planned to marry Hoffman Aug. 17, was among 11 British women who traveled to Baghdad Friday to seek the release of their captive husbands and relatives - against the advice of their government. The British Foreign Office advised the women against going and called the trip ``risky,'' but they ignored the advice. Mrs. Hoffman, who wrote several letters to Saddam urging her son's release, said she doesn't know Ms. Murgatroyd's whereabouts or whether she knows Hoffman has been released. ``We're all thinking about Nikki,'' she said. In Oak Ridge, Mrs. Thomas said she saw her daughter and son-in-law on a Cable News Network report Thursday. ``They've lost a lot of weight and looked haggard,'' she said. ``Brenda mouthed, `Hi Mom.' She knew I'd be watching.'' Swanke, who is in his 60s, has a heart problem. ``That is the reason he has gotten out,'' Thomas said. The Swankes had been living in Kuwait City about eight months before the invasion.Swanke, a vice president of DMJM International, a Los Angeles-based engineering firm, had been hired by the Kuwaiti government to help build a university in the city. Thomas expects his son-in-law will have to stay in Frankfurt a few days for medical observation before the couple can come home. ``We don't know for sure if they are coming to Los Angeles or Oak Ridge,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cianci Declared Winner of Providence Mayoral Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with challenge filed against Cianci over felony conviction, Cianci's comments on victory and on legal challenge, Lippitt conceding. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A recount Friday enabled former Mayor Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. to reclaim the post he was forced from in 1984, but his eligibility to hold office was challenged because of his felony conviction. The state Board of Elections, after an afternoon recount of voting machines, declared Cianci the winner by 248 votes over fellow Republican-turned-independent Frederick Lippitt. ``As far as comebacks go, sure it was a comeback,'' Cianci said. ``Maybe it was astonishing to some people but I always knew we could do it.'' A legal challenge immediately was filed by three Providence voters, disputing Cianci's right to hold office. The challengers, who say they are not affiliated with Lippitt, cite a 1986 amendment to the state Constitution that prevents anyone convicted of a felony from holding office until three years after the conclusion of their sentence and probation. Cianci pleaded no contest on April 24, 1984, to assaulting a man he thought was having an affair with his estranged wife. His wife testified Cianci went after the man with a fireplace log, a lit cigarette and an ashtray. In Rhode Island, a no contest plea is recorded as a conviction. The felony forced Cianci from office. His five-year suspended sentence ended in 1989. Cianci said his campaign had researched the question, decided the law could not be apply retroactively, and called the challenge ``strictly political.'' ``The people have spoken. I think the people would rise up if anyone tried to steal the election,'' said Cianci, who became a popular radio talk show host after leaving office. The city Board of Canvassers planned to certify Cianci's victory on Tuesday. Executive secretary Laurence Flynn said it would consider the legal challenge later in the week. Cianci had led Lippitt by 105 votes going into the recount after mail ballots were counted Thursday. His total then was 16,189. Both men had claimed victory Tuesday night in the three-way race, which also included Democrat Andrew Annaldo. About 100 people watched and recorded the tallies as each of the voting machines was opened and read into a public address system. Lippitt, 73, later hugged tearful supporters at his campaign headquarters, and, with his voice cracking slightly, read a statement giving Cianci the victory, but not his respect. Cianci ``has great talent, if he can put it to good use,'' Lippitt said. ``Not everyone is given a second chance and this time I hope he really will be different.'' Cianci's 10 years in office were some of the most corrupt in recent city history, with 22 people connected to the administration convicted of various crimes. Cianci never was charged in connection with those misdeeds.

DOC.HEAD: Scranton May Be Forced to Lay Off Half of City Employees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with unions rejecting package, details, reax from mayor and union leaders. Picks up 7th graf pvs: `Both the ...'
DOC.TEXT: The hometown of Pennsylvania Gov. Robert Casey is facing a fiscal crisis that could cost half of the 650 city workers their jobs, and the layoffs could start as soon as next week, the mayor said Friday. The unions representing city firefighters, police and the public works employees rejected a new health-benefits package Friday night that Mayor James Connors said would save the city $1.5 million. In light of the unions' decisions, Connors said he expected to begin the layoffs next week. He said he will consider options other than raising taxes, adding: ``At some point someone has to represent the citizens, someone has to represent the taxpayers.'' The proposed layoffs could affect about 100 firefighters, about 70 police officers, 30 clerical workers and 78 Department of Public Works employees. Connors said the city has enough money to meet only its payroll this week. City officials said a court decision refusing to allow the city to float a $4.5 million bond issue triggered the financial crunch. Lackawanna County Court denied the bond issue Nov. 2. The city had to win the court's approval because the money would be used for payroll expenses. Scranton had counted on the bond for general operating expenses when the City Council passed the current budget. Eugene Carroll, president of the local Fraternal Order of Police, said the union voted 111-16 against the health-care plan, calling it a ``giveback'' and violation of the union's contract. When asked what advice he would give to city residents who may be served by a smaller police force, Carroll said, ``Buy a gun, lock your doors and keep your children off the street.'' The firefighters voted 169-15 against the plan. Paul Bernardi, president of Local 669 of the International Association of Firefighters, said he hoped the vote sent a message to the city that ``we are not fooling around.'' The public works union had voted earlier Friday to accept the plan only if police and firefighters approved it. Both the police and firefighters' unions have minimum-manning clauses in their contracts, calling for complements of 200 in the Fire Department and 140 in the Police Department. On Thursday, the city's clerical workers rejected the health benefits package the city offered, and Connors rejected a counterproposal by the clerical union to negotiate a health care package. The union's current contract with the city expires at the end of the year. ``We want to bargain. We don't want it shoved down our throats,'' said union representative Sal Maglio. ``We don't have any more concessions that we can make that won't cost the taxpayers money,'' said Connors. Connors told WNEP-TV that those unions who vote for the new benefits package would probably suffer fewer layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Prior Restraint May Be OK to Protect Noriega
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with judge's comments. Picks up 5th graf, `Noriega's attorneys ...'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge extended a ban against broadcast of taped conversations between Manuel Noriega and his attorneys, but Cable News Network defied the order Friday by playing another recording. In the tape, Noriega discussed two potential government witnesses with his defense team, and speculated on the prosecutors' strategy. CNN President Tom Johnson defended the broadcast, calling the judge's order ``unconstitutional prior restraint.'' U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler told CNN's attorneys he would hold the network in contempt of court if the tapes were played, but did not act immediately. In an interview with a CNN producer broadcast later Friday, Hoeveler said that whether or not he will find the network in contempt ``remains to be seen.'' Noriega's attorneys, meanwhile, accused the U.S. State Department and the Panamanian government of President Guillermo Endara of being the source of the tapes leaked to CNN. ``We believe the State Department had obtained copies of the tapes, and gave them to the Endara government,'' said Noriega's lead attorney Frank Rubino. ``A high-placed person in the Endara government then provided them'' to CNN. A State Department spokesman said the agency was aware of Rubino's comments, but had no immediate reaction. Noriega is charged in a February 1988 indictment with accepting $4.6 million in bribes to turn Panama into a way station for the Medellin cocaine cartel's U.S.-bound drug shipments. He has been held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami since shortly after he surrendered in the wake of the December 1989 U.S. invasion of Panama. The tape played Friday by CNN was a conversation between Noriega and Rubino's secretary, who acted as a translator for the two men. She tells him two more people have been arrested in Panama, and says he should review their names to determine ``whatever they can know about you.'' The men apparently referred to in the tape were an Alfredo Sanchez and Felipe Camargo, a Noriega loyalist now imprisoned in Panama who had been the general's top liaison with the Cubans and is believed to be cooperating with the U.S. government. ``It is very interesting because it shows their strategy,'' Noriega says. ``It says they are trying to induce any of the two of them to testify before the court against me.'' Other tapes played Friday were conversations between Noriega and allies, including a discussion with his mistress' mother about the transfer of $4 million, CNN said. Earlier Friday, Hoeveler extended for 10 days his order banning CNN from using any portion of the tape that could compromise the former Panamanian dictator's attorney-client privilege. ``I cannot conceive that the law of prior restraint is so sacrosanct and so encompassing'' it would allow broadcasting a confidential attorney-client conversation no matter how damaging to the defense, Hoeveler wrote in his order. The judge has also told CNN to turn over the tapes to a federal magistrate, but suspended that requirement after the network appealed the gag order to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. Noriega attorney Jon May said he was preparing arguments to be delivered in Atlanta Monday balancing the right of free speech against the right to a fair trial. ``Right now we are on the cutting edge of the law in both the First Amendment and the Sixth Amendment,'' May said Friday. ``This could end up very quickly in front of the Supreme Court.'' The U.S. Justice Department Friday was continuing its investigation into whether the tapes were made by the Bureau of Prisons and how they got into CNN's hands, said spokesman Doug Tillett. The Justice Department said the Bureau of Prisons had the legal right to tape such calls and does so routinely, but May said Noriega's attorneys were assured their clients calls would not be taped. ``If he asked the guard to call his lawyers, we had been led to believe that those calls would not be recorded,'' May said. And he noted that the prison knew when Noriega spoke to the attorneys, because the guards, and not the prisoner, dialed the calls. Noriega's attorneys say they expect to ask for dismissal of the charges against their client if they can prove misconduct in making or handling of the tapes. The government of Panama, which in January had said its shattered legal system could not properly try Noriega, says it is now in a position to prosecute him if the U.S. case falls apart. ``In the case that the North Americans can't do it, we're going to ask for him, and he will be judged in accord with Panamanian law, because he committed many, many crimes,'' Endara said. Vice President Ricardo Arias said Noriega has ``very serious charges against him'' in Panama. The Panamanian government has charged Noriega and at least seven of his officers with looting the treasury.

DOC.HEAD: New Mexico Police Fan Out For National Interstate 40 Traffic Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: New Mexico authorities joined police along Interstate 40 from California to North Carolina in a 24-hour traffic safety crackdown that ended early Friday. The effort was the first involving every state crossed by the more than 2,500 miles of I-40, New Mexico State Police Chief Neil W. Curran said. ``Operation 24-40'' was organized by the New Mexico state police and the Arizona Department of Public Safety, state police Lt. Bill Kuehl said. I-40 extends about 380 miles across New Mexico from just west of Gallup to just east of Tucumcari. Nationwide, nearly 5,700 tickets were issued, including 2,790 for speeding, said the International Association of Chiefs of Police, which coordinated the crackdown. Police made 56 criminal arrests and seized small amounts of marijuana and cocaine, the association said. In New Mexico, 603 traffic tickets were issued and one drunken driving arrest was made, state police said. Two felony arrests were made in connection with the seizure of 2 grams of crack cocaine and the recovery of a stolen vehicle, Kuehl said. ``It turned out to be a pretty good operation,'' he said. ``At first we were afraid the weather would cause problems.'' Icy roads were reported in a number of states. The effort was dubbed ``Operation 24-40'' for the number of hours and the interstate number. In all, about 80 officers from the state police, New Mexico Mounted Patrol and state Motor Transportation Division took part in the crackdown in New Mexico. The New Mexico National Guard assisted motor transportation officers, who primarily deal with commercial vehicles, Kuehl said.

President Bush is ordering more than 150,000 additional American troops to the Persian Gulf, a move that nearly doubles U.S. firepower in the region and marks a fundamental shift toward an offensive military stance. Bush said Thursday in announcing the new wave of troop deployments for Operation Desert Shield that he still hoped to get Iraq out of Kuwait without starting a war. But he said he wanted an ``adequate offensive military option'' in case United Nations economic sanctions and diplomatic pressures against Iraq prove futile. Analysts said the move brought the United States closer to war with Iraq. ``The Iraqis, in effect, are being put on notice that they will be attacked'' unless they withdraw from Kuwait under Bush's terms, said Frank Gaffney Jr., director of the Center for Security Policy and a former Pentagon official. ---= MOSCOW (AP) - The Soviet Union is giving its qualified approval for the use of military force to drive Iraqi invaders out of Kuwait if the economic embargo and other peaceful pressure tactics fail. But even as Secretary of State James A. Baker III accomplished this goal in talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, it became apparent that Moscow would be a very reluctant partner to such a move in the United Nations. Shevardnadze told reporters Thursday that the use of force probably could not be ruled out. But later, when he was asked to repeat the assertion, he laughed and said: ``I won't say.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration hasn't uttered the dreaded ``R'' word yet concerning the economy, but it is getting awfully close. President Bush on Thursday talked about ``tough times'' and Michael Boskin, his chief economic adviser, spoke of the possibility that the economy could contract in either the final three months of this year or early 1991. Bush and Boskin both avoided using the term recession, but Boskin opened the door to that possibility by discussing the chances that the gross national product, the country's total output of goods and services, might decline in one or more quarters. The traditional definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of declining GNP. ---= SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) - Sen. Alan Cranston's decision not to seek re-election in 1992 because of prostate cancer has focused attention on an already crowded field of would-be successors. But some of them may instead challenge the person Gov.-elect Pete Wilson picks as his successor for California's other U.S. Senate seat. Attracted by Cranston's political weakness stemming from his involvement in the savings and loan scandal, at least 10 Democrats, including former Gov. Jerry Brown, former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein and Walt Disney Corp. President Frank Wells, had floated trial balloons about challenging Cranston or running if he stepped down. Likely Republican candidates include former Rep. Ed Zschau, a moderate who narrowly lost to Cranston four years ago.
