Zschau might be challenged in the Republican primary by a conservative such as former U.S. Treasurer Bay Buchanan, sister of Washington commentator Pat Buchanan, or television commentator Bruce Herschensohn, a former White House aide to Richard Nixon. ---= OSHKOSH, Wis. (AP) - A man convicted of sexually assaulting a woman who testified against him with six of her 46 personalities maintains she wasn't mentally ill and that she consented to have sex with him. Mark A. Peterson, whom a jury Thursday found guilty of second-degree sexual assault, denied he knew the 27-year-old woman had a multiple-personality disorder and said he will appeal. ``I have been the victim for just having a fling with a girl,'' Peterson said. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine during sentencing scheduled for Dec. 10. He remained free on $10,000 bond. ``I still don't think she is mentally ill,'' Peterson said after the verdict. ``What's there to be sorry about? Why should I be sorry for her?'' ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Pawnshops are increasingly becoming home to the gold that made the 1980s glitter as layoffs wrack Wall Street and other industries. But after years of being rudely portrayed by Hollywood as a usurous business preying on the impoverished, the pawnbroking industry is loathe to be seen as a leading recessionary indicator. Lincoln Square Pawnbrokers is an example of the boom. Newly hard-pressed New Yorkers have contributed to a 10 percent jump in unreclaimed valuables hocked this year at the tiny pawnshop. ``This is the largest increase in 15 years,'' said owner Gary Kalter. He said gold jewelry is his most frequently pawned item. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - Two entrepreneurs hope to make their mark in the future with a business from the past. Mark Kominkiewicz and Paul Yeh have left behind their jobs in the world of computers to become milkmen. This week their Lincoln Park Dairy Service began making deliveries in a square-mile area with about 46,000 apartments and condos near the affluent Lincoln Park neighborhood. They've signed up more than 50 customers to start. ``The decade of the 90s is a service-oriented era,'' Kominkiewicz said. ``And we thought that this was a market that definitely could be tapped.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians Fleeing in Unprecedented Numbers
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people are fleeing repressive Albania, but the welcome is wearing thin in Yugoslavia, a troubled neighbor that already has ethnic problems with a large Albanian minority. Officials say more than 600 Albanians have crossed the heavily guarded border from their communist homeland so far this year, compared to only 40 in 1989. Albania's leaders have begun cautious reforms and seek to emerge from decades of self-imposed isolation, but many of their people are taking a faster route to freedom. ``We were forced to escape after enduring years of horror,'' said Pashko Preldakaj, who led 20 people through the rugged mountains of northern Albania last month. ``I cannot describe what it is like to live in Albania.'' Preldakaj's group evaded Albanian frontier guards in an all-night trek that covered 20 miles from Nikc, his home village, across a mountain range more than 6,000 feet high. Adults carried children in their arms, scrambling in the dark over narrow, rocky trails above deep gorges, Preldakaj said. Yugoslav authorities routinely give escaping Albanians up to 30 days in jail for illegal entry, then turn them over to representatives of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. Judith Kumin, deputy director of the refugee agency, said they may be kept in Yugoslavia temporarily if the United Nations pays their expenses. She said the high commissioner's office has no way of knowing how many people are caught trying to flee Albania. On average, Albanian refugees spend six months in Yugoslavia before emigrating. Most go to the United States. The influx has created resentment in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, where the refugees are kept while awaiting resettlement outside the country. Exaggerated claims in Serbian media that 300,000 Albanians have moved into the restive southern province of Kosovo in the past 50 years have incited ethnic hostility. Official statistics indicate only 3,000 people from Albania have moved to Yugoslavia since 1945. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent the 1.9 million people in Kosovo, the heart of medieval Serbia, where 60 people have been killed in ethnic violence during the past year. Only four of the eight refugee centers in Yugoslavia still accept Albanians. About half of them are housed in the federal detention center at Padinska Skela, where conditions are described as overcrowded and unsanitary, with up to three people sharing a cot. About 100 Albanians were moved out of a refugee center in Koviljaca, southwest of Belgrade. Townspeople accused them of molesting local women and, after allegations in the Serbian press that the refugees had poisoned the town's water supply, held a public protest to demand the Albanians be removed. ``We had to comply quickly before someone got hurt,'' Ms. Kumin said. In the words of the Vecernje Novosti of Belgrade, a Serbian newspaper: ``The townspeople felt they were living under Albanian occupation, so they rose up against it, demanding that they (the Albanians) be expelled.'' Recent reports say Albanian authorities have softened their shoot-to-kill policy on the border and have significantly reduced the 25-year prison terms previously imposed on citizens caught trying to flee. Soldiers on shore opened fire with automatic weapons, however, when Aleksandar Gruda and 14 other people hijacked a naval patrol boat Sept. 11 and headed for Yugoslavia, across Lake Scutari. Dozens of rounds hit the vessel, virtually demolishing the superstructure. Gruda's 4-year-old daughter Anisa was killed by a bullet that penetrated the hull and struck her in the head. ``One of the reasons we left was to provide her with a life worthy of a human being,'' Gruda said.

DOC.HEAD: Korean War Documentary Ignites New Battle
DOC.TEXT: The Korean War ended 37 years ago. But a six-hour PBS documentary, ``Korean: The Forgotten War,'' has touched off a new battle even before the start of the series' three-night run tonight. Retired Army Gen. R.G. Stilwell, a regimental commander during the war and 20 years later the commander of United Nations forces in South Korea, thinks it is a ``revisionist'' account favoring North Korea and China. Not so, says Jon Halliday, a British writer who did the documentary for Thames Television, a British commercial network that undertook the project as a co-production with Boston public TV station WGBH. ``I think we'll catch flak from both the left and the right,'' says WGBH executive producer Austin Hoyt, who says he shot new interviews and rewrote some portions of the show to create a more balanced account. The show's U.S. version, narrated by an American, includes interviews with North Korean officers who fought in the war and North Korean civilians. In one exotic case, there are comments by Joshua Chance, a man of Jamaican-Chinese ancestry who Halliday says was with the massive army of Chinese ``volunteers'' sent into the war when U.N. troops pushed up to the Yalu River in late 1950. The show revives old controversies about the war, including the charges of North Korea, which invaded the South with troops and tanks in June 1950, that South Korea started the conflict. It also re-examines - and in the WGBH version, generally rebuffs - the communist side's accusation that the United States waged germ warfare in North Korea, charges sharply denied by the United States. But the show is not solely about the three years of combat in which military casualties on both sides came close to 2.4 million, including 33,629 U.S. combat dead. It also offers views - Korean, Soviet, and American - of the forces that led to the establishment of North and South Korea when Korea was divided at the 38th Parallel after World War II. It also looks at the rise to power of Syngman Rhee in the South and Kim Il Sung in the North, the harsh life under their regimes, and what the North and South have become in the years following the armed truce that ended the war. The origins of the series, Hoyt says, ``were really sort of a revisionist view'' by Halliday and Bruce Cumings. The latter is a Chicago-based history professor with whom Halliday wrote a book on the war. He is among those interviewed in the series. ``I think they made a very good contribution to see the Korean War in the context of Korea,'' Hoyt said. ``But there were a lot of battles at Thames between the official British military historians and Cumings and Halliday over who was responsible for the war, and whether the United States presence was a destructive one.'' Hoyt asked Stilwell to look at the series and offer comments, and initially he was listed as a consultant on the WGHB version. He later asked that his name and those of two colleagues be deleted. The request was granted. The general said he basically objects to the series because he considers it tilted toward the North Korean and Chinese viewpoint: ``I think they've (the show's makers) shown great cynicism about the American effort to come to the aid of a nation under siege and stay the course and secure the freedom of that country,'' he said. The show doesn't favor the communist side, Halliday said by phone from London. In fact, he said, the Chinese ``refused to cooperate with us'' in the making of the series. His goal ``was to make it as objective as possible,'' he said. ``That is, you have to listen to the voices of the competing parties. But it's absolutely not pro-North Korean or pro-communist.'' His assessment of Hoyt's version of the series: ``I think there is a tilt towards what I would call sort of the official U.S. position.'' All is well between Hoyt and Thames officials, according to Hoyt, who says they have backed and are pleased with his changes. He's philosophical about the war over the documentary: ``The fur is flying from both the left and the right. Frankly, Gen. Stilwell thinks we didn't do enough to temper the revisionist views of Halliday and Cumings, and Halliday and Cumings think I'm in bed with Gen. Stilwell.'' He doesn't anticipate peace for a while. ``The way I see it, this is sort of like Panmunjom,'' he said, referring to the Korean site where peace talks dragged on for two years before the war finally ended and where negotiations between the former combatants still occur. ``There's not an armistice yet.'' --- Elsewhere in television... BACK TO THE FUTURE, THE PREQUEL: CBS, which last season got high ratings when it aired the pilot of what became ``I Love Lucy,'' tonight offers a retrospective of ``The Honeymooners,'' another top CBS series that began during the Korean War. Hosted by Audrey Meadows, who played Jackie Gleason's long-suffering wife, Alice, the one-hour show is called ``The Honeymooners Anniversary Special.''

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Commission Hero Just Wants a Job
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes ordinary people can do extraordinary things. This month, the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission recognized 18 men and women for saving the lives of others; here is one in a series of portraits of those heroes. ---

Robert Mathews says it was just a reflex that led him to go into a burning house to rescue a 3-year-old boy - three times. ``What got me, there were people just standing there,'' said Mathews. And he couldn't pass the horror by. Mathews, 33, is unemployed. But he says he was reluctant to take the $2,500 check that he won from the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission this month. It is embarrassing, he says, to profit when the little boy he saved, James Edwards, suffered such pain and disfigurement. ``I kind of don't like to take the money because he got burned up and all,'' Mathews said. ``I really don't need the money right away. ... I'll probably get him a little something for Christmas.'' Mathews was driving his friend Carl Knopf to work Nov. 17, 1989, when he saw smoke coming out of a house. A nightgown-clad Darla Edwards was on the roof, screaming that her son was trapped in a rear, second-floor bedroom. ``I couldn't believe it,'' Knopf said. ``We saw smoke, and he stopped the car right in the middle of the road, ran to the house and kicked in the door.'' Twice he was driven back by smoke and heat. On the third try, Mathews put a coat over his mouth, took flashlight in hand, rushed up the stairs and found James unconscious and on fire. He was burned on 85 percent of his body. ``There were flames coming out of the room. Part of his arm was still on fire. The coat I had over my mouth to keep the smoke out of me I put on his arm to get the fire out,'' said Mathews. ``He lost the outer part of his ears and all his fingers,'' Mathews said. ``I just wish I could have come along a little bit earlier.'' The boy was released from the hospital this summer, and is back at home after plastic surgery. Surgeons have fashioned thumbs out of his flesh. The Carnegie honor is one of several that have come Mathews' way. Warren Fire Chief Roger Hernon hopes the publicity will get him a job. Mathews hasn't worked in more than a year, unable to find a job in this Rust Belt city in northeast Ohio. The area fell on hard times during the 1970s and 1980s, when the steel industry declined. Mathews lives in a one-room apartment and uses welfare payments to pay his rent and keep his car running. He has moved from job to job, laying carpet, hanging dry wall, doing maintenance work and working as a security guard. As a child, his family was burned out of their home. But there was no foreshadowing of the heroism he exhibited a year ago. ``It was especially a thrill to me the way he did it,'' said Hernon, the fire chief. ``He made an attempt up the stairs, ran back down and got a coat and ran upstairs and rescued the baby. ``The thing that impressed me most was everybody today is saying, `What's in it for me?' ... You've heard, `Let George do it.' Well, he was George. It reaffirms your faith in your fellow man.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, Nov 12

DOC.HEAD: Truck Driver, Worried About City's Safety, Killed Stopping Robbery
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes ordinary people can do extraordinary things. This month, the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission recognized 18 men and women for saving the lives of others; here is one in a series of portraits of those heroes. ---

David Guillen was walking from his apartment to an outdoor phone booth one night last December when he saw two men shove a 13-year-old boy and order him to give up his moped. Guillen, a 32-year-old truck driver who had grown tired of crime in his neighborhood, told the men to leave the boy alone. They did. And one man shot Guillen to death. Nearly a year after the Dec. 1, 1989, shooting in this Los Angeles suburb, the David Guillen killing remains unsolved, with no arrests and apparently no leads. But Guillen's action was not forgotten. The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission posthumously awarded Guillen with one of its medals Nov. 1. To Guillen's friends and family, his actions came as no surprise. ``He'd give you the shirt off his back, then end up the next day without a shirt,'' said brother Tony Guillen. Among his friends and family, he was known as something of a character, doing things like helping strangers stranded on the freeway and talking to just about everybody he met on the street. Guillen had big plans. He worried the neighborhood was getting too dangerous for his pregnant girlfriend and their son, Alex. He wanted to move to the Sacramento area, and put in a request to transfer to his trucking company's Northern California office. ``He just wanted to get to a smaller, safer place,'' said Yvonne Pechenco, his girlfriend of five years. ``He was tired of all the violence, where you couldn't watch the news without all the drive-bys and shootings.'' Guillen was so sure the transfer was coming that late last year he told Yvonne to start packing, and he had the utilities shut off in their apartment. As of the first day of December 1989, the phone was disconnected. With boxes filled and ready to move, Guillen needed to make a quick telephone call to a relative. The nearest phone was at a market across the street. At about 7:30 p.m., Guillen left the apartment. ``It looked like what we call a street shakedown robbery,'' said Los Angeles County sheriff's Detective Michael Lee. ``These guys were hassling a young man. Guillen says this and that and tried to intervene. For his trouble, he got shot.'' His death left scars that have been slow to heal. Miss Pechenco, who gave birth to Guillen's son, David, six months after the shooting, still can't bring herself to return to work and put her life back on course. Not as long as the case is unsolved, she said. ``I have it in me to go, maybe to Arizona or something, but something keeps telling me to stay,'' said Miss Pechenco, raising the two boys and living in her mother's East Los Angeles apartment. Guillen also has two other children, both daughters, by a previous marriage. The $2,500 Carnegie award and the medal went to Guillen's oldest child, 13-year-old Norma, by his first marriage. A year later, tears still well in the eyes of his mother, Pilar Guillen, when she talks about him. Told his son was considered a hero, she answered in Spanish: ``That doesn't bring my son back.''

DOC.HEAD: `Hero' Shrugs Aside Honor, Says `Anyone Would Have Done It'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes ordinary people can do extraordinary things. This month, the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission recognized 18 men and women for saving the lives of others; here is one in a series of portraits of those heroes. ---

Ask Michael Radwich about his 1974 Malibu and he'll regale you with tales of cranking up his pride and joy on a local stock car racetrack, and how he hopes next year will be his big year. Ask about the rescue that won him an award from the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission and made him a much-admired local celebrity and he's apt to roll his eyes, grin an engaging grin and emit a series of ``Yeps'' and ``Nopes.'' ``It's all right, I guess,'' he says. A year ago, Radwich grabbed co-worker Scott Pierce and fought a desperate tug-of-war with a gravel grinder hungry to snatch both men into its rusty maw. Today, he doesn't know what made him risk his life for a man who was no more than a casual acquaintance. Nothing in his previous 23 years had raised the issue of what he would do if it came to a decision between standing aside or chancing death. ``I never really thought about it to tell you the truth,'' he said in a recent interview from his modest apartment tucked behind the hardware store in this western Massachusetts town of 1,700. ``I figured I had to do something. I couldn't leave him.'' Radwich still works at the gravel plant, and he still carries the marks of his actions, a bent and scarred left thumb he can wiggle only about a half-inch. Left-handed, he had to teach himself to write again, and it will be a few more months before he can go back to his passion, stock-car racing. ``My doctor says one crazy thing to another,'' he said with a laugh. The man he rescued has a little more to say. ``I'm just glad someone was there that was quick thinking. If he wasn't there I would have been killed. My arm would have been torn off by the shaft and I would definitely have been killed,'' Pierce said. ``There aren't enough words. `Thanks' seems to be all right with him.'' The accident occurred Oct. 18, 1989, while the 21-year-old Pierce and Radwich were trying to repair the grinder, a large structure towering 80 feet above the ground that on a good day clanks and throbs as it spits out gravel and sand. ``He moved in to look at something. He had a shirt on that was unbuttoned and the tails came out and got wrapped up in the shaft and he reached in to try to pull it out and that's when he got caught up in it,'' Radwich recalled. ``He started yelling to shut it off and the switch to shut it off was down on the ground so I grabbed a hold of him,'' he said. After a third man hit an emergency switch on the ground, the two men fell back on the platform, Pierce with his left arm hanging on by the triceps, Radwich with his left thumb all but severed. Both men have regained use of their injured limbs through operations and therapy, but neither is back 100 percent. The two men said they've become closer since. ``He doesn't expect anything from me,'' Pierce said. ``When we see each other we talk and stuff, but he never says, `Well, since I did this you go down to the store and get me something.' He treats me just like everybody else.''

DOC.HEAD: N.C. Hero Says He Never Hestitated to Save Life
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes ordinary people can do extraordinary things. This month, the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission recognized 18 men and women for saving the lives of others; here is one in a series of portraits of those heroes. ---

Roy Aden didn't hesitate when he saw a man grab a gun away from a state trooper. ``If you don't help someone in need, then you're a failure,'' he says. ``And one failure can destroy your whole life.'' Aden, 48, a former Marine who still sports a crew cut, jumped in when state trooper Christopher Phillips was on the verge of losing a life-and-death struggle with a man in front of the Skyland, N.C., service station where Aden worked. ``I feel good about being recognized, but I didn't do it for that,'' he said. ``I'd like to think another person would do the same thing.'' After working the late-night shift at the Exxon station last Feb. 11, Aden saw Phillips pull over a car in front of the gas pumps. As the trooper approached the car, the driver got out and pulled out a large hunting knife. After Phillips took the weapon away, the man bolted. Phillips caught up with him, and they struggled. As he tried to cuff him, the man grabbed Phillips' service revolver from its holster. That's when Aden rushed to the trooper's aid. ``He was on top of the trooper and I came up from behind and pulled him off. That's when I saw the gun point up in the air,'' Aden said. ``The man screamed, `Get away. I've got a gun!' I held his arm and the gun went off. ``We were struggling and we went down. This guy was pretty strong. It took both of my hands to hold his one hand. Then Trooper Phillips regained his balance and the two of us grabbed hold of the gun. ``I didn't even think about what had happened until it was over,'' he said. ``He could have killed both of us.'' When word of his deed hit the local media, Aden was recognized as a hero. He received awards from the highway patrol, several local civic organizations and Gov. Jim Martin. ``To tell you the truth, if I didn't help, I wouldn't have been able to look at myself in the mirror the next morning,'' he said. ``My mother and father raised me to know the difference between right and wrong.'' Aden admits he's far from infallible. He's been married three times, the last 10 years to his wife, Pat, who urged her husband to intervene when she saw the trooper in trouble. With her help, Aden has kicked a drinking problem. The day before he received the Carnegie award and a $2,500 cash prize, he lived up to his promise to her and went to church for the first time in years. He used part of the money to help his sister pay some overdue bills. Aden said he found it difficult to accept the Carnegie award after he learned that three of the winners died in their attempts to save others. It reminded him of how he felt after receiving the Silver Star and other medals upon returning from duty in Vietnam, where many of his friends were killed or seriously injured. ``The ones who died - those are the real heroes,'' he said. ``I may have risked my life, but they gave it.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs PMs, Nov. 15

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Man Cited For Heroism in Saving 2-Year-Old
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes ordinary people can do extraordinary things. This month, the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission recognized 18 men and women for saving the lies of others; here is one in a series of portraits of those heroes. ---

Larry Ogletree doesn't think of himself as a hero. The Evans, Ga., man said he was just doing what he hopes anyone would do when he chased a runaway car, dodged traffic and stopped an oncoming 18-wheeler to rescue a 2-year-old boy inside the car. ``If one of my sons were in a life-threatening situation, whether it be that or anything, I would want somebody to do the same thing,'' said Ogletree, general manager for the American National Insurance Cos. office in Augusta and the father of three boys, ages 12, 7 and 4. Ogletree, 40, had just turned onto a busy five-lane highway in suburban Martinez on his way to work Aug. 8, 1989, when he spotted the silver compact car rolling out of a convenience store parking lot. ``It just didn't look normal,'' he said. ``There was something wrong. The wheels weren't turning or anything. Then I saw the child's head in the back of the car.'' He also saw a woman, later identified as the child's mother, standing in the parking lot screaming. ``At that point, I knew what was happening,'' Ogletree said. He jumped the median in his own car and parked, then began chasing the runaway car, which was traveling diagonally across traffic headed into the path of the oncoming tractor-trailer rig. ``I looked up at the 18-wheeler,'' Ogletree said. ``His and my eyes met. He just understood and he, of course, applied his brakes. He was about 10 feet from the car. I was running the whole time.'' Ogletree finally got close enough to grab the driver's side of the car, which was open. ``I threw myself into it. I had a hold of the steering wheel and applied the brakes. The child was calm until I hit the brakes. Then he started crying. He was in a safety seat.'' Ogletree, who escaped with only scarred shins, said he believes the boy's sister accidentally hit the gearshift when she got out of the car, allowing the car to roll. The mother thanked him but implored him not to release her name or the names of her children, a request he has honored. Ogletree said he didn't fully grasp what might have happened until that night, when he went to pick up his two younger boys at a day-care center adjacent to the convenience store. ``I guess that at that point it kind of came over me I might not have been there to pick them up. It was very emotional,'' he said. Frank Spears, an insurance agent in a competing firm, has known Ogletree more than 10 years and said he wasn't surprised by his actions. ``He's that kind of a fellow,'' Spears said. ``He is not one that sits on the sidelines. He is a doer, a mover, a shaker. If you go into a fight, you want him to be behind you.'' ``I don't think any of us were prepared for the fact that someone would have the courage to do what he did,'' said Carol Shearer, a volunteer at the Columbia County Humane Society, who met Ogletree, now the group's president, about two years ago. ``He's been very modest about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Big Dip in Small-Business Confidence
DOC.TEXT: The small-business optimism index fell in October to its lowest level in more than 10 years, presaging a shrinking of the economy in the final quarter of the year. Economist William C. Dunkelberg, who analyzed replies from more than 2,000 small- and medium-size businesses, said gross national product would decline by 1.5 percent, ``the first official quarter with negative growth.'' Dunkelberg said the responses suggested the decline would be accompanied by higher unemployment and worsening inflation, and he blamed the latter partly on what he said was Congress' failure to solve the deficit problem. Adding to inflationary pressures, he said, was the prospect that Congress is ``prepared to heap on a whole new set of cost-raising regulations,'' including various mandated costs and paperwork that will consume time and effort. The index is based on responses from members of the National Federation of Independent Business, which claims more than 500,000 members, ranging from proprietorships to companies with sales in the hundreds of millions of dollars. The federation says the business community it represents employs about half the private non-farm work force and produces about 50 percent of gross national product, and that its optimism index foretells economic direction. Its estimate of third-quarter gross national product, for example, was for a gain of 1.7 percent on an annual basis, just one-tenth of one percent from the Commerce Department's preliminary estimate of a 1.8 percent gain. Dunkelberg, dean of Temple University's school of business and management, was especially critical of what he said was legislation-induced inflation resulting from imposition of regulations and mandates on an already stressed private sector. Among regulations he said would add to business costs were a rise in the minimum wage and ``mandated health costs, mandated leaves, mandated access for the handicapped, mandated pollution controls, and lots of related `paperwork' that will eat up valuable entrepreneurial time.'' In effect, he said, mandates are a form of taxation atop official taxation, which the responding companies declared the No. 1 problem facing small business today. The Federal Reserve, he said, cannot reduce this kind of inflation through monetary policy, adding that ``only Congress can do it with some responsible legislation and some common sense.'' While many people expect the Fed to ease up on the money supply and allow interest rates to fall, Dunkelberg discounted the possibility. Inflation fears, he said, will simply prevent any major easing. A large factor in the decline of the confidence index was what Dunkelberg said was the ``incredible'' finding that 43 percent of the companies expect business conditions to worsen, almost double the previous quarter's level. Expected business conditions is one of 10 items making up the index. Among others are expected sales volumes, expected credit conditions, current job openings, plans to hire and capital outlay plans. The index was begun in 1974 and uses 1978 conditions as its base of 100. The latest reading of 92.3 was the lowest since the second quarter of 1980, when the all-time low of 81.1 was reached. Aside from the all-time low, the latest reading was the lowest for any quarter since the first year of the index's existence, when it reached 87.8 in early 1975. Summing up he results, Dunkelberg said ``it's clear the economy is going down, at least for a short count.'' The expansion wasn't marked by extremes, he said, ``and it is likely the slowdown that follows will be equally boring.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Mon Nov 12.

DOC.HEAD: Utilities Are Stock Analysts' Current Hope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: If you look for a spark of life in the stock market these days, the search pretty much begins and ends with electric utility issues. While the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was climbing to record highs near the 3,000 mark earlier this year, the electric utility group languished in disfavor. But since late summer, as fears of recession gripped the markets, the roles have been reversed. From its low point for the year on Aug. 24 through Nov. 2, Dow Jones's average of 15 utilities climbed more than 13 percent. Among the 15 common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that made new 52-week highs in the week ended Nov. 2, nine were shares of electric companies - from DQE Inc. in Pittsburgh to Houston Industries in Texas, from Dominion Resources on the East Coast to Pacific Gas & Electric in California. As often happens in periods of market euphoria, investors shunned the group in the spring and early summer while they looked for racier ways to benefit from rising stock prices. Now, analysts say, money is flowing back the other way looking for a high-yielding haven from the perils of a bear market. ``Investing in the electric utilities in a climate of economic weakness presents something close to a win-win situation,'' maintains Barry Abramson, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities, in a recent report spotlighting the group. ``Electric utilities would be strong in a sideways market. If the economy continues to stagnate and the stock and bond markets show no clear direction, the electric utilities should outperform thanks to their superior and very safe yields. ``On the other hand, if a recession continues to threaten and the Federal Reserve eases dramatically, falling interest rates would also provide a catalyst for the group. ``In fact, just about the only scenario that would be negative for the electric utilities would be a rapidly strengthening economy and a renewed bull market - a very unlikely outcome, at least in the near term.'' The current level of utility dividends - the stocks yielded about 6.7 percent, on average, as of early this month - is an attraction by itself. Beyond that, analysts say, utility profits and payouts aren't much affected by the ups and downs of the business cycle, and can even keep growing gradually in periods of recession. ``They offer high dividends that our analysts believe are secure,'' said Jack Lavery, director of global research at Marrill Lynch. Utilities also stand to be prime beneficiaries of declining interest rates, since lower rates reduce the relative allure of bonds as the two classes of securities compete for the favor of yield-conscious investors. But that last point has a flip side, caution some wary utility-watchers. When hopesfor lower rates go unfulfilled, utility stocks often bear the brunt of their frustration. The group fell sharply last January, for example, when a rise in worldwide interest rates caught many optimists off guard. Whether the news is good or bad, however, many observers say utilities' ultra-sensitivity to changing interest-rate expectations often qualifies them as an advance indicator of where the rest of the stock market might be heading. Said William LeFevre at Advest Inc.: ``Frequently the utilities turn early, both before the broad stock market starts down and before it turns up.''

DOC.HEAD: All Men (Sic) May Be Equal, But What About Women?
DOC.TEXT: Just a minute, Karlyn Kohrs Campbell. Hold on there, Kathleen Hall Jamieson. What do you think you're doing? You set out to write a serious, scholarly, maybe just-a-little-dull book about the crucial role that language plays in the making of a successful presidency. You say you want to ``demonstrate rhetoric to be a fundamental, constitutive element of the presidency.'' That you've done. The University of Chicago Press published it. The title is ``Deeds Done in Words: Presidential Rhetoric and the Genres of Governance.'' It is full of arcane language and heavy thoughts. ``The special character of presidential inaugural addresses is defined by these general epideictic features and by the nature of the inauguration ceremony,'' you write. Stuff like that. You didn't set out to write, one would think, a feminist tract. But that you've done, too. You've dedicated your book: ``To the women who should have been president; to the women who tried to be president; to the women who will be president.'' In footnote 12 to Chapter 4, you drop your bombshell. You've read every State of the Union address ever delivered, and discovered that in these speeches, women are invisible. ``Through 1966,'' you write, ``they are mentioned only twice, once in relation to polygamy, by (Ulysses) Grant; once in relation to suffrage, by (Woodrow) Wilson. More recently they have been alluded to indirectly in Ronald Reagan's statements supporting abortion.'' And to drive home your point about the maleness of presidential vision, you turn to a linguistic device. You use ``sic'' to show that the words quoted are reproduced exactly as they appeared in the original. You use ``sic'' to show that in their most formal rhetoric, presidents have always talked about (and thought about) ``he'' when they might have said (and thought about), ``he or she.'' In this book, sic is a scythe. Look: - Quoting the Constitution: the president ``shall from time to time give to the Congress information on the state of the Union and recommend to their consideration such measures as he (sic) shall judge necessary and expedient.'' - Quoting George Washington: ``The magnitude and difficulty of the trust to which the voice of my country called me, being sufficient to awaken in the wisest and most experienced of her citizens a distrustful scrutiny into his (sic) qualifications, could not but overwhelm with despondence one who ought to be peculiarly conscious of his own deficiencies.'' - Quoting Theodore Roosevelt: ``Our aim is to recognize what Lincoln pointed out: The fact that there are some respects in which men (sic) are obviously not equal ....'' - Quoting Harry Truman: ``In all that we do we should remember who we are and what we stand for. We are Americans. Our forefathers (sic) had far greater obstacles than we have, and much poorer chances of success.'' - Quoting Lyndon Johnson: ``For our ultimate goal is a world without war, a world made safe for diversity, in which all men (sic), goods and ideas can freely move across every border and every boundary.'' What's up? In an interview, author Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, ducks. ``That's my co-author,'' says Ms. Jamieson. ``We let the senior author do the stylistic stuff. If it had been up to me, I'd have settled for a statement in the introduction. You can make the point once. Your readers are smart enough.'' So, senior author Campbell, professor of speech-communication at the University of Minnesota, what are all these sics here for? ``As kind of a reminder to the audience about the very real male character of political thinking in this country in the past. ... I don't think of it as a feminist book, but I think of it as a book that has some feminist sensibility.'' So take note, Mister (sic) Presidents.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tue AMs, Nov. 13

DOC.HEAD: In N.C., the Acrid Aftermath of a Bitter Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: In what they did and what they didn't do after their bitter U.S. Senate race, Jesse Helms and Harvey Gantt symbolized the rift in a state deeply divided over its most conspicuous member of Congress. Helms gleefully tweaked his antagonists, the ``ultraliberal establishm'' promising to press on with his agenda, a combination of traditional anti-big government conservatism and anti-abortion, anti-homosexual and other appeals. ``Can't you just hear the sobs?'' he asked with a broad smile after winning his fourth term. Gantt acknowledged only that Helms received more votes, refusing to phone the state's senior senator or officially concede. ``I don't concede to that kind of campaign or that kind of vision for North Carolina,'' he said. ``There's no way to extend a hand,'' said Professor John Aldrich, chairman of Duke University's political science department. He and other analysts, and voters themselves, said Helms' strongly held views and iconoclastic style leave few constituents lukewarm about him. Some North Carolinians voted for Helms as a folk hero, others voted against him as an embarrassment. Many of Helms' supporters feel proud - and, some say, relieved - that the ultraconservative Republican pulled out a victory. They still smart, however, at labels they say were pinned on them during the campaign: illiterate, uneducated, racist. Gantt's faithful boast of the strong showing - 47.4 percent of the vote - by the black challenger, who had been given little chance when he entered the contest. They're determined to ``try, try again.'' For now, though, many say they feel unrepresented. Two North Carolinians whose votes canceled each other out illustrate the strong feelings Helms elicits. Joe Overby voted for Helms. He likes the senator's conservative fiscal and social views. Overby said he's concerned about the growing national debt, troubled by the influence of liberal politicians and commentators. Just as much, he likes Helms' refusal to compromise even when under harsh attack. ``He's the only man that's ever run for office who said he'd do so and so, and he's done it. He won't back down,'' said Overby, 80, who arrived at a Helms post-election rally wearing the stars-and-stripes top hat and jacket of Uncle Sam. A printed card he gave a reporter contains his picture and examples of his philosophy, which he said reflects his idea of the ``traditional North Carolina values'' that Helms said he represented. ``Let's all read our Bible,'' the card says in part. ``Let us thank God that we live in the greatest nation in all the world.'' Helms' won 58 percent of the votes of older North Carolinians and 67 percent of the white Protestant vote, along with support from traditional Republicans and others, according to exit polls. He won about 65 percent of the white vote overall, and did better in rural areas. Younger, more urban people tended to vote for Gantt, and he garnered 93 percent of the black vote, according to the polls. Clarence McAdoo, 36, a black custodian at a public school in Greensboro, fits that profile - and he said he saw North Carolina's divisions deepening with Helms' campaign and victory. He cited a television ad Helms used late in the campaign when polls indicated the race was close. It showed the hands of a white job seeker crumpling an application after being told that racial quotas required the position go to someone else, even though that person was less qualified. ``The old bogey-man tactics,'' said McAdoo. Gantt said a day after the election that he may have underestimated race as a factor among voters. ``We have to deal with the question of race as a state,'' he said. Taking a lunch break from his custodial duties, McAdoo said the racial message he picked up from Helms hurt, and he told a story about his children. ``My youngest two came over last night to help me clean up after the election (the school had been a polling place), and we talked about it as we were riding home. There was a mock election at school that day and it showed Mr. Gantt was going to win. So they were disappointed, too. ``I told them not to look at the race as a black-and-white issue. I don't want them to get that type of mentality,'' McAdoo said. ``It's more or less that, when at first you don't succeed, try, try again. I'm just trying to teach them the old-fashioned values, like I was taught.'' State Republican party officials denied race decided the election, and local organizers contended the charge was just part of an unfair view of the voters they knew. ``I keep reading about the stereotype, that it was a racist thing,'' said Patrick Farmer, GOP chairman in Onslow County, which voted 61 percent-39 percent for Helms while also electing a black Democratic judge by a landslide. The racism charge ``just wouldn't be borne out.'' Farmer said he resented the way Helms voters often were portrayed, especially as the television networks focused on the North Carolina race. ``One of the newscasters said, `Well, obviously the Helms supporters are the illiterate, tobacco-chewing, uneducated people.''' But Farmer described them as ``a cross-section of everyone'' - business people like himself, retirees, farmers, factory workers. They ``breathed a sigh of relief'' when the election was over because of the sharp political differences between their candidate and his opponent. ``We're glad to have someone in Washington who does say no,'' he said. Gantt made no effort to conceal his liberal credentials. Government has a role, he said, in solving education, enviromental and health care problems. He called Helms ``the last of a dying breed'' of Southern politician. A day before the election, Helms fired back at Gantt in familiar style: ``He is bought and paid for by militant left-wing groups such as NARAL (National Abortion Rights Action League), the homosexuals, the lesbians ... the ACLU - you name it ... ``They just want to get this conservative, Jesse Helms, out of Congress.'' Campaigning before white audiences, Helms accused Gantt of running a ``secret campaign'' to get black voters to the polls. Some voters remembered Helms' 12-year tenure in the 1960s and early '70s as an on-air commentator for a Raleigh television station, during which he called civil rights leaders communists and blasted war protesters and the press. ``He operates by playing on the fears of people about secular devils,'' said political science professor Abraham Holzman of North Carolina State University. ``Degenerate devils, homosexual devils, abortionist devils, liberal devils.'' Some Gantt supporters described Helms in terms of evil, too, and such bitterness can't be put aside at the end of the campaign, Holtzman said, asking, ``How can you shake hands with the devil?'' Aldrich, the Duke professor, said changing demographics may eliminate the gulf. Helms won votes from people born in the South, but more and more North Carolinians are emigres from other states, he said. He also noted the younger vote against the 69-year-old senator and the declining populations in many rural areas, a Helms stronghold. Eventually, Helms no longer will have the kind of majority he assembled, Aldrich said. ``Then,'' he said, ``the acrimony level will drop off tremendously.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeast regional reporter, based in Atlanta.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Nov. 11

DOC.HEAD: Economic Frustration, But Little Direction in Voting
DOC.TEXT: Those looking for economic signals in Tuesday's election noted lots of frustration with the status quo. The economy was a top concern among voters, according to surveys conducted outside polling places. But the resolve to bear any burden to rebuild the economy was much less evident. The results defied a simple label: anti-Bush, anti-tax, anti-incumbent, anti-spending. There was evidence of all that, leaving the surviving office holders to wonder what their next moves ought to be. Raise taxes? Forget it. The voters turned out governors in Florida and Kansas associated with tax hikes, and Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., was nearly defeated because of state tax increases initiated by Democratic Gov. Jim Florio, who wasn't even on the ballot. Cut the deficit? OK, but watch where you cut. Candidates endorsed by President Bush were blistered by the voters, partly because of his awkward handling of the federal budget compromise. Incumbents in Congress, who were also a party to the pre-election deficit deal, mostly were returned to office, but margins were shockingly slim in many cases. Raise money for public projects through bond issues? Not so fast. Propositions for prison construction, colleges, parks, environmental initiatives and housing loans went down to defeat. Voters seemed disenchanted with government in general. Indeed, one lucky survivor, Republican William Weld, won the governor's office in Massachusetts by promising to pare government and ``keep the priority list short.'' Even more troubling were the large numbers of voters who chose to bypass the election, many because they had lost faith in the problem-solving ability of any politicians. Yet the results did not suggest an all-out tax revolt. In Massachusetts, for instance, the voters rejected a ballot initiative that would have rolled back state taxes by about $2 billion a year. The voters called instead for new ideas. They elected Democrat Lawton Chiles governor of Florida because he promised to spurn special interests and listen to the people. Chiles's grassroots campaign included talking with people at recycling centers, teen-age pregnancy programs and day-care centers. The economic mandate was best articulated by House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., himself a re-election survivor, who said the president had to ``come to Capitol Hill with an action plan for reviving the economy and reworking the system to the benefit of working families.'' The goal - to rework the system - was clear, but the plan for achieving it wasn't. Leaders from the statehouse to the White House faced the challenge of designing fresh approaches from a limited array of options.
DOC.HEAD: MARKETS: Attention Turns Back to Fed, Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The markets, for their part, went right on hoping for an easy way out of the economic downturn: namely, looser credit from the Federal Reserve. The quickest fix for the economy would be a bigger-than-normal shot of inflation. That would make debts carried by all entities - government, businesses and households - a lot easier to shoulder. The Fed gave a pre-election sign that credit would ease when it lowered the rate charged on overnight loans between banks in response to thebudget compromise. The markets were hoping for still more. The forecast for lower rates prompted heavy demand for $34 billion in new government securities offered for sale in a quarterly refunding by the Treasury. Investors gobbled up the new bonds and notes to lock in current interest rates. Meanwhile, traders worried about the prospects for war, now that national officials have the election behind them. Stocks and bonds tumbled and oil rallied the day after election, mostly in response to new signals that war could be imminent in the Persian Gulf. Among those reviving such talk was the normally reliable British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Two oil market analysts even tried to narrow the window for war by analyzing the tides and the moon. Peter Beutel and Thomas Blakeslee of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. said the best time for attack would be after midnight between Nov. 12 and Nov. 22. The Kuwaiti tide would be high after midnight, allowing commandos to get closer to a potential beachhead. The moon phase would keep the sky dark.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: Retailers Continue Their Swoon
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top retailers reported dismal sales for October, heightening concerns about the Christmas season. Several companies, including Sears, Roebuck and J.C. Penney Co., said sales were down from October of last year. The retail business has been slow since August, due to uncertainty over the economy and the Persian Gulf, and most experts said the slump would continue through the holidays. One analyst, Jeffrey Feiner of Merrill Lynch & Co., said shoppers had settled into ``a recessionary psychology.'' The impact on holiday sales could be devastating for storekeepers - and mean smaller, cheaper gifts under the tree.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Some Good News on Auto Sales
DOC.TEXT: Auto sales provided some unexpected good news. Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks rose 8.5 percent in late October and were up 5.7 percent for the first month of the 1991 model year. But the figures clashed with comments from dealers, who said people were looking but not buying the new models. Meanwhile, the government issued a report showing the productivity of American workers climbed at the fastest pace in two years during the July-September quarter. But the number of hours worked declined, indicating businesses were making do with fewer employees. A Labor Department report on producer prices showed wholesale inflation soared in October for the third consecutive month. Rising energy prices were to blame.
DOC.HEAD: ADVERTISING: How to Squash a Volvo
DOC.TEXT: Volvo owners should not try this one at home. A TV commercial by the automaker showed a Volvo holding up to a trouncing by a monster truck with thousand-pound tires. Other vehicles in the path of the truck were squashed to a pulp. How did the Volvo survive? That was precisely what the Texas Attorney General's office wanted to know. The answer was the car had been reinforced with steel or wood. Under pressure from the ornery Texas regulators, Volvo agreed to make no unproven claims, run corrective newspaper ads and pay the state $316,250 in investigative costs.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Match Markets' Gloomy Mood
DOC.TEXT: The American consumer gives little promise of providing much help as the economy and Wall Street struggle into the last few weeks of a difficult year. Surveys that seek to measure sentiment among the shopping public show a pronounced mood of caution heading into the traditional peak season for business at the nation's retail stores. Even if consumers were inclined to come riding to the rescue, analysts say, all the economic evidence shows them low on ammunition in the form of money to spend. ``Personal income growth is slowing markedly,'' observed David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. ``This decline reflects the triple threat of declining total employment, higher taxes and surging energy costs. None of these holds much hope for quick relief. ``Nor do the other main factors that influence consumer spending look encouraging. The sharp decline in stock prices since mid-July and the ongoing slide in housing values has slashed household wealth. ``Market interest rates may be edging down, but there's no evidence that this is lowering consumer borrowing costs.'' October sales reports issued by major retailers this past week provided a gloomy picture, on balance, of the state of demand at the threshold of the holiday selling season. Figures due this Wednesday from the Commerce Department on retail sales for October are likely to show a drop about 0.2 percent, according to the Merrill Lynch Market Letter. Adjusted for inflation, ``sales have been essentially flat since June,'' Merrill Lynch analysts say. ``We think sales will weaken through the fourth quarter and into early 1991.'' A primary damper on consumers' optimism, by common agreement, has been the near doubling of oil prices that has accompanied the showdown in the Persian Gulf over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. At their recent levels, energy costs act in the manner of a tax increase, draining disposable income from consumers' wallets and checkbooks. Beyond that, analysts say, enthusiasm has been chilled by heightened uncertainty over what gasoline, heating fuel and petroleum-based products will cost in the future. Three months into the crisis, economists, investors and consumers are still able only to guess among a broad range of possible outcomes in the Middle East. That kind of uncertainty made itself evident in the stock market this past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,488.61, down 2.23 points from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.10 to 171.17; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 5.50 to 341.95, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 1.05 at 291.03. Volume on the Big Board averaged 147.70 million shares a day, against 154.29 million the week before. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to step up efforts soon to stimulate the economy through an easing of credit policy. But many analysts caution that even measures of that kind aren't likely to work wonders overnight. ``Monetary policy should ease, but it will take until at least mid-1991 for this policy to help the economy,'' said Robert J. Stalla at the Cleveland-based firm of McDonald & Co. in a recent commentary. ``Easy money affects the real economy only after a nine-month lag.'' In addition, Stalla declared, ``the root of the economic problem lies mainly inthe financial rather than the real sector. This means that lower interest rates might be used to shore up the capital structures of financial intermediaries rather than as an excuse for liberalizing lending policies.''

DOC.TEXT: The outlook for the Christmas shopping season went from bad to worse as the nation's biggest retailers reported dismal sales results for the month of October. Several companies including Sears, Roebuck & Co. and J.C. Penney Co. Inc. Thursday said sales dropped from levels of a year earlier as consumers, with one eye on the economy and the other on the Middle East, avoided buying anything they didn't need. With Christmas less than seven weeks away, neither the retailers nor the industry analysts who track their performance expect consumers to suddenly shift gears and go on mammoth gift-buying sprees. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Americans took out a seasonally adjusted $3 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in September, the government said. Some analysts saw Thursday's report as a further sign of a consumer spending slowdown, compared to previous years. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Six of the 16 members of a newly appointed Environmental Protection Agency panel considering the health risks of second-hand cigarette smoke have ties to a tobacco industry research organization, documents show. A seventh member of the panel was appointed upon the recommendation of the Philip Morris tobacco company, EPA officials said. ``They've stacked the deck with people who have close ties to the tobacco industry,'' said Dr. Alan Blum, a founder of the anti-smoking group Doctors Ought to Care. ``It's pathetic.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - The Hearst Corp. says it has purchased the 20 percent interest in the sports cable television service ESPN Inc. that had been held by RJR Nabisco Inc. Terms were not disclosed in the Thursday announcement. RJR Nabisco, taken private last year in the biggest debt-financed takeover on record, had hired an investment adviser 15 months ago to help it evaluate whether to sell the ESPN stake. Capital Cities-ABC Inc. owns 80 percent of the cable channel and had the right to match any offer for RJR's interest in ESPN. --- BOSTON (AP) - Groupe Bull, France's state-owned computer maker with extensive U.S. operations, says it will eliminate more than 10 percent of its work force due to a ``crisis'' facing the world computer industry. Bull said Thursday it would slash 5,000 jobs, including up to 1,000 in Massachusetts where it has extensive operations and its U.S. headquarters, and 250 in Phoenix. Bull also projected it would lose 2.88 billion francs, or about $511 million, this year. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Officials in New York and Massachusetts have taken legal action to bar the sale of two junk-bond mutual funds that allegedly duped 270,000 investors, many of ``very modest means,'' with tricky sales pitches. First Investors, a large mutual fund company targeted in the suit, denied the charges Thursday, which included scripted and misleading sales pitches by aggressive representatives seeking to sign up investors in their own living rooms. The company said in a statement it ``will vigorously defend itself and is confident it will prevail.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Developer Donald Trump, already under heavy pressure from his creditors, must prove he can cover the monthly costs of his Trump Palace condominium before any more units are sold, the state attorney general's office said. Trump must produce evidence he can cover the common charges, real estate taxes and other obligations on the 57-story building at 69th Street and Third Avenue, Richard Barr, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert Abrams, said Thursday. --- LONDON (AP) - British Petroleum and Royal Dutch Shell Group have announced dramatically higher third-quarter profits, after riding a sharp rise in crude oil prices prompted by the Persian Gulf crisis. British Petroleum Thursday announced third-quarter net profits of 822 million pounds, or $1.5 billion, nearly a three-fold increase from the 211 million pounds earned in the same period last year. --- DETROIT (AP) - Nissan Motor Corp. has recalled about 33,000 1987-1990 model Nissan Vans because of a potential power steering problem which could result in an engine fire. The company said Thursday it was aware of one slight injury stemming from the problem. The company said a power steering hose may deteriorate because of engine heat. Fluid then could leak onto the exhaust manifold, causing a fire. Nissan said it would notify owners and perform repairs for free. ---

The stock market posted a small gain Thursday after several fitful attempts to rally from Wednesday's broad decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 44.31 points Wednesday, edged up 2.97 to 2,443.81. The dollar staged a sharp advance on world currency markets and gold prices rose. Bonds slipped. Oil prices rallied in a wild session in the petroleum market.

DOC.HEAD: Bad October Sales Makes Gloomy Christmas For Retailers More Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Kmart in 24th graf is cq, reflecting new style on company name.
DOC.TEXT: Hopes for a successful Christmas shopping season all but vanished after the nation's biggest retailers said their business continued to deteriorate in October. Several companies including Sears, Roebuck & Co. and J.C. Penney Co. Inc. reported Thursday that their sales dropped from levels of a year earlier as consumers, preoccupied with concerns about the economy and the Middle East, avoided buying anything they didn't need. The disappointing October sales followed poor showings in August and September, and with Christmas less than seven weeks away, retailers and the industry analysts who track their performance expect consumers to remain frugal during the holiday season. ``They'll probaby be going in and buying the same number of items, but they're not going to pay as much ...'' said Thomas Tashjian, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles. ``They're not going to buy $100 electronic toys for their kids, not this year.'' Analysts said shoppers will be looking harder for bargains and waiting longer for price reductions than in past years. ``They're going to be busy spending fewer dollars,'' said Daniel Barry, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. Consumers cut spending as the economy weakened and after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait raised the specter of war, inflating prices of gasoline and home heating oil. The first items crossed off shopping lists were so-called discretionary items - clothing, furniture, home appliances and other extras that are the bread and butter of many big stores. If retailers have a difficult Christmas, it could contribute to a further deterioration of the economy, since two-thirds of the nation's economic growth is generated by consumer spending. Unsold goods on store shelves could also affect manufacturing - if stores don't place new orders, factories don't need to provide as many products and could lay off workers. And a poor Christmas season could be devastating for the retailers themselves, as they depend on holiday shopping for about half their annual sales and profits. Christmas 1989 was a disappointment for many storeowners after they were forced to slash prices to attract customers. Sears, the country's largest retailer, said October results from stores open at least one year fell 0.4 percent from a year earlier, while overall sales dropped 1.2 percent. Analysts believe sales from stores open at least a year - also known as same-store or comparable store sales - provide a more accurate assessment of a retailer's performance than overall sales do. New stores tend to have extraordinarily strong sales that can skew a retailer's results. One of the hardest hit last month was Penney, which said comparable store sales fell 6.3 percent from October 1989, while overall sales dropped 4.9 percent. Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, reported comparable store sales dropped 1 percent as overall sales rose 13 percent. Apparel stores were also affected by continuing warm weather in some parts of the country. May Department Stores Co., parent of big department store chains including Lord & Taylor, Hecht's, Filene's and Foley's, said comparable store sales dropped 4.4 percent, while overall sales edged up 1.1 percent. But Wal-Mart Stores Inc., one of the biggest discount retailers, continued to outperform the rest of the retail industry, reporting comparable store sales rose 10 percent while overall sales rose 25 percent. Analysts are already predicting trouble for some stores, especially those going into the Christmas season with high inventory levels and unexpectedly poor sales. These retailers are expected to be the first ones to mark down merchandise - and see their profits evaporate. Markdowns set off a spiral of sorts as consumers, having seen one round of price reductions, wait for more merchandise to be marked down and end up forcing retailers to take further cuts. When one retailer lowers prices, it pressures others to follow. Among other reports from retailers Thursday: -Dayton Hudson Corp. said comparable store sales rose 4.1 percent, while overall sales picked up 16.7 percent. -Kmart Corp. reported a 1.3 percent sales gain at comparable stores, and an 11.2 percent rise overall. -Woolworth Corp. said comparable store sales increased 1 percent, while overall sales rose 4.2 percent. The results announced Thursday differ from the monthly retail sales report from the government. The Commerce Department's figures includes sales from supermarkets, restaurants and car dealers.
