DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Companies Compete to Create Faster Supercomputers
DOC.TEXT: As competition heats up to make the speediest computers to solve the biggest problems in science, Intel Corp. is poised to introduce what the company says is the world's fastest supercomputer. Supercomputer fever, spurred on by Pentagon funding in many cases, is getting hotter as researchers look for ways to apply the machines that can speed up medical research and help create ``smart'' bombs, among other uses. ``If we can make microprocessors smaller and faster, they would be very useful for advanced weapons systems,'' Pentagon spokeswoman Jan Bodanyi said Thursday. ``They will be the ultimate weapons system. ... Once we get supercomputers down to soup-can size we can put them on missiles.'' Industry analysts warn, however, that despite the push to create supercomputers that can handle more information at one time and at mind-boggling speeds, the real challenges are to harness that power, to maintain top speeds and to make the systems even smaller and cheaper. ``There aren't many people out there who can afford to pay $25 million to $30 million for a top of the line supercomputer,'' said Christopher Willard, senior industry analyst at San Jose-based DataQuest. ``Another problem is actually getting and using the full power of the highly parallel computers. It's hard to deliver and sustain the full power.'' Officials at Santa Clara-based Intel have refused to release information on the company's new supercomputer before a formal announcement at an industry conference in New York on Tuesday. The California Institute of Technology at Pasadena, where the supercomputer will be installed, also has refused to comment. Intel, which invented the microprocessor, is an industry leader in chip design and manufacture. Its new supercomputer will use 512 of the company's powerful i860 chips. Now, Intel's most powerful machine uses 128 of those chips. A parallel system links separate microprocessors to create the supercomputer, which in Intel's case would reportedly reach speeds of up to 32 GigaFLOPs, or 32 billion floating-point operations per second - the customary measure of a computer's ability to crunch numbers and information. Skeptics, including Intel's competitors NCube of Beaverton, Ore., and Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis, wonder if the new machine can actually reach that computation speed even for simple problems. ``No supercomputer can maintain that type of speed,'' said Charles Grasfl, marketing analyst for Cray, which dominates the supercomputer market. ``I want to know what it can do. Where's the breakthrough?'' One analyst compared supercomputers to using 10,000 rabbits to plow a field instead of four horses; the rabbits may have more total energy, but controlling that power is difficult. Still, scientists continue to try. ``What's fascinating about supercomputers is what people will be able to achieve one day,'' said Abbie Kendall, spokeswoman for NCube. ``Right now we're on the edge of technology.'' In mid-1989, NCube introduced its supercomputer, which at 27 GigaFLOP was the world's fastest. The company is working on a quicker model. The Intel supercomputer will reportedly be used for research, including study of how to better apply such huge computer brains. ``Supercomputers still have a long way to go in terms of use for the average programmer,'' said DataQuest's Willard. ``The application, I think, will come from not what the system's top configuration can do but with what its smaller chunks can accomplish. ``Now, the marketplace is limited to universities, military, NASA ... What they need to do is some supercomputing for more mundane uses.'' NCube hasn't sold its top-of-the-line, $20 million supercomputer yet, but Kendall said the private company expects to sell one by mid-1991. Now, she said, NCube sells smaller parallel systems that can do more work faster than regular computers. A drug company, for example, gets results in three to four hours about molecule configurations for new manufactured drugs instead of the three months such a computation took previously.

DOC.HEAD: Economists See Prices Moderating, Barring Gulf War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires. Will be topped with 8:30 a.m. EST report.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices were still climbing three months after Iraq's takeover of Kuwait jolted world oil markets but - absent a shooting war - they should begin to moderate soon, many analysts believe. The Aug. 2 invasion wrecked many economists' prediction that inflation would ease this year. Oil prices doubled from an average of around $20 a barrel in July. Overwhelmed by the shock, the Labor Department's Producer Price Index, which measures the prices paid by manufacturers, farmers and other producers, took off. It shot up 1.3 percent in August and 1.6 percent in September for the biggest two-month increase in a decade. In advance of today's report on the index for October, most economists were expecting a rise of about 0.7 percent. Although much milder, that's still worrisomely high. If continued for 12 consecutive months, it would produce annual wholesale inflation of 8.7 percent. But better times are ahead unless war disrupts oil supplies further, analysts said. Crude oil prices, although jumpy, have settled back to around $35 a barrel from highs of $40. ``The worst of the oil shock is going to be past after this month's data. Of course there could be a war at any moment and that would change the outlook,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Inc. Wholesale prices overall increased at a 6.3 percent annual rate during the first nine months of 1990, sharply higher than the 4.8 percent gain for all of last year. Economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University predicted a 1990 increase in the Producer Price Index of only 3.1 percent. Ratajczak and Steinberg both foresaw some ripple effects from higher oil prices into related items, particularly those with heavy transportation costs. But they said the economic slowdown, which many analysts say has just about deepened into a recession, will subdue those effects. ``In general, the inflation outlook is improving,'' Steinberg said. ``The reason is simple: if you have a recession, inflation goes down. It always works. Since I believe we're having a recession, I believe inflation will come down.'' Steinberg said demand is just too weak and sales too slow for businesses to pass on most of their increased energy costs. Michael Boskin, chief economic adviser to President Bush, argued that the runup in petroleum prices will be less destructive now than during previous oil shocks in 1973 and 1979. ``No. 1, thus far the price increase has been substantially less than the .. increases of the 1970s. (And) in proportionate terms, we use one-third less energy ... than we used to,'' Boskin told the American Council for Capital Formation. ``Once the Middle Eastern situation resolves itself, obviously oil prices are going to come down,'' he said. Economist Samuel Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. said the break in inflation should provide the Federal Reserve with an opportunity to stimulate the economy with lower interest rates. He predicted a quarter-point cut in the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 7{ percent by early December. ``The economy looks like it's weakening and I think they want to provide the cushion to prevent it from becoming a sliding collapse,'' Kahan said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress May Put New Controls on Insurers to Cut Costs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The health insurance industry will be an ``irresistible target'' as Congress sets out anew next year to try to rein in the costs of medical care, a key senator says. Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., said the attractiveness of further regulating private insurers is that doing so would not cost the federal government any money. ``You talk about an irresistible target - a nice plump turkey sitting on the table at Thanksgiving time - that's it,'' Rockefeller, chairman of the Senate Finance subcommittee on Medicare and long term care, said Thursday. And as evidence that Congress has the will to make such changes, he noted that lawmakers included in the deficit-reduction package passed last month new limits on companies selling private ``medigap'' insurance policies, which pick up where Medicare leaves off. ``It was very, very easy'' to get bipartisan agreement on the changes, which among other things, require these companies to pay 65 cents in benefits for every dollar of premiums and to guarantee that policies are renewable, Rockefeller said. If private insurers do not change their ways and make a contribution to controlling the cost of health care, Congress will do it for them, he said. ``If they bring Congress a proposal that continues to permit insurance companies to deny coverage and charge widely varying premiums based on health status, they will be making an egregious error,'' Rockefeller said. ``That will send the message that their industry intends to pursue business as usual,'' he told a media forum on health care issues. However, Rockefeller also said ``the health insurance industry is working very hard'' to satisfy Congress. Indeed, James Dorsch, Washington counsel for the Health Insurance Association of America, said ``we know the status quo can't continue.'' To that end, he said, the association has offered several proposals to Congress to make health insurance more accessible to small employers. Some of these changes have been enacted in Connecticut, he said. The association is working with other states ``and we will be back to Congress next year,'' Dorsch said. He also said insurance companies have been making strides to contain health care costs through ``managed care'' programs, in which insurers attempt to assure that effective care is being delivered. Americans will pay more than $600 billion this year for health care. Still, more than 30 million people have no health insurance and do not qualify for public programs. Many are forced to rely on hospital emergency rooms for conditions that could have been prevented with earlier care or could be delivered more efficiently and inexpensively in a doctor's office. Rockefeller headed the bipartisan Pepper Commission, which last March recommended a $66 billion public-private plan to provide health care to nearly all Americans. It also included some insurance industry changes. The senator said he and other lawmakers of both parties are starting to draft some of those insurance changes into a legislative bill. He said that any proposals the industry offer will have ``to have to adhere to standards that are very close or exactly what the Pepper Commission recommended.'' These would prohibit private insurers from denying coverage for pre-existing conditions and require them to accept anyone who wants insurance and to set rates on the same terms to all groups in an area. ``We're basically going to have to get that far to have true health insurance reform,'' Rockefeller said. If by the end of the decade the health care crisis persists, the American people will lose confidence in the current public-private system ``and we will go to national health insurance,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Offers New Rules on Toy-Based TV Shows; Critics Unimpressed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission says it's taking aim at toy-based television programs, but critics claim the agency's action misses the mark. The commission on Thursday proposed a new definition of a ``program-length commercial,'' which is what critics say makes up much of children's TV. The critics cite the likes of ``He-Man'' and ``G.I. Joe,'' saying these programs are thinly disguised, 30-minute sales pitches that drive out quality kids' shows. They have urged the FCC to put the brakes on such shows. But the FCC won't go that far. ``The mere fact that a story line ... is built around a toy being sold on the market would not make it a program-length commercial,'' Regina Harrison, an attorney in the FCC's mass media bureau, said after the FCC voted 5-0 to adopt a new definition of program-length commercials. Harrison added that the commission was ``twisting and turning trying to reach a definition that won't cut out shows'' such as ``Sesame Street.'' The FCC, under orders from Congress to complete a 3-year-old investigation into toy-based programs, proposed to define program-length commercials as any children's show ``associated with a product in which commercials for that product are aired.'' Previously, the commission defined program-length commercials as material ``so interwoven with, and in essence auxiliary to, the sponsor's advertising'' that the entire program is, in effect, a commercial. The FCC said Thursday that the new definition ``appeared to be in harmony with the traditional definition.'' But Peggy Charren, president of Action for Children's Television in Cambridge, Mass., said the FCC was trying to adopt a definition that would avoid the issue of programs promoting toys. She said toy manufacturers don't put commercials into shows on which their toys are based because kids tend not to notice the ads. ``The commercial gets lost,'' she said in a telephone interview. A G.I. Joe commercial, for instance, ``sticks out much better in `My Little Pony,''' she added. The commission invited public comment on what penalties, if any, should be imposed on program-length commercials. It may decide that such programs violate new advertising time limits that Congress also ordered the FCC to impose as part of the Children's Television Act of 1990. The commission on Thursday also proposed to implement the ad time limits: 10.5 minutes of advertising per hour on weekends and 12 minutes per hour on weekdays on kids' shows, including cable TV. Violations of the rules, to take effect in April, could lead to fines ranging from $25,000 to $250,000. The commission lifted similar restrictions in 1984, and Congress later was told that advertising on some programs increased to 14 minutes per hour. A federal appeals court in 1987 ordered the FCC to reconsider its decision. The commission also said it will consider during license renewal whether a station has provided programs specifically designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children. President Bush, citing First Amendment concerns, allowed the measure to become law last month without his signature. The commission said children would be defined as age 12 or under for advertising purposes. For programming, it said it would consider expanding the limit above 12, which critics argue would make it too easy for broadcasters to claim they were meeting the needs of kids. The commission also said that besides a station's own kids' programs, it also would consider at license renewal a station's non-programming actions - giving money to support public TV educational programs, for example.

DOC.HEAD: Plan to Save Philadelphia from Bankruptcy Includes Local Sales Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference not expected until afternoon. Lede prospects uncertain. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A plan to save Philadelphia from bankruptcy would plug a short-term cash shortage and address a projected $206.4 million deficit this year in the city's general fund budget. The plan scheduled to be unveiled this afternoon was also expected to contain such measures as a 1 percent local sales tax, spending cuts, sale of city-owned assets and a financial oversight mechanism outside city government. To avert the cash shortage, the long-awaited plan reportedly includes short-term borrowing of up to $350 million from the city's $1.5 billion pension fund, state treasury and local banks. State House Speaker Robert W. O'Donnell said he expects to announce the plan today along with Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other leaders. He said many of the plan's details could change once they reach lawmakers. ``What we've done is go down into details far enough to get a sense that it can be done, without specifying as part of the agreement that this is the way it will be done,'' he said Thursday. The sales tax, for example, could end up being another type of tax, as long as it accomplishes the same goal, he said. City Council members, however, have denounced the package as vague and inadequate, The Philadelphia Inquirer said in today's editions. The city's short-term cash shortage has threatened to force a halt in payments next month to city vendors and employees. The plan would address that problem and look at long-term problems contributing to the deficit in the city's $2.19 billion general fund budget. Officials also have sought higher state support for court costs and for prorams that serve abused and neglected children. The city needs money to tide the city over until spring, when major tax payments are due. In September, the city was snubbed by Wall Street when it tried to float $375 million in temporary loan notes. Bond-rating agencies have lowered the city's debt to the lowest among major U.S. cities. They have urged city and state leaders to cooperate to find permanent solutions. Philadelphia is not the only city in the state with fiscal woes. In Scranton, a court denial of the city's request to float a $4.5 million bond issue may put half of the 650 municipal employees out of work Monday, city officials there said Thursday. Scranton Mayor James Connors said the city, which had to win court approval because the money would be used for payroll expenses, now has only enough money to meet its payroll this week.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dumps Part of Lawsuit But Leaves State Wage Claims Against Nordstrom
DOC.TEXT: A judge has dismissed part of a Washington state lawsuit against fashion retailer Nordstrom Inc., but left intact the state's effort to collect back wages for employees who claim they were coerced into working unpaid overtime. The state Department of Labor and Industries in February found that Nordstrom had violated state labor laws by failing to pay some employees for such things as attending company meetings, writing customer thank you notes and making deliveries. Nordstrom admitted there were some errors in tracking employee time and established a $15 million reserve to pay workers. But the company denied deliberate violations of wage and hour laws. It sued Labor and Industries, contending the department's findings denied them due process. The state countersued in April, and asked that Nordstrom be forced to pay damages double the amount of money owed workers. That amount has not been determined. Acting on a motion by Nordstrom to dismiss the department's lawsuit, King County Superior Court Judge Susan Agid on Thursday ruled the state couldn't collect damages or constrain the way Nordstrom pays its employees in the future. But Agid upheld the department's efforts to collect back pay for perhaps hundreds of Nordstrom employees in Washington state that Labor and Industries contends were coerced to work without pay. ``We certainly were pleased with where the judge went with her ruling,'' Nordstrom spokesman Dave Marriott said. ``The state was seeking pretty broad authority.'' Jim Robart, an attorney for Nordstrom, called Agid's decision ``a major victory.'' ``We were unable to get everything tossed out today, but we were able to get three-quarters of it,'' he said. State attorneys indicated they may appeal. Without the ability to seek injunctions, Labor and Industries would have the power only to enforce labor laws ``after the damage has been done,'' said Paul Triesch, assistant state attorney general. The limitation on damages also reduced the leverage the department can wield to enforce its findings, Triesch said. Agid's ruling was the latest in a series of decisions stemming from various legal actions filed by the state, Nordstrom and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. UFCW is bargaining agent for about 2,000 Nordstrom workers, although fewer than half belong to the union. Last week, National Labor Relations Board lawyers rejected appeals by UFCW Local 1001 to overturn settlements between the retail clothing chain and the federal agency. In the settlements, Nordstrom had agreed to post notices promising not to penalize employees for union activity, not to bargain with workers directly rather than through the union and not to withhold information rightfully sought by the union for negotiations. After the notices have been posted for 60 days, the chain may be found in compliance with the settlement, said John Nelson, NLRB regional director. At that point, Nordstrom employees could begin circulating petitions for an election on whether to retain the union, but Local 1001 president Joe Peterson said the decertification effort would be blocked by new unfair labor practice charges to be filed within two weeks. Nordstrom has about five dozen stores in Washington state, Oregon, California, Utah, Alaska, Virginia, and New Jersey. Its dispute with the union arose 1{ years ago during contract talks covering sales clerks in five stores in Seattle and one in Tacoma. Nordstrom negotiators refused to accept renewal of a provision that required employees covered by the contract to belong to the union and the contract expired July 31, 1989. Last winter the union sued, seeking more than $300 million in back pay for about 30,000 Nordstrom employees nationwide. A separate but similar union complaint resulted in the state Department of Labor and Industries' ruling in February and its subsequent countersuit against the company. Also pending is a federal lawsuit by three stockholders who said the labor battle had cost them financial losses and claimed company officers failed to disclose those problems.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Raises International Plane Fares
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday approved aseries of plane fare increases, including a 5 percent hike on fares for international flights out of Tokyo and a 7 percent increase for flights to Tokyo. The increases, which come in the wake of soaring fuel prices, will be in effect from Dec. 12 through March 31, said Hiroyuki Nakano, a Transport Ministry spokesman. The cost of a round-trip business-class flight from Tokyo to New York will go up to $3,218 from the current $3,065. A Tokyo-San Francisco round-trip will cost $2,375, a $113 increase. Flights into Tokyo will cost more. The price of a round-trip flight originating in New York will be raised from $2,826 to $3,024; the price for a round-trip ticket to Tokyo from San Francisco or Los Angeles will be $2,330. Separately, the ministry approved Apex discounts for flights from Tokyo to the United States and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Profit in Third-Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. posted a profit of $56.9 million in the third quarter, citing lower interest expense, cost savings and improved book sales. The earnings for the three months ended Sept. 30 amounted to 73 cents a share compared with a loss of $85.8 million, or $1.41 a share, a year ago. The 1989 results were lowered by $127 million in write-offs. Revenue for the third quarter totaled $476.5 million, up 1.4 percent from $470.1 million in the same quarter last year. The book publisher and insurance company has been contending with a heavy debt burden ever since it fought off a hostile takeover bid by British publisher Robert Maxwell in 1987. The company borrowed heavily to finance the battle, laid off 10 percent of its workforce and sold its theme parks to Anheuser-Busch Inc. Last week, HBJ announced that it hired the New York-based firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Inc. for financial advice on dealing with HBJ's debt of more than $1.7 billion. For the first nine months, Harcourt said it lost $38.0 million, or 73 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $244.4 million, or $4.05 a share a year earlier. Nine-month revenue rose 5.8 percent to $1.10 billion from $1.04 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Steel Cutting Price Hike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comments from analyst, USX
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp., reacting to weak conditions in the steel market, said it would cut in half an 8 percent price increase scheduled for sheet steel shipments after Dec. 29. The move is expected to be followed by other major steelmakers, who have announced similar price increases in an effort to shore up eroding profits. ``This action is being taken to better reflect the realities of the marketplace,'' Bethlehem spokesman Henry H. Von Spreckelsen said Thursday. The sheet steel - used for autos, appliances and construction materials - is produced at Bethlehem Steel's Burns Harbor, Ind., and Sparrows Point, Md., plants. The original price hike was announced in September, but customers asked for a reprieve, Von Spreckelsen said. ``At an appropriate time in months ahead, customers can expect an additional increase to offset rising costs,'' he said. A USX spokesman declined to say whether the nation's No. 1 steel maker would follow Bethlehem's lead. However, Charles Bradford, a steel analyst with UBS Securities in New York, said USX and other steel makers have little choice. He said the 8 percent increases announced by steel makers ``were kind of joke in the first place.'' ``I don't think too many people really expected to get that much,'' he said. ``But if you don't ask for more you don't get anything.'' Bradford said steel makers need price relief to cover increased costs and wage hikes that go into effect Jan. 1. Bethlehem Steel reported earnings of $53.3 million for the first nine months of 1990, compared to earnings of $195.7 million in the same period of 1989. Under the new schedule, the price increase on hot-rolled steel would be lowered to $20 from $35 a ton, on cold-rolled steel to $25 from $47 a ton and on galvanized steel to $30 from $49 a ton.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 338.60 up 2.23 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Soar for Third Month
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New 3rd graf to include historical comparison, 9th graf to include natural gas price, 14th graf with quote, trims last 4 grafs pvs. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices in October soared for the third consecutive month, the government said today, as the fear of war in the Persian Gulf kept energy costs rising. The Labor Department said its Producer Price Index for finished goods, one stop short of retail, jumped 1.1 percent last month after rising 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. The three-month jolt brought producer price inflation for the first 10 months of 1990 to a 7 percent annual rate. That's sharply higher than the 4.9 percent rate for all of last year is the worst since prices soared 7.1 percent in 1981. If wholesale inflation were to continue at the October rate for 12 consecutive months, the annual rate would be 13.7 percent. However, most economists expect energy inflation to moderate soon, barring the outbreak of war in the Middle East or if Saudi Arabian oil production facilities manage to survive a short war relatively intact. In October, as in August and September, energy prices led the index higher, rising 8 percent compared with a 0.9 percent increase for food - the worst since January - and no net change in the prices of all other items. Still, it was better than the 13.8 percent rise in energy costs in September and the 9.5 percent increase a month before that. As temperatures across much of the North turned chillier, fuel oil prices rose 15 percent and were 67.5 percent higher than a year earlier. Natural gas costs, however, edged down 0.3 percent. Gasoline prices increased 8 percent, bringing the level to 50.2 percent higher than a year before. Food prices, meanwhile, turned significantly higher, led by a 9.5 percent increase for eggs, an 8.2 percent rise for pork and a 5.1 percent advance for beef and veal and turkeys. Costs also rose for vegetables and pasta. The increases were only partly offset by declines in the prices of fresh fruit, rice, chickens, fish, dairy products, coffee and cooking oils. Economists were encouraged by the lack of inflation outside the volatile food and energy sectors, taking it as a sign that the sluggish economy is keeping a lid on price pressures. The so-called core rate of inflation, excluding food and energy, is considered a better barometer of underlying inflation trends. ``The good news is the bad news could have been much worse,'' said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. ``The overall report is much higher than expected, but the good news is that core prices remain unchanged.'' The price of passenger cars fell 2.7 percent. Other declines were recorded for men's and boy's clothing, floor coverings and household flatware. Prices rose 3.4 percent for newspapers and were also up for books, sanitary papers, women's clothing, cosmetics, tobacco and jewelry. The various changes left the Producer Price index for all finished goods at 122.3 in October. That means that a hypothetical selection of goods costing $100 in 1982 cost $122.30 last month, up from $114.70 a year earlier. Inflation at earlier stages of the production process was also up sharply, driven by energy. Prices rose 1.5 percent for intermediate goods and 8.7 percent for crude goods. But, excluding energy and food, prices rose only 0.4 percent at the intermediate level and fell 1.7 percent at the crude level. Crude petroleum prices jumped 29.2 percent in October and were double the level of a year ago. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. Economist Samuel Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. predicted a quarter-point cut in the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 7{ percent by early December. ``The economy looks like it's weakening and I think they want to provide the cushion to prevent it from becoming a sliding collapse,'' Kahan said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Banking Regulators Expected to Request Billions From Drexel
DOC.TEXT: Two government agencies are expected to seek up to $10 billion against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for alleged fraud in junk bond dealings with several savings and loans, sources said today. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. have until next Thursday to file claims against the collapsed Wall Street firm now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The filings are expected to seek from $5 billion to $10 billion for losses incurred by several major savings and loans from investments in high-yield securities marketed by Drexel, people with knowledge of the agencies' plans said. The total is expected to reflect a tripling of damages based an allegations of antitrust law violations, people involved in the talks said. The FDIC insures deposits for the nation's savings and loans while Resolution Trust oversees the federal thrift bailout. Lawyers for Drexel and investors, ex-clients and government agencies are negotiating over the total compensation to be alloted in Drexel's bankruptcy court reorganization. About 100 civil securities fraud lawsuits nationwide are outstanding. The claims allege stock manipulation, racketeering, insider trading and numerous other crimes by Drexel and its junk-bond department led by convicted financier Michael Milken. Litigated separately, they would take 10 years or more to resolve. Instead, attorneys plan to negotiate an estimate of maximum damages Drexel should pay. A figure would have to be approved by U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack and would be included in a reorganization plan to pay Drexel creditors. ``It's a major stumbling block to the plan,'' Drexel lawyer Alan Miller said. ``You have to figure out how much you owe, how high is up. And you have to figure out how to get it done in our lifetime.'' Final damage awards will likely be only a fraction of the billions of dollars being sought because of Drexel's limited assets, lawyers said. The claims include class actions by shareholders of companies that did business with Drexel or whose securities were affected by Drexel deals, individual firms and federal agencies. The negotiations do not cover 200 arbitration disputes and another 100 lawsuits alleging wrongdoing other than securities fraud, which also must be addressed in the bankruptcy. Drexel already has agreed to pay $350 million into a civil restitution fund to compensate investors harmed by its actions. The Securities and Exchange Commission is trying to recover $150 million Drexel still owes the fund, which was formed as part of its 1989 guilty plea to six felony crimes. If the civil litigation settlement exceeds $350 million - which is likely - Drexel will be liable for the rest. The litigation automatically came to a halt when Drexel filed for Chapter 11 on Feb. 13. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Frank Conrad recently also froze lawsuits naming current and former Drexel employees but not the firm. Most of those claims involve Milken, to be sentenced next week on his guilty plea to six trading-related felony counts. Drexel lawyers requested that freeze on grounds a liability finding against a Drexel employee could be binding on the firm. Also, information discovered in preparing civil cases against outside parties could turn up evidence against Drexel. ``If Mike Milken said `I didn't do it but Drexel did,' he has now accomplished what the plaintiffs wanted to accomplish,'' Miller said. That's not an unlikely scenario. During a special court hearing on unadmitted charges against Milken, his lawyers said in one case that a stock was manipulated and Milken didn't do it - but someone else at Drexel did. But Richard Kirby, the SEC's senior litigation counsel, said the freeze is delaying compensation to investors in cases only indirectly related to the Drexel bankruptcy. ``You have ... victims of securities fraud who can't collect money because Drexel is taking its sweet time figuring out how to shape up its own affairs,'' he said Thursday. ``If a plaintiff can prove a case against Mike Milken he ought to be able to collect against Mike Milken.'' Melvyn Weiss, lead attorney in 16 fraud lawsuits, said lawyers were hamstrung by the freeze but developing their cases as much as possible pending a ruling by Judge Pollack. A reorganization plan would establish how much Drexel's creditors receive when the firm emerges from bankruptcy and whether unsecured creditors, such as former employees who owned company stock, get anything. Drexel currently is paying only operating expenses on a 300-person staff, down from more than 10,000 at its peak. A total of 19 Drexel-related entities are involved in the bankruptcy. Legal fees in the first three months of the case totaled nearly $4.7 million. About 15 Drexel professionals are managing the firm's junk-bond portfolio but not selling many securities because of the market's collapse. The bulk of Drexel staff handles bankruptcy-related administrative and financial matters. Drexel has vacated all but 130,000 of 1.5 million square feet of office space. Almost all remaining employees are at the firm's New York headquarters, with a handful at a small Los Angeles office.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Production Projected to Hit Five-Year High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 22nd graf pvs, This fall's, to clarify that comparison is with earlier estimate, not last year's production. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A bumper corn harvest this fall is leading the way for the largest total crop output by American farmers in five years, the Agriculture Department says. The 1990 corn harvest was estimated Thursday at a four-year high of 7.93 billion bushels, up 5 percent from last year, although down slightly from prospects in October. An all-crops production index was reported at 112 percent of its 1977 average used for comparison. That was up one percentage point from October and the highest reading since the index averaged 116 percent in 1985. The latest corn production outlook, based on Nov. 1 indications, was down 1 percent from USDA's October forecast. The harvest was about 64 percent completed by Oct. 28, slightly behind normal. ``Many growers continue to report yields lower than previously anticipated,'' the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said. ``Ears in late-planted fields in Indiana did not fill out. Corn borers also did considerable damage in Illinois.'' Farmers harvested 7.53 billion bushels in 1989, and the department in its initial 1990 forecast on Aug. 9 put this fall's harvest at 7.85 billion bushels. The forecast was raised on Sept. 12 to 8.12 billion bushels and then lowered to 8.02 billion on Oct. 11. At 7.93 billion bushels, this year's harvest still would be the largest since farmers produced 8.23 billion bushels in 1986, according to USDA records. Based on the latest surveys, the average corn yield nationally was estimated at 119 bushels per acre harvested, compared with 116.2 last year and 120.3 indicated last month. The record was 119.4 bushels in 1987. As livestock feed, corn is the largest and most important U.S. farm crop and is essential for the production of meat, poultry and dairy products. Consumer food prices, which rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981, are expected to climb an additional 5 percent to 7 percent in 1990. Soybean production, a source of high-protein meal and vegetable oil, was estimated at 1.9 billion bushels, down 1 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels but 4 percent more than the October forecast of 1.82 billion bushels. Cotton production was indicated at 14.9 million bales, up 22 percent from last year's output of 12.2 million bales and 2 percent more than the October forecast. No new estimates of 1990 production of wheat and other crops harvested earlier were included in the report. The fall crop of potatoes was estimated for the first time this season at 342 million hundredweight, up 5 percent from last year due to an increase in acreage. Average yields were forecast at 298 hundredweight per acre, down one hundredweight from 1989. ``Drought in North Dakota and Minnesota cut into production potential for the third straight year,'' the report said. ``Maine farmers were hit by heavy October rains, followed by hard freezes late in the month that virtually shut down harvest operations.'' The potato outlook also was said to be hurt by ``extremely variable temperatures'' in Idaho, Oregon and Washington during the growing season. In a related supply-and-demand report, analysts said total corn use in the 1990-91 marketing year that began Sept. 1 is expected to be about 8.045 billion bushels. With use exceeding estimated production, the U.S. corn stockpile may decline to a projected 1.236 billion bushels by Sept. 1, 1991, compared with 1.344 billion this Sept. 1. The report said corn prices at the farm may average $2.20 to $2.60 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year, down from $2.36 in 1989-90 and unchanged from the October projection. Soybean prices were indicated to average $5.35 to $6.35 per bushel, down from the October range of $5.70 to $7 per bushel. This fall's larger than expected crop is putting pressure on prices and will mean a rise in soybean stockpiles in 1990-91. By next Sept. 1, the report said, soybean inventories could be around 255 million bushels, compared with 239 million bushels this Sept. 1 and last month's projection of 175 million bushels next year. The report also showed the Soviet Union's grain harvest at 235 million metric tons this year, unchanged from the October forecast. However, analysts said Soviet grain imports in 1990-91 now are expected to be 28 million tons, down from 30 million anticipated last month. Other 1990 crop estimates based on Nov. 1 indications, compared with 1989 output, included: -Sorghum, 559.8 million bushels and an average yield of 60.5 bushels per acre, compared with 617.9 million and 55.4 in 1989. -Rice, 154.4 million hundredweight and a yield of 5,499 pounds per acre, compared with 154.5 million and 5,749. -Peanuts, 3.45 billion pounds and a yield of 1,949 pounds per acre, compared with 3.99 billion and 2,426. -Tobacco, 1.6 billion pounds and a yield of 2,198 pounds per acre, compared with 1.37 billion and 2,016. -Sugar beets, 27 million tons and a yield of 19.7 tons per acre, compared with 25.1 million and 19.4. -Sugar cane, 25.3 million tons and a yield of 35.3 tons per acre, compared with 29.4 million and 34.5.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Plunge on Big Crop Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government raised its 1990 harvest estimate by more than 4 percent to a higher-than-expected 1.9 billion bushels. Wheat and corn futures also opened lower despite a lower corn crop estimate in Thursday's monthly Agriculture Department crop report. Most analysts had expected the USDA's increase in its soybean projection to about 1.84 billion bushels from last month's estimate of 1.82 billion. The government also raised its estimate of how large the U.S. soybean stockpile will be next Aug. 31, the end of the current marketing year, to 255 million bushels from 175 million. That projection reversed the USDA's October prediction that the soybean stockpile would shrink from last August's carryout of 239 million bushels. ``Not only is it adequate but it starts to border on burdensome,'' said Doug Jackson, grains analyst with Farmers Commodities Corp. in Des Moines, Iowa. The USDA lowered its corn production estimate from 8 billion to 7.9 billion bushels, but selling pressure for the soybean pit overshadowed that ostensibly bullish factor at the opening. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.68 a bushel; corn was unchanged to { cent lower with December at $2.32} a bushel; oats were { cent to } cent lower with December at $1.21 a bushel; soybeans were 10 cents lower to 1 cent higher with November at $5.73{ a bushel. Cattle futures were higher and pork futures lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .37 cent higher with December at 77.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .40 cent higher with November at 87.90 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent to .52 cent lower with December at 52.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .03 cent to .45 cent lower with February at 68.80 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled lower on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Green Bonds Trashed At Voting Booths
DOC.TEXT: Bond issues that would have borrowed billions of dollars to preserve open spaces and clean the environment went the way of plastic foam hamburger boxes this past week. Voters in New York state Tuesday rejected a $1.9 billion bond package that would have spent most of its money to buy and set aside Adirondack woodland and establish solid-waste programs. In California the ``Big Green'' environmental proposal, which would have raised money for forest protection, such as $300 million to buy stands of ancient redwoods, was defeated. ``People first and foremost are concerned with economic events,'' said Neal Atterman, municipal research director at Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``Look at consumer confidence, then put that into a voting booth connotation. People don't want radical changes right now.'' California Attorney General John Van de Kamp, a primary sponsor of the environmental measure there, also said voters were showing a move toward fiscal conservatism. ``I think the invasion of Kuwait, the beginning of the recession, the national budget crisis, the state budget crisis - all those things have scared people,'' he said. Environmental issues weren't the only bond questions turned away. Voters rejected 43.5 percent of the proposed bond issues, amounting to 59.5 percent of the total dollar value of bonds on Tuesday's ballot, according to The Bond Buyer, the municipal bond market daily newspaper. Voters approved 242 state and local government bond issues totaling $4.887 billion out of 428 issues totaling 12.067 billion, The Bond Buyer reported. The percentage of approvals was the lowest in a general election since 10 percent were approved in 1975, the newspaper said. In last year's general election, 85.7 percent of the $6.68 billion of bond issues on ballots were approved. ``A lot of it is probably related to the economy. It may also be related to the federal tax increase. People think we can't afford to borrow,'' said Claire Cohen, head of government finance at Fitch Investors Service Inc., a bond rating agency. Other analysts, like George Friedlander, head of municipal research at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the heavy rejection of bond issues this year was a sign voters didn't trust political leaders to spend the money wisely. Bonds that would have funded affordable housing and public facilities were turned away, but voters were more receptive to issues for education, health care and transportation. In Massachusetts, voters rejected a plan that would have cut tax revenues by $1.35 billion this fiscal year. ``I think that what's going on is very positive,'' Atterman said. ``Voters are concerned about the future and want to keep public debt lower rather than higher.'' Analysts said voters showed they were selective about the issues they approved, with California voters giving the go-ahead to $800 million school construction issue and defeating more than three-fourths of the $5.279 billion worth of proposed bonds. The heavy drubbing bonds took should not have a major impact on the already short-supply municipal bond market, Friedlander said. The vast majority of municipal bonds are not decided at elections, he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Nov. 12

DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for light sweet crude was $34.95 per barrel at 12 p.m. Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Nestle Creates New Umbrella Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Timm in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Nestle SA announced Friday it has created an umbrella company to oversee its extensive U.S. food and beverage operations, including Carnation Co., Stouffer Foods Corp. and Nestle Hospitality Group. The new company, Nestle USA Inc., with more than $7 billion in combined U.S. sales, ``will permit us to improve on customer service and focus on key product categories with a simplified business structure,'' said Helmut Maucher, chairman and chief executive officer of parent Nestle SA. The new company, part of a larger restructuring within Nestle SA, is set to begin operations on Jan. 1. James Biggar, who will remain chairman and CEO of Hospitality Group and Wine World Estates, is chairman of the new company. Timm Crull, chairman and chief executive officer of Carnation, will become its president and CEO. Nestle SA is based in Vevey, Switzerland.

DOC.HEAD: Deford Confirms The National Sports Daily Will Drop Sunday Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with confirmation of report. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The National plans to discontinue its Sunday issue next month and publish five rather than six days a week, the editor in chief of the nine-month-old sports daily said today. Editor Frank Deford also said there may be ``a handful'' of jobs cut at the newspaper but that he was hopeful the number would be so small that it could be absorbed through attrition rather than layoffs. ``There is a feeling that as in practically every other business in America we should tighten our belts,'' Deford said in a telephone interview. Deford denied that the newspaper was in serious financial trouble as it tries to become the first national sports daily in America. ``it's just a matter of belt-tightening,'' he said. On Thursday, a source who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Sunday issue was being discontinued because circulation on Sundays has amounted to only about 80 percent of that on weekdays and it has proven harder to distribute the paper on Sundays than on weekdays. The National has been published six days a week, Sunday through Friday, since it was launched on Jan. 31. Deford said the last Sunday issue will be published on the Sunday after Thanksgiving. The newspaper is owned by a partnership led by Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga. Repeated calls seeking comment were made to Publisher Peter O. Price but they were not returned. The paper started out with editions in three markets - New York, Chicago and Los Angeles - but six other markets have been added since then. The other editions are in San Diego, San Francisco, Dallas, Detroit, Boston and Miami. The newsapaper has announced plans to begin another edition in the Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area in early December and an edition in Philadelphia in January. The newspaper's arrival was met with considerable skepticism about whether there are enough readers and advertisers to support a daily newspaper devoted exclusively to sports. The launch also coincided with a sharp decline in the advertising market for newspapers in many parts of the country that has shown no signs of abating. But Azcarraga and his partners reportedly went into the enterprise prepared to spend $100 million and several years in making the newspaper profitable. The source who told of the plans to end the Sunday edition said the decision was not a sign that the paper was in danger of folding. ``My sense of it is that it is a very viable concern,'' he said. He said ending the Sunday issue was part of the ``normal shakedown'' that occurs in finding a sensible production schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Figure in Silverado Debacle Claims $196 Million in Debts
DOC.TEXT: Former Denver developer Bill Walters, who defaulted on $106 million in loans from Silverado Savings and Loan, has filed for personal bankruptcy in Santa Ana, Calif., claiming $196 million in debts. Nathan Jones, a San Diego attorney representing Walters in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court filing, said Thursday that creditors include Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., Mellon Bank, Silverado and Walters' ex-wife, Mary Lou. Jones said creditors probably will only get a fraction of what they are owed. ``There are a few assets available, possibly a few hundred thousand dollars,'' said Jones. ``Bill is a good guy who has gotten a lot of bad publicity. He was at the end of his rope.'' During early and mid-1980s, Walters was one of Denver's highest profile developers. He listed his net worth at $200 million during those years. But the oil bust took its toll on his real estate and banking holdings. He sold Cherry Creek National Bank in 1988 and it failed last month. His other two banks failed in 1987. Earlier this year, Walters told a congressional panel investigating Silverado's $1 billion failure that he was broke, but vowed not to seek bankruptcy protection and to pay back what he owed the thrift. But a few weeks later, he was found to be living in a $1.9 million estate in Newport Beach, Calif., listed in the name of his wife Jacqueline. Walters became a prominent figure in the nation's thrift crisis because of his business relationship with President Bush's son, Neil, a Silverado director. Bush voted to approve $106 million in loans to Walters, who defaulted on the loans. The bankruptcy filing says he owes Manufacturers Hanover $111 million and Mellon Bank $23 million. Jones said Walters owes Silverado $18.5 million and Mary Lou Walters about $5.35 million. Jones said Walters has no personal obligation to pay many of the loans from Silverado and thus owes only a fraction of the $106 million on which he defaulted.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Sabena Will Go Partly Private
DOC.TEXT: The Belgian government is seeking private investors for the national airline Sabena, Communications Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene said Friday. Dehaene also announced that Pierre Godfroid, a vice president of Campbell Soup Co. in the United States, has been named chairman of Sabena. Godfroid succeeds Carlos Van Rafelghem, who has been hospitalized since July. Dehaene told reporters the government was setting a January 1991 deadline to privatize Sabena. The government owns 53 percent while the rest is owned by regional governments or state-controlled investment funds. Dehaene said the company would be ``as close to private'' as possible while remaining publicly controlled, with the government maintaining a minority stake. He said some form of Sabena shares could trade eventually on the Brussels stock exchange and expected most of the fresh capital coming from Belgian groups. He did not say how much capital Sabena needs. Belgian newspaper reports have said the company may need $196 million to maintain its operations. Sabena posted an operating loss of 1.26 billion francs, or $41.2 million, in 1989. Airline officials predicted in June the company would lost another 1.5 billion francs, or $49 million, in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Friday after a lackluster session. Share prices picked up small gains in early trading as investors took advantage of Thursday's sharp decline to pick up some bargains. But as soon as the buying dried up the market drifted lower, failing to gain support from Wall Street's performance. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 4.4 points, or 0.2 percent, at 2,040.6 at the close. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 7.7 points to close at 1,582.6. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 1.15 points to close at 1,085.87. Volume was 370.1 million shares compared with 423.1 million shares Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Charged With Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: Two men were charged with fraud in an alleged insider trading scheme in which prosecutors claim they traded stocks based on information obtained from advance copies of Business Week magazine. Benjamin B. Libera, 35, and Francis R. Sablone, 41, each were charged with one count of conspiracy, prosecutors said. Libera also was charged with 45 counts of mail fraud and 55 counts of securities fraud; Sablone was charged with 26 counts of mail fraud and 58 counts of securities fraud. Sablone's attorney, James Wade, said Friday his client denies any role in the alleged scheme. ``He ... asserts vigorously his innocence and indeed, we raise the question as to whether or not a crime took place at all,'' Wade said. The indictment, returned Thursday by a federal grand jury in New Haven, alleges that between October 1986 and July 1988, Libera and Sablone engaged in a scheme to trade securities based on information from the ``Inside Wall Street'' column in copies of Business Week magazine not yet released to the general public. The two men allegedly paid $20 to $30 to employees of the magazine's printing company, R.R. Donnelley & Sons, of Old Saybrook, in exchange for advance copies of the magazine, said U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy Jr. The indictment alleges the magazines were delivered to Libera and Sablone every Thursday morning; the magazine is released to the general public later in the day. Companies receiving favorable mention in the column often see their stock price rise temporarily. By obtaining the column early, the two allegedly were able to get a jump on the market by trading the stocks of companies in the column. The indictment alleges that Sablone grossed $75,079 and that Libera grossed $113,806 as a result of the early trades. Each of the charges carries a maximum penalty of 5 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Attempts to reach Libera and Sablone were unsuccessful.

DOC.HEAD: Newsletter Says Economists Forecast Brief, Mild Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EST. With AM-Economy, Bjt. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The vast majority of top economists in a monthly survey believe a recession will begin before year's end, but most predict it will be brief and relatively mild, a prominent economic newsletter reported Friday. Blue Chip Economic Indicators said 80 percent of the 55 economists in its survey feel a downturn will start before the end of 1990. Another 5 percent said the slump would start in 1991. ``It now seems very likely that America's longest peacetime expansion is about to come to an end,'' wrote Blue Chip editor Robert J. Eggert of Eggert Economic Enterprises Inc. in Sedona, Ariz. Even President Bush, while avoiding the use of the word recession, acknowledged at a Thursday news conference that ``we're in for some tough times right now.'' And Michael Boskin, Bush's chief economic adviser, said Thursday the economy could slip into ``negative territory'' this year. ``The economy at best is in a lull, but we do expect that lull to be relatively brief and relatively minor,'' Boskin told the American Council for Capital Formation here. The Blue Chip survey found three-fourths of the respondents expect any downturn to last no more than two or three quarters. ``An even larger majority - 82 percent - anticipate that the recession will be relatively mild,'' the newsletter said. Because of the predicted slump, the newsletter's masthead was printed in red ink for the first time since the last recession - a warning that economic growth may drop below zero. A recession generally is defined as two consecutive quarterly economic declines. Since the economy emerged from the July 1981-November 1982 downturn, the Blue Chip banner has been either green or yellow. Green meant the economy was expanding above long-range growth potential of 3 percent, while yellow warned that economic growth was lagging between zero and 2.9 percent. The survey's consensus forecast anticipated a 0.8 percent annual rate of decline during the current quarter, followed by a 0.6 percent drop from January through March 1991. It projected growth picking up 0.8 percent, 2.1 percent and 2.5 percent in the following quarters. The survey participants represent many of the nation's top banks, brokerage companies, corporations, economic forecasting organizations and universities. However, there are dissenting economists. Lawrence Kudlow, a top Reagan administration economist now with Bear Stearns & Co., told the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Thursday he foresees ``no off-the-cliff recession.'' But he said he wouldn't be surprised to see a negative fourth quarter before the economy picked up to a 2 percent growth rate for 1991. Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Co. also says the economy could fall during the current quarter, but added ``we are not projecting two consecutive quarters of declining GNP.'' The gross national product, the nation's broadest measure of economic activity, is the nation's total output of goods and services. The consensus forecast in the Blue Chip survey calls for 1 percent growth this year in the GNP. It grew 1.7 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter, followed by 0.4 percent and 1.8 percent rates in the next two. But expectations for growth in 1991 continued to slide, ``dropping three-tenths of a percentage point to a paltry 0.5 percent.'' And, the newsletter reported, ``the outlook for inflation also continued on the gloomy side with the consensus estimate for the annualized rate of increase in the Consumer Price Index for the current quarter jumping to 7.1 percent.'' That would push the inflation rate for the year to 5.5 percent. However, the inflation rate would slow to a 5.2 percent increase during 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Take Third Big Hit in 3 Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 8-10, In fact, for release after 6:30 p.m. EST. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Fear of war in the Persian Gulf jolted oil prices for the third straight month in October, but slowing economic growth held wholesale price inflation for non-food and non-energy items to zero. The Labor Department said Friday that its Producer Price Index for finished goods, one step short of retail, jumped a seasonally adjusted 1.1 percent last month. That followed increases of 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August, bringing the annual inflation rate for the year so far to levels not seen in nine years. Wholesale price inflation, on an annual basis, was 7 percent for the first 10 months of 1990, the highest since a 7.1 percent rise in 1981. Even though the October number was higher than the predicted 0.7 percent rise, stock and bond markets rallied immediately after the report because prices outside the volatile food and energy sectors were unchanged. This so-called ``core'' inflation rate is considered a better indicator of long-term inflationary trends. Traders took the absence of core inflation as a sign the Federal Reserve Board likely would stimulate the economy with lower interest rates after its policymakers meet Tuesday. Economists are optimistic that despite the sharp rises of the last three months, inflation will remain under control unless war in the Middle East destroys Saudi Arabia's oil-production facilities. The economy is simply too weak for most goods producers to pass on higher energy costs, they say.
DOC.HEAD: Following 3 grafs FOR RELEASE 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: In fact, the latest edition of a prominent survey of private economists said the nation likely will topple into a recession before the end of the year. Blue Chip Economic Indicators of Sedona, Ariz., reported Friday that 44 of the 55 economists in its survey believe a downturn will start before the end of 1990. Another three said the slump would start in 1991. To symbolize the shift, the survey newsletter changed its nameplate from yellow to red for the first time since the 1981-82 recession.
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
DOC.TEXT: ``The climate is not going to be favorable for an increase in inflation,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``We're in a bad inflation patch now, but we'll get through it.'' In October, energy costs led prices higher, rising 8 percent compared with 13.8 percent in September and 9.5 percent the month before that. Fuel oil prices rose 15 percent and were 67.5 percent higher than a year earlier. Natural gas costs, however, edged down 0.3 percent. Gasoline prices increased 8 percent and were 50.2 percent higher than a year earlier. Food prices, meanwhile, rose 0.9 percent, the biggest increase since unseasonably cold weather froze southern fruit and vegetable crops in January. Egg costs were up 9.5 percent; pork, 8.2 percent, and beef and turkeys, 5.1 percent. Prices also rose for vegetables and pasta. Economist Donald Ratajczak said consumers' demand for red meat has fallen about as much as is likely and farmers are building their herds in anticipation of growing demand. That means they are sending fewer animals to slaughter, pushing prices higher. The increases were partly offset by declines in the prices of fresh fruit, rice, chickens, fish, dairy products, coffee and cooking oils. In other categories, the price of passenger cars fell 2.7 percent after jumping 3.4 percent a month earlier. Economists attributed the fluctuations to the fact that price increases and discounts this year have been out of sync with auto dealers' usual seasonal pattern. Other declines were recorded for men's and boys' clothing, floor coverings and household flatware. Prices rose 3.4 percent for newspapers and were also up for books, women's clothing, cosmetics, tobacco and jewelry. The various changes left the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 122.3 in October. That means a hypothetical selection of goods costing $100 in 1982 would have cost $122.30 last month, up from $114.70 a year earlier. Prices at earlier stages of the production process were also up sharply, driven by energy. Prices rose 1.5 percent for intermediate-level goods and 8.7 percent for crude-level goods. Excluding energy and food, however, prices rose only 0.4 percent at the intermediate level and fell 1.7 percent at the crude level. Crude petroleum prices jumped 29.2 percent in October and were double the level of a year ago. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

DOC.HEAD: EDS to Handle Systems Work for Saab
DOC.TEXT: Electronic Data Systems, the computer services division of General Motors Co., will develop computer systems and applications for the Swedish automaker Saab in a 10-year deal worth an estimated $300 million, the companies said Friday. The contract is the first of its type for a Swedish company. It is also the first time EDS has acknowledged work for another automaker. EDS will manage Saab's current information systems and develop data processing strategies. About 250 Saab data processing employees will be transferred to EDS. ``We see this as a long-term strategic partnership which will help us handle our (information technology) needs more efficiently and cost-effectively,'' David Herman, president of Saab Automobile, said in a news release from Stockholm. The Saab agreement is a ``natural progression'' for EDS' European business, said Juergen Berg, who directs the company's European operations. Berg said the pact will form a base for EDS in the Swedish information technology market, which has been predicted to grow 18 percent annually over the next four years.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Morale Sinks, Paranoia Soars as Wall Street Retrenches
DOC.TEXT: Depressed business across Wall Street has triggered a round of severe cuts that for the first time is digging sharply into the high-profile fields of the booming 1980s and leaving many senior executives unemployed. The reversal of fortune has caused punishing losses and pushed a few firms into bankruptcy, eliminated tens of thousands of jobs, dried up key money-making areas and deflated the image of Wall Street pros as ``Masters of the Universe.'' In the last two weeks alone: -Merrill Lynch & Co. fired 50 investment bankers, reducing the department to 575 from about 700 at the beginning of 1990. The nation's biggest securities firm has eliminated 2,300 jobs this year. No. 2 Shearson Lehman Holdings Inc. has cut 3,000. -First Boston Corp. laid off 45 workers from its 475-person stock division, bringing a week's firings to about 100. Hundreds more layoffs are expected there by year-end. -Bear, Stearns & Co. let go 10 investment bankers from a staff of around 200. Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. fired 120 of 180 investment bankers and revered Morgan Stanley & Co. pared 50 bankers, 6 percent of its force. Other firms are firing professionals in small increments. Wall Street executives say rumors of further layoffs have triggered paranoia that is hurting firms' ability to do what limited business exists. Salaries and bonuses are forecast to drop sharply. Unlike earlier cuts, senior managers and partners are being let go. ``Everyone is looking behind them to see if the ax is coming at his head,'' said Joan Zimmerman, executive vice president with GZ Stephens Inc., a recruiting firm. ``You have an immense morale problem right now,'' she said. ``When people are this insecure, their ability to go out and generate business and ... concentrate on the business at hand drops dramatically.'' Nationwide, more than 45,000 securities industry jobs have been cut since the October 1987 stock market crash. The latest reductions focus on highly paid investment bankers who handled the large mergers and takeovers of the 1980s but have seen their business evaporate. The value of U.S. mergers and acquisitions in the first 10 months of 1990 was down 50 percent compared with the same period last year, according to IDD Information Services, a research and publishing concern. IDD said 3,575 deals valued at $185.9 billion were completed from January through October, vs. 4,273 valued at $373.4 billion in the same 1989 period. The drop was most severe in deals worth more than $50 million, where investment firms make the most lucrative fees. Crucial fees from underwriting stocks and bonds plummeted to $1.5 billion in the first nine months of 1990, down 30 percent from a year earlier and the lowest level since 1984, according to Securities Data Co. The lack of mergers and underwriting by U.S. companies is blamed on a slow economy, declining stock market volume and insecurity about the future, in large part because of the Middle East crisis. Analysts' projections on further securities industry layoffs range from at least 10,000 to as many as 40,000. ``If '91 turns out to be the way the last couple months have been then you'll probably see much more,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential-Bache. ``I would say that '91 would have to be the washout year.'' Several Wall Street executives said the degree of layoffs was exaggerated because financial firms typically pare staffing in the fourth quarter to plan for next year. Cynics say it's cheaper to pay severance than an annual bonus. ``People say the environment is rough and tough and I agree,'' Bear Stearns Chairman Alan C. Greenberg said. ``That doesn't mean it won't change tomorrow.'' All agree that Wall Street firms are adjusting to reality following a period of startling growth. Employment has been reduced to 1985 levels, but that's still more than 50 percent higher than in 1980. As profits and revenue at top firms sink, managers are assessing the productivity of certain business lines - witness Prudential-Bache's investment banking purge - and cutting back spending as much as possible. Some executives said the task is made more difficult by the uncertain future. If firms scale back too much, will they be prepared for a possible rebound? ``There's a slowdown, but I've seen four or five cycles before,'' said William E. Mayer, who this week announced his resignation as First Boston's head of merchant banking. ``This is just nastier and a little longer.'' ``Beyond that, there's going to be an industry and people are going to do well in it,'' he said. ``But that's going to take a couple years.''

DOC.HEAD: USX, Union Negotiate New Contract As Deadline Approaches
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. and United Steelworkers union negotiators gave no hint Friday on the fate of a new contract for 18,000 employees as Saturday's deadline for reaching an agreement approached. Neither the company nor the union would discuss the progress of the talks, which began Oct. 15. ``I don't know whether we'll have something over the weekend or not,'' said USX spokesman Ernie Glenn. Failure to strike a deal by Saturday would not necessarily be a major setback. The old contract does not expire until February. But if the talks drag on, the risk of losing customers who fear a strike will grow, analysts said. ``They've got to settle very, very soon to avoid losing a lot of business,'' said Charles Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York. ``They can't wait until early December. The customers will put their business elsewhere.'' The union wants USX to fall in line with other steel makers who restored pay cuts taken by workers during the industry's decline in the early 1980s. The wage concessions made by USX workers average about $1.30 an hour, said Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm, the union's chief negotiator. Greg Drahuschak, an analyst with Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh, said USX can afford to restore concessions today, but could face a struggle to pay higher wages if the economy doesn't improve soon. ``This business is still highly cyclical,'' he said. ``They have tremendous capital costs.'' Industry steel orders in the past month were about 20 percent lower than in the same period of 1989, reflecting high inventories, a slowdown in construction and some automobile plant closures, Bradford said. In the third quarter, USX's earnings dropped 6.8 percent from a year earlier, with gains in the energy segment but a 26 percent income drop from the steel division. Most major steel makers' earnings have dropped in the past year, and competitors would eagerly snatch customers from any supplier whose ability to produce is interrupted by a strike. But analysts said they expect no strike at USX this time. The last, four-year agreement was reached after a six-month lockout and shutdown of the company in 1986. ``Neither side wants a strike,'' Bradford said. ``Both sides lost in the strike last time.'' Ben Fischer, director of the Center for Labor Studies at Carnegie Mellon University, said the early target date signalled both sides were feeling confident. ``They didn't plan to fail and they don't plan to fail,'' said Fischer, who believes meeting Saturday's deadline is not critical. ``If they are still meeting, if they are continuing to work, then the particular hours and days are not that critical,'' he said. ``The most critical thing is to not give people reason to think there will be a strike.'' USX's board of directors voted Oct. 30 to make the steel and energy giant's steel operations a wholly owned subsidiary in a move that could pave the way for a restructuring. Fisher said there was no reason to believe the move would jeopardize an agreement. ``It's not like USX has never had spinoffs and joint ventures and to the best of my knowledge none of them have resulted in charges the workers' actual vested interests have been subverted,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rentschler Resigns at Northwest; Dasburg Named President
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines on Friday named John H. Dasburg president and chief executive officer to succeed Frederick B. Rentschler, who has resigned. Rentschler, who will remain a director on the NWA Inc. board, had been president of the nation's fourth largest carrier since June. He said his reasons for leaving are personal. ``There are personal and family situations that require my time and energy,'' he said. ``I leave Northwest with genuine regret. The people have been terrific and the industry is exciting and gratifying. There is no doubt in my mind that John will be a leader in the travel industry.'' Said Northwest Chairman Al Checchi: ``While I am sorry Fred is leaving our team, I understand the need to focus on overriding family and personal priorities. I respect his decision.'' Dasburg, 47, previously Northwest's executive vice president-finance and administration, will begin his new duties immediately. He joined Northwest in November 1989 after nine years at the Marriott Corp. He held several positions with Marriott, including president of its Lodging Group, a $3.5 billion business with more than 100,000 employees. Before that, he was Marriott's chief financial officer and also was responsible for real estate development and architecture and construction programs. ``John Dasburg has impeccable business experience, he knows the importance of customer service in the travel industry, and he shares the vision of making Northwest the airline of preference for our customers and the best place to work for our employees,'' Checchi said.

DOC.HEAD: Government To Seek Billions for S&L Claims; Drexel Says It's Show
DOC.TEXT: Federal savings and loan regulators may seek up to $10 billion from Drexel Burhnam Lambert Inc. for junk bond investment losses at more than 20 thrifts, people involved in the case said Friday. A lawyer for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. said ``very substantial claims'' would be filed next week against the collapsed Wall Street firm now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The agencies are expected to seek $5 billion to $10 billion for losses incurred by failed thrifts on investments in high-yield debt securities handled by Drexel, an individual familiar with their plans said. The total is expected to reflect tripled damages based an allegations of antitrust law violations, the individual said. The FDIC insures deposits for the nation's savings and loans. Resolution Trust oversees the federal thrift bailout. The agencies plan to allege fraud and other wrongdoing in dealings between Drexel's junk bond department headed by convicted financier Michael Milken and more than 20 savings and loans, FDIC attorney Thomas Barr said. Barr declined to comment on the size of the potential claims, or whether they would include antitrust or racketeering charges. Several big savings and loans invested billions of dollars in risky high-yield securities sold by Drexel. The junk bond market collapsed about a year ago, devastating the value of these securities. In papers filed in bankruptcy court, Barr said Resolution Trust on Oct.31 had a junk bond portfolio valued at $3 billion to $4 billion, with most of the securities underwritten or managed by Drexel. Resolution Trust has taken over more than 100 savings and loans. The filings said Resolution Trust and some of the thrifts have been forced to sell large amounts of Drexel-related junk bonds ``at substantial losses.'' Through their lawyers, Drexel and Milken have denied any role in the collapse of the nation's savings and loans. At a pre-sentencing hearing for Milken, former Drexel employees stated that Drexel engaged in illegal activity with at least one major thrift. Civil lawsuits filed against Drexel, Milken and others have alleged widespread junk bond fraud at thrifts including Lincoln Savings & Loan Association and Columbia Savings & Loan Association. Separate trials involving those thrifts are scheduled. Drexel is reorganizing under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law. It faces more than 100 civil lawsuits alleging stock manipulation, racketeering, insider trading and numerous other crimes by Drexel and related entities. Lawyers are negotiating over the total amount to be allotted in Drexel's reorganization to settle the lawsuits by investors, ex-clients and others. A figure must be approved by U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack, who is handling the litigation. The thrift claims are part of those talks. In addition, the Internal Revenue Service also is expected to file a large claim against Drexel. Drexel attorney Alan Miller said ``there won't be anything like'' $5 billion to $10 billion in an agreement settling the civil litigation. He criticized the possible FDIC filing as ``an attempt by one creditor to dilute the claims all the other creditors'' and to blame Drexel for the thrift collapse. Drexel has about $3 billion in assets and $2.85 billion in existing undisputed claims. The assets do not reflect the value of the firm's junk bond portfolio and stock investments in Drexel-managed takeover deals. In court papers, the FDIC said its claims would be filed by a Thursday deadline but asked for 90 more days to complete its investigation. The FDIC charged that Drexel was not cooperating with its efforts. The papers said that more than 100 accountants and 50 lawyers were investigating the junk bond holdings of failed thrifts nationwide and had collected more than five million pages of documents. They said junk bond records of thrifts taken over by Resolution Trust ``are in a state of some disarray.'' They also charged that thrift executives removed boxes of records before the federal takeovers and that important employees refused to cooperate with the investigation. Claude Montgomery, a lawyer for former Drexel stockholders, whose claims would be last to be met, said a huge demand by the thrift agencies could lead to more litigation ``because some numbers are just too big to negotiate.'' ``It does strike many of us that somewhat strange that the RTC should be filing claims against an institution on the theory that it brought the S&Ls down,'' he said, adding that ``to blame Drexel instad of Congress and the regulators and 50 years of history is a little bit aggressive.''

The stock market staged a spirited rally today, getting further mileage out of hopes for a more generous credit policy at the Federal Reserve.
