DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Down
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.09 percent this week, down from 10.13 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.09 percent, down from 8.15 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Staff Cuts, Other Measures Planned at Australian Carrier
DOC.TEXT: Qantas Airways will reduce its workforce by 500 by the end of February to help it survive an industrywide downturn prompted by higher jet fuel costs, chief executive John Ward said Friday. Ward also said five Boeing 747s would be sold earlier than planned and flying hours would be cut back, as part of a cost-cutting plan. ``These steps are essential if we are to survive,'' he said, adding that more job cuts were ``inevitable, although the number depended on the state of the world economies and the impact on travel demand.'' Qantas has said its annual fuel bill would rise by 100 million to 200 million Australian dollars ($78 million to $156 million U.S.) because of the Middle East crisis and its effect on jet fuel prices. The airline, 49 percent of which the government plans to sell, has already axed 60 management jobs and 21 jobs in Europe. It has also frozen staff recruiting and withdrawn services from Amsterdam, Athens, Bombay and Bahrain. ``We're in a critical period,'' Ward said. ``Small downturns in traffic and small increases in costs play havoc with profitability.'' The International Air Transport Association has predicted collective losses of $3.5 billion U.S. for the world's airlines this year. Later this month, Qantas is expected to report a small profit for the past financial year after some aircraft disposals prevented a loss. Ward said Qantas had to restructure its operations to ensure it can continue to compete on international routes and take full advantage of tourism opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Stocks May Grow But Some Experts Still Bullish On Prices
DOC.TEXT: The government now says the U.S. soybean stockpile is growing instead of shrinking but market analysts aren't quite ready to reverse their predictions for higher soybean prices in the coming year. Some experts say it is too early to know whether this year's larger-than-expected U.S. soybean harvest means prices will continue to weaken after the shock of the government latest crop report wears off. But others contend the six-month outlook is as bullish as ever, based mainly on expectations for a small South American soybean crop. They agree that two keys to the market's behavior between now and next summer will be the level of export demand for U.S. soybeans that develops early next year after current South American supplies are depleted, and the growing conditions that prevail in Brazil and Argentina this winter, which is their summer. ``If we get any kind of weather problem down there, it will restimulate the bullish situation,'' said Doug Jackson, a grain analyst with Farmers Commodities Corp. in Des Moines, Iowa. Analysts were forced to reassess their price forecasts after the Agriculture Department on Thursday raised its estimate for the 1990 U.S. soybean crop by an unprecedented 4.4 percent to 1.9 billion bushels from its October projection of 1.82 billion. It was the biggest October-to-November increase ever in the USDA's harvest projections. Most experts had expected a number near 1.84 billion bushels. The government also raised its estimate of how large the U.S. soybean stockpile will be next Aug. 31, the end of the current marketing year, to 255 million bushels from 175 million compared with 239 million bushels last August. Soybean futures prices plunged Friday, the day after the report. Soybeans for delivery in November fell 16{ cents to $5.66} a bushel. Prior to the report, many analysts were expecting soybean prices to rise sharply early next year due to relatively tight U.S. supplies and prospects for low production in South America, where economically distressed farmers are expected to plant fewer acres than last year. Thursday's crop report indicates U.S. supplies will not be as tight as expected. ``The situation has gone from one that's slightly constructive fundamentally to one that's neutral to bearish,'' said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York But other analysts said the bigger U.S. harvest estimate will encourage South American producers to plant even fewer soybean acres, which would offset the negative impact on prices. The South American planting season is under way. ``This will lock in the fact that South America will lower production,'' said William Biedermann, research director with Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. The wild card is export demand, which has been extremely weak lately but is bound to pick up by early next year as foreign consumers seek U.S. supplies. Biedermann said foreign demand will be stimulated by a drop in soybean prices in the next few weeks as the market digests the crop report. ``The lower we go bewteen now and December, the more bullish the picture gets long-term,'' he said. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., agreed. ``I think the lower prices will enhance demand,'' he said. ``I think by next summer we'll be back up again.''

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 170.64 Friday, up 1.29, or 0.76 percent, from a week ago and down 26.64, or 13.50 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 161.80 Friday, up 1.23, or 0.77 percent, from a week ago and down 23.31, or 12.59 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 121.30 Friday, up 0.96, or 0.80 percent, from a week ago and down 47.01 or 27.93 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Fall on Rumor of Saddam's Ouster
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell sharply near the close of trading Friday on a wild rumor of an Iraqi coup. Oil had been moving lower anyway, as traders decided they had bid prices too high Thursday on erroneous speculation that President Bush was about to announce steps leading to an immediate conflict in the Persian Gulf. ``People aren't expecting any gunfire until next year now,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. The coup rumor floated in with about a half hour left to trade, pushing the already depressed price down another 60 cents. ``That probably just fueled things a little bit,'' said trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Light sweet crude, the benchmark blend of petroleum, settled at $33.89 per barrel, down $1.64, for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for delivery in later months all closed more than $1 lower. For the week, crude fell 11 cents a barrel for next-month delivery. Oil opened lower Friday, as traders determined they had overestimated the impact of a news conference Bush had given the evening before. During Thursday's session, oil shot up as traders speculated Bush's statement, which came after the market closed, would contain either an ultimatum to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein or a vow to airlift supplies to the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Bush instead said he was vastly increasing the U.S. military presence in the Gulf, which traders already had been anticipating. ``I think people were expecting some type of ultimatum and what they received was the same old thing,'' Blakeslee said. Traders in the New York Mercantile Exchange recently have been scared of going through the weekend with speculative positions, so some of Friday's selloff came as they sold oil contracts. As crude oil fell, it dragged down the price of refined products traded on the exchange, a key market for petroleum. Wholesale home heating oil dropped 4.06 cents to 90.24 cents a gallon on December delivery contracts, while wholesale unleaded gasoline fell 2.28 cents to 88.23 cents a gallon for December delivery. Later contract months were all lower for both products. For the week, heating oil rose 2.82 cents for next-month delivery, while unleaded gasoline fell .98 cent. Natural gas prices were lower or unchanged Friday, with December delivery contracts falling .6 cent to $2.429 per 1,000 cubic feet. For the week, next-month contracts for natural gas were up 7.1 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Hit 8{-Month Low on Bigger Crop Estimate
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell to 8{-month lows Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade, dragging grain futures down as well, after the government issued a surprisingly large estimate of the newly harvested crop. On other commodity markets, oil and precious metal futures fell; cattle futures rose; and pork futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 5 cents to 17\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in November at $5.66} a bushel, the lowest settlement of a near-month soybean contract since Feb. 28, when the March contract finished at $5.66{. Wheat futures ended 2{ cents to 3{ cents lower with December at $2.65} a bushel; corn was { cent to 2 cents lower with December at $2.31 a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 4 cents lower with December at $1.17{ a bushel. Soybeans were pounded by heavy selling from all sectors after the Agriculture Department on Thursday released a monthly crop report raising its soybean production estimate 4.4 percent to 1.9 billion bushels from the October estimate of 1.82 billion. The market had expected a number near 1.84 billion. The report heaped more bearish news on a market that has been burdened recently by slack export demand. ``With export business not being robust, what we need here is lower prices to hopefully induce better demand,'' said Gerald Zusel, grain analyst with E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. The government reduced its corn production estimate to 7.9 billion bushels from 8 billion, which was not enough to offset the bearish implications of the soybean number. Oil futures fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid profit-taking that reflected reduced fears of imminent war in the Middle East. President Bush's announcement Thursday that more U.S. troops will be sent to Saudi Arabia might indicate the U.S.-led multinational force is preparing to attack Iraq troops eventually, but it quashed expectations for an offensive move in the next few days. The oil market rallied earlier in the week on perceptions that the U.S. was preparing for an attack this week. ``Now it looks like the attack might be put off for a while,'' said Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser with Jesup Josephthal & Co. in New York. Light sweet crude oil futures finished $1.01 to $1.64 lower with December at $33.89 a barrel; heating oil was 2.55 cents to 4.06 cents lower with December at 90.24 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.51 cents to 2.38 cents lower with December at 88.23 cents gallon. Gold and silver futures retreated on New York's Commodity Exchange in reaction to a variety of bearish factors including lower oil prices, sharply higher stock prices and a government report on wholesale prices that indicated inflation outside the food and energy categories virtually vanished last month. Platinum futures fell sharply in thin trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gold futures were $2.60 to $2.90 lower with December at $386.30 a troy ounce; silver was 4 cents lower across the board with December at $4.237 a troy ounce; platinum was $11.20 to $11.30 lower with January at $410.30 a troy ounce. Cattle futures advanced, paced by sharp gains in the live cattle market, as strength in the cash cattle and beef markets pulled futures higher. Recent gains in pork prices have made beef more attractive to retailers, which resulted in stronger packer demand for cattle, said Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Hog futures ended mostly lower but pork bellies advanced amid continuing concerns about tight supplies of frozen stocks. Live cattle were .20 cent to .95 cent higher with December at 78.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .55 cent higher with November at 88.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .42 cent lower to .18 cent higher with December at 52.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .65 cent to 1.25 cents higher with February at 69.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Spindler Replaces Sculley as Apple President
DOC.TEXT: Michael H. Spindler, Apple Computer Inc.'s chief operating officer, has been named president in a move that changes no one's responsibilities but endorses his leadership role, the company said Friday. Spindler, who helped launch the computermaker on a turnaround program, will continue to report directly to John Sculley, Apple's chairman, chief executive officer and former president. Spindler also was nominated to Apple's board of directors. ``These actions represent strong votes of confidence in Michael Spindler and ringing endorsements of the excellent job he has done at Apple since becoming chief operating officer in February 1990,'' Sculley said. Spindler's new title and Sculley's relinquishing of it are merely formalities, said Apple spokeswoman Barbara Krause. ``It really is just a title change. At many Fortune 100 companies, the COO is also president because it signifies leadership of the operational units of the company,'' she said. Apple, after several years of fast growth, recently suffered a sales slowdown and its share of the desktop computer market fell. Critics blamed the problem on the high prices Apple charged for its Macintosh line - $1,799 to $11,000 - as clones of International Business Machines Corp. personal computers dominated the low end of the market. But Apple has overhauled its strategy, hoping to trade high profit margins for increased sales. It introduced low-cost Macintoshes last month that start at just under $1,000. Spindler, who successfully headed Apple's European operations, was made chief operating officer in a top-level reorganization. He took over sales, marketing, manufacturing and corporate communications while Sculley focuses on research and development. Bernard Goldstein, a partner at Broadview Associates, a Fort Lee, N.J., investment bank specializing in the information technology industry, also has been nominated to Apple's board, the company said. Shareholders will vote on the nominations at the annual meeting in January.

DOC.HEAD: Toys R Us Takes Manhattan
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Toys R Us, which made its name and fortune by setting up shop in the 'burbs, has finally moved into the big city. The world's largest toy retailer reached a new milestone last week with the opening of its first downtown branch in the United States, a three-level store in Manhattan's Herald Square just across from two big competitors, Macy's flagship department store and Lionel Corp.'s Kiddie City. The move represents a big opportunity for Toys R Us, convenience for Manhattanites who used to travel to suburbia for toys and a headache for stores that haven't had this kind of competition before. Robert Nakasone, a Toys R Us vice chairman, said the company was doing so well in the suburbs it felt for years that it didn't need to move into downtown locations. ``We said, `Why go ahead and do it?'' he said Friday, the store's second day open. But eventually Toys R Us realized Manhattan was too lucrative a market to keep passing up, Nakasone said. The company decided to open a toy store and a companion Kids R Us clothing store in the heart of the city. The success of Kiddie City's Herald Square store may well have been an inducement to Toys R Us to give Manhattan a try. Until a few years ago, if you wanted to buy toys in Manhattan, you had few choices. There was FAO Schwarz on Fifth Avenue for the upper crust and department stores and a handful of small neighborhood stores for everyone else. Kiddie City was a trailblazer when it opened its Herald Square store several years ago. It was a big success, and Lionel followed with two other stores in residential areas of Manhattan. Toys R Us, which has more than 700 stores in the United States and overseas, has branches in New York City's other four boroughs. But before last week, its only other downtown stores were in Singapore and Germany. The site chosen by Toys R Us is the building known as Herald Center, on Broadway between 33rd and 34th streets. It couldn't be more high profile - it is smack in the middle of Manhattan's biggest shopping area, directly across from Macy's. The arrival of Toys R Us provides Herald Center with a chance at revival following a checkered history. The building began retail life as a Saks & Co. branch. Known as Saks 34th, it was a poor cousin to the more famous Saks Fifth Avenue. Saks closed the store about 30 years ago and it later became a discount retailer, Korvettes. After Korvettes folded in the 1970s, the building became Herald Center, a vertical mall that had few stores and few shoppers. The building later was tied to former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos and his wife Imelda. It was sold at a court-ordered auction recently and is being renovated with Toys R Us and Kids R Us as the mall's centerpieces. For Toys R Us, moving into Herald Center required a revamping of the company's standard one-story configuration. Shelves had to be fit around pillars and columns and elevators and escalators had to be installed. The total facelift cost more than $1 million, Nakasone said. The Herald Square store also is more expensive to run. With less stockroom space than other Toys R Us stores, it will have be resupplied more often. That means more trips to the company's New Jersey warehouse, and higher labor and fuel costs. Moving into Manhattan also meant Toys R Us trucks had to be adapted to fit into the Lincoln Tunnel, a key thoroughfare that connects New York and New Jersey. But to children, it's like any other Toys R Us outlet. It's stocked from floor to ceiling with dolls, Nintendo units and cartridges, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and bicycles. To competitors, Toys R Us poses a big threat. Macy has long touted itself as the place to go for Christmas toys, but the department store may find itself hard-pressed to compete with the price and selection that shoppers will find just across the street. Kiddie City, while carrying many toys, also does not have as wide a selection as Toys R Us. While Toys R Us had aisles of Nintendo equipment and cartridges last week, Kiddie City's video games were tucked into a corner of the store. FAO Schwarz could find it has lost some sales to its downtown rival because Toys R Us prices are lower. For instance, a popular baby doll called Oopsie Daisy - so named because she falls down and cries - costs $66 at FAO Schwarz, and $40 at Toys R Us. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles figures that go for $8 in FAO Schwarz were selling for $5 at Toys R Us. But this doesn't mean a store like FAO Schwarz should close up shop. The store appears to be downscaling somewhat - it no longer features a $15,000 junior Ferrari in its catalog - but still has $100-plus plush animals, $300-plus dolls and a Fifth Avenue cachet that no other toy store has. Nakasone appeared unconcerned about competition. He noted Toys R Us competes with Kiddie City in other markets. He also did not appear worried about the effect that the weakened economy and the Persian Gulf crisis have had on the retail business. While declining to project what Toys R Us sales will be this year, Nakasone predicted parents would still spend generously on toys. ``We expect to have a good Christmas,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: DollarDown in Sluggish Trading, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined broadly in slow trading Friday amid concerns over the U.S. economy and enthusiasm over possible weekend tensions in the Middle East. Gold prices fell. With New York currency markets closed on Veterans Day, traders stocked up on the U.S. currency in advance of a possible Persian Gulf escalation during the three-day weekend. The dollar is generally viewed as a relatively safe investment in times of strife. In addition, possible oil shortages resulting from a Persian Gulf strife could hurt Japan's oil-dependent economy and help diminish the yen's value against the dollar, traders said. But before the day's end, currency trading in New York slowed to a virtual crawl, as investors eyeing the Middle East already had covered their short-dollar positions. Analysts said a bigger influence was an earlier Labor Department report that showed the nation's ``core'' inflation rate - the producer price index minus food and energy costs - remained unchanged from September. Investors sold on this sign of moderating inflation, seeing it as one more reason for the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates to stimulate economic growth. Lower interest rates can have a chilling effect on the value of the dollar. ``You're starting to build up a fairly reasonable case for at least a quarter of a percent cut,'' said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank PLC. In New York, the dollar dipped to 129.70 yen from 130.35 yen on Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.00 yen to a closing 130.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 129.75 yen. In New York, one British pound cost $1.9655, more expensive than Thursday's $1.9625. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.9670, unchanged from late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.4870 German marks, down from 1.4930; 1.2499 Swiss francs, down from 1.2535; 4.9940 French francs, down from 5.0105; 1,119.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.75, and 1.1683 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1694. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.4875 German marks, down from 1.4885; 1.2495 Swiss francs, down from 1.2580; 4.9940 French francs, up from 4.9935; 1.6775 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6780; 1,119.50 Italian lire, down from 1,129.75; 1.1698 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1685. Gold fell in slow domestic trading, depressed by a lack of volatile news about the Middle East standoff, analysts said. It fell $2.50 a troy ounce to $384.80 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $384.40 a troy ounce, down $2.75. In earlier trading in London, gold fell to a late bid of $384.75 a troy ounce, down from $385.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to $385.80 an ounce from $384.75 late Thursday. DOC.HEAD: Boosts Ad Rates at Wall Street Journal, Closes Composing Operation
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Friday it was boosting advertising rates for 1991 at The Wall Street Journal, the nation's largest daily newspaper. At the same time, the company confirmed it was closing the composing operations at its printing plant in Naperville, Ill., and transferring the plant's responsibilities to a plant in Dallas, for a net reduction of 30 jobs. The moves come as Dow Jones begins an austerity program under which it has frozen capital spending, is trying to hold salary spending in 1991 at 1990 levels and is taking other steps to cut costs. Two weeks ago, Dow Jones said it was boosting the cover price of the Journal to 75 cents from 50 cents effective Dec. 3 and the yearly subscription price by 7.8 percent to $109. The Journal has the largest daily circulation of any U.S. newspaper, averaging about 1.85 million in the six months ended Sept. 30. The company's earnings have fallen this year as the slump on Wall Street and the economy as a whole has shown up in sharply reduced advertising spending by financial companies. The new ad rates, which take effect Jan. 2, 1991, include increases of 6 percent for national edition advertising and bigger increases for regional and overseas editions. The increase will boost the cost of a full-page ad in the national edition of the Journal to $105,352. Rates in the Eastern, Midwest, Western and Southwest editions will increase 7 percent while regional rates will rise an average of 9 percent. The ad rates will jump 12 percent for the Wall Street Journal Europe and 10 percent for the Asian Wall Street Journal and The Asian Wall Street Journal Weekly. Roger May, a spokesman for Dow Jones, said the closing of the composing operation at the Naperville plant effective in January reflects technological improvements that enable the company to cut the number of its composing operations to three from four nationwide. He said the closing would mean a cost savings and an improvement in operating efficiency but would not adversely affect the quality of the newspaper. He said some of the 40 people employed in the composing operation in Naperville would be transferred to Dallas, but that the company expected there would be a net reduction of 30 jobs. In addition to the Journal, Dow Jones publishes Barron's magazine, the Ottaway Group of community newspapers and electronic business information services. Its Telerate Inc. subsidiary provides financial information.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 3rd graf pvs, I have, and inserts 4 grafs after 13th graf pvs, There was, with Waxman reaction and explanation of pocket veto. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday vetoed a bill intended to block drug companies from reaping windfall profits through monopolistic marketing of drugs that treat rare diseases. The bill applies to ``orphan drugs'' used against diseases that affect fewer than 200,000 people. It was designed to foster more competition by eliminating the 7-year exclusive marketing rights granted under current law to companies that develop such drugs. Bush withheld his signature from the bill, and in taking no action at a time when Congress is not in session killed it through what is known as a pocket veto. ``I have serious concerns about the effect that (the bill) would have upon the incentive of drug companies to develop orphan drugs,'' Bush said in a statement. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., chief sponsor of the bill in the House, said he was ``really shocked'' that Bush did not sign the bill because the White House had ``never made a fuss'' previously about the legislation. The White House contends that taking away the exclusivity benefit actually would decrease the willingness of firms to come up with orphan drugs because of the expense involved in the research and development. The legislation Bush vetoed would have amended the 1983 Orphan Drug Act that established the 7-year marketing monopoly as an incentive for companies to develop drugs that don't promise as large a profit as drugs that are used against more widely prevalent diseases. ``I believe we must not endanger the success of this program, which is due in large measure to the existence of the `market exclusivity' provision in the Orphan Drug Act,'' Bush said. ``Weakening the current 7-year period is the basis of the economic incentive to attract drug firms to invest in orphan drugs.'' Critics, however, complain the current law has resulted in excessively high prices for some drugs, including those used to treat AIDS, and millions of dollars in profits by the drug firms. Bush also objected to changing the current law's provision that allows orphan drug status to diseases that affect more than 200,000 people when there is no reasonable expectation that the cost of developing the drug will be recovered from sales. The new legislation would have cut off a drug's orphan drug status as soon as the number of people who need the drug exceeded 200,000. Bush said he was ``extremely concerned ... that individuals with rare disease may suffer because of changes that this bill would make in the incentives to develop new drug treatments.'' The legislation was supported by AIDS activists and other advocacy groups. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association opposed the legislation, but said it was not recommending that Bush veto it. The PMA contended the current act was working well to stimulate development of drugs that otherwise would not be of interest to manufacturers. ``Only six of the 45 orphan drug approvals since 1983 are for populations greater than 50,000. Many of these drugs would not be available without the incentives offered by the Orphan Drug Act,'' the organization said in a position paper on the legislation. There was no immediate comment from the PMA on Bush's veto, said spokesman Mark Grayson. But Waxman alleged, ``Some drug companies have gotten to the ear of the White House.'' Waxman said companies don't want to lose the advantage they enjoy by being the monopoly supplier of drugs used to treat diseases that once were limited to a small population but have spread to thousands of people. He said drugs to treat AIDS, for example, should no longer be considered orphan drugs. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, who sponsored the bill in the Senate, was not immediately available for comment. The Food and Drug Administration has granted so-called orphan status to more than 375 drugs, more than 40 of which have reached the market. Critics have been concerned that some of these drugs were producing monopolistic windfalls for the drug companies that marketed them. Some of the diseases that orphan drugs have been developed to treat include Huntington's disease, Tourette's syndrome, narcolepsy and muscular dystrophy. On a separate matter, Bush on Friday signed a bill requiring food manufacturers to put more nutrition information on the labels of food packaging. The bill also would prohibit manufacturers from making health claims on their packaging unless scientifically proven according to the Food and Drug Administration. The legislation mandates that most bulk food in bins, raw fish and fruits and vegetables be displayed with a sign or brochure providing nutritional information. Food labels will have to show calories, calories from fat, fat content, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, total carbohydrates, complex carbohydrates, sugars, dietary fiber and protein.

DOC.HEAD: Three U.S. Firms Question Their Elimination From Cellular System Bidding
DOC.TEXT: The Communications Ministry said Friday it selected five finalists for Poland's first cellular telephone contract and defended the bidding process from questions about its fairness raised by three U.S. companies. Communications Minister Jerzy Slezak did not name the finalists, but said he had proof the review was fair and would provide full documentation to the companies seeking the contract, valued at up to $100 million. According to U.S. Ambassador Thomas W. Simons, two U.S. companies, two European consortia and a Hong Kong company were among the final five. The contract is the first major government project in Poland to be put to open bid. It attracted international telecommunications companies and is considered a test of whether the newly capitalist economy is ready for sophisticated business dealings with the West. Cellular telephones are viewed as a quick fix for Poland's disastrous telephone system, which is impeding business investment. For the bidders, the contract represents an entry point into the former East bloc. The discontent registered by the three American companies was underlined by an unusual meeting with journalists held by Simons to discuss the bidding. While cautioning that the U.S. government is making no judgment about the veracity of the companies' concerns, he said, ``we recognize there are questions'' about fairness. Communications Ministry specialists invited detailed proposals from eight of 24 companies that made initial offers in February. In September, three U.S. competitors were eliminated: U S West Inc. of Englewood, Colorado, Ameritech of Chicago, and Millicom Inc. of New York. From the five finalists - including the U.S. companies Nynex and Crowley - two will be selected by late December for final negotiations, Simons said. The three disqualified U.S. companies are ``seeking clarification'' about why they were eliminated based on a review of the technical section of their proposal, said James Whisenand of Ameritech. ``All the rejected companies are concerned with is that - win or lose - they have the comfort that the process was pristine and fair,'' he said. Whisenand would not specify how the companies felt the bidding had been compromised, but said they seek a reappraisal by the ministry. ``All three companies would hope that the process will be clarified and all eight companies' proposals reviewed,'' he said. The companies contend that their size and experience make clear their ability to meet the technical requirements, Simons said. Slezak said he was ``astonished'' by the questions. ``I have materials proving ... the fairness of the process,'' he said. ``Each of the firms concerned will receive full documentation.'' The ministry said two of the companies were eliminated because they violated an anonymity requirement by disclosing their names in the technical portion of their bids.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Steel Cutting Price Hike
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp. said it would halve an 8 percent price increase scheduled for sheet steel shipments after Dec. 29, a move that other major steel makers are expected to followed. Bethlehem and the others raised prices in an effort to shore up eroding profits, said Charles Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York. Bethlehem told its customers about the price hike in September, but customers asked for a reprieve, said Bethlehem spokesman Henry H. Von Spreckelsen said Thursday. ``This action is being taken to better reflect the realities of the marketplace,'' Spreckelsen said. But he added, ``At an appropriate time in months ahead, customers can expect an additional increase to offset rising costs.'' A spokesman at USX declined to say whether his company, the nation's No. 1 steel maker, would follow Bethlehem's lead. However, Bradford said USX and other steel makers have little choice. He said an 8 percent increase was ``kind of a joke in the first place.'' ``I don't think too many (companies) really expected to get that much,'' he said. ``But if you don't ask for more you don't get anything.'' Bradford said steel makers need price relief to cover increased costs and wage hikes that go into effect Jan. 1. Sheet steel is used for autos, appliances and construction materials. Bethlehem makes it at its Burns Harbor, Ind., and Sparrows Point, Md., plants. The company reported earnings of $53.3 million for the first nine months of 1990, down sharply from $195.7 million in the same period of 1989. Under the new schedule, the price increase on hot-rolled steel will be lowered to $20 from $35 a ton, on cold-rolled steel to $25 from $47 a ton and on galvanized steel to $30 from $49 a ton.

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Sales Rise, Earnings Decline in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc. earnings declined 7 percent despite an 11 percent increase in sales during the third quarter, the retailer said Friday. The company said profits for the quarter ended Oct. 31 amounted to $20.4 million, or 25 cents a share, on $634.9 million in sales, compared with $22 million, or 27 cents a share, on $572.4 million in sales for the same period last year. The sales gains came entirely from stores opened within the past year. They include stores opened in the third quarter in Santa Barbara, Calif., and Paramus, N.J., and clearance outlets in San Leandro, Calif., and Dale City, Va., said John Goesling, senior vice president. Sales at stores open more than a year were down 2 percent in the quarter, Goesling said. ``We are not immune from effects of the softening sales trends in the entire retail industry,'' he said. ``We are encouraged, however, that our efforts to control inventories and expenses have reduced the impact on earnings.'' Goesling said advertising and the work force at some stores had been reduced. He refused to give figures or say what other belt-tightening moves the chain had taken. For the first nine months of 1990, net earnings were $69.5 million, or 85 cents a share, on $2 billion in sales, compared with $84.5 million, or $1.02 a share, on $1.8 billion in sales a year ago. Nordstrom operates 63 stores in Washington, Oregon, California, Alaska, Idaho, Utah, Virginia and New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Jump as Market Anticipates Lower Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Government bond prices jumped Friday as the market anticipated the Federal Reserve Board would lower interest rates when it gathers next week, traders said. The price of the government's bellwether 30-year bond climbed 29-32 point, or about $9.06 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which falls when the bond's price rises, slid to 8.62 percent from 8.70 percent late Thursday. Bond prices rose despite a government report showing wholesale prices soared 1.1 percent in October, the third consecutive monthly advance, boosted by rising food and energy prices. The jump brought producer-price inflation for the first 10 months of the year to a 7 percent annual rate, sharply higher than 1989's 4.9 percent rate and the worst since inflation soared at double-digit rates in the early 1980s. But the bond market took its cue from the so-called core inflation rate, which doesn't include food and energy prices, said Bob Sbarra, a senior vice president at the investment firm Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc. Minus those factors, inflation didn't change from September. Investors believe the Fed's Open Market Committee will vote at a meeting Tuesday to lower interest rates to counteract increasing signs that the economy is entering a recession, traders said. The flat core inflation rate also gives the Fed more latitude to lower rates, they added. Lower rates benefit fixed-return securities such as bonds. Some traders are looking for a \-point reduction in the federal funds rate following the Fed's meeting. That is the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans. That belief prompted investors to buy government bonds Friday, bidding up the price, said William Pike, a managing director in the government bond-trading department of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The government bond market is closed Monday for Veterans Day. Pike said the market also was buoyed by a general sense of optimism, sparked by lower oil and gold prices, higher stock prices and the successful completion this week of the Treasury's record quarterly refunding auction. In the market for existing Treasury bonds Friday, short-term issues rose 3-32 point to 11-32, intermediate maturities rose 11-32 point to } point, and long-term issues rose 29-32 point to 31-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 4.09 to 1,164.70. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.26 percent as the discount fell 5 basis points to 7.04 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.37 percent as the discount slipped 3 basis points to 7.02 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.29 percent as the discount dropped 4 basis points to 6.84 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 7 9-16 percent, down from 7| percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose \ point to 90 11-32. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.59 percent from 7.61 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Mulroney Aide Named To Lead Campeau Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Stanley Hartt, a former chief of staff to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, was named Friday to succeed the ousted Robert Campeau as head of Campeau Corp. Hartt, who was also a Canadian deputy finance minister, was named president of Campeau Corp. and was expected to be named chairman and director, the company said in a statement. Robert Campeau, 66, was replaced in August as chairman and chief executive after Campeau Corp. could no longer handle the $10 billion debt burden from its takeovers of Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. Allied and Federated are currently undergoing reorganization in bankruptcy court in the United States. After Robert Campeau's ouster, James Raymond and Gary Goodman shared the chief executive's duties on an interim basis. They will continue as directors of the corporation, representing two of Campeau's major creditors and shareholders. Raymond is a director of Montreal-based National Bank of Canada while Goodman is a top executive of Toronto-based Olympia & York Developments Ltd. The bank and Olympia & York became more closely involved with running Campeau Corp. after it ran into trouble. Olympia and York took control of Campeau in Sept. 1989 after giving the company a $250 million loan. The bank became a major shareholder after Robert Campeau defaulted on bank loans that were secured by his Campeau Corp. stock. Robert Despres has been Campeau's interim chairman and will continue as a director of the corporation. Campeau lost $298 million in the first half of its current fiscal year, following a $1.74 billion loss for the year ended Jan. 31, 1990. Third-quarter results for the current year have not been released.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda Recalls RX-7s with Faulty Airbags
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor of America on Friday recalled 2,708 RX-7s because three of the sports cars may have defective airbags. The automaker has been notified by airbag manufacturer TRW that there might be three defective airbags among RX-7s manufactured between Nov. 1, 1989, and July 2, 1990, said Mazda spokesman Bob Marsocci. ``There's a mechanism that senses when there's an impact and that module might be defective,'' he said. The recall was voluntary. Owners are being notified by mail to take their cars to Mazda dealers for inspections. If necessary, the airbags will be replaced at no cost. Mazda said it was not aware of any injuries that have resulted from any defective airbags.

More than half the securities fraud charges against Charles H. Keating Jr. were jeopardized by a judge who said they cannot stand as written. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito said Friday that in 20 of the 42 counts against the Arizona developer and three co-defendants, the indictment appeared to be lacking. He said two other counts violated the defendants' right to due process because they were too vague. Keating, the former head of American Continental Corp., was jailed for 33 days on a 42-count indictment. He posted a reduced bond of $300,000 last month. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Fear of war in the Persian Gulf jolted oil prices for the third straight month in October, but slowing economic growth held wholesale price inflation for non-food and non-energy items to zero. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index for finished goods, one step short of retail, jumped a seasonally adjusted 1.1 percent last month. That followed increases of 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August, bringing the annual inflation rate for the year so far to levels not seen in nine years. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The vast majority of top economists in a monthly survey believe a recession will begin before year's end, but most predict it will be brief and relatively mild, a prominent economic newsletter reported. Blue Chip Economic Indicators said 80 percent of the 55 economists in its survey, released Friday, feel a downturn will start before the end of 1990. Another 5 percent said the slump would start in 1991. --- RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Saudi Arabia expects to be producing 8.5 million barrels of oil a day soon and is considering expanding its oil industry to put out 10 million barrels a day despite the threat of war with Iraq. Saddam Hussein has threatened to devastate the kingdom's main oilfields in the northeastern desert if the U.S.-dominated multinational force in Saudi Arabia launches an offensive to liberate occupied Kuwait. The Saudis have already raised their oil output to 8.2 million barrels a day, a 10-year high and a 57 percent increase since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Federal savings and loan regulators may seek up to $10 billion from Drexel Burhnam Lambert Inc. for junk bond investment losses at more than 20 thrifts, people involved in the case said. A lawyer for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. said Friday that ``very substantial claims'' would be filed next week against the collapsed Wall Street firm now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The claims are to be negotiated along with dozens of other civil actions in the bankruptcy reorganization. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said it was boosting advertising rates for 1991 at The Wall Street Journal, the nation's largest daily newspaper. At the same time, the company said Friday it was closing the composing operations at its printing plant in Naperville, Ill., and transferring the plant's responsibilities to a plant in Dallas, for a net reduction of 30 jobs. The moves come as Dow Jones begins an austerity program under which it has frozen capital spending, is trying to hold salary spending in 1991 at 1990 levels and is taking other steps to cut costs. --- ATLANTA (AP) - Foreclosure proceedings began against John C. Portman Jr.'s holdings in downtown Atlanta's Peachtree Center, including six office towers, a retail shopping mall, two parking decks and an athletic center. Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., which holds a $332.6 million mortgage, began the foreclosure process Friday. Equitable and Portman, however, said they expect to conclude a refinancing agreement soon halting the process. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush has vetoed a bill intended to block drug companies from reaping windfall profits through monopolistic marketing of drugs that treat rare diseases. The bill, vetoed Friday, applies to ``orphan drugs'' used against diseases that affect fewer than 200,000 people. It was designed to foster more competition by eliminating the seven-year exclusive marketing rights granted under current law to companies that develop such drugs. --- SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - Qantas Airways will reduce its work force by 500 by the end of February to help it survive an industrywide downturn prompted by higher jet fuel costs, chief executive John Ward said. Ward also said Friday that five Boeing 747s would be sold earlier than planned and flying hours would be cut back, as part of a cost-cutting plan imposed because of rising jet fuel prices. ---

The stock market staged a broad rally Friday, inspired by falling interest rates and hopes for a more generous credit policy at the Federal Reserve.The Dow Jones industrials average climbed 44.80 to 2,488.61. The dollar declined broadly in slow trading. Bonds jumped. Soybean futures tumbled; oil and precious metal futures fell; cattle futures rose; and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Minority-Owned Bank In the Country Fails
DOC.TEXT: The government declared the Freedom National Bank of New York insolvent Friday, closing what local officials called the largest minority-owned bank in the country. The bank had assets of $101.9 million. Its main branch was in Harlem and two others were in Brooklyn. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., the federal agency that closed the bank, by law must reimburse depositors with holdings up to $100,000 each. However, about 100 of the bank's accounts exceed the $100,000 limit, totaling $11 million. Those uninsured depositors will share with the FDIC the proceeds of liquidating the failed bank's assets. The FDIC said there were no bids by other banks to take over the Freedom National Bank. The bank has a total of 22,000 accounts in which $90.8 million had been deposited. Debts and liabilities owed by the bank but secured by various types of collateral total about $9.1 million. In a statement, Mayor David Dinkins expressed regret over the bank's closing. He said it was the largest minority-owned U.S. banking company. ``Since its founding in 1964, Freedom has served as the financial backbone of the Harlem community at a time when few other institutions showed much interest in doing business there,'' Dinkins said in a statement. ``Over its 26 years, it has provided loans and safeguarded the deposits of thousands of neighborhood residents and businesses.'' Dinkins said the city has accounts at the bank that totaled $300,000 Sept. 30, but that the money is in separate accounts of no more than $100,000 each and is therefore protected. Deposits up to the $100,000 limit will be made available to account holders starting Tuesday. The FDIC had not yet determined where the reimbursements would be made.
